The annual curling match for the Gordon medal was begun yesterday on Van Cortlandt Lake. After the snow had been removed the ice presented a comparatively smooth surface, which was soon ground into excellent...
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 2.--The bookkeeping of the Wilkinsons, insolvent bankers, was put under keen scrutiny to-day, and some startling revelations were foreshadowed.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 2.--A war between three local journalists--N.G. Gonzalez, of the Columbia Bureau of the Charleston News and Courier; C.A. Calvo, Jr., proprietor of the Columbia Register, and T.J. Lamotte, a reporter for the latter paper--occurred here to-day, in which a cowhide, pistols, and fists figured.

ALBANY, Feb. 2.--The Senate Judiciary Committee, of which Mr. Comstock is Chairman, proposes to investigate the dispute over the legislative printing, and was to-day given authority to seed for persons and papers. Some very interesting testimony will doubtless be elicited if the State officers are compelled to attend and tell what they know about this Democratic issue.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 2.--George W. Phillips, a wealthy Chicago commission merchant, arrived here to-day in search of his runaway wife, a handsome, dashing woman of 35. About a year ago Mr. Phillips was taken ill at the Palmer House, Chicago, where he boarded.
The Phillips vault, which was built 20 years ago in the churchyard of the First Presbyterian Church, at Fifth-avenue and Twelfth-street...

STAUNTON, Va., Feb. 2.--A disastrous collision occurred on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad here at 1 o'clock this morning. No. 3 night express ran into a freight train on siding and completely wrecked both engines.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 2.--At a delegate convention of the coal miners of Western Pennsylvania to-day the scale of wages presented to the operators at the recent national conference here was unanimously adopted. Delegates to the national convention of operators and miners which is to be held at Columbus, Ohio, on the 23d inst., were also elected.

More than 200 gentlemen gathered at Delmonico's last evening at the annual dinner of the Associate Alumni of the College of the City of New-York. Nearly all the classes for 30 years back were represented.
The Board of Directors of the National Rifle Association met yesterday afternoon in Temple Court. Gen. Wingate presiding.
NYACK, N.Y., Feb. 2.--A serious accident resulted from the collision of two wagons in this place last night. Frank H. Beers, a wellknown resident of this place, who keeps choice...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 2.--Quite a scene was enacted at Heffron's Morgue this morning over the remains of Mrs. Wilson, one of the victims of Suday's butchery. Dr. J.F. Sell, who had assumed to take charge of the murdered woman's remains and arrange the details of her funeral, was confronted by Mrs. Heath, the dead woman's mother.

Some of the few newspapers which owe a great deal to Mr. Thomas C. Platt and who are trying their best to pay off their obligations are very indiscreet in challenging the press of the State to impeach his Republicanism. It is not necessary to go back very far in our political history to strike some ugly facts in this connection. An invitation to print them, we are inclined to believe, might bring them out.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 2.--The thirteenth annual session of the Grand Lodge American Order of United Workmen of the State of NewYork convened here to-day.

The proposition to build a large abattoir, with all the latest sanitary improvements, to take the place of the numerous objectionable slaughter houses on the east side of the city, was discussed at a meeting of the Ladies' Health Protective Association at No. 139 East Fifty-ninth-street...

The 14 united cigar manufacturers are apparently no nearer to getting their workpeople back in their factories than they were two weeks ago. No signs of weakness are visible on either side, and only routine business is being done.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Feb. 2.--Capt. Barnard, of the schooner Fannie A. Milliken, who, with his crew, arrived here to-day on the Norwegian bark Sigurd Jarl, reports that the schooner sailed from New-York Jan. 14 for Key...

NEWBURG, N.Y., Feb. 2.--The Orange Lake Ice Yacht Association will hold their annual regatta on the lake for the champion Pennant on the first pleasant day when the ice is favorable. Several of the fastest yachts are now at the lake awaiting the race.
DENVER, Col., Feb. 2.--A decision of importance to insurance companies was rendered in the United States Circuit Court yesterday by Judge Hallett.
ALBANY, Feb. 2.--The eighty-ninth annual convocation of the Grand Chapter Royal Arch Masons of the State was opened in due form here to-day by M.E. James Morrison.
KEOKUK, Iowa, Feb. 2.--The county bridge across the Des Moines River at Pittsburg, Iowa, was carried away by high water last Spring.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 2.--Deputy Marshals Belford and O'Neill made a raid on the distillery of W.R. Colwell at Gibson, Susquehanna County, yesterday, and found a lot of...
The veteranc of Company K. Seventh Regiment, gave a reception to the active members of that organization at Delmonico's, last night. The occasion was wholly informal.

The concessions of shorter hours and better pay recently made to the drivers and conductors on five of the principal surface roads in the city have not been entirely voluntary on the part of the companies, even in those cases where the demands of the men have not been publicly urged.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Feb. 2.--The annual meeting of the shareholders of the Nova Scotia Sugar Refining Company was held to-day. The Directors' report showed a rather discourseine state of affairs.
George H. Sergeant, dealer in hardware at No. 37 Chambers-street, asked Capt, McCullagh, of the Sixth Police Precinct, to aid him in finding out thieves who had been robbing him of goods.
The trial of the Kohout brothers was continued in Part II, of the Court of General Sessions yesterday, before Recorder Smyth. Several unimportant witnesses were recalled, and the summing up began.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 2.--Gov. Hill entertained at dinner in the Executive Mansion this evening Lieut.-Gov. Jones, State Treasurer Fitzgerald, Secretary of State Cook, Controller Chapin, Attorney-General O'Brien, State Engineer Sweet: Senators Pierce, Nelson, Cullen, Plunkitt, Daly, Fagan, Wemple, Reilly, Trapbagen, and Dunham, and W.L. Meuller, Gov. Hill's former law partner.

The memory of the oldest member runneth not back to the time when the New-York Yacht Club has been so agitated over an approaching election of officers. Usually the elections have been purely formal and rather tedious affairs.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 2.--The situation at Olneyville to-night is still exciting. The air is full of rumors of the coming strike, and everybody is anxiously awaiting the result of the conference between the owners of the Atlantic Mills and the Executive Board of the Knights of Labor of Rhode Island.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2.--Among the private bills introduced in Congress to-day was one to relieve Private Richard Greens from the charge of desertion, which charge has been hanging over him without his knowledge since Aug. 22. 1862. Greene's story is a romantic one. He was born in Rochester, N.Y., in 1826, and is a grandson...
The novelists are discussing in the Times the "three-volume" question. They are not quite canded as to the facts.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 2.--The br. g. Albert France, record 2:20 , by George Wilkes, dam Alley, by Rysdyk's Hambletonian, was sold to-day by Mr. W.O. France, of New-York City, to Frank Van Ness, of this place, for $5,000. Mr. France also sold to S.A. Browne Co., Kalamazoo, Mich., two mares by George Wilkes, one by Mambrino Patchen and the other by Sweepstakes, for $5,000.

Upon the death of John A. Roebling, the engineer who built the great Suspension Bridge over Niagara River, and who designed the East River Bridge, his widow came into the possession of an estate valued at between $300,000 and $400,000. In her employ, at that time, as maid and companion, was Ellen Gahan, to whom...

DETROIT, Feb. 2.--The news from the Grand Haven fire to-day places the estimate of the loss at $300,000, and the insurance is a little less than that amount. The elevator which was destroyed was the property of Newberry McMillan, of this city, who will probably not...

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Fed. 2.--In the United States court to-day the case of E.W. Redpath and brother, of Boston, against Michael Fletcher, of Lebanon, in this State, was brought to an abrupt termination in a rather sensational manner.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 2.--A notable gathering of Republican politicians is promised in the banquet of the Michigan Club, to be held in this city on the 22d of this month. Among those from outside this State who have been invited and signified their intention to be prosent are Senators Evarts, Logan, and Sherman; Gov. Foraker, of Ohio; Congressmen Frye, Hiscock, McKinney, and others.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 2.--The remains or the wife of Secretary Bayard were buried in the family vault, at the old Swedes' Cemetery, this afternoon. The sad occurrence attracted an immense concourse of people to the old churchyard, but only the friends of the family and relatives were admitted.
DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 2.--A terrific explosion occurred to-day at the Miami Powder Works, at Goe's Station, near Xenia, where three large powder mills were blown to atoms, and...

ALBANY, Feb. 2.--The Senate and Assembly Canal Committees held a joint session to-day. Several members of the Union for the Improvement of the Canals appeared before the committee and gave their views.
All day yesterday the representatives of the leading silk firms of the United States were In session at the rooms of the Silk Association of America, in Broome-street.

PARIS, Jan. 12.--A London paper which is always hostile to everything which savors of republicanism, especially in connection with France, has published an article on the late Presidential election that shows how little our neighbors understand the spirit of the French Constitution.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Feb. 2.--At Donglastown, to-day, Annie Ranney, aged 7 years, while coasting, slid into the river. Her brotner Robert, aged 9 years, and Harry Hutchinson, in trying to save her, were also carried into the river. All three were drowned.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 2.--The annual meeting of the State Board of Agriculture was begun in the Masonic Hall to-day. The sessions will continue until to-morrow evening. The attendance is large. The reports from the subordinate societies show that the interest in the work of the board is increasing. Col. A.K. McClure addressed the board on "Agriculture" at the State House to-night. The officers will be elected to-morrow.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 2.--There is tonight a more hopeful feeling that the subcommittee of the Senate conference committee will arrive at an agreement that will be accepted by both parties in caucus. The matter in dispute has not yet been fully discussed, but the most...
PARIS, Feb. 2.--Baron Artaud Haussmann has been arrested, charged with having attempted to murder Count Montauzan at the Hotel Louvre, in this city.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Feb. 2.--The decision of the manufacturers' committee not to make in advance until April it is hoped by the operatives will not be sustained by the Board of Trade, and that a concession will be made by which an immediate increase of at least 5 per cent. will be made in the wages of the operatives.

EL PASO, Texas, Feb. 2.--Army Paymaster Major Robinson received a dispatch from Fort Bayard, New-Mexico, to-day stating that a courier had just arrived there bringing news of the unconditional surrender of the Apache Chief Geronimo to Lieut. Maus, who succeeded the late Capt. Crawford.

BERLIN, Feb. 2.--The Polish policy of Prince Bismarck, as announced in the Landtag, has produced general excitement throughout Germany and Austria. The immense Lubrienski estate, containing 82,406 hectares, or about 200,000 acres, one of the largest estates in Prussia, is offered for sale next April as a result of the...
LONDON, Feb. 3.--Capt. Clark, of the American ship Frank N. Thayer, has arrived at Plymouth on the Cape steamer, by which he was picked up at sea.
SAN FRANCISO, Cal., Feb. 2.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20 to 17 . Drafts on NewYork, telegraphic, 25 to 22 .

The members of the State Board of Assessors seem to share the distress common to many who know little or nothing about the subject of taxation at the small proportion of taxes derived from personal property.

TRENTON, Feb. 2.--The Senate occupied all of to-day arguing pro and con the resolution to Congress, passed by the House last week, petitioning that body to defeat the measure now pending before it to allow the bridging of Arthur Kill by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company.
Inspector Byrnes is to be given a dinner at Delmonico's next Monday night by a special committee of the New-York Stock Exchange.

Twice the suit of Catharine Jennings against Henry Van Schaick has been tried, and twice has it been before the General Term of the Court of Common Pleas. On the first trial the jury gave Mrs. Jennings a verdict for $10,000 damages.
Inspector Byrnes is to be given a dinner at Delmonico's next Monday night by a special committee of the New-York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2.--First Lieut. H.H.C. Dunwoody, Acting Signal Officer, will proceed from this city to West Point on public business under instructions from the Chief Signal Officer.

The excitement in the butter trade over the vigorous efforts to discover the dealers in oleomargarine and imitation butter was raised to a higher pitch yesterday. The legitimate traders in butter came to the Exchange with confidence in their eyes and hope in their hearts.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2.--In the daily circular issued by a prominent Board of Trade firm occurred, this afternoon, the following: "The Pennsylvania Railroad has cut the rate on grain and provisions 5 cents per 100.

LONDON, Feb. 2.--Mr. Chamberlain has refused the office of First Lord of the Admiralty. Mr. Collings will be given an important post. Mr. Morley has accepted the Chief Secretaryship for Ireland, Earl Rosebery the Foreign portfolio, Mr. Charles Russell the AttorneyGeneralship, and Mr. Cohen the Solicitor-Generalship.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 2.--A singular suicide occurred near here yesterday, George Keller, one of the most prosperous farmers in the county, hanged himself. His family relations were pleasant, but he was often heard to complain that he too much money, and was not well enough educated, to take care of it.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 2.--The eightieth convention of the State Medical Society opened here this morning.
WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 2.--On Jan. 25 the bottomers in the boot factory of Goddard. Fay Stone presented a demand for an increase of wages.

Very elaborate is the North American's presentation of the Sherman-Fry correspondence, the essential ports of which are already known to the general public. Half a column of an ordinary newspaper has been found sufficient to reproduce the correspondence clearly and, in truth, quite exhaustively.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2.--Another step toward a public discussion of the controversy between the President and the Senate as to the respective rights of the executive and legislative branches of the Government in the matter of suspensions and removals of Federal officers was taken to-day, when Mr. Riddleberger introduced the following resolution in the Senate:

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Feb. 2.--The Democrats have nominated for Mayor, N.L. Osborne; for Assessor, Lewis Baird, and for Commissioner of Charities, Pierre F. Cunningham. The Republicans have nominated for Mayor, Joseph Johnson; for Assessor, Erasmus Chollar, and for Commissioner of Charities, C.B. Dodge.

The impropriety of Attorney-General GARLAND'S and Senator HARRIS'S course in accepting gifts of telephone stock is in nowise lessened by the fact that the newspaper outcry about the Pan Electric scandal is promoted and for the most part paid for by the Bell Telephone Company.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 2.--David P. West, formerly of Tisbury, died here in the almshouse to-day. From 1843 to 1860 he sailed on six whaling voyages from Fair Haven and New-Bedford, taking 15,000 barrels of oil and 140,000 pounds of whalebone. Lately he lived in Providence, whence the Overseers of the Poor sent him here two weeks ago, unattended on the cars though he was unable to speak.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2, 1886. The President to-day approved the bill making an appropriation for the purchase of the old Produce Exchange Building in New-York for army purposes.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 3.--Messrs. Sullivan and Ferguson, of the Prince Edward Island Government, left here for England to-day. They say they have received the consent of the Dominion Government to lay their grievance before her Majesty in the same manner as the British Columbia complainants did in 1876.
State Civil Service Commissioners Richmond and Schoonmaker, with Secretary Angell, visited Brooklyn yesterday and held a long conference with Mayor Whitney and his local Civil ...

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 3.--A cablegram from London states that a stalwart negro preacher from Kansas, who gave the name of David Nero, was arraigned at a Glasgow police court on charges of swindling different church congregations and individuals out of $2,000.
Detective Reilly entered the District Attorney's office yesterday with a well dressed man apparently about 60 years of age.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 3.--Mr. Arthur T. Hadley, Chief of the Connecticut Labor Bureau, lectured to the Yale students to-night "On the Labor Question." He said that 16,000,000 handworkers in the United States earned $400 a year apiece on the average.

WHEELING, West Va., Feb. 3.--Cameron, a town of 1,000 population, situated about 25 miles from this city, is experiencing a wonderful religious revival under the inspiring presence of Miss Jennie Sherman, the evangelist.

Mary F. Sidman took her three children to live at the boarding house of Mrs. Fanny M. Peters, No. 109 West Forty-eighth-street, agreeing to remain there, under certain contingencies, from October, 1884, until May 1, 1885, and to pay $50 a week.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 3.--Mr. A.O. Wilson, a well known civil engineer, recently arrived here from Florida, where he had been engaged in land surveying.

"Lohengrin," although it has long since lost its freshness, still finds favor in the eyes of the public, and its latest production was potent enough to again attract a large audience to the Academy of Music last evening.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 3.--One of the saddest results of the Wabash shop strikes of last Summer came to light to-day in the finding of the little 10-year-old daughter of Presley Saunders insane by the County Court.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 3.--The Hon. David H. Bailey was sued by the Government to recover $38,000 of money collected by him as ConsulGeneral at Hong-Kong, China, and not paid to the Government. Judge Baxter has found that Bailey's accounts showed him indebted $9,000, and gave judgment for that sum against J.J. Gest, his bondsman.

Reuben Crawford, great-greatgrandfather; Mrs. Annie Crawford, great-greatgrandmother; William and Elizabeth Smith, great-grandparents; George and Gracy Eckels and John J. and Suffrony Smith, grandparents.

KUTZTOWN, Penn., Feb. 3.--Several students in the State Normal School at Kutztown bound and gagged one of their fellow-students. They then took him to an upper room and painted his face black, telling him that if he attempted to make a noise he would be severely beaten. They were informed upon by a student who overheard them. The Principal, Dr. N.C. Scheaffer, after an investigation, expelled the entire party of hazers.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 3.--Last week a gentleman about 70 years old and calling himself Dr. Mitchell, of Washington, D.C., arrived in Spartanburg, this State, and inquired the way to the Gowensville neighborhood, in that county.

Gen. James Jourdan, Receiver of the Brooklyn, Flatbush and Coney Island Railroad, began a suit in the Supreme Court yesterday for $300,000 damages against the Long Island Railroad Company for breach of contract.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Feb. 3.--Argument was commenced this morning in the United Stated Circuit Court before Judges Pardee and Billings, sitting en banc, in the case of the Bell Telephone Company and others against the National Improved Telephone Company.
George G. German, one of the most prominent members of the Produce Exchange, posted a notice at the Exchange yesterday announcing that he was unable to pay his creditors.

Twenty-one pews in the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church were sold at auction last night in the church because the assessments on them had not been paid.

The snowstorm which began operations in this city at 10:45 A.M. yesterday was, like most of its predecessor, a product of the great and growing West. It began to come down with Great steadiness and seriousness of purpose, and though later in the day it displayed a tendency to waywardness, it did not show any inclination to shrink from the slippery path of duty.
The drivers and conductors on the Fourth-avenue, Broadway, and Sixth-avenue surface roads are disappointed in the new time tables, which purport to give them but 12 hours work per day.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3.--Gov. Gil Pierce, of Dakota, passed through the city to-day on his way home from Washington.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 3.--A freight train on the Buffalo, New--York and Philadelpbia Railway came into collision with a bandcar, containing a party of section hands, near the city limits this afternoon. All the men except one, John Butler, jumped in time to escape injury. Butler was caught between the locomotive pilot and the hand car and instantly killed.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3.--The driving snowstorm only served as a picturesque setting to the wedding of George M. Newhall and Miss Jennie J. Reeves, which took place to-day in St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON Feb. 3.--The Secretary of the Treasury has written a letter to Representative Wilkins, Chairman of the Subcommittee on Public Buildings and Grounds, in regard to the public building at Rochester, N.Y., in which he says:
George Crocker, 14 years old, and son of Peter Crocker, colored, who lives at Bayside, Long Island, died yesterday from lockjaw.

TRENTON, Feb. 3.--Both branches of the Legislature held two sessions to-day, but both were short, and at 5 o'clock both bodies adjourned for the week. The Senate engaged in a warm discussion over a local option bill in counties.

Mme. Henry Greville, (Mme. Durand,) the French novelist and lecturer, will begin a series of lectures in Chickering Hall to-morrow night. Her first lecture will be given in French, and will tell "How I Became an Author."
In the midst of the driving snow last evening a rowboat, with a crew of the Austrian ship of war Donau, which is lying in the North River off Twenty-seventh-street, put off into the storm.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 3.--The residence of Samuel Williams, a farmer, situated near Trenton village, was destroyed by fire at about 5 o'clock this morning. Mr. Williams and his wife were burned to death. The fire is supposed to have originated from a defective stovepipe.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3.--Gossip in financial circles was largely confined to-day to the cause of the recent boom in Reading general mortgage bonds.

READING, Penn., Feb. 3.--David Yingst, a farmer aged 63, while walking on the railroad tracks between Palmyra and Derry this morning, saw through the snow storm ahead of him a freight train approaching.

James Meeks, a well known resident of Jersey City, was making preparations yesterday to attend the funeral of his son from his home, No. 103 Grand-street, when he was seized with an apoplectic fit and fell to the floor.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 3.--A distressing case of poverty has just been brought to light in the police court, in which a woman, through the hunger and want of herself and children, had been tempted and yielded to crime.

LANCASTER, Penn., Feb. 3.--State Veterinarians Bridges and Weber to-day visited the pleuro-pneumonia-infected herds of B.S. Fry, near Masonville, and H.G. Rush, near West Willow. At Fry's the surgeons killed four head of cattle, and kept the remainder in close quarantine. The Rush herd is improving, and the disease there will soon he stamped out.

A long line of carriages discharged a goodly crowd of people at the doors of the American Art Galleries last evening. They were members and guests of the Nineteenth Century Club, who were assembling for one of the regular meetings of the club.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 3.--Short Stop Burns, of the Chicago baseball nine, was referee at a polo game match in this city to-night between the New-Haven and Springfield (Mass.) teams. Some of his decisions didn't please the crowd, and when the game was over they rushed him up and down the rink until the patrol wagon and a a squad of policemen arrived and rescued him.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 3.--The war between the journalists has been concluded by fines for carrying concealed deadly weapons and for disorderly conduct. The Mayor had all parties bound over to keep the peace in the sum of $500 each.
Mary Lafield, 17 years old, of No. 16 Garrison-street, Brooklyn, went into the drug store of John Franz, at No. 79 Main-street, yesterday ...
LONDON, Feb. 3.--The new Cabinet is officially announced as follows: The Right Hon. WILLIAM E. GLADSTONE, Prime Minister and First Lord of the Treasury. Sir FARRER HERSCHELL, Lord High Chancellor.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 3.--The Senate Conference Committee on Differences was in session all day, and being unable to formulate a report to the Senate by 4 P.M., the hour for meeting, was given further time, and the Senate adjoured.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Feb. 3.--W.B. Snead, contractor and builder, of this city, has made an assignment. His liabilities are unknown, but supposed to be about $30,000. The assets, it is said, will pay 75 per cent. of his liabilities.

Ellen Gahan's suit to recover $50,000 from the estate of the late Mrs. John A. Roebling on an alleged verbal contract is attracting much attention. The trial was continued before Judge Peckham and a jury in Part I, of the Supreme Court, yesterday, and the court room was crowded.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Feb. 3.--For six months complaints have been coming in to the baggage departments of the railroads centring at Auburn Junction of the loss of valuables from trunks and valises.
I have already given a sketch of the history of the Princess Lilli Dolgourouki, who on Thursday appeared at a promenade concert in London as a violinist.

The ticket agent's experience at a station on the Maine Central Railroad in selling a lady and a boy a ticket to Montana has been the rounds of the papers. This lady didn't care in what part of the great Territory she landed, provided she got to Montana.
COHOES, N.Y., Feb. 3.--Sunday night George Wasterhouse, aged 14, was taken ill and showed signs of hydrophobia.
Mr. A.F. Godfrey, a hair dresser and dealer of St. Louis, has invented a method of taking up and discharging passengers and goods from railway trains which is decidedly novel.
DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 3.--A case without precedent, in the jurisprudence of Michigan at least, was finally determined in the Supreme Court of this State this morning.
The gross earnings of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company for the month of December, 1885, were $1,872,887 11, against $1,570,385 for the corresponding month of 1884.
BERLIN, Feb. 3.--The agreement between France and Germany regarding their respective posessions on the west coast of Africa and in the South Sea has been submitted to the Reichstag.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 3.--About 80 delegates are in attendance upon the second annual convention of the International Association of Fairs and Expositions, which began its sessions to-day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3, 1886. Among the measures reported favorably from committees to the Senate to-day was a resolution by Mr. Frye--reported, as he believed, "with unanimity" from the Committee on Foreign Relations--declaring it to be the opinion of the Senate that Congress ought not to provide for a joint commission of Great Britain and the United States in relation to the fisheries. It was placed on the calendar.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 3.--This morning a candy kettle in Flynn Durfee's establishment, on Michigan-avenue, exploded, injuring three persons. Carl Snickenbacker was covered with the boiling candy and terribly burned. It is thought his injuries will prove fatal. E. Fidler and Nellie Galvin were severely but not dangerously scalded.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 3.--The Grand Lodge this afternoon elected Isaac B. Barrett, of Albany, Grand Master Workman, and J.H. Mech, of Buffalo, Grand Foreman, both unanimously.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 3.--At an early hour this morning a difficulty occurred in a low concert saloon on Baltimore-street, in which Charles E. Taylor fired three shots from a revolver at Joseph Bucholtz, the proprietor of the place. One of the balls tools effect in the back of Mrs. Bucholtz, wife of Joseph, and passed through the right lung. Taylor was arrested. The condition of Mrs. Bucholtz is critical.

An investigation concerning the remarkable appointment of BARNEY CONROY to be Transfer Mail Agent in Indianapolis has revealed some curious facts. This man's application was virtually supported by the State of Indiana, for the State officers urged his appointment.
Fire broke out in some unaccountable way in one of the purifiers at the gas works in Paterson yesterday shortly before noon.
HARTFORD, Feb. 3.--Increased life insurance, as a test of improving business, is very favorable.
It looks as if there would not be any empty boxes at the concerts to be given at Madison-Square Garden in aid of the Irish Parliamentary fund by P.S. Gilmore and a band of 150 pieces.

An unknown man, about 33 years of age, 5 feet 7 inches, in height, and wearing a black mustache and side whiskers, was run over by an early morning train on the Brighton Beach Railroad yesterday, receiving injuries from which he died in an hour.

HUNTINGTON, Penn., Feb. 3.--Sheriff Garrett, of Mifflin County, has seized the office and fixtures of the Newton Hamilton Watchman, owned by B.E. Morrison, on executions issued by creditors in Philadelphia.
A car on the Sixth-avenue elevated railroad left the track on a switch at the One Hundred and Forty-fifth-street station at about 9 o'clock last evening, delaying travel for nearly an hour.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3.--James H. Hough, a member of the United States secret service force, shot and instantly killed himself at his residence in this city to-day. He was at one time a prominent merchant of Baltimore. No cause is assigned for the act except that for some time past he had boen ill and was unable to attend to his duties and had grown despondent.
CRISFIELD, Md., Feb. 3.--Last night a German, known only as George, was arrested for some slight offense.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 3.--New-Haven lawyers are excited over the charges which have just been brought against three of their brethren. The Superior Court has not yet returned its decision about the charges against C.S. Hamilton, and to-day complaints against S.W.F. Andrews and David Strouse were filed with the Bar Grievance Committee. Both are accused of crookedness in money transactions.

The contest about the construction of a bridge at the gap at the foot of Washingtonstreet, Jersey City, has developed a new phase. The opposition to the bridge comes mainly from the Matthiessen Wiechers Sugar Refining Company, who employ about 2,000 men.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 3.--The snowfall in Middle Tennessee is the heaviest in many years, and railroad traffic and general business is almost suspended. The storm continued for 24 hours, ending at an early hour this morning. The snow has drifted badly in the mountains, and mails will be delayed for a week.

"Jack" Dempsey, the pugilist, who has won over 30 battles without sustaining a single defeat, was the victor in a hard glove contest that took place in this city at an early hour yesterday morning.

During all of yesterday and until the lights were lowered in the evening the MadisonSquare Garden was noisy with the cluck and crow of poultry, of which 3,000 specimens had arrived for exhibition at the fourth annual show of the New-York Fanciers' Club, which has come to stay a week.
ALBANY, Feb. 3.--The General Term has denied the appeal of Louis Willitt, the Kingston murderer, for a new trial, and has ordered that he be resentenced at the Ulster Circuit.

ALBANY, Feb. 3.--Unless the Legislature affords some relief right away the management of the State prisons is likely to become involved in costly troubles. Few of the members realize this, because they have not taken the time or given the thought necessary to an understanding of the situation.
HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 3.--The resolution appropriating $10,000 for the erection of a monument to the memory of Gen. Israel Putnam came up in the House of Representatives this morning.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 3.--The New-York State Medical Society continued its sessions today with an increased attendance, the number of physicians thus far registered far exceeding the number registered for several years past.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 3.--The proceedings at Columbus to-day which resulted in the removal of the Police Commissioners by Gov. Foraker were instituted by the Committee of One Hundred, which came into existence with the disclosures as to the election frauds and is now a permanent organization.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 3.--John D. Archbold, Henry H. Rogers, and Ambrose McGregor, of New-York, and Hiram B. and Charles M. Everest, of Rochester, all connected with the Standard Oil Company, have been again indicted on a charge of conspiracy to ruin the business of the Butffalo Lubricating Oil Company. A glance at the interior of the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening vanquished all thoughts of Winter, and instantly put to flight the unpleasant remembrance of the blustering storm of wind and snow that held high carnival outside.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 3.--The jury in the case of Superintendent Hinckley sud Steward Heustis, of the County Insane Asylum, indicted for furnishing bad food to the inmates, rendered a verdict of not guilty this evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3.--Senator Ingalls failed to keep the promise he made yesterday to move a reference of Senator Riddleberger's resolution regarding the powers of the Senate and the Executive to the Committee on Privileges and Elections, but that course was taken when the resolution and Mr. Pugh's substitute came up for action to-day.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 3.--Nora Daly and Ella Town, companions of the escaped Fishkill burglars, were taken to Fishkill Landing to-day to testify to-morrow against James McCaffrey, charged with aiding the prisoners to escape. McCaffrey replying, "Yes, I am coming to-night to let you out."

Private Detective Sisson caused the arrest on Tuesday afternoon of a woman whom he charged with having stolen articles valued at $4.31 from Ehrichs' dry goods store, at Eighth-avenue and Twenty-fifth-street, where he is employed.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3.--The jury in the suit of Lorrette M. Crandall against the Accident Insurance Company of North America to recover the amount of a paid-up policy on her husband's life returned a verdict this morning in the United States District Court presided over by Judge Dyer.

WATERLOO, Iowa, Feb. 3.--The Minneapolis express train going north on the Cedar Rapids and Northern Railroad yesterday ran into a train consisting of three engines and a caboose on the Central Iowa Railway at Manly Junction.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 3.--Coke men are very much interested over a new move by the H.C. Frick Coke Company which has just been made public. They have secured the contract, which has been hold by McClure Co. for 10 years, for furnishing the North Chicago Rolling Mill with coke.
Gen. Nathaniel Prentiss Banks, the handsome old politician with the peerless voice, was 70 years old yesterday.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Feb. 3.--The schooner Viola Reppard, from Cienfuegos for Delaware Breakwater, with sugar for orders, put into quarantine to-day short handed.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 3.--The Brockton Baseball Club bas signed Charles Gagus, of San Francisco, as a pitcher. He played last season with the National and Neward clubs. In 1884 he was in the Western League. He will be backed up by Grady, who caught for him last year. John Moriarty, of Holyoke, has also been signed to pitch, thus giving the Brocktons five pitchers and three catchers.

The mate and steward of the brigantine Rockport, which was lost at Port de Paix in December last, were on the schooner C.R. Flint, which arrived at this port late Tuesday night. The shipwrecked men landed yesterday morning and started for their homes, in Boston, in the afternoon.

Rollin Migratory Squire, the remarkable poet (?) from Boston, who as Commissioner of the Department of Public Works has been the creature of Maurice B. Flynn, yesterday did just what THE TIMES said he would do.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 3.--The hands in the machine shop at the Wanskuck Mills struck for an increase of pay to-day, per order of the Executive Board of the Knights of Labor.

The Evening Post last night let itself cautiously down into the pit which we dug for it yesterday morning. The Sun will bound gleefully in this morning. Atop of the two we propose to throw in a few solid boulders of law and fact and precedent, and if they ever get out it will be by wriggling out.

Ferdinand Schweitzer, a, Swiss immigrant, 22 years of age, was married yesterday at Castle Garden to Theresa Hebele, a Bavarian widow, 37 years of age, who has two children by her first marriage.
The Surrogate yesterday patiently listened to another budget of testimony as to the makings of Isaac Marcus's will. That instrument was made just before Mr. Marcus died.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 3.--It is understood that a general whitewashing bill will be introduced by the Government indemnifying all the members for any violation of the Independence of Parliament act they may hay a committed by taking pay for their services in connection with the Northwest rebellion.
Senator Miller, of California, laughed heartily last evening when a paragraph was shown him stating that he was in a precarious condition and expected to die at any moment.
MANCHESTER, Feb. 3.--A huge block of buildings in this city, occupied by Hamilton Co., Patton Co., and Peak Co., has been gutted by fire. The loss will exceed $500,000.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 3.--The first game of the St. Louis series in the chess contest between Steinitz and Zukertort was played to-day in Harmonic Hall and was won by Steinitz.

The trial of Edward and Henry Kohout, the two Bohemian cigarmakers, who were charged with setting fire to a tenement house in East Sixty-fourth-street and causing the death of Mrs. Fialla and her two children, was finished yesterday, and resulted in a conviction of arson in the first degree.
The entries to the stakes of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association, which closed on Feb. 1, are numerous enough to insure a successful meeting in May.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3.--When Charlie Clowes, the distiller, shot Blanche Gray, his mistress, the other night in Carrie Watson's house, and then killed himself, the first person notified was the lady whom he had for some months introduced to everybody as his wife.

ZANESVILLE, Ohio, Feb. 3.--Last night, at Dellon's Falls, five miles west of here, on the Baltimore and Ohio Road, one section of a freight train crashed into another. Charles Sisk, of Newark, a conductor, was terribly mangled. Brakeman Trott had a leg broken.

Harry Hill was closeted with Superintendent Murray and a stenographer for an hour yesterday giving his testimony concerning the alleged blackmailing operations involving exDetective James Moran and Capt. Murphy, late of the Fourteenth Police Precinct.
ROCHESTER, Feb. 3.--St. Blasius Day was observed in the Catholic churches of this city to-day. Large numbers of people thronged the churches to have their throats blessed.

The Sterling Rubber Company, at No. 21 Park-row, with a factory at Astoria, Long Island, has become insolvent, and yesterday the property of the concern was sold out by the Sheriff on execution issued in favor of William R. Grace Co., on a judgment for $7,443 for money loaned.

CINCINNATI, Ohio. Feb. 3.--The Cincinnati Price Current will say to-morrow that the number of hogs packed in the West last week was 275,000, compared with 290,000 for the corresponding time last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3.--Leave of absence for four months has been granted Chaplain George G. Mullins for disability, with permission to leave the Department of Dakota; the leave of absence of First Lieut. Robert London, Fifth Cavalry, has been extended one month; the leave of absence for four days granted Major E.B. Kirk and that of First Lieut. R. R. Steedman have been extended five days.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Feb. 4.--The taking of testimony in the breach of promise case of Louisa Perkins against E.J. Baldwin for $500,000 damages was begun yesterday.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 4.--The Dartmouth College Faculty and Church Committee prevented a lecture committee from arranging a lecture here by W. H. H. Murray. A few students wrote to Mr. Murray that they were bound to hear him, and he says he will come anyway.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4.--The benefit performance given at McVicker's Theatre this afternoon in aid of the Theatrical Mechanics' Beneficial Association netted nearly $1,200. BALTIMORE, Feb. 4.--The snowfall here was about 17 inches, the heaviest since 1856. Trains from every direction are delayed, and the navigation on Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries was entirely suspended. The wind has changed to the northwest, and the snow is drifting badly in exposed situations.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4.--General Traffic Manager Wilson, of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, was informed to-day that the terms of the proposed new bituminous coal pool for the ensuing year were acceptable to the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad Company. This was telegraphed to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, and the pool will probably be definitely formed within a few days.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 4.--Charles Gould, of New-York, an agent for a billiard manufacturer, rang the bell at a residence here last evening and said to the servant who answered the summons: "For God's sake, let me in, I am dying." Before a physician arrived Gould was dead. He had been calling on some friends and was on his way back to his hotel. He was appareptly in good health.

COLUMBIA, S.C. Feb. 7.--A negro boy, 10 years of age, struck a comrade on the head with a shinny stick in Williamsburg County and instantly killed him. The negro whose head yielded to the blow was 17 years old.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 7.--The steamship Wanderer, which came in this morning from Central American ports, brought the second mate and nine seamen of the German bark Antonia, wrecked at Puerto Cortez on Jan. 14, during a norther, while loading mahogany for the Continent. The Captain, Allwardt, remained behind to settle his affairs, and the first mate died at Puerto Cortez.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Feb. 7.--A company of United States soldiers came in yesterday en route for Fort Concha, Texas. They are 50 in number, for Fort Concha, the barracks of Columbus, Ohio, where they were recruited. Several soldiers stated that recruiting officers had been instructed to enlist all the available men at once, and that it was reported in Ohio that trouble with Mexico on the border was a possibility at no distant day.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 7.--The body of a man was found in Pleasant Run, near this city, this afternoon. He had attempted to commit suicide by hanging himself from a tree overhanging the stream. The rope broke and he was precipitated to the bed of the creek. He was about 25 years old, and his name is supposed, from papers found on his person, to be Johannes Abe.

OTTAWA, Kan., Feb. 7.--A report is current that the Knights of Labor are boycotting the State militia throughout the State. Several firms have been warned against employing militiaman. Popular feeling condemns the attempted boycott, which is not proving effective.
HARROLD, Texas, Feb. 7.--Judge G.A. Brown, of Clarendon, arrived here to-day from his ranch in the Upper Pan Handle. He reports the losses of cattle as very great throughout the Pan Handle country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7.--Senator Colquitt, of Georgia, will introduce in the Senate this week a bill establishing local option in the District of Columbia. The bill provides in detail for a vote by the people upon the question and is extremely rigorous.

ANSONIA, Conn., Feb. 8.--Correspondent Fitzpatrick, of the New-Haven Register, went to-day into Town Clerk Reuben Tucker's office to get an explanation about a little difficulty the two men had. Tucker khocked Fitzpatrick down and put him out of the office. Fitzpatrick returned a short time after and was again ejected. He threatens to sue for heavy damages.

The steamer Massachusetts, of the Stonington Line, left here early yesterday morning for Stonington. She returned to the company's pier, at the foot of Spring-street, soon after 5 o'clock last evening with a hole in her bottom and her pumps vigorously at work.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8.--The opposition of a majority of the leading Irish people in Chicago will probably prevent the celebration of St. Patrick's Day this year by the usual parade. Local Irishmen think that in the present condition of Ireland so heavy an outlay as would be required would be little less than treason to the mother country.

BOSEMAN, Montana, Feb. 8.--Last night a body of masked men entered the meeting at Grange Hall, marched up the aisle, and, covering the choir with revolvers, took W.W. Ulm out, and, placing a rope around his neck, strung him up to a tree in a field near by and strangled him until his friend Henry Dawes appeared with a brace of revolvers and secured his release. Warrants are out for 12 members of the mob.

Adams and his prisoner went to New-York this afternoon.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 8.--Petitions are being circulated in the upper part of this State, and numerously signed, asking Congress to enact a law requiring temperance instruction in the public schools in the District of Columbia, the Territories, the Military and Naval Academies, and in the Indian and colored schools supported wholly or in part by funds from the National Treasury.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 8.--The match between the chess giants was resumed this afternoon at precisely 2 o'clock before about the same spectators as on the previous days. On the third move one of the clocks got out of order and stopped, and considerable time was consumed in getting a substitute.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 8.--Gov. Hill has refused to commute the sentence of Charles Herrmann, who is to be hanged in this city on Friday. Herrmann, a butcher by trade, deliberately cut his wife's throat on the night of Nov. 1 last, and for three nights after slept in the same bed with the body. It was the most cold-blooded murder ever committed in this city.

The brig George W. Whitford, Capt. Brown, which rescued the crew of the waterlogged Norwegian bark Catherine on Jan. 27, and was caught in the ice at Smithtown Bay, in Long Island Sound, on Saturday, was towed through Hell Gate yesterday morning.

Judge Virgin, one of the ablest jurists of the Maine Supreme Court, was born and bred among the Oxford bears. His father was a lumberman, and when a young man the Judge used to go into the woods and chop with the best of them or run the logs down stream with the most daring river drivers. The Judge recently told me some of his adventures as a log runner.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 8.--A large cake of floating ice struck the lighthouse off this harbor last night with such force as to damage the French lens to the extent of $600. The light will be displayed as usual, but its brilliancy will be much impaired. The ice struck the structure with such force as to alarm Keeper McNeil, who made preparations to move out, fearing that the building would collapse.

MENDOZA, Feb. 8, via Galveston.--A heavy rain has been falling since Friday night, and continues to fall. Railroad traffic between here and San Juan is interrupted at various places. Four engines and 600 laborers are working hard to repair the damage, which is enormous. The running of both passenger and freight trains has been suspended. Telegraphic communication has been interrupted two days in consequence of the floods.

BOSTON, Feb. 8.--The yacht Ambassadress with a party of four, consisting of Nathaniel Thayer, her owner; his brother, Bayard Thayer, Frank Bradlee, and Ogden Codman, and a crew of 19 all told, sailed off gallantly to-day on a cruise to the West Indies, following Mr. Weld's yacht, the Gitana, which sailed a few weeks ago.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8.--Judge Blodgett to-day made an order setting aside the judgments in the 40 or 60 "carton" customs cases recently heard by him.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Feb. 8.--Mrs. John Hainsey, of Barre, this county, visited a neighbor yesterday morning, leaving her 2-year-old child at home in a high chair near the stove. When the mother returned she found the child lying on the stove with its clothing burned from the body and the flesh horribly charred. Death ensued two hours later.

TRENTON, Feb. 8.--The trial of Minnie Shaeffer, whom State Prison Keeper Laverty accuses of perjury because she charged him with being the father of her unborn child, was commenced in the County Court here to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8.--In a rickety little bed in a cheerless little room of a little frame house on Walnut-street, near Pond, in Bristol, Ida Cannon, a mill girl, lay to-night at the point of death suffering from being terribly frozen on Thursday last, when the thermometer was only 2 or 3 above zero.
The United Cigar Manufacturers decided yesterday to open their 14 factories to-morrow morning, under a scale of prices averaged on the rates paid previous to Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8, 1886. Mr. Hoar, from the Committee on Privileges and Elections, reported favorably to the Senate today a bill fixing the time for the meeting of Congress in 1887, and every second year thereafter, on the first Monday in October, and in 1886, and every second year thereafter, on the second Monday in November.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 8.--James Scott, manager for Wilson Waddingham, the millionaire, who has spent a fortune on his West Haven mansion, is under arrest on a civil suit, charged with irregularities in his accounts. Scott has handled thousands of dollars belonging to his employer, and the case is expected to be a long and interesting one. Scott is in charge of a Deputy Sheriff.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8.--Andrew Haight, one of the oldest and most widely known circus men in the United States, who was suddenly stricken with paralysis here a few days ago, died this afternoon at the Briggs House, where he has been stopping for some time past.

The articles of incorporation of the American Opera Company, Limited, were filed at Albany yesterday. The capital is $250,00. The object for which the corporation is formed is to establish a national opera and to promote a higher musical education in the United States.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8.--It is definitely settled that Sam Jones will reach Chicago about the 15th of the present month, and among church people the advent of the revivalist is awaited with the deepest interest.

NUNNELLY, Penn., Feb. 8.--Mrs. Slater, her baby, and nurse were drowned on Saturday in Mill Creek, near Graham Station. Mr. Slater, who is employed by the Warner Iron Company to run a pump which conveys water to the Nunnelly mines, had taken his wife and two little children out on the ice.

SEATTLE, Washington Territory, Feb. 8.-- At an early hour this morning the militia and home guards marched to Ocean Dock, where the Chinamen were confined, and took charge. Warrants had previously been issued for the arrest of the prominent agitators. Before daylight the work of arresting them began, and by 8 o'clock all the leaders were in jail.

Capt. Clarke, of the American ship Frank N. Thayer, whose murder by his crew off Cape of Good Hope, was announced by telegraph last Saturday was the central figure in one of the most prominent crimical trials in the history of this city.

The English-speaking framers of Brooklyn met last evening at Turn Hall, at No. 191 Sumpter-street, to-organize a new union. They were addressed by Edward King, John Campbell, and James Bell, of the Brooklyn Central Labor Union.
Interest in the Fanciers' Show touched the top notch yesterday. There was no let up in the stream of people that poured into the Garden.

Crozer, of Upland. Messrs. John B. and Garrett Roach resigned their positions as Directors, and were succeeded by Samuel A. Crozer, Jr., and W.H.H. Robinson. The Roach family formerly controlled the company, but they have disposed of all their stock.

The contract for building the bid Elsworth sloop Atlantic has been awarded to John F. Mumm, whose shipyard adjoins the Atlantic Yacht Club basin at Bay Ridge. By the terms of the contract the yacht is to be finished by May 1. The frame will be of oak, with hackmatack above the water line.

ROCKLAND, Me., Feb. 8.--A dispatch has been received here from Pensacola by the owners of the schooner May Munroe, Capt. Hall, announcing that the vessel has been totally wrecked. The crew were saved. No further particulars have been received.

The proposed repeal of the law prohibiting the hounding of deer in this State was discussed at length at a meeting of the New-York Association for the Protection of Game at No. 6 East Fifteenth-street last evening.

The police were requested yesterday to search for Mary Bartens, a girl of 16, who has been absent from her home, No. 1,424 Third-avenue, since Friday. On that day the girl's mother sent her on an errand, and she remained out a longer time than seemed necessary. When she came home her mother scolded her for the delay, and the girl ran out of the house and has not since returned.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 8.--The news of the pardon of Joseph Bork, ex-Treasurer of this city, which will be published to-morrow morning, will certainly create a sensation. While he was Treasurer of this city in 1874 he embezzled nearly $500,000.

OTTAWA, Feb. 9.--The prospects for this year's lumber trade in the Ottawa district are reported better than for many years past. WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--1886. Secretary Manning has prepared a reply to the resolution of the Senate calling for the papers relating to the administration of Internal Revenue Collector McCormick, of West Virginia. He will forward copies of the periodical reports of the special agents of the department, which are all the official papers on the files. They show no reasons for McCormick's removal, and none will be given.

TRENTON, Feb. 10.--The first joint meeting of the session was held this morning. C.A. Butts was elected State Director in the United Railroads Company, and the resignation of his Judgeship by Allan L. McDermott, who has just been appointed Clerk in Chancery, was read.

A very large attendance marked the regular shoot of the Coney Island Rod and Gun Club yesterday at the Prospect Park Fair Grounds. C.W. Wingert, the noted wing shot, won the handsome silver cup in Class A and J. Shevlin tn Clase B, but both presented the cups for further competition in the club.

The schooners Spartan and Fred W. Chase, which arrived yesterday at City Island, are the first vessels which have come through the Sound to that point under sail since Feb. 5, when the ice blockade began. The brigantine Charles Platt, of Philadelphia, went ashore at Long Beach, N.J., at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. She was bound from Pernambuco for this port with a cargo ofsugar. Her crew of 10 men were landed by LifeSaving Crews Nos. 18, 19, and 20. The Platt measured 601 tons, and was built at Mauricetown, N.J., in 1873. She is owned by C. Lawrence.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 10.--Adjt.-Gen. Porter has selected the following organizations in the National Guard to go into camp this season, provided the appropriation for the maintenance of the National Guard will permit:

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Feb. 10.--The remains of Gen. Hancock will be interred in the General's mausoleum in Montgomery Cemetery. The cemetery can properly be termed the burial ground of the Hancock family.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 10.--The troubles of the Toledo Produce Exchange have broken out afresh, and to-day there is talk of selling the magnificent Exchange building to the city to be used as a City Hall for $200,000, about one-half its real valve.

ALBANY, Feb. 10.--Both houses discussed an Appropriation bill for the prisons to-day. A conference committee will be necessary, as the amounts fixed by the two bills are different. That passed in the Assembly grants $1,100,000, and that progressed to a third reading in the Senate $500,000.

The trial of the Rev. Robert F. White, Pastor of the Methodist Episcopal church at Purdy's Station, under an indictment for a brutal assault upon Miss Elfreda Robinson, was begun in the Westchester County Court, at White Plains, yesterday.
Vassar College has recently received a gift for its botanical department of a full collection of the native ferns of Hawaii, Sandwich Islands. The donor is Mrs. Emily Talbot Walker, of San Francisco.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 10.--Wales Doolittle is a prominent farmer of Bethany. Last Saturday he ordered one of his men, William Ford, to repair a harness for him. Both men then went off and became beastly drunk.

MONTREAL, Feb. 10.--The annual report of the Directors of the Richelieu and Ontario Navigation Company was issued to the shareholders to-day, and states that in consequence of the alarm caused by the epidemic and of the strict measures adopted by the Boards of Health of the United States and Canada the general receipts, and more particutarly those proceeding ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10.--The Connecticut Tariff Reform League met here this afternoon to consider the plan of holding public meetings throughout the State for the purpose of promoting a thorough discussion of the tariff question. BOSTON, Feb. 10.--The conference of counsel in the Nickerson will case with Judge Harriman, of the Barnstable County Probate Court, which was held here to-day, according to agreement, did not result in a final settlement of the point the Judge raised at Barnstable yesterday.

Two art collections belonging to persons named Morgan have been offered for sale sonear together, that the fame of the larger and finer did something to call attention to the less the latter having been brought to auction first, and many people being ignorant of the difference between the two.
Although no subscriptions were received yesterday by Treasurer Eugene Kelly in aid of the Irish Parliamentary fund, everybody at headquarters was happy over the cheering advices received.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10.--A morning paper says: "Indian Territory possesses a strong attraction for all of the Southwestern roads, and plans as to future construction hinge largely on future possibilities in that direction. The Burlington is contemplating a move on the Territory.

In making appropriations for carrying on the work of the prisons on State account the Legislature is embarrassed by uncertainty as to what policy is to be adopted for the employment of the convicts hereafter.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 10.--The French frigate La Flore, carrying 20 guns, arrived up to-night and anchored in front of the city. She is from the West Indies. Other French war vessels are shortly expected to join her here.

ALBANY, Feb. 10.--In the Court of Appeals today, the Hon. W.C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and associates present, the following business was transacted: No. 515--Jeffrey McCall, appollant, vs. Josiah J. Frith ...

ALBANY N.Y., Feb. 10.--The Assembly Committee on General Laws gave a hearing in the Assembly Chamber this evening on the bill allowing women to vote at municipal elections. There was a large and brilliant audience present. Eloquent addresses were made in favor of the measure by Mrs. Mary Seymour Howell, of Albany; Mrs. Matilda Joslyn Gage. of Lansingburg, and Mrs. Lillie Devereux Blake and Mrs. Annie G. Miller, of New-York. The committee took no action.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Feb. 10.--Mrs. Eliza W. Parkhurst, of Goshen, who has figured prominently in the Berdell litigation during the past 10 years, has made an assignment to John C. Adams, of Newburg. Mrs. Parkhurst owns a valuable cottage on Murray-avenue, Goshen, with several acres of land attached, and claims to have a lien upon the Berdell property in that village.

WEST RUTLAND, Vt., Feb. 10.--A portion of the Vermont Marble Company's quarry caved in this afternoon, killing E.R. Copps, the foreman, and seriously injuring Napoleon Vondette. Twenty others narrowly escaped.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Feb. 10.--The schooner Narcissus, Capt. Slocomb, from Baltimore for Halifax with a cargo of corn, was abandoned at sea Feb. 3, during a heavy northeast gale, 30 miles east of Barnegat. Her crew were taken off by the schooner Stephen G. Hart, from Savannah for Portland, and brought here. Nothing was saved from the schooner but personal effects. The Narcisaus belonged in St. John's, Newfoundland.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 10.--Chairman Cowgill, of the select committee now investigating the charges of corruption in connection with the election of Senator Payne two years ago, has found it necessary to a thorough examination to request further authority from the House.

Representative DUNN, of Arkansas, introduced in the House on Monday a bill to prevent the establishment of monopolies under the patent laws of the United States. Section 4,884 of the Revised Statutes gives the inventor a complete monopoly of his invention.
The following additional sums have been received from the Hospital Saturday and Sunday collection:

The Progressive and Central Labor Union delegates visited the factories of Sutro Newmark, Kaufmann Brothers, and George P. Lies Co. yesterday, and finished the compilation of their new scale of prices for cigars.
Robert H. Woods, the Tarrytown burglar, who was arrested on Monday by dedectives of Inspector Byrnes's squad, remained a prisoner at Police Headquarters yesterday.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 10.--The funeral of Thomas Broderick, late Mayor of this city, took place this afternoon. The remains were escorted from his residence by the police force to St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, where they lay in state for several hours. Thousands of men, women, and children passed in solemn review before the coffin. Business was entirely suspended, the county offices were closed, and all courts were adjourned for the afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10.--It is very doubtful whether the heading syndicate will be ready to submit their proposition to the Reading Trustees at the meeting tomorrow, as they had expected. It has been found a very difficult matter to provide a plan that will be acceptable to the junior security holders, and at the same time profitable to the syndicate.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10.--Col. J.H. Mapleson was entertained at lunch to-day at the Union League Club by the old Board of Directors of the Opera Festival. Some speeches were made complimenting the operatic manager, who in turn avowed his belief that Chicago outdistances New-York in wealth, refinement.

At the meeting of the Young Men's Republican Club at the Coleman House last evening, the Committee on Incorporation informally reported progress. The House Committee reported having in view two or three houses between Twenty-eighth and Thirty-third streets, either of which could be had as a clubhouse at a rental of not more than $3,000 a year.

Capt. Michael Hart, of Engine Company No. 48, situated at Thomas-avenue, near King's Bridge road, reported to the Fire Commissioners yesterday that on Tuesday he found, in a stable near shaft No. 20 of the new aqueduct, 31 boxes of dynamite cartridges, containing nearly 2,000 pounds of explosives.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Feb. 10.--An elopement, which is the talk of the town, took place to-day. Albert Smith is a boilermaker, 23 years of age, and his wife is a golden-haired woman of 20. When Smith came home from work last evening his home was deserted.

Archbishop Corrigan received from Rome yesterday a cablegram announcing that Archbishop Gibbons, of Baltimore, would be raised to the Cardinalship at the coming Consistory, to be held in the latter part of next month. The cablegram added that the biglietto or official note informing Archbishop Gibbons of the Pope's intention was mailed at Rome on Monday of this week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--The Secretary of the Treasury has had prepared and to-day sent to the House of Representatives a statement of some of the more important queations arising under she tariff act of 1883 which, upon protest and appeal to the department, have been decided adversely to the importers.

TROY N.Y., Feb. 10.--In the Circuit Court this afternoon, in the suit of Althea Mackie against William D. Mackie, to annul their marrige, the jury rendered a verdict for the plaintiff. Althea is 16 years old and William 23. It was claimed that he was induced to marry Mackie by his threats, and on this ground and on the plea that she was married without her parents' consent the action was based.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 10.--The, Hon. Henry Watterson continues very ill, but a restful night and quiet during the day have aided him very much, and there is a strong hope that he will speedily begin to recover.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Feb. 10.--The Philip Mills started up this morning. A good portion of the help are at work.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 10.--John G. Thompson, ex-Sergeant-at-Arms of the House of Representatives, died suddenly at Seattle, Washington Territory, yesterday. He had gone there as Land Claim Agent, an appointment he recived from the, President last August. The immediate cause of death was dropsy of the heart, a complaint with which he had been troubled since December last.

SR. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 10.--The chess match was resumed to-day. About the same spectators as on previous days ware present. Mr. Steinitz expressed himself as feeling remarkably well, having recovered form the attack of insomnia which he had been suffering from since before he left New-York, and he thinks he shall remain in good condition during the remainder of the contest.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10.--At the Church of the Ascension in this city a solemn requiem mass was celebrated this morning for the repose of the soul of Henry Jardine, the Kansas City clergyman who was expelled from the ministry and subsequently committed suicide in St. Louis.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Feb. 10.--The fishing schooner Lizzie H. Haskell, of Gloucester, from the Georges Bank with 60,000 pounds of haddock, went ashore on Plum Island in a fog this morning. The crew are safe. It is thought that if fine weather holds the schooner can be pulled off. She is valued at $10,000.

MADISONVILLE, Ky., Feb. 11.--T.J. Beal shot and killed James Bracket, his young farm hand, at the home of the former, five miles from here, on Tuesday night. Bracket had been charged by Mrs. Beal with attempting to kiss her. He called her a liar, and immediately the two men drew pistols. Bracket fired first and missed, and was immediately killed.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 11.--Capt. Samuel H. Smithers, well known to sporting men, died this morning of typhoid pneumonia, after an illness of only a few days.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 11.--Coroner Mix this afternoon ended his investigation of the death of William Ford, who was fatally beaten by Wales L. Doolittle, of Bethany, on Saturday. The evidence is so strong against Doolittle that be will undoubtedly be charged with murder in the first degree.

BUFFALO, Feb. 11.--The general passenger agents of roads from Chicago met here today to discuss the heavy cutting of east-bound rates from that city. An agreement was made to raise and maintain rates at the full tariff after the 15th inst.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 11.--Figures taken from the annual report of the Chamber of Commerce, made public to-day, show that over $10,000,000 in treasure has been shipped to China during the past year from this port in excess of the amount remitted in payment of the balance of trade against this port, which amounted to $2,300,000. Mr. Curtis, Judge Green, Major Haggerty, Mr. C.D. Toule, of Lake County, the wealthy landowner who attempted to obtain his price for right of way for the New-Albany and Chicago Railway by opening the draw of a bridge and running a scow into it, holding a north-bound train at bay for several hours, was convicted to-day in the Federal court of obstructing the United States mail. In East Dedham it is feared that two dams will give way, and men have been working hard to strengthen them. The movement to honor the memory of Gen. Hancock by contributing to the fund of which J. Pierpont Morgan is Treasurer promises to become very popular and of wider extent than its promoters perhaps intended.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 15.--The situation is becoming graver every hour. To-night all the bodies of laborers connected with the Morgan Line have determined to strike. This includes the longshoremen, freight handlers, and workmen in the shops.

A new play, and the first appearance this season in his own theatre of Mr. Lester Wallack--so, of course, Wallack's was jammed. To describe one first night audience at Wallack's is to describe them all. Leaders of fashion are in the stalls, while the top gallery is invariably filled with enthusiastic unfashionable folks.

The will of Charles Cohn, who was connected with the German press in this city for over 20 years, was filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday. The instrument is dated Oct. 21, 1884, and was written by Mr. Cohn himself on note paper.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 15.--A Frenchman about 50 years old, and known as Arthur Wurnod, committed suicide this forenoon in his lodging room on St. Louis-street by stabbing himself to the heart with a dirk knife.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 15.--John Pettis, a respectable farmer living near town, who was arrested last night on the charge of counterfeiting, had a preliminary examination to-day and was discharged.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 15.--A special dispatch published here this morning says that great excitement exists among the people on and about the cattle range of the Kansas and New-Mexico Cattle Company, in Northwestern New-Mexico and Southwestern Colorado, because of the killing and wounding of Mexican sheepherders by cowboys in the employ of the cattle company.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15.--Application has been made to the Secretary of State for a license to organize a company for the purpose of selling teas at auction in Chicago. Teas have been sold in this way in New-York for several years, and the sales there have lately become an important factor in the trade.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 15.--The Supreme Court of Georgia, Judges Jackson, Blandford, and Hall sitting in Chambers to-day, heard argument in the two cases involving the constitutionality of the recent prohibition election.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15.--Henry Kiesch, a farmer, who was arrested sevaral days ago for an alleged attempt to tamper with a juryman, was taken before Judge Tuley this morning.

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 15.--Robert Morris, who pleaded guilty heretofore to the charge of unlawful cohabitation, was sentenced to-day to six months' imprisonment and $150 fine. Samuel F. Ball and James O. Poulson were convicted of the same charge, and will be sentenced March 1.

The members of the House have not yet succeeded in constructing a River and Harbor bill that can safely be exposed to discussion and a vote, but the Senate has made some progress in log-rolling for public buildings.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 15.--Herbert B. Wood is the Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, and he is quite a prominent and successful lawyer of Providence. A few weeks aag he institutes a suit for divorce against his wife. Everybody was surprised, as Mr. and Mrs. Wood were believed ...

The Strike Committee of the Cigarmakers' International Union yesterday sent out many hundred circulars to trades unions in various parts of the country setting forth the grievances of the cigarmakers against the bosses and protesting against the action of the joint ...

Blue eyes, light hair, and an innocent expression almost belied the bad reputation which was given to a boy 14 years old who was taken before Justice Welde, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday.

TRENTON, Feb. 15.--A petition, signed by about 10,000 people, requesting the Legislature to pass no act or resolution changing the general railroad laws or tending to obstruct the plan of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company to reach deep water on New-York Bay by crossing Staten Island Sound, was offered in the Senate to-night, and several petitions to the same...
TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 15.--The House today discussed and agreed upon an important amendment governing mutual life insurance associations doing business in this State.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. Feb. 15.--Two brothers named Jefferson and Samuel Ellis became engaged in a quarrel yesterday over a trivial matter, and Jefferson, in the heat of passion, drew a pistol and shot his brother through the heart, killing him instantly.

BOSTON, Feb. 15.--The persistent Pastor Downs appeared at the regular weekly conference of Baptist ministers to-day, this time at the opening of the proceedings. With him were his faithful counsel, Messrs. Coffey and Keyes, and several of the Bowdoin-Square Church people who stand by him.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 15.--The bodies of two men were found floating in the Susquehanna River to-day.

W.S. Gilbert is an amusing person by trade, and it is his bounden duty to provide laughter for mankind. In his letter in regard to the 10 sent him from America he has laid himself open to a sharp retort.
The rooms of the Harlem Democratic Club, at No. 59 East One Hundred and Twentyfifth-street, were full of Democrats last night, to do honor to Charles W. Dayton.

The little archipelago lying to the northeastward of our colony of Fiji, which is now generaly called by its euphonious native name of Samoa, used to be better known among us by the appellation given to it by early European visitors, viz., the Navigators' Islands.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Feb. 15.--A decision of a most important character was delivered by the Supreme Court of this State to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15.--Mr. Arthur T. Hadley, Chief of the Connecticut Labor Bureau, talked to Yale graduate students to-day on "Means of Enforcing Government Action." There will always be attempts, he said, by individuals to avoid the consequences of the law.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 15.--Adolph Dadowsky, a grocer at No. 40 Wabash-street, and an unknown man were in a covered wagon this afternoon, en route to the Eighteenth Ward. While crossing the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad, at Woodlawn Hills-avenue, the eastern express struck the wagon, killing both men and the horse and wrecking the wagon.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15.--The number of bushels of grain in store in the United States and Canada Feb. 13 and the increase or decrease compared with the previous week will be posted on Change to-morrow as follows: Wheat, 53,562,382; decrease, 634,560. Corn, 8,176,971; increase, 925,398. Oats, 1,861,242; increase, 36,673. Rye, 700,495; decrease, 14,988. Barley, 1,658,861; decrease, 92,816. The amount in Chicago elevaters was: Wheat, 14,409,122; corn, 2,788,252; oats, 326,986; rye, 291,194; barley, 156,255.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 15.--A terrible story of exposure and suffering has reached here from the western portion of the State. Johnson Halford and family, of St. Leger, Mo., started to visit relatives in Izard County, Ark., on Thursday last.

The German bark Anna Thorman, from Montevideo, arrived here last Tuesday with the crew of the schooner Five Brothers, who reported that they were obliged to abandon their vessel on Jan. 31, in latitude 35 56' and longitude 72 57'. Yesterday the Five Brothers was brought into this port by a prize crew from the Norwegian bark Templar, bound from London for Philadelphia.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 15.--Mrs. Nelson S. Woodford is a very happy woman. Fifty-six years ago, when she was a child in Cherry Valley, N.Y., she stepped upon a nail protruding from a fence picket that lay on the ground.

Although the drivers on the Belt line are greatly dissatisfied, there will be no strike until the 15 days which the company asked from their committee in which to make answer to their demands have expired.

The Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee has introduced a bill to amend the tariff laws. It will in the natural course be referred to his committee, discussed, perfected, and reported to the House.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 15.--Drafts on NewYork, sight, 29; drafts on New-York, telegraphic, 25.

The County Democracy's Executive Committee held a memorial meeting last night in honor of Gen. Hancock and ex-Gov Seymour, Police Justice Maurice J. Power, in opening the meeting, said that death had lately fallen on two conspicuous Democrats and citizens. Gen. Hancock's demise had been unexpected, though ...

The Senate investigation into Jacob Sharp's method of getting his Broadway Railroad franchise from the Aldermen has been suspended until Saturday. Mr. Conkling was not present when the Senators were ready for business yesterday, and it was understood that he would be absent until after the funeral of ex-Gov. Seymour.

The trial of the Rev. Robert F. White, at White Plains, on the charge of committing a brutal assault upon Miss. Elfreda Robinson while at his parsonage, at Purdy's Station, yesterday attracted a larger attendance of spectators than ever. Mr. Odie Close, of the counsel for the defense, moved that the complaint be dismissed ...

CHICAGO, Feb. 15.--L.A. Hopkins, the cashier of Chapin Gore, liquor dealers, is missing. He had charge of the cash on Saturday, and as $3,500 in money and some papers have also disappeared suspicion attaches to him. He is 40 years of age and unmarried.
A few weeks ago we published a description of the Tongue Guard Society, to which the members pledge themselves to give one penny to its treasury every time they speak disparagingly of another person.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., Feb. 15.--A negro, named George Gray concealed himself in ambush Saturday night by the side of a road leading out from that town, along which he knew an old man named Vincent would soon pass.
