Eliza Bichler, a young German girl, died on Sunday at the residence of her brother-inlaw, August Hauck, at John-street and Atlanticavenue, New Lots, under circumstances that caused Dr. Meyersburg, who was called in at the last minute, to notify the police.

READING, Penn., Feb. 15.--This morning about 9 o'clock, while Daniel B. Glass and other workmen were engaged in cleaning out and redrilling an old blast in a stone quarry belonging to the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, near Tuckerton, there was a terrific explosion.

WABASH, Ind., Feb. 15.--Elias Stone, a merchant of Lagro, Ind, made an assignment late Saturday night. His liabilities are $10,000 and his assetts about $4,000. The principal creditors are in Chicago and Boston.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Feg. 15.--John A. Mason, previously reported as having been appointed Deputy Collector at the New-York Custom House, was interviewed to-day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15.--Opinion at the War Department is about unanimous that Howard and Terry will succeed Hancock and Pope. The prejudice that exists among many army officers toward Howard finds frequent expression, yet it is admitted that his military services and standing on the Army Register entitle him to advancement to one of the two places to be vacant ...

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 15.--Sheriff Haskins, of Mississippi County, Ark., to-day arrested two white men, near this city, charged with having committed a piece of flendish cruelty during the recent heavy snow.

One of the largest single shipments of dress goods ever made from New-England to a single firm was made from Lewiston recently to a leading Chicago dry goods house. The movement of cotton goods is increasing, and the prospect for the coming year is far better than a year ago. What everybody looks for is most likely to happen in the business world, where it is oftener the expected than the unexpected that happens.
The first hearing in the action of the Pacific Railroad of Missouri against Robert L. Cutting, Jr., Peter Marie, and others took place yesterday before Special Master in Chancery Edward K. Jones.

Andreas de Palido, the Italian who is charged with shooting and killing his wife at No. 65 Mulberry-street on Jan. 18, was placed on trial before Judge Cowing, in Part I, of the Court of General Sessions yesterday.

SALEM, Mass., Feb. 15.--It is stated on good authority that the leather manufacturers of Salem and Peabody are preparing for a general shut down of six months on account of the high wages and uncertain trade conditions.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15.--In the Birmingham Town Court to-day Jacob Cossack, one of the Derby Silver Company's strikers, was charged with assault and battery upon three of the hands now employed by the silver company.

The spacious parlors of No. 210 Carrollstreet, Brooklyn, the home of the late Winchester Britton, were overcrowded last evening by those who wished to pay the last mark of respect to his memory.

GALVESTON, Texas, Feb. 15.--A special to the News from Corpus Christi says: "A courier arrived here this evening from Los Alamo, Starr County, bringing intelligence of a desparate fight which occurred there between Catarino Lermo, Justice of the Peace for the Los Alamo district, and Pedro Pena, in which Lermo was killed. Pena fled to Mexico. Lermo was recently appointed Justice by the Governor, and the quarrel was the outgrowth of opposition to his appointment."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 15.--The funeral of the Hon. Dennis McCarthy will be held at St. Mary's Church in this city on Thursday morning at 10:30 o'clock. Messages of condolence have been received from Gov. Hill and others.

A gentleman in this city has just sold to a collector an autograph letter by George Washington, which is of special interest as throwing some doubt upon the assertion that the Father of his Country was never a slaveholder by purchase.

Gen. Roger A. Pryor made a motion before Recorder Smyth yesterday to dismiss the indictment found against William S. Roberts, formerly President of the Bank of Augusta, of Augusta, Ga. ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 15.--W.T.B. Wilson Atlanta's Postmaster, forwarded his resignation to Washington two weeks ago, and to-night it is currently reported here that the resignation has been accepted, and that J.W. Renfro, late State Treasurer, will be appointed by the President to-morrow. It is known here that A.P. Woodward, the present Assistant Postmaster, will continue in office.

There was delay in the arrival of all through trains over the railroads between this city and Boston at the Grand Central Station yesterday. Some of them were nearly five hours late, and few of them were less than two hours behind schedule time.

NASSAU, New-Providence, Feb. 10.--The bark Cyclone, of New-York, Capt. J.G. Merryman, went ashore on the night of Jan. 27 near Memory Rock, at the west end of Bahama Island, while on a voyage from New-Orleans to New-York with a cargo of 2,900 bales of cotton.

The twenty-sixth annual sale by the Artists' Fund Society of paintings contributed in aid of the fund was begun last evening at Association Hall. The bidding during the greater part of the evening was slow.

Benoit Gagnieres, a young French silk weaver, of Patterson, shot himself yesterday just above the heart, the ball penetrating the left lung. He was insane about six months ago, but had apparently recovered.

The lawyers in the cases that have clustered around the suit of George C. Holt, Ferdinand Ward's Assignee, against W.S. Warner, gathered in Referee Hamilton Cole's office yesterday afternoon to submit their briefs. They covered a big table with copies of these documents and the load of exhibits that have lum bered the case, and over which Mr. Cole is expected to rack his brain.

Serenity quickly changed to hilarity at the Irish Parliamentary Fund Committee meeting in the Hoffman House last night when Patrick s. Gilmore laid his check for $6,000 on the table before Chairman Kelly.

BERLIN, Feb. 15.--There is great excitement in Berlin over apparently well authenticated reports that Prince Bismarck is preparing to yield entirely to the Vatican in the religious disputs waged by Prussia against the Papacy for the past 15 years.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15.--The personal estate of the late J.B. Lippincott has been inventoried at $3,588,113.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Feb. 15.--"Major" Fegley, leader of the Salvation Army post at Welisville, Allegany County, accompanied by his child bride, left this morning on the 7 o'clock train on the Fall Brook Road, for Seneca Falls, Fegley's former and expected future home. NEWBURG, N.Y., Feb. 15.--Last evening Charles Wallace and Daniel Meskill, residents of Highland Falls, quarreled upon a street of that village, and Meskill fired four shots at Wallace from a revolver, which he had held in his hand.

PASPEBIAC, Quebec, Feb. 15.--The stores of Robin Co. and Le Boutillier here were today raided by an excited crowd of 200 French Canadians, who carried off about 260 barrels of flour. Every effort was made by the agents of the firms, the clergy, and the Mayor to bring the crowd to reason, but without avail.

Thursday afternoon eight judgments against the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company were filed in the Onondaga County Clerk's office. Michael Maloney, William Kane, Matthew Maloney, and Patrick Sullivan rode from Syracuse to Memphis on the Central Railroad on Dec. 28 last.

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 15.--After a day of intense anxiety to his family, Mr. Watterson at 10 o'clock to-night was quietly sleeping. After midnight last night he roused from the stupor in which he had lain all day, but only to wander in his mind among friends and associates.
The bookmakers' billiard tournament at the Rossmore Hotel continues to excite great interest among sporting men.

RED CLIFF, Col., Feb. 15.--On Friday last two miners named Perry and Gleason became involved in a dispute concerning the payment of $5 that Perry owed to Gleason, and the former shot the latter through the heart. Perry was arrested.

DETROIT, Feb. 15.--Judge Brown, of the United States Circuit Court, rendered an exhaustive decision this morning in the case of Joseph E. Young against the township of Clarendon, impleaded with the Michigan Air Line Railroad Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15.--A heavy windstorm, which lasted about three hours and in its last stages was accompanied by a violent rain, struck this city this afternoon and unroofed several buildings and blew down the brick wall of a house in course of erection in the western part of the city, causing damage to the extent of about $3,000.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15.--It is reported to-night that James Scott, of West Haven, is to be arrested to-morrow on criminal charges of forgery and defalcation.

The chief point of interest to the general public in the proposed reorganization of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad and Coal Company lies in the fact that its main purpose is to effect a combination of coal interests which shall be an ironclad monopoly.

It is a mistake and a blunder to make Judaism in America anything but American. Maintain it as Polish, German, Portuguese, Hungarian, or Russian, according to the ideas of foreign rabbis and laymen who continue foreign, and you alienate young Israel.
Operations have been lately begun for the purpose of clearing away the mass of sand which has accumulated during centuries around the famous statue of the Sphinx.

NASSAU, New-Providence, Feb. 10.--The schooner yacht Nirvana, of New-York, Kenner master, belonging to Gen. H.W. Perkins, arrived here on the 30th ult., all hands well, after a very stormy and eventful voyage.

In the Special Term of the Supreme Court, Judge Brown presiding, yesterday, Patrick Kiernan was resentenced. When Kiernan was asked if he had anything to say why sentence should not be pronounced he replied: "I didn't intend to do that act. I have nothing more to say."

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 15.--J.B. Mannix, late Assignee of Archbishop Purcell, who was arrested last week for embezzlement and perjury and committed to jail in default of $110,000 bail, was to-day released by Judge Johnston, of the Common Pleas Court, on a writ of habeas corpus, the bail being reduced on $30,000 and bondsmen obtained.
BELLEVILLE, Ill., Feb. 15.--Last evening at Gartsides, four miles from this town, Mrs. Wilkenson, a widow 50 years old, committed suicide by jumping into a well.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15.--John B. Gough, the renowned temperance advocate, was attacked with a stroke of apoplexy this evening while delivering a lecture at the Frankford Presbyterian Church. He was removed at once to the residence of Dr. R. Bruce Burns, near the church. Late to-night Dr. Burns pronounced his condition as serious.
The much discussed project of building an addition to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in Central Park, is in a fair way of being promptly pushed to a consummation.

Prince Krapotkine says that it his intention to go and live in England, within a convenient distance of the British Museum, the library of which he wants to make use of in preparing a work that he has in his head. He added that he had been relatively well off at Clairvaux, where he had the society of 20 fellow-Anarchists, who shared his ideas and aspirations, and of whom he became the schoolmaster.

BUFFALO, Feb. 15.--An interesting suit is to be tried this week in the Supreme Court in this city. It is an action begun by the Cleveland Baseball Association against Henry V. Lucas, manager of the St. Louis League Club.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 15.--A special to the Pioneer Press from Lancaster, Wis., says: Nelson Dewey, who served from 1848 to 1852 as first Governor of the State of Wisconsin, has brought a suit in Grant County Court for a divorce from his wife, Catherine Dewey, to whom he has been married 36 years.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 15.--While the tug Purcell was going east to-day with nine coal barges in tow she encountered a southwest gale off Norwalk Island, and during the blow lost six of the barges. The other three she brought safely to Willson's Point.
At the continuation of the Sartorius reference, before Edward C. Perkins, yesterday afternoon, Ellen Noonan, the nurse of the child which is being fought for by the father and mother, was examined.

A pretty little girl of 4 years frisked about the room of the Court of Common Pleas, in which Judge J.F. Daly and a jury sat yesterday to determine Whether her mother was the wife of her father. The greater part of the day her mother occupied the witness seat. The woman calls herself Mrs. Annie M. Kohler.
Richard A. McCurdy, of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, pleasantly entertained some of his friends at dinner in the Union League Club last night.
Sergt. Rooney had the desk in the Nineteenth Precinct Police Station at about 3 o'clock yesterday morning, while Sergt. Woodruff was just coming in off patrol.
The attempt of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company to obtain possession of property belonging to the Post estate situated at New-Brighton.

The story of the killing by cowboys of the members of a Sheriff's posse in NewMexico sheds a somewhat lurid light upon life in our Southwestern Territories. Gov. Ross is not perhaps the most discreet of men, but we see no reason to distrust his version of this story.

The rescued Fenian, Michael Harrington, was buried yesterday from the house of his brother-in-law, Edward Phelan, No. 111 East One Hundred and Eighth-street. The coffin was handsome, but the plate contained no allusion to his history.
More evidence concerning the testamentary capacity of Miss Harriet Gross, who left her money to servants and friends, ignoring her brother and sisters, was presented to Surrogate Rollins yesterday.

About 60 feet of the north wall of storehouse No. 7 of the cotton warehouses at the American Docks at Tompkinsville, Staten Island, fell yesterday morning and buried in the ruins five men and injured two others who were breaking open the cotton bales damaged by the fire on Jan. 20.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15.--Nobody but women and persons having actual business there were permitted to pass into Judge Anthony's court room to-day, where tha trial of Rose Moran's suit against Christian Weihe was resumed. Young Weihe was on the stand the early part of the day, and sleepily told how he yearned to be free from his engagement with Rose and why he felt thus.

Two ladies who had heard numerous stories of the munificent generosity of all brokers, but of stock brokers in particular, entered the Stock Exchange yesterday morning by the Broad-street entrance. They wore a confident air until they reached the iron railing behind which stands a personage incased in a blue cloth suit, brass buttons, and the air of one in authority.
READING, Penn., Feb. 15.--Benjamin F. Berlin, who, with his wife and two children, has been occupying rooms at the Keystone House for 10 years, has been missing for over a week.

ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, Feb. 16.--John Hilton, of the firm of Hilton Thomas, machinists, was arrested this evening in the act of polishing connterfeit silver coins. A die and other articles found on the premises are now in the possession of the police. Further arrests and important developments are expected to morrow.

Mental stagnation and muscular weakness are the ailments of Frederick W. Renwick, who has been in Bloomingdale Asylum since May 10 last. He lies abed the greater part of the time. He has contradictory delusions.
BERLIN, Feb. 16.--Emperor William has prohibited the performance of the drama "Sedan" at Kroll's Theatre.

Some veterans of the United States Volunteer Marine Artillery of New-York met last evening at the office of Lieut. M. O'Malley, No. 120 West Twenty-seventh-street, to consider the formation of a veteran association.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 16.--Four hundred soldiers met here to-day for the purpose of furthering the passage of a service pension bill.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 16.--Eben Moore, recently from Detroit, Mich., died at Carlisle this morning from the effects of a wound received yesterday while driving. Moore and his wife were in a buggy and drove over a log, when his pistol was discharged, shattering his right leg. He was worth $100,000 and leaves a family. He was largely interested in land and cattle.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Feb. 16.--R.J. Marshall, alias Morton, Postmaster at Fort Dade, Fla., was arrested here yesterday charged with embezzling money order funds by Post Office Inspector Baird, who came here in answer to a telegram from Postmaster Yonge, who had located Marshall the day before. Marshall absconded last July, leaving a wife and two children at Fort Dade, and the postal authorities have been after him since that time.
A number of ladies well known in society not long ago wrote to Mr. John Fiske requesting that he would deliver a course of lectures this Winter at the University Club Theatre.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 16.--At 6 o'clock to-night Mr. Watterson was somewhat better, though he was restless during the afternoon. It will be several days before the crisis is past.

The remains of Charles Cohn, who died on Friday at No. 102 East Eighty-fourth-street, were laid yesterday in a vault in the Lutheran Cemetery at Newtown, Long Island, pending the decision as to who is the Executor of his will.

MONTREAL, Feb. 16.--Judge Yates, of Peoria, Ill., who while acting as curator for a rich widow succeeded in ridding her of her immense fortune, has been equally successful in eluding the detectives here. A private agency learning that he was coming to Montreal had all the trains watched, ...
Sales amounting in the aggregate to $1,800,000 were made at the Real Estate Exchange between noon and 4 P.M. yesterday, the property being the estate of V.K. Stevenson.

The records in the Register's Office give evidence of the material prosperity of some of the members of the New-York Board of Aldermen of 1884. Such prosperity may Possibly be a matter of interest to the Senatorial committee ...

BEVERLY, Mass., Feb. 16.--The shoe manufacturers here have for some days been considering a demand for an advance averaging 30 per cent. in wages. This afternoon the 200 employes at Wallis, Kilham Bray's shop struck, although the firm had offered to arbitrate. This action will probably occasion a general shut-down of the shops to-day.

A bottle lying in the gutter in front of the vacant lots from Nos. 300 to 306 East Thirtyeighth-street met the eye of Officer Donovan, of the Twenty-first Precinct, while on his beat about 7:30 o'clock last evening.

Drunkenness used not to be a French vice; but what with the destruction of the vines by the phylloxera, the manufacture of brandy out of beet root and potatoes, the beer devoid of malt and hops which floods the cafes, and the drugged wine, the race is going to the dogs in the towns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.--The report submitted in the House by Representative Laird to-day recommending the passage of a bill authorizing the President to raise two regiments of volunteers for service against the Apaches, after reviewing the history of the outbreak and the campaign against the hostiles, says:

Deputy Sheriff Burke, who has been seeking ex-Sheriff Alexander V. Davidson with an order of arrest since last Friday, received information yesterday that Mr. Davidson was within half an hour's ride of this city.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 16.--Ella Lawrence, wife of M.J. Lawrence, proprietor of the Ohio Farmer, filed a petition to-day asking for divorce, custody of their three children, and reasonable alimony.
The roadway on the north side of the East River Bridge was closed to travel at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Subsequently teams going in both directions used the roadway on the south side.

SCRANTON, Penn., Feb. 16.--John Ahearn, who was convicted of bigamy in this city the other day and sentenced to 18 months in the Eastern Penitentiary, died on the train a few miles from Scranton this morning while on his way to Philadelphia with eight other convicts in ...
A tall, sickly-looking German was noticed lingering on the bridge promenade about 8 o'clock yesterday morning, by Officer Creighton, of the bridge patrol.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16.--Dispatches from three or four points in Wisconsin give scanty details of a frightful tragedy in the town of Greenbush, Sheboggan County, in that State.
The constitutional changes in Japan may appear somewhat obscure to the ordinary reader unversed in the mysteries of far Eastern politics, but they may be described in a few words.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 10.--The first woman buried with the honors of war in Pennsylvania was Mrs. Elmira Simmons, whose funeral took place here to-day, the interment taking place at Pottsville.
POINT PLEASANT, West Va., Feb. 16.--The passenger train on the Ohio Central Road due here from Charleston at 5 o'clock this evening was wrecked at Ten Mile trestle a few minutes before that hour.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 16.--Mrs. John H. Martin, residing on Eighth-street, this city, appeared at the police station last night inquiring for her husband, who she said had been taken from his bed and arrested at an early hour yesterday morning by policemen.

MOODUS, Conn., Feb. 16.--Nancy Sears, Luman Loveland, David Blyth, and Oliver Blyth, operatives in twine and net factories here, have been informed that they are heirs to the late Thomas H. Blyth, who died in 1883 in California, leaving an estate of $6,000,000. Blyth went West from Moodus in 1849, and his relatives here had forgotten all about him, when a lawyer chanced to come across his name in looking over some old family papers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.--Attorney-General Garland in an interview to-day said that he had nothing new to say concerning the manner in which he became interested in the Pan-Electric Telephone Company, or of the circumstances under which the suit at Memphis against the Bell Company was instituted by direction of the Solicitor--General last Autumn, "for," he said, ...

MONTREAL, Feb. 16.--A special from Paspebiac this evening says matters stand much as they did yesterday. For the present the worst rioters are appeased, but they are preparing for a second raid, this time not for flour, but for anything they can lay their hands on.

The Democratic Party was wholly unprepared for its victory in 1884. It very feebly comprehended the responsibilities of power. It had not for a long time believed in itself; it regarded itself with apology and dismissed the subject as soon as possible.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 16.--In the Senate to-day the bill of Mr. Pugsley, providing for non-partisan Boards of Election for the citie of Cincinnati, Cleveland, Columbus, Dayton, and Toledo was passed. The bill authorizes the Governor to appoint a board of four persons, not more than two of whom shall belong to the same political party.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 16.--The striking weavers of the Amoskeag Mills, at a meeting this afternoon, several thousand operatives being present, voted, without a dissenting voice, to stay out.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 16.--President J.W. Johnson, of the Georgia Pacific Road, passed through Atlanta to-day on his way to Birmingham, Ala.

According to the Washington dispatches of the Herald at least one "prominent Democrat in a Southern State, not an officeholder, but a man of some influence in his party," has become aware of a "Kilkenny cat fight" going ...

Tuesday is usually a dull day at the headquarters of the Parnell Parliamentary fund as far as contributions are concerned. Yesterday, however, proved an exception, and $390 were received. Of this sum $290 was sent by the Rev. D. O'Connor, of Dobbs Ferry. The contributors were:
General Passenger Agents of the trunk lines which are in the emigrant pool recently formed met yesterday at Pool Commissioner Fink's office.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16.--Every wheel in the great works of the McCormick Reaper Company, on the south branch of the Chicago River, stopped turning at 9 o'clock this morning, and a strike which has been planned to go into effect to-morrow was anticipated by 24 hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16, 1886. Speaker Carlisle has determined to fill the vacancy on the Committee on Banking and Currency created by the resignation of Mr. Curtin by the appointment of Mr. Findlay, of Maryland.
Nearly 200 brothers in the Psi Upsilon Fraternity gathered at the Hotel Brunswick last evening to participate in the annual reunion and banquet of the association in this city.

The fifth orchestral matinee given this season under the auspices of the Philharmonic Society of Brooklyn occurred at the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday. The "wedding music" originally composed by Jensen for performance on the piano, and lately scored for a band, was played for the first time in the sister city, and its pretty dance movement had prompt and delighted ...
GALVESTON, Texas, Feb. 16.--Capt. Hamilton Jefferson Gedney, an old and familiar resident of this city, died here to-day under sad and distressing circumstances.

Judge Barrett, sitting in Supreme Court, Chambers, is considering whether he ought to allow Mrs. Bertha Locherer alimony pending the trial of the suit of Heinrich Locherer for an absolute divorce from her.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16.--Sam Small, who used to be well known to newspaper readers as "Old Si," of the Atlanta Constitution, and is now a successful evangelist, began a series of religious meetings here to-day, under the auspices of Chicago churchmen.

A tramp entered Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, in Newark, N.J., at noon yesterday, and found his way into the Vestry room, where Miss Emma Gordon had left a hand sachel, in which was about $60 worth of jewelry. The fellow secured the valuables and escaped, but was arrested last night in a lodging house.

SAND CUT, Wayne County, Penn., Feb. 16.--President Judge Seeley, of the Wayne County Courts, having granted a rule on the attorneys for the defendants in the suit of Mary Jane Ganaghan against J.L. Simons and wife to produce all papers in their case at the March term of court, the rule being absolute, counsel are ...

HAYS CITY, Kan., Feb. 16.--Charles I. Fellows, a druggist at Cleveland, St. John County, became crazy from the use of whisky and morphine, and murdered his wife yesterday by shooting four bullets into her body. They were married at Albuquerque, New-Mexico, their former home, last July. The murderer was brought to this city yesterday for safe keeping.
About 60 or 70 farmers and others interested in agriculture met at the Grand Central Hotel yesterday in response to a call for the sixth annual convention of the American Agricultural Association.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 16.--The water, which for four days has covered two square miles of the city in the Roxbury district has for the most part disappeared. The danger of washouts and buildings falling down from undermining is over, but the greater danger ...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.--Secretary Manning today sent to the Speaker of the House along letter upon the revision of the tariff, in which he says:

William J. Abbott, a resident agent of Buffalo for Stephen Moorehouse Co., wholesale grocers, of this city, was arrested there yesterday on a charge of grand larceny preferred by James Harrison, a member of the firm.

The Grant Monument fund was increased yesterday by $1.10, collected by J.W. Wyman, of Crown Point, Essex County, N.Y. Mr. Wyman, Ben Breed, C.F. McNeal, and James Raine each contributed 25 cents, and E.J. Barker 10 cents.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 16.--Mt. Richard Roche, who backed Schaefer in his late match with Vignaux, as well as in the present one, is lying ill at his residence in this city. Mr. Roche arrived from New-York only yesterday, and seems to have contracted a severe illness while on route here.

Branch No. 26 of the St. Patrick's Alliance of America was enjoying a ball and reception at Adelphi Hall, at Seventh-avenue and Fifty-second-street, about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, when smoke was noticed in the lobby on the second floor, opposite the entrance of the ladies' dressing room.
NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 16.--West Haven's sensation, the case of James Scott, the agent of Wilson Waddingham, the millionaire, took a new turn to-day.

BOSTON, Feb. 16.--James A. Deland, of New-York, aged 35 years, Superintendent of the Boston Art Club, shot himself at the club room this evening, dying instantly. No cause can be assigned for his rash act. He leaves a widow and seven children.

BUENOS AYRES, Feb. 16, via Galveston.-- A revolution is in progress in Uruguay. The commotion is not yet very great, but if the revolution is not quickly suppressed it is feared the Government will be too weak to resist it effectually. The revolutionists have gained influence over some of the regiments of the line.

The will of the late David Baylor, a well known citizen of Augusta County, Va., was admitted to probate in Staunton Saturday. By it Mr. Baylor leaves $8,000 to the Union Theological Seminary, a Presbyterian school near Farmville, Va.

The closing sale of the paintings contributed for the benefit of the artists' fund at Association Hall last evening was better attended than on the opening day. Better prices, too, were obtained, and $3,962 more than at the previous sale were realized, 24 of the 48 pictures sold bringing over $100 each.
The House Committee on Commerce is expected to report to-day in favor of the Eads Ship Railway bill, the subcommittee having recommended a favorable report.

The few months she has spent in this country have apparently been a very lively, yet sorrowful, period for Miss Mary Thompson. She says she is an authoress of various works of fiction and travel, one of which is a novel called "Robert Forrester" and one a book of Italian ...

While the schooner Priscilla Scribner, Capt. John P. Firmer, of Wilmington, Del., bound for New-London with a cargo of coal, was being towed up the East River yesterday afternoon a fight broke out between the mate, James Steele, and several of the crew, who had been drinking.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16.--The convention of third and fourth class Postmasters, in its session to-day, adopted a report declaring that the operation of the present postal law fixing the salaries and allowances of third and fourth class Postmasters works great hardships upon those public servants.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 16.--The low license candidate for Excise Commissioner was elected to-day over both high license and Prohibition nominees. The board is now solid for Many and cheap licenses. Returns indicate that most of the county towns have voted in favor of license. Only a few years since prohibition was nearly complete in Chautauqua County.
MONTREAL, Feb. 16.--Yesterday Jonn S. Dyde, junior partner of the firm of Eckerdorff Co., importers and wholesale grocers, was arrested on a charge of uttering forged paper, but was released on bail.

Attorney-General GARLAND in a briefstatement made by him yesterday intimates that his critics should be divided into two classes--those who would willingly approve any honorable course he might take in regard to his telephone ...

William Rutherford was yesterday admitted to the Ninety-ninth-Street Hospital suffering from the effects of an enforced ride in a corn-laden freight car from Dayton, Ohio, to this city, which occupied five days.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 16.--Notwithstanding the cold wave at hand, the ice in the Hudson broke away at New-Hamburg, mine miles south of here, this morning, and moved in places between New-Hamburg and Milton later on.

The first of a series of three Tuesday afternoon readings was given by Mr. Charles Roberts, Jr., yesterday at the Madison-Square Theatre. The house was nearly crowded, ladies predominating in the audience, of course.

The Queen has given permission for the private apartments in Holyrood Palace to be opened to the public on certain days in each week, under similar regulations to those which are in force at Windsor Castle.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 16.--A three-column letter is published here this evening over the signature of Blanche M. Garvin, late Assistant Matron of the Toledo House of Refuge, a State institution, in which she makes detailed charges against its management.
"Rienzi" will be sung at the Metropolitan Opera House this evening, and "Orpheus and Eurydice" be given at the Academy of Music.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 16.--A farmers' institute is being held at Cornell University at which delegates from all parts of this State and from Pennsylvania are in attendance. The first-session of the institute was held this morning and sessions will continue to-morrow and Thursday.

The death of Mrs. Fletcher Harper, the wife of the well known publisher of this city, yesterday morning, was a surprise to her friends, many of whom were unaware of her illness. She had been sick for not quite 24 hours, but it was not considered a serious illness, and at midnight on Monday she was not thought to be in danger.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 16.--John Teemer's eyes snapped yesterday when he saw in a St. Louis paper an account of an interview in which J.A. St. John calls him a coward and says that he dare not race Gaudaur. He at once deposited $100 at the Herald office and issued a challenge giving Gaudaur the option of covering that or Teemer's other deposit or $500 in Cincinnati for a race for from $2,500 to $5,000.

MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 16.--A slight shock of earthquake was felt Saturday, at day break along the Tombigbee River in Sumpter, Marengo, and Choctaw Counties, greatly alarming the inhabitants. But little damage was done.
CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 16.--Joseph Marshall, a mail carrier, was arrested yesterday on a charge of robbing the mails. He has been six years in the Chicago service.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 16.--Yalesville, a village about 15 miles north of New-Haven, is excited over the investigation made by a committee of the Methodist Episcopal Church of the place into charges against their Pastor, the Rev. H.T. McLaughlin.

UTICA, Feb. 16.--The funeral of the late Horatio Seymour was held from Trinity Church at 2 P.M. to-day. The body was borne thence to the "Chapel of Roses," in Forest Hill Cemetery, where a plaster cast of the face was taken by a New-York sculptor.

The ship Wilna, which lately arrived in this port, had an unlucky crew. One of the sailors on the voyage from the Phillipine Islands one day while steering the ship suddenly got up on the rail and jumped overboard.

OLYMPIA, Washington Territory, Feb. 16. --The United States prisoners, Hetzel, Bales, Gooding, and Frazier, leaders in the antiChinese riots here last week, were taken to the penitentiary on McNeil's Island this morning, where they will remain until the District Court meets in June. A large number of Chinamen left here for Portland, Oregon, today. Everything is quiet here.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Feb. 16.--The weather to-day was clear and pleasant and the attendance good. The track was in fair condition. Following were the events:
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 16.--Drafts on NewYork, sight, 20; drafts on New-York, telegraphic, 25.

Edward F. Williams, who keeps a liquor saloon at One Hundred and Thirty-sixth-street and Third-avenue, is the defendant in a breach of promise suit on trial before Judge Peckham and a jury in the Supreme Court.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 16.--The Senate spent most of the morning and all the afternoon in the discussion of Senator Chase's anti-Staten Island sound bill. The bill provides that no bridge shall be constructed over inter-State navigable waters unless the plans are first submitted to and approved by the State Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.--By direction of the President the following Army Retiring Board has been ordered to convene at Omaha, Neb.: Brig.-Gen. O.O. Howard, Col. Thomas A. McParlin, Surgeon; Majors Samuel Breek, Assistant Adjutant-General, and J.M. Brown, Surgeon, and Major R.H. Hall, Twenty-second Infantry. Capt. Gustavus Valois, Ninth Cavalry, will appear before the board for examination for retirement.

Forty-five policemen, under the command of Capt. Meakim, of the Fourteenth Precinct, made a raid upon No. 270 Bowery at 11 o'clock last night, and captured 130 prisoners, 30 of whom were women.

BOSTON, Feb. 16.--Paddy Ryan writes from Chicago to John L. Sullivan that he cannot make a match for $5,000, as Sullivan has proposed, but will meet him in a public contest for gate receipts, 80 per cent. to the winner and 20 per cent. to the loser.
Several times during the meeting of the Board of Emigration yesterday afternoon it seemed as if some of the Commissioners were about to indulge in an old-fashioned fight.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 16.--Martin Brockman and Fred Hermann, City Infirmary Directors, who have been held to answer to the Grand Jury for malfeasance in office, have disappeared and are said to have fled to escape trial and punishment. Both have resigned. Another warrant for their arrest and one for Neuforth, the other Director, was issued this morning, charging that they made out vouchers for $4,000 for a job of roofing that cost but $700.

The revelation in last Saturday's TIMES of the true inwardness of the bill now pending in the United States Senate for "equalizing" the payments of the $100,000,000 of indebtedness to the Government has attracted much attention.
ERIE, Penn., Feb. 16.--To-day Judge Galbraith denied John P. Ward a new trial, and sentenced him to five years in the penitentiary for the murder of his son.
The second and last of the Junior Patriarchs' balls was given last evening at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Frank Kavanagh, a soldier stationed at Camp Grant, Riverside Park, received six stab wounds, some of them severe, during a fight with an unknown man last evening in a saloon at No. 373 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifthstreet.

A correspondent sends us the following particulars of the ex-King of Burmah in his place of exile: "The residence selected by the Madras Government for King Theebaw is close to the Government distillery, carried on by Mr. Henry G. Morison, at Arcot.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16.--The condition of Mr. John B. Gough, the temperance lecturer, who was last night stricken with apoplexy, remains unchanged. Throughout the night and up to noon to-day he has been unconscious.

The representatives of the railroads in the Transcontinental Association again met yesterday morning, at the Windsor Hotel, and listened to the report of the special committee to which had been delegated the task of preparing a schedule of percentages for both passenger and freight business for the current year.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 16.--The meeting of the Kentucky Distillers' Association here today was in response to a call from the Secretary, who urged that the vital interests of distillers were at stake and could be averted only by the most rigid conservatism.

Mr. Frederick Warde appeared at the People's Theatre last evening as Iago in Shakespeare's tragedy, "Othello." The audience was large and exceedingly generous in its applause. Mr. Warde is an actor of experience and judgment, and his intelligence is quite equal to a comprehension of Iago.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 16.--The strike of this end of the Southern Pacific Railroad has completely paralyzed the traffic of the line, and no freight is being handled and no work performed.

SHEBOYGAN, Wis., Feb. 16.--At the Republican Congressional Convention last evening Charles Luling, of Manitowoc, was nominated as the candidate for the Congressional vacancy caused by the death of the Hon. Joseph Rankin.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 16.--Part I, of the annual report of the Insurance Department showing the condition on the 31st of December last of the various fire, fire-marine, and marine insurance companies doing business in this State will be transmitted to the Legislature to-morrow. This is the earliest date at which an annual report has ever been submitted by the department.

The Rev. Alfred P. Grint, of St. Mary's Church, Brooklyn, was married at 6 o'clock last evening at Grace Church to Miss Martha J. Sampson, daughter of the late Alfred Moore Sampson, of Brooklyn. The church was filled with friends of the contracting parties. The marriage ceremony was performed by Assisstant Bishop Henry C. Potter.

The action of the Police Board in accepting the resignation of Patrolman James Moran, who was to have been tried yesterday on a charge of blackmailing Harry Hill, was a genuine surprise to all who had any knowledge of the case--at least to all outside of the Police Department.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Feb. 16.--The prominent men in social and business life who are to be present at the Young Men's Christian Association State Convention, to commence in this city Thursday of this week, have been very active in the work of the society and comprise some of the best men in the State.
Sunday, the 14th of February, was a warm, bright, and beautiful day in this region for the middle of the last calendar month of Winter.
Michael Cregan was one of the first to arrive at the Grand Opera House last night to attend the meeting of the Republican County Committee.

The trial of the Rev. Benjamin F. White on the charge of committing an assault upon Miss Elfreda Robinson, at Purdy's Station, was continued yesterday at White Plains. As on the four previous days of the trial the court room was filled with spectators.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 16.--Proceedings for the disbarment of J.B. Mannix have progressed so far that an information was filed to-day in the Common Pleas Court by the attorneys appointed for that purpose, charging him with embezzling $400,000 as Assignee of J.B. and Edward Purcell, as well as with embezzling sums which came into his possession as attorney for the Assignee.

LONDON, Feb. 16.--Mr. Gladstone's letter of the 12th inst. to Lord De Vesci is a disappointment to the Irish press. The letter is generally interpreted as an attempt on the part of Mr. Gladstone to gain time.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 16.--Sadie Lanfare, a 12-year old girl, living with her parents at Double Beach, five miles east of this city, is lying in a critical condition from the effects of a wound inflicted by a playmate's carelessness.

LONDON, Feb. 16.--A dispatch from Belgrade says that a conspiracy has been discovered there to overthrow King Milan and place upon the throne Prince Alexander Karageorgevics. Several persons who are charged with being implicated in the conspiracy have been arrested. Prince Karageorgevics has long been a pretender to the Servian throne.

The simple fact that thousands of physicians and pharmacists of the highest standing affirm in writing that Benson's porous plasters are incomparably more efficacious and curative than all others, settles the only vital point at issue in the present plaster controversy.
The night of July 7, 1885, was made memorable to the inhabitants of Great Barrington, Mass., by the destruction by fire of the barn of Henry S. Leavitt in that town.

BOSTON, Feb. 16.--This evening the first of a series of lectures on the "Professions" was given in Sever Hall, Cambridge, before a large audience of Harvard students.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.--The tariff bill introduced yesterday by Mr. Morrison was received at the document room of the House today and was called for by many of the members who were anxious to study its provisions in large type and at their leisure.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16.--The election for members of City Councils and minor ward officers was held to-day. Except in a few of the wards, where there were factional fights, there was very little interest taken in the result. The Republicans will again have a good working majority in both the Select and Common Councils.
The Brooklyn police were informed yesterday that George Yergason, of No. 118 Manhattan-avenue, had, in a fit of jealousy, stabbed his wife, Millie, in the neck.

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 16.--Ex-Delegate George Q. Cannon, the Mormon leader who was arrested in Nevada on Saturday and was being brought back to this city by United States Marshal Ireland and three Deputies for prosecution ...

Dressed in brown silk, with a brown fur tippet lying on her shoulders and a brown hat on her head, the woman who asserts herself the wife of Lawyer Joseph Kohler, sat before Judge J. F. Daly in the Court of Common Pleas the greater part of yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.--The President has withdrawn the following army nominations made on the 8th inst.: Lieut.-Col. Nelson B. Switzer to be Colonel; Major Lewis Merrill to be Lieutenant-Colonel; Capt. Edward J. Spaulding to be Major; First Lieut. Colon Augur to be Captain, and Second Lieut. Alonzo T. O'Brien to be First Lieutenant.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 16.--Samuel Ely, a well known resident of this county, died in Gerry to-day, aged 99 years and 5 months. He was the father or 18 children, 9 of whom survive. He enjoyed robust health until a short time ...
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 16.--Two women are here to-day each claiming to be the widow of the same man, J.W. Pierce, who was killed in the terrible slaughter on the Georgia Pacific Railroad last December.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 16.--At a largely attended delegate meeting of the striking cokers to-day a proposition from the operators composing the coke syndicate was presented by the Rev. Father Lambing, agreeing to pay the men the advance on March 15 if they would return to work at once. The proposition was received favorably by those present, and it was decided to call a general convention next Tuesday to consider it.

When Mme. Henry Greville stepped upon the platform at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon to talk upon "Unobjectionable French Novels" she started back in surprise, as the usually bare platform had been tastefully arranged and decorated with tropical plants and tall palms, giving it the appearance of a huge garden.

In consequence of the indisposition of M. Bouhy, who was to have made his debut in the concert room last evening, the Popular Concert at the Academy of Music was given yesterday without the assistance of a soloist. The programme was made up of familiar compositions.
About three years ago James Westerman, Tax Collector of the town of Southfield, Staten Island, disappeared, leaving his bondsmen to settle a deficiency of nearly $6,000 in his accounts.

The Sun has printed two very interesting letters, never before published, we believe, from JEFFERSON DAVIS to his wife, one dated at Danville, April 5, 1865, and the other at Charlotte, April 23, 1865.

Many years have elapsed since Edwin Booth has acted in New-York the leading character in Philip Massinger's "New Way to Pay Old Debts."
