BOSTON, Feb. 16.--A petition of D'Oyly Carte against Frank H. Evans for an attachment for contempt in disobeying a restraining order of the court was before the United States Circuit Court this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17.--In the case of Hugh H. Penny and others against the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company for a foreclosure of the income mortgage, William A. Porter filed a petition to-day in the United States Circuit Court asking to become a party to the suit.

The Trunk Line Executive Committee met yesterday at Commissioner Fink's office and devoted the day to a discussion of the troubles surrounding the live stock shipments and rates. No decision was reached, and the matter goes over until a meeting to be held next week.
A tall man and a short man entered Charles Vogel's bakery, at No. 90 Fourth-avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, and obtained change for $5.
LONDON, Feb. 17.--Two German, one French, one Italian, and one Austrian men-ofwar have joined the British squadron in Suda Bay. The Duke of Edinburgh commands the fleet.

Some 4,000 acres of the most valuable land on Mount Desert Island, including much of the site of Bar Harbor, the famous Summer resort, is likely soon to become the subject of litigation, says a correspondent.

WICKSBURG, Miss., Feb. 17.--Messrs. John H. Inman, C.N. Bliss, Theodore Rutter, J.A. Bostwick, Dr. Henry M. Field, Robert W. Hall, and C.B. Booker, of New-York, and Mr. H.O. Armour, of Chicago, arrived in this city to-day by special train over the Valley Road. They dined at the residence of Mr. Lee Richardson, where they met a large number of the citizens. They leave for Memphis to-morrow.
DETROIT, Feb. 17.--The Detroit Baseball Club filed amended articles to-day increasing its capital stock from $10,000 to $25,000 and the number of its Directors to nine.

When Mr. and Mrs. Edwin N. Jackson returned to their rooms in the Mansion House, Yonkers, from an entertainment on Tuesday evening they found their door locked, as they had left it, but the window was open. The bureau had been ransacked, and a gold watch and chain, a cluster diamond breastpin, and a pair of gold bracelets stolen.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 17.--There are no new developments in the freight brakemen's strike on the Morgan Railroad. No freight trains go out, and the laborers will neither discharge nor load steamships at the wharf.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 17.--In its review of the flour production for its issue of Feb. 19 the Northwestern Miller will say:

The excitement caused on Tuesday night in the neighborhood of Thirty-eighth-street and Second-avenue by the discovery of a quantity of giant powder and three dynamite cartridges was greatly increased yesterday morning.

Cyrus Clarke, Ira Bursley, Flemming Smith, and S.E. Church attended the meeting of the Park Commissioners yesterday and submitted a plan for the improvement of Riverside Park, prepared by Gen. Egbert Viele.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 17.--At a meeting of the Central Passenger Committee to-day the discussion of the new articles of association was resumed. Only 20 of the 38 members had ratified the articles, and much friction was provoked in considering the objections of those dissenting.

Mr. Barrett brought forward at the Star Theatre last night Mr. George H. Boker's strong poetical play, "Francesca da Rimini," which will be given there during the remainder or the week. So much has been written in the past of the merit of Mr. Boker's drama and the artistic worth of Mr. Barrett's performance of Lanciotto that there is little to be said of them now.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 17.--United States Senator Arthur P. Gorman showed his strength in Maryland politics again to-day when he sucseeded in inducing President Cleveland to send to the Senate the names of James Black Groome for Collector of the Port of Baltimore and I. Freeman Rasin for Naval Officer.

It has appeared to us to be relevant to the currency issue which is now agitating this country to recur to the last important illustration thereof as evidencing how logically and inevitably persistence in the flat money principle leads to injustice, suffering, and the comparative ruin of the less wealthy portion of the community.
WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 17.--The Delaware State Temperance Alliance, in annual session here to-day, elected the following officers: President--Richard M. Cooper, of Morton; Recording ...
Messrs. Adrian H. Muller Sons sold the following securities at auction at the Libertystreet Real Estate Exchange yesterday.

An Italian barber, who has recently opened a modest little shop in East Twentythird-street, is in a state of painful perturbation. With a view to increasing his income and keeping his apprentice out of mischief during idle hours, he stuck in his neat window a gayly bordered showcard making this announcement to the public:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 17.--Father R.C. Betts, a Rector of one of the Episcopal churches in this city, when he delivered the funeral sermon over the body of his friend, Father Jardine, who committed suicide some time ago, took occasion during the delivery of the sermon to denounce Bishop Robinson as the real cause of Jardine's death, he having refused Mr. Jardine a rehearing.

The twentieth annual report of the St. Francis Hospital, in Fifth-street, just issued, shows that 1,956 patients were treated during the year 1885, of whom 1,012 were discharged as cured and 494 as improved. In appeal for public support, the Sisters in charge of the hospital say that it has a larger field and more patients than any other hospital in the city, except Bellevue and Charity, under the control of the city.

Apropos of the visit of the Rev. E.L. Magoon to the city the following incident is told: Some time about 1844 one night after the Rev. Dr. Jeter of sainted memory had preached for Mr. Magoon he turned to the latter and said: "Dear Brother Magoon, please raise the tune."

NEW-CITY, N.Y., Feb. 17.--The persistent book agent has at last been overcome. A young man giving his name and place of residence as Harry Jordan, of Harlem, and canvassing for a book of reminiscences of the late civil war, entered the yard of a gentleman living a Short distance south of this place yesterday and walked up the long steps leading to the piazza at the second story of the dwelling.

Matthew McInerney, the Park policeman, and John T. McDonald, the ex-Park policeman, who are charged with assaulting and robbing Jacob Schwarzler, a builder, of No. 1,365 Fifthavenue, on Dec. 19 were placed on trial before Recorder Smyth, in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions, yesterday.
The first exhibition of "eudoliths," or artificially colored marbles, ever given in America was opened yesterday at No. 123 Fifth-avenue.

MONTREAL, Feb. 17.--Langellier Descelles, storekeepers of St. John, in this province, have failed. Their liabilities are $60,000. The firm is one of the oldest in the province, and suspended once before, but compromised for 50 per cent. of the liabilities.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Feb. 17.--Thomas Birmingham, convicted of unlawful cohabitation, was sentenced in the District Court to-day to six months' imprisonment and to pay a fine of $300. Abram H. Cannon took the witness stand when his case was called.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17.--Hugh McMahon, James Cosgrove, and John Burns, who are charged with conspiracy to cheat and defraud nine insurance companies out of $16,000 by setting fire to the grocery store of McMahon on the night of Jan. 19 last, were arraigned for a further hearing this afternoon. After hearing the testimony the magistrate held McMahon and Burns in $5,000 bail for conspiracy and held them without bail for arson and discharged Cosgrove from custody.

The Transcontinental Railway Pool ended its distress yesterday by smashing itself all to pieces, and the corridors of the Windsor Hotel looked like the scene of a mass meeting last night as the score or so of Western magnates who have been so long conferring and wrangling in this city crowded up to the clerk's desk to pay their bills and give orders for the shipment of their baggage.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 17.--Two important suits in connection with post notes issued by the Bank of Tennessee in 1861 are attracting much attention throughout the State. The bank issued notes aggregating nearly half a million dollars for the accommodation of business men who wished to use them in New-York.

A meeting of gentlemen to make arrangements for the lecture to be delivered at Steinway Hall on Sunday, Feb. 28, for the benefit of the starving fishermen of the west coast of Ireland, was held last night in the Hotel Brunswick.

The Remsen Rooms, at the corner of Remsen and Court streets, Brooklyn, were elaborately decorated last evening in honor of the rose ball, given by a number of young ladies of Brooklyn Heights. One hundred and fifty invitations were sent out, and ...

About 50 persons attended a meeting of the Hotel Men's Mutual Benefit Association of the United States, at the Gilsey House last evening, called for the purpose of making arrangements for the reception and entertainment of delegates to the Hotel Men's National Convention to be held here on May 11.

CHICAGO, Feb.17.--Recorder Scribner, of this city, has had to deal with a question similar to that which has disturbed Register Reilly and his predecessor in the New-York Hall of Records, namely, dealing with people who want to make abstracts of the documents in their offices.

The Cigarmakers' International Union has declared F.B. Thurber, the Anti-Monopolist to be an enemy of organized labor and a sham reformer. President Strasser, of the International Union, said yesterday that the union had become tired and disgusted with his double dealing, and intended to appeal to all organized workingmen to boycott him.
There is a bill in the hands of the Assembly Committee on Banks the object of which is to extend the field of investments for savings banks.
The New-York Sun has studied the annual report of the Commissioner of Patents, and it finds in it the following paragraph:

Horatio Seymour, of New-York, and Thomas H. Seymour, of Connecticut, were nearly related, were cadets together at Partridge's Military Academy in Middletown, and Governors at the same time, 1852, of their respective States.

The attendance at yesterday's session of the Agricultural Convention was much larger than that of Tuesday. All through the day and evening the parlor set aside for the convention at the Grand Central Hotel was crowded with ...

Gen. BOYNTON has probably been in a state of surprise for three or four days to learn that a newspaper syndicate had been formed, at great trouble and expense, to reprint certain facts relating to the history of the war which were originally printed in a book of his own ten years ago.

Some of the distinguished statesmen who are gathered at Trenton are in favors of protection of the right of New-Jersey to furnish all the terminal facilities for railroads coming to New-York from the West.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 17.--The Polish Church troubles, which have existed here for the past three years, culminated this evening in the burning of the church, situated in the western part of the city, by a band of fanatics.

After many years of the use in glass works of crucibles in the preparing of glass for the pipes of the blower, a German named Ferrari has found a way of doing without them by the use of a new furnace, which now reaches its highest exposition in the Bushwick Glass Works of William Brookfield, situated on Grandstreet, Brooklyn.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 17.--Yesterday afternoon, while a number of fishermen were busily engaged in the river at the foot of Ellwoodstreet, Carondelet, they saw what appeared to be the body of a man floating in midstream at some distance away.

"Rienzi" is not likely to enjoy as prolonged a spell of popularity as "Lohengrin," for example, and the general criticism that condemns its music as but imperfectly representative of both the Italian and the German school rests on substantial grounds.

ROCKY HILL, Penn., Feb. 17.--"There never was a greater coon hunter than old Josh Cobb, who belonged everywhere in this part of the State, and yet nowhere in particular," said an old-timer, who remembered his subject well.
BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 17.--The following letter has been received by Probation Officer Edward H. Savage from C.E. Howard Vincent, member of the British Parliament:
Colds, aches, and pains Benson's porous plasters will do more good than a dozen of any other kind or all the oils, liniments, and lotions ever compounded. Not a nostrum. No quackery.--Exchange.

BOSTON, Feb. 17.--On the Central Massachusetts Railroad the damage has been so far repaired that trains began running this morning between Boston and Hudson, and the whole line is now open for traffic.

There is some more crookedness in the work of the Electrical Subway Commission. THE TIMES has exposed many of the dark and devious ways of two of the Commissioners, and has shown the connection therewith of Mr. Maurice Bennett Flynn and the syndicate interested in the Dorsett combination system of underground wires; but startling as the conspiracy ...
LOUISVILLE, Feb. 17.--The special meeting of the Louisville Presbytery, called to try the charges made against the Revs. F.B. and T. F. Converse, editors of the Christian Observer, commenced to-day.

An aged and faithful Deacon of one of the orthodox churches, who very infrequently even thinks of attending any church but his own, after calm deliberation decided one Sunday about six months ago to listen to a sermon by the Pastor of a sister church, and, before the bells for morning service had ceased ringing, he was comfortably ensconced in a Baptist pew.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Feb. 17.-- The crater of the volcano of Colima has diminished in size, but the eruptions still continue. The inhabitants of the surrounding villages and haciendas are fearful of coming disaster. A large number of tourists are here.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 17.--The cotton goods trade is looking up. Stocks are exhausted and all factories in and near Augusta are running to their full capacity. The mills are working at a small margin of profit for the first time in three years.
VIENNA, Feb. 17.--An action for libel will be begun here Monday against the Vienna agent of a New-York insurance company.
Mr. Dwight H. Olmstead delivered an address last evening upon "Land Transfer Reform" before the Citizens' West Side Improvement Association, at their hall, at Seventy-fifthstreet and Tenth-avenue.

Political circles here have been considerably agitated for some days past by the rumor that J.C. Flood, the banker, was a probable candidate for the United States Senate. When interviewed on the subject yesterday Mr. Flood was non-committal.

Alonzo Elmer Mallette died in the Roosevelt Hospital about 5 o'clock on Tuesday afternoon from fracture of the skull. He had been unconscious since late on Monday night, when he was found lying on the sidewalk at the southeast corner of Eighth-avenue and Twenty-firtsstreet.

JAMESTON, N.Y., Feb. 17.--William Cato, a young colored man, hanged himself this afternoon in the woodshed. Unrequited love was the cause. The young woman is under arrest, as she discovered him while he was still gasping, but instead of cutting the clothes line by which be was suspended she informed the neighbors.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 12.--One of the most remarkable and perfectly authenticated cases of a presentiment of approaching evil occurred in this city in connection with the Driscoll murder case.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17, 1886. The House passed to-day the bill reducing from 8 to 5 cents the charge for money orders not exceeding $5. The remainder of the day was occupied in debate on the Fitz John Porter bill.

Capt. Allaire, of the Tenth Police Precinct, made a raid last evening on the Belvedere dance hall and saloon, at Nos. 23 and 25 Bowery. Ten men and 20 women wore arrested, ana will be arraigned this morning in the Essex Market Police Court. It is charged that liquor is sold at the place, although it has no license.

READING, Penn., Feb. 17.--Owing to the prevalence of diphtheria and scarlet fever in the northern portion of this county a number of the public schools have been compelled to close. The diseases are especially virulent ground Lenhartsville and Klinesville, where many deaths have occurred. Of 45 pupils enrolled in the Furnace school, near the former place, all are on the sick list except three.
BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 17.--Observations by the Boston Water Works Board show that the recent rain fall varied from 4.64 to 6.09 inches. The water gathered in the Sudbury River reservoir ...
ALBANY, Feb. 17.--The report of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad for the quarter ending Sept. 31, 1885, shows:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17.--The thirty-first annual report of the Directors of the Northern Central Railway Company was issued to-day. It shows gross earnings of $5,490,922; operating expenses, $3,255,613; net operating earnings, ...

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 17.--The train with George Q. Cannon on board left Promontory at 4 o'clock this morning and reached here at 8. Cannon was promptly taken before Judge Zane and gave bonds in $45,000.
INDIANPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 17.--The Department Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic of Indiana met here to-day with a large attendance of delegates.

FORT EDWARD, N.Y., Feb. 17.--The centennial anniversary of the introduction of Freemasonry in Washington County was celebrated here to-day with appropriate exercises in the Opera House. Speaker Husted, Assemblyman Manville, and other distinguished guests were present and addressed the meeting.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Feb. 17.--John B. Gough's condition at midnight is reported by his physician and very low.
Secretary WHITNEY has at length reached the second preliminary stage in arranging for the production of the new cruisers and gunboats ordered by Congress a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17.--The Coroner today held an inquest in the case of Stephen B. Appleby, who died at the London Hotel on Monday morning. It was at first suspected that there had been foul play, but the jury found that Appleby-died from dropsy of the brain.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 17.--In the Senate to-day the bill prepared by Lieut.-Gov. Massey was introduced by Senator Wingfield to facilitate the settlement of the public debt of the State.

TRENTON, Feb. 17.--In the Senate this morning the discussion of the Chase bill, which is supposed to have been introduced for the purpose of preventing the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad from entering New-York by the way of a bridge across Arthur Kill to Staten Island, was ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 17.--The Hon Newton C. Blanchard, the irrepressible and indefatigable Congressman from the Red River District, is credited with another victory in securing the withdrawal of the nomination of Major Lewis Merrill for promotion to LieutenantColonel after it had been sent to the Senate for confirmation.

BUFFALO, Feb. 17.--A meeting of those interested in forming a State League Baseball Club was held to-day. A delegate will be sent to the League meeting at Syracuse to-morrow to apply for admission. Three-fifths of the capital stock necessary is already subscribed. The grounds of the National League Club will be leased. Chapman has been engaged as manager.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17.--Mrs. Emily Zienthouski, aged 40 years, was found lying dead in bed this afternoon at her residence, and from circumstances surrounding the case it is supposed she was choked to death by her husband, Stephen Zienthouski, a Pole. The police arrested the husband and a boarder named Theodore Bruise, both of whom will be held to await the action of the Coroner's investigation, which will be held to-morrow.
LONDON, Feb. 6.--As John Morley enters the new Liberal Cabinet from the bottom the Marquis of Hartington leaves from the top. In these two facts is comprised the whole significance of the situation.
Magdalena Jung, of No. 512 East Fifteenth-street, appeared against Anton Jung, a cigar-box maker, in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday, and charged him with bigamy.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 17.--A most rare and singular case of disease has just been made public at Jackson, in this State. About three years ago Danford J. Waite, aged 55, a farmer and carpenter by trade, living in the township of Spring Arbor, a few miles from Jackson, was ...

Andrea, De Polida, the Italian who shot and killed his wife in their apartment on the fourth floor of a tenement house at No. 65 Mulberry-street on Jan. 18, was convicted of murder in the second degree in the Court of General Sessions yesterday.

HARRINGTON, Miss., Feb. 17.--An agent of the Mississippi Valley Railroad Company has captured three negroes who attempted to wreck a train near Gloster Station last Sunday. They have confessed the crime.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13.--Archbishop Gibbons, of Baltimore, was in Washington yesterday and went over the grounds that have been selected as the site of the National Catholic University.

A commission has been issued by Judge Barrett, in the Supreme Court, directing A.J. Requier, John Von Glahn, and Dr. Elliott to inquire, with the aid of a Sheriff's jury, whether George Cabot Ward is insane. Mr. Ward is well known in society and in Wall-street.
LONDON, Feb. 17.-- The steamship Regina. (Br.,) Capt. Cook, sld. from Sunderland for New-Orleans the 16th inst.
John Hannon, of Tarrytown, formerly a constable, was arrested by Sheriff Duffy, of Westchester County, Tuesday evening, on suspicion of being concerned in the recent burglaries in that town.
It is not strange that the people of the United States take very little interest in the proceedings of the Senate.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 17.--Dispatches received here indicate that the Ohio Central Railroad accident near Point Pleasant, West Va., resulted in the death of two men--Mr. Humphries, of Poca, West Va., and Daniel Searles, of Hurrilane Station, Putnam County, West Va. Mr. Searles had gone to the front platform, and when the coach went down he was caught in some way and either drowned or killed. His body was got out this morning and sent home.
Attorney-General Dennis O'Brien, of Albany, is at the Westminster Hotel. Ex-Senator E.S. Esty, of Ithaca, is at the Park-Avenue Hotel.

"The Comet discovered in Paris Dec. 1," said Prof. Boss, the Director of the Observatory, last night, "is slowly increasing in brightness, and promises to be a grand spectacle. About April 1 the increase will begin to be much more rapid, and by the middle of April the comet will undoubtedly become visible to the naked eye.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 17.--In a row tonight at the Pacific House saloon S.A. Walsh, a carriage trimmer, was shot and fatally wounded by an unknown man. The bullet was intended for Sergt. Kunhoiz, of the police force, who in trying to make an arrest was roughly handled.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 17.--The Payne investigating committee recalled Mr. Hull, who desired to make some corrections of the testimony he submitted yesterday.

The problem of public health, as embodied in the subject, "What the State Owes to the People and what the People Owe to the State," was discussed at length by Erastus Brooks, of the State Board of Health, at a meeting of the Medico-Legal Society, at the College ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 17.--Personal inspection of the ice fields of the Upper Hudson to-day show that the ice harvest has been resumed in a dozen places, and if the weather stays cold many thousand tons will be yet gathered. New fields have been opened from which good ice is being obtained.
The examination of A.J. Connelly, who stabbed George Spatford fatally on Sunday night at the Murray Hill Hotel, was continued in the Yorkville Court yesterday.

The New-York Athletic Club held a Special meeting last night to consider amendments to the constitution relating to an increase in the number of governors and to the proposed admission of non-resident members.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 17.--For some time Sing Lee, a Chinaman, has been running a small laundry at No. 122 South Main-street. He was as quiet and unobtrusive as most of his race are and nobody paid any particular attention to him until recently.
BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 17.--The following amounts have been subscribed here to the fund for the benefit of Mrs. Hancock: Abbott Lawrence, $500; J. Henry Sleeper, $200; "A Friend," $250, Total, $950.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 17.--George Robinson was an industrious, well behaved negro, and stood well in Monroe, La., where he was born and raised.
The troubles on the Sixth-avenue surface railway are not yet at an end, though under a temporary agreement effected last night a "tie-up" was avoided.

TORONTO, Feb. 17.--George Thomas Smith, of Jackson, Mich., was arrested here at a hotel where he was stopping on a charge of perjury, preferred by Benjamin Barter, a manufacturer of mill machinery of Toronto.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 17.--The National Lancers, of Boston, arrived here at 2 o'clock to-day.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17.--Quiet reigned at the works of the McCormick Reaper Company to-day, and the 1,400 men who have been locked out contented themselves with gathering in little groups in the neighborhood and talking over the situation.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 17.--Mr. Watterson was not so well at 10 o'clock to-night. His mind was very active to-day, and he talked too much, in spite of all that could be done. His physicians report his temperature at 101 , pulse 116, respiration 22. This is not as good as was hoped for, and occasions fresh apprehensions. Mr. Watterson is still in great danger, and the resumution of brain activity is not regarded as favorable.

Dealers in silver coin and bullion, and various large corporations who find it necessary to send considerable sums of subsidiary coin and Bland dollars to the Sub-Treasury to be exchanged for silver certificates, are making complaint on account of a new rule made by Assistant Treasurer Canda.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 17.--The trial of Martin Keeler, brother of John M. Keeler, the murderer, whose remarkable escape from the police has been the wonder of the town, was submitted to the jury to-day. Martin is charged with aiding his brother to escape.

PRINCETON, Ind., Feb. 17.--In the case of William Guyton against the Evansville and Terre Haute Railway, brought here from Evansville on a change of venue, the jury has rendered a verdict for the plaintiff and awarded damages of $5,083.

The annual dinner of the Xavier Union will be given at Delmonico's this evening, and, as a number of distinguished gentlemen have signified their intention to be present, the event gives promise of more than ordinary interest. R. Duncan Harris, President of the union, will ...

Gluck's "Orpheus" was given at the Academy of Music last evening by the American Opera Company. The audience was very large and brilliant, and followed the progress of the opera with the closest attention.

The trial of the Rev. Robert F. White for an assault upon Miss Elfreda Robinson was continued at White Plains yesterday. The first witness called to the stand was the Rev. William R. Goss, who had been recalled to contradict the testimony given by the defendant.

PANAMA, Feb. 17, via Galveston.--Ferdinand de Lesseps and the European delegation appointed at his invitation to inspect the Panama Canal arrived in Colon to-day on the steamer McGway. They will arrive in Panama on Sunday next, making an inspection of the canal works en route in the meantime.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17.--In the United States District Court this afternoon the jury rendered a verdict of guilty in the case of Emil Bassett, alias Edward Theodore Lenk, upon the ...

J.P. Morris, cashier of the Girard House, Philadelphia, Penn., writes, Nov. 27, 1884: "For the past 12 years I have been a sufferer with what is known to the medical profession as lumbago. Having been recommended about five years ago to try Allcock's Porous Plasters, I did so, and was more than astonished at the result. I found almost immediate relief on their application. I consider them invaluable."--Exchange.

LONDON, Feb. 17.--Mr. Gladstone has taken the office of Lord Privy Seal in addition to that of Premier. This is unusual and proves that Mr. Gladstone is experiencing difficulty in securing suitable colleagues.
The second meeting of the Federation of Bookkeepers and Office Clerks, at No. 141 East Eighth-street, last evening, was attended by more than 200 persons.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 17.--Michael Pickett, of No. 62 Hallock-street, has four children who at night occupy one room in the second story of the house.

ALBANY, Feb. 17.--Senator Griswold received a mass of correspondence to-day urging the passage of his bill to abolish the fees now levied upon the commerce of the port of NewYork by the Health Officer. Secretary Houghton wrote him that the Maritime Association of the Port of New-York passed this resolution yesterday:

HAVANA, Feb. 13.--The inhabitants of this island have witnessed this Winter some remarkable and unusual freaks of weather. In the first place they were visited by an extremely cold spell, the temperature having fallen at one time as low as 41 , a point almost unprecedented in lowness in Cuba.

OTTAWA, Feb. 17.--Ludger Blanchet, a member of one of the leading French Catholic families of Canada, has joined the Presbyterian Church, creating a great sensation. He is a nephew of the late Catholic Bishop Blanchet, of Oregon, brother of the Hon Jean Blanchet, Secretary of State in Quebec Province, and nephew of the Hon. J.G. Blanchet, late Speaker of the Canadian House of Commons.

The Sage of Deerfield, who is laid to rest to-day amid the tears of thousands, was always particularly kind to young men. He helped them whenever it was in his power to do so, sometimes in one way, sometimes in another, not least by his advice, which was that of a father to a beloved son.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17.--Major Charles W. Foster, Quartermaster, has been ordered as inspector of certain unserviceable public animals at St. Louis, for which Capt. F.H. Hathaway is responsible.

The Vienna newspapers report that at the beginning of last month King Louis of Bavaria, acting at the urgent request of the Queen mother, instructed the steward of his domains and the Minister of Finance to draw up a list of his debts and a general statement of his financial position.

Calvin Sears Harrington, Professor of Latin in Wesleyan University, at Middletown, Conn., died yesterday at the age of 66. He graduated from Wesleyan University in 1852; from 1852 to 1863 was teacher and Principal of the New-Hampshire Conference Seminary at Sanbornton Bridge, and from 1863 to his death had been Professor of Latin in Weslevan University.

OTTAWA, Feb. 17.--Welland Canal contracts have been awarded as follows: C.F. Dunbar, of Buffalo, four sections; James Ichester, of Ottawa, three sections; F.B. McNamee, of Montreal, and John Conlan, of Thorold, one section, and R.T. Sutton, of Toronto, one section. The aggregate price for the entire work is about $400,000.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17.--In 1872 Ferdinand S. Winslow was President and chief stockholder of the Scandinavian National Bank in this city. He went into a railroad enterprise, lost his own ...
Store rents in what is regarded as the first-class business Portion of the city are being advanced about 20 per cent. For instance, one store on State-street, near Washington, which ...

The Trades Assembly of Newark, N.J., composed of various labor organizations, at a meeting last night resolved to boyott the Daily Advertiser of that city, because the proprietor of that paper refuses to make it a union office. The typographical union demanded that seven men who had left the union be discharged, and the proprietor refused to accede to the demand.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17.--Six weeks ago Brooks Red Eagle, an Indian boy, 15 years old, from the Pine Ridge Agency. Dakota, was stricken at the Carlisle School, where he was being educated, with a disease which rapidly developed into acute consumption. He was told a few days ago that he could not live, not even long enough to be taken to his own people.

NORWICH, Conn., Feb. 17.--The management of the Ponemah Mills at Taftville has granted the employes' demand for a 10 per cent. increase in wages and a reduction in the hours of labor to 60 per week, after March 1. The Shetucket Company has raised wages 5 per cent. in addition to the 5 per cent. recently given.

Another name made use of by the woman who is trying to prove herself the wife of Lawyer Joseph Kohler was brought to light yesterday in the course of the proceedings in her suit for a limited divorce before Judge Daly, in the Court of Common Pleas. She now stands with as many names as a German princeling.

A suit, having for its ultimate object the recovery of something like $75,000 from Nathaniel Jarvis, Jr., Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas, was begun before Judge Donohue, in the Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday, by Prescott Hall Butler, Administrator of the estate of the late Bomanjee Byramjee Colah, a Parsee ...
DENVER, Col, Feb. 17.--The Colorado State Silver Convention met in the Academy of Music this morning with 150 delegates present representing every county in the State.
OTTAWA, Feb. 17.--The Dominion Artillery Association has decided to send a competing team to the great English artillery meeting at shoeburyness this year.

At the continuation of the Sartorius reference yesterday Mrs. Annie Sartorius was examined by her counsel; Benjamin Steinhardt. Her husband told her, she said, on the day she left home at his request that their marriage should not take place unless she would promise never to see her parents again.
BERLIN, Feb. 17.--Count von Moltke, Chief Marshal of the German Empire and Chief of the General Staff, is seriously ill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17.--An explanation of the reasons for Senator Edmunds's delay in presenting the report of the Judiciary Committee on the right of the Senate to demand all papers in the custody of any Cabinet officer was found to-day when 25 of the Republican Senators met in caucus.

There is war between Col. Hart, of the Ninth Regiment, of the New-Jersey National Guard, located at Hoboken, and his men. The differences between him and his officers grew out of disparaging remarks dropped by him concerning his staff.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Feb. 17.--The ice yacht race on Orange Lake this afternoon for the championship pennant of the Orange Lake Ice Yacht Association was won, after a sharp contest, by the Alert, owned and sailed by George Trimble, of Newburg. The race was over a 10mile quadrangular course, and there were fivecompeting yachts owned by Newburg and NewWindsor members of the association. Good time was made.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 17.--Throngs of people flocked to another league game of polo at the Casino to-night. The Casinos, of this city, again defeated the Bellvonas, of Sing Sing, Irish, of the Casinos, won the first, second, and fourth goals in 9 minutes 9 seconds, 6 minutes, and 1 minute 24 seconds respectively. Ambler, of the Bellvonas, won the third goal in 35 seconds.

"I have been struck," writes a correspondent, "by a curious little fact about the exhibition at the Grosvenor Gallery. Millais is undoubtedly our greatest painter, and I was curious to see who bought his pictures. See the list of contributors.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Feb. 17.--William Bell, formerly a man of wealth and social standing, but who through dissipation was reduced to poverty, cut his throat from ear to ear to-day to escape being sent to the poorhouse.
BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 17.--John L. Sullivan arrived here from Woonsocket at 10:30 o'clock this morning. On seeing Ryan's letter he promptly wrote off the following:

The annual meeting of the Grolier Club, founded two years ago for the encouragement of fine books and bindings, took place at the club rooms, No. 64 Madison-avenue, last evening. After the election of Mr. Robert Hoe as President, Mr. Brayton Ives as Vice-President, Mr. Albert ...
DOVER, N.H., Feb. 17.--The State Department Encampment, G.A.R., convened here to-day. The attendance numbered 331. The streets were paraded.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17.--While it is generally admitted that certain large shippers are receiving concessions from the tariff on east-bound freight, rates are a trifle firmer.

BOSTON, Feb. 17.--The United States District Court Grand Jury to-day indicted Jeffrey Gerrier, Captain of the schooner Racer, for barratry in casting away the schooner off Cape Elizabeth on the 28th of last December: also for attempting to cast her away. TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 18.--The railroad tax law of 1884 has been declared unconstitutional and void, on the ground that it is a special law and selected a certain portion of the property of the State to bear the burden of taxation. Chief-Justice Beasley this morning read a very long and exhaustive opinion on the subject and discussed the matter very thoroughly, but when he announced the result it came like a thunderclap.

INDIANA, Penn., Feb. 18.--At 1 o'clock this morning a jail delivery occurred at this place. Four prisoners escaped, including Derr and Wilson, who were in for illegal liquor selling. The night watchman visited the cells at 12 o'clock, and while with Derr and Wilson partook freely of drugged liquor. When insensible his keys were taken from him, and the prisoners walked out at the front door.

OCALA, Fla., Feb. 18.--The accounts published of the effects of the late frosts in this State are 75 per cent, exaggerated. Instead of having been killed, the bearing orange trees are even now in bloom, and the prospects for the coming crop are as favorable as any other year. Florida is a great State, but she has some awful liars to contend against, and they have hurt her reputation worse than the alleged frost.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 18.--The funeral of the late ex-Senator McCarthy occurred here to-day. The community in general participated. Business pursuits were almost entirely suspended. Lieut.-Gov. Jones, State Treasurer Fitzgerald, and Senate and Assembly committees were present. Four hundred employes of the business houses with which the deceased was connected and 500 business men were in attendance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18.--As soon as Senator Edmunds had obtained the indorsement of his proposed report from the Judiciary Committee on the refusal of the Attorney General to transmit certain papers relating to the Duskin case, by the 25 Republican Senators who met in caucus yesterday, he determined to get the report into the Senate as speedily as possible, and so called a meeting of the Judiciary Committee for this morning.

Sedan chairs that for the last 30 years have been altogether unknown in Bath are again being introduced. The advantages of hot bathing for invalids are greatly increased if the patient can be carried home "well packed" immediately after a bath. Sedan chairs are found more suitable for this purpose than a carriage or the Bath chairs that for some years have entirely displaced them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18.--Rear-Admiral Davis, commanding the Asiatic squadron, has made report to the Navy Department under date of Hong-Kong, Jan. 15. Charles A. Easton, a well known resident of Sing Sing, and a former resident of this city, committed suicide at his home on Thursday by shooting himself through the head with a revolver.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 19.--Cotton reached its lowest point since the war to-day, the lowest, in fact, for 38 years. The grade of middling dropped to 8 5-16. The lowest previous point on record was in 1878, when it dropped to 8 3/8.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 19.--James E. Walsh, of Peoria, owner of two dry goods stores in this city, made an assignment yesterday for the benefit of his creditors. The assets are given at $21,000 and the liabilities at $35,000. The heaviest creditors are New-York parties.
Judge S. Burdette Hyatt seems to have been excited on Wednesday and Thursday last. He is holding Chambers of the City Court. Other excitable Judges have preceded him there.

BOSTON, Feb. 19.--The bark Neptune, from Cienfuegos, reports having encountered, Jan. 30, a furious gale, during which the seas ran so high that the Captain was about to lie to, when, as an experiment, he put four quarts of oil in bags and dragged it overboard. The effect was marvelous, calming the water so that the vessel, instead of having to lie to, made the remarkable run of 280 knots in 24 hours.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 19.--Mr. Watterson's condition continued better all during the day. At 6 o'clock his temperature was reduced to 98 , pulse, 94. The physicians are hardly as sanguine, but are very hopeful of ultimate and complete recovery.

Brigham, of Cherry Creek, N.Y., a traveling man, in a room with two other lodgers and ordered him out. Pressley is in custody.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19.--Emil Fritz, a night watchman employed by Wallance Sons, of Ansonia, went home this morning apparently in good spirits. After greeting his wife he passed into an inner room and went to bed. About 3 o'clock this afternoon he woke up, picked up a revolver, and shot himself through the head, killing himself almost instantly. No reason can be assigned for the act.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 20.--The Western Nail Association met here at 11 o'clock this morning to discuss the recent break in the ranks of the manufacturers and consider the situation. OTTAWA, Feb. 20.--The total value of goods imported into and exported from the Dominion during the month of January was, respectively $6,367,664 and $3,056,711, showing a decrease as compared with the month of January, 1885, of $211,891 in imports and of $53,917 in exports. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 23.--It is reported here to-day that a deal has been made between the Canadian Pacific and Manitoba Roads which, it consummated, will make the Canadian Road a formidable competitor of the Northern Pacific and an active factor in Northwestern railroad affairs in the United States.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Feb. 18.--Senator Vest has had a relapse. His condition to-day has been such as to occasion much alarm. He passed a very bad night, and is worse than he has been at any time since the first attack.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y. Feb. 24.--An explosion of dynamite occurred this afternoon at the works of the Clinton Powder Company, two miles from this village. One building was demolished. William P. Foss, Superintendent, was injured slightly, and Walter Austin, 17 years old, it is feared fatally. The cause of the explosion is unknown.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 24.--The Haines Brothers, of Glens Falls, will lay a street railway in this city as soon as permission is given by the city authorities. The capital stock is $50,000, and the road will be five miles long.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 25.--The daily Evening Post announces this afternoon that it has sold out to the Bee and that to-day's issue is the last. The Post was started two years ago to drive the Bee out of the field, and defeat Frank Hurd for Congress. Its demise has been expected for several months.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25.--Representatives of the lines interested is the St. Paul business met here to-day and tried to form an agreement for the maintenance of rates and commissions.

LONDON, Ontario, Feb. 25.--William Shrimpton and several companions, accompanied by two loose women, drove into the country to the house of William Monk, a member of the Salvation Army, last night. Monk refused to admit them. Shrimpton kicked is the door, when Monk shot him through the body with a shot gun. The wounded man will probably die. Monk gave himself up.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 25.--Dr. Edward H. Coates shot and fatally wounded Dr. D.B. Keith at the corner of Fourteenth and Pine streets this morning.

A concert was given last evening in Steinway Hall in aid of the German Emigrant House. There was a large audience present prepared to encore almost any kind of performance to which it might be invited to listen. The entertainment presented various degrees of merit and demerit.

After winning two verdicts, both of which were reversed on appeal, Mrs. Ann Mallach, of No. 62 Third-avenue, yesterday lost her suit against Edward Ridley Sons in the Supreme Court, before Judge Beach.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 25.--The meeting of the Democratic State Editorial Association to-day was signalized by an energetic attack upon Cleveland's policy in the annual address of W. Scott Ray, of the Shelbyville Democrat, the President of the association.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 25.--Constable Patrick A. Griffin, convicted of taking part in the molders' riot last Spring, was called before the Court of Sessions this morning to receive his sentence. Judge Morgan said that the law was framed to protect officers in the discharge of their duty, but to punish them if they exceeded it. He then sentenced Griffin to nine months in the penitentiary.

READING, Penn., 25.--The details of a shocking accident that occurred in Rush Township have just reached here. Lillie is the name of the man owning a grist mill at Shamokin hill.

A "Sun and Planet" engine, designed by James Watt, has still a place in the famous brewery of Messrs. Whitbread Co., in Chiswell-street, and is still performing the duty for which it was constructed in 1785. Though there have been alterations to increase its power, all the principal parts remain as they were originally manufactured. A metal tablet affixed to the engine gives an account of its invention and history.

COLUMBUS, Ohio., Feb. 25.--The House Committee on Privileges and Elections are greatly out of humor to-night because of the failure of Sergeant-at-Arms Allen to bring Clerk Dalton to Columbus this afternoon. Both the Senate and House committees have made very annoying blunders in the Dalton case.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25.--Leave of absence for three months has been granted First Lieut. Thomas W. Lord, Twentieth Infantry, for disability.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 25.--A meeting of the miners of the first and second federated districts of the National Federation of Miners and Mine Laborers was held here to-day, and the territory represented in these was formed into one district, to be known as Federated District No. 1.

PITTSBURGH, Penn., Feb. 25.--A wonderful feat has just been accomplished by the Washington Natural Gas Company. By a clever but rather hazardous experiment they have saved the famous McGuigan natural gas well over in Washington County from destruction, and at the same time struck the greatest and most powerful flow of gas in the world.
The contest of the will of the late William B. Ogden was begun yesterday before Surrogate Lott, in Brooklyn, by the widow and son of the deceased.

JACKSON, Tenn., Feb. 25.--This is the second day of the Inter-State Agricultural and Industrial Convention. The exercises last night were highly entertaining.

RONNUTTALIGA, Fla., Feb. 19.--By the recent low temperatures the tender sprouts, buds, and the more delicate growth of the trees may be inured, the hurt being near the ground, but no serious damage has been done to the orange trees in this section. About the same quantity of fruit will be sent from here as last year.

LONDON, Feb. 25.--The reports that the Parnellites possess compromising letters from Lord Randolph Churchill pledging him to home rule are declared to be untrue. Churchill, it is asserted, never reduced his offers to writing. Parnellites assert that Churchill had personal interviews with the Irish leaders and offered them home rule.

LAKE MILLS, Wis., Feb. 25.--Among the persons who took up their residence here in 1880 was Dr. Russell T. Bishop and wife. They came from the East in a special car, were stylish appearing people, dressed richly, and had an air of good breeding.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 25.--The Republican City Convention was held to-night, and Police Commissioner James D. Casey was nominated for Mayor, and Frank Aldrich for member of the Executive Board.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 25.--A train of 16 cars loaded with silk, en route overland from San Francisco to New-York, passed through Buffalo yesterday. The route is the Central and Union Pacific, Chicago and Milwaukee, and St. Paul, Michigan Central, and New-York Central Roads. The value of the shipment is over $1,000,000, and the time schedule from ocean to ocean is 13 days.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 25.--Col W.H. Simmons, of Jasper, Pickens County, was in the city to-day. Col. Simmons was counsel some years ago for J.W Vandergriff, a man who was convicted in Morgantown on a charge of arson, and who received a sentence of 10 years in the penitentiary.

Edward Solomon and Lillian Russell did not take the trouble to go to the City Court, Chambers, yesterday, for examination about their property, but they did not ignore the summons.

The publication of the confession of Edward P. Timmons, the leader of the recent masked burglaries in Tarrytown, was a revelation to the people in that village. One of the results of the confession has been the utter demoralization of the "Cortlandt-street gang."

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 25.--The strikers at McCormick's reaper factory, to the number of about 1,000, appeared in the vicinity of the works this morning and for the first time made a display of violence.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 25.--Regarding a current report that the Erie was not paying traffic balances with connecting roads, General Passenger Agent Abbott authorizes the following: "There is no truth in the rumor that the Erie is in financial embarrassment.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 25.--The financial embarrassment of the State is almost over, and in a few days the Treasurer expects to be able to meet all warrants. Relief came this morning from a very unexpected quarter.

The funeral services of the late Charles Forrester were held at his home, No. 280 Henrystreet, at 7:30 o'clock last evening. The house was crowded by old volunteer firemen, old Post Office clerks, and other friends.

SCHEDECTADY, Feb. 25.--The Rev. J.P. B. Pendleton, of St. George's Church, of this city, has instituted a Latin prize of $25, to be competed for by the classical section of the Sophomore, Junior, and Senior Classes of Union College. The examination will be confined to eight translation of Cicero and Roman history and antiquities.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 25.--At 3 o'clock this morning the Indian Asylum at Quaker Run, just on the border of the Cattaraugus Reservation, was burned to the ground.

Mr. Lawrence Barrett appeared as Don Felix in Mrs. Centlivre's best comedy for the first time in New-York at the Star Theatre last night. "The Wonder" was given in an abridged form, being reduced to three acts, and with no particular care as to its scenic requirements.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25.--Millionaire William M. Singerly's coachman, William P. Robinson, was married this evening to Miss Hattie J. Rumsey, of No. 304 Juniper-street, at the Zoar Methodist Episcopal Church, on Melon street, above Twelfth.
I had always intended to visit Walt Whitman should I ever get the chance. The chance came to me a month ago (December) at Philadelphia. He lives at Camden, a town just across the ferry.

The trial of James T. Holland, of Abilene, Texas, accused of murdering "Tom" Davis, on Aug. 31 last, began yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before Judge Van Brunt. Davis was a man of unsavory reputation, though he was most widely known as a backer of pedestrians.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 25.--Some weeks ago the managers of the Yale University crew tried the experiment of hiring a professional trainer for the men who were working for seats in the boat. A Philadelphian named Gallanaugh was engaged and gave satisfaction, devoting his time to looking out for the physical condition of the crew.

A gentleman from Folsom states that the Chinese are flocking to the mines in that vicinity, and old mining tailings, worked over 30 years ago by the whites, are being washed over again by the Celestials.

PARIS, Feb. 25.--At a meeting of the Union Left to-day M. Ferry said that while he was not satisfied with the Madagascar treaty, he advocated its ratification in order to avoid another war.

ALBANY, Feb. 25.--Secretary of State Cook says in his report that the reports of the several Superintendents of the Poor furnish a repetition of the oft-repeated story of shortcomings and failures by keepers of poorhouses and Overseers of the Poor of towns and cities to furnish the necessary data upon which the county Superintendents must greatly rely in making up full and accurate county reports.

VIENNA, Feb. 25.--This capital is suffering from a partial water famine, and is much agitated over the question of a water supply. The monopoly of supply is at present held by the Municipal Council, and the water is brought from the celebrated Hochquelle and Kaiserbrunn Springs.
An admirably managed and thoroughly successful Lady Washington bazar was held in Arcanum Hall, Westfield, N.J., on Monday, by the lady beneficiaries of Fireside Council, No. 715, Royal Arcanum.

Detective Sergeant Heidelberg arrived from Buffalo Wednesday evening with Herbert Hepworth, alias Vonnello, a young Englishman, who is accused of many robberies, and yesterday he was committed to the Tombs by District Attorney Martine on an indictment.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 25.--Shortly after 8 o'clock this morning Alexander Rose, an employe of the electric light company, ascended a tower at the corner of Gratiot-avenue and Mack-street, for the purpose of replacing the burned out carbons.

The trials for the wrestling competitions that are to take place at the championship contests of the New-York Athletic Club in Tammany Hall to-morrow evening were decided in the gymnasium of the club last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25.--Messrs. Charles H. Chase, nominated to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the District of Maine, and Eben F. Pillsbury, named for the same position in the Third Massachusetts District, may thank Senator George, of Mississippi, for the fact that they have not yet been rejected by the Senate.

This has been a very unprofitable season for the Southern fruit and vegetable growers. It has been more disastrous to the Florida growers than elsewhere. Not only hay a they suffered a great loss from the immediate crop of oranges, but the groves have also suffered greatly.

CHESTER, Ill., Feb. 25--Philip Pyle, a well-known citizen of Buena Vista, has been mysteriously missing from his home. An inquiry has developed the fact that he has eloped with a young lady of that city for parts unknown. He leaves a wife and three children.

Hosts of comrades and friends of the late Gen. Hancock sat around his vacant chair last night at the Military Service Institution meeting, on Governor's Island, and talked about his courage as a soldier and his endearing qualities as a man.

Judge Barrett, holding Supreme Court, Chambers, has decided that an inquiry shall be made to ascertain whether the young woman who is variously known as Minnie Van Dorn and Minnie Pancoast is of sound or unsound mind.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 26.--The chess contest between Steinitz and Zukertort began at 1 o'clock. Steinitz was seated with his back to the light coming in from the Baronne-street window, and played with the whites.
TORONTO, Feb. 26.--As an express train on the Northern Railway was approaching Thornhill Village, about 10 miles north of here, to-night, a team of runaway horses came into collision with it.
BOSTON, Feb. 26.--Myron E. Hapgood, a cider peddler, 26 years old, who has been employed as a mail carrier in Watertown, recently stole from a letter a sixty-dollar check on the First National Bank.

Since the New-York Signal Service Station was established, in 1870, there has never been any such gale in this vicinity as that of yesterday. And it didn't confine its efforts to the city either, but took in half the country. The wind began blowing from the northwest at about 2:15 A.M., and from that hour to midnight the average velocity was about 50 miles an hour.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 26.--Since the accident at slope No. 1, of the Nanticoke mines, by which 26 men were entombed, every effort has been made by the Susquehanna Coal Company, at great expense, to recover the bodies.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 26.--About 9 o'clock last night, while the wind was blowing a strong gale, a lady was blown from a Lake Shore train between Erie and Dunkirk.

In several States men who oppose the use of railroad passes by legislators are at work trying to secure the enactment of laws forbidding legislators to accept such passes and railroad companies to issue them.
SIMCOE, Ontario, Feb. 26.--N.C. Ford Co., distillers and general storekeepers, have suspended. Their liabilities are $100,000 and assets the same amount.

Mary McKenna, 60 years old, residing at No.6 Hague-street, was knocked down and run over last night at 6:20 o'clock by a Second-avenue street car at the corner of New Chambers and Pearl streets.

Minnie Pancoast-Van Dorn waa taxen before Judge Barrett, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on the writ of habeas corpus procured by William Van Dorn, to whom she was married last November, She is a tall, prepossessing young woman, whose face does not suggest that she is an imbecile, as her relatives assert.

While traveling through New-Hampshire last week it was my good fortune to meet Mr. George I. Robinson, formerly a wholesale merchant of Boston, but who is now boarding at the Elm House, Gilmanton Iron Works.
An interesting concert was given in Steinway Hall last evening by a number of the pupils of Signor Emilio Belari, who is well known as an instructor of the art of singing.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 28.--Charles G. Finney,the famous President of Oberlin College, must have been a cheerful and pleasant gentleman to know if one-half the stories told of him by those who lived near him are true. He has left an autobiography in which, it is unnecessary to state, the best of these anecdotes do not appear.

STAMFORD DEPOT, Conn., Feb. 26.-The steamer Idlewild, from Bridgeport, was blown ashore last night on Shippan Point with 30 passengers. The main deck only is out of water. A gale is blowing, and there is a prospect that the vessel will be a total loss. The passengers have been taken off.

JACKSON, Tenn., Feb. 26.--At the InterState Agricultural and Industrial Convention to-day a resolution was adopted calling for legislative action in all the States of the Union against speculation in futures in cotton, breadstuffs, and produce. The Hon. Robert I. Cherter, aged 93, delivered an address.

The small savings of a thrifty community make a large aggregate, The "Old Saving Fund," as it is called, at the southwest corner of Seventh and Walnut streets, contains nearly $26,000,000 that are the savings of over 105,000 persons.

The trial of James T. Holland for the killing of the "sport" Tom Davis on Aug. 31 of last year proceeded yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before Judge Van Brunt. The entire day was spent in filling the jury box with good men and true.

The orange crop of California is rapidly pouring out of the State to supply the great demand at the East. The overland roads are putting the fruit trains through to Chicago at the average rate, it is reported, of from 20 to 25 miles per hour.

BOSTON, Feb. 26.--In the case of the United States against John B. Sanborn, to recover a moiety of taxes on legacies and successions due the Government from the estate of the late Gen. John E. Wool, of Troy, N.Y., which was paid to Mr. Sanborn, as an expert, by mistake, the court finds that the plaintiff is entitled to recover $7,334, with interest from Aug. 16, 1873. Gen. Butler was senior counsel for the defendant.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26.--The second game of the McKenna-Morris billiard match was played last night. It was won by Morris, who made 1,612 and McKenna 386 points in 21 innings. Morris's highest run was 505 and McKenna's 170. The total score for the two nights is: Morris, 3,000; McKenna, 1,886.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26.-The Merchant to-day gives statistics concerning the export of California wine. These show a total export for 1885 of nearly 4,500,000 gallons, or nearly 1,000,000 gallons more than for 1884.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 26.--Drafts on New-York, sight 25c; telegraphic. 30c.

The Convention of Irish Societies held a meeting last night at Central Hall, No. 229 East Forty-seventh-street, to make arrangements for the procession on St. Patrick's Day. Michael Gilmartin was elected Grand Marshal and Thomas O'Connell and John W. Quigley First and Second Aides.

READING, Penn., Feb. 26.--Masked robbers committed a brutal assault last night on an old farmer and his housekeeper, at Cocalyo, Lancaster County. The farmer's name is Isaac Doubach, and he is rich, living alone with his housekeeper.

Argument was heard by Judge Barrett in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on the order forbidding Edward J. Shelley, as custodian under the attachments against the property of Kossuth Marx Co., from breaking open the safes to obtain property which the Assignee of the insolvent firm had refused to deliver to him.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 26.-The case of Samuel Ashman, convicted of perjury, which came up before Judge Swift, of the Recorder's Court, yesterday, will probably go into the supreme Court of the United States.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 26.--A number of coke producers have been in session in this city during the past few days, and, while it is not yet definitely known what action was taken, it has been ascertained from an operator that their syndicate will, in all probability, be dissolved in the near future.
Lippincott for March contains an extremely interesting account of Thomas Thorold's six months' residence 10 years ago among the savages of Tierra del Fuego. The tale is thrilling and curious.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. 1886. The House Committee on Shipping to-day heard a delegation representing the New-York Chamber of Commerce in support of bills to grant to American vessels a subsidy of 30 cents per ton for every 1,000 miles traveled.
EASTON, Penn., Feb. 26.--A rumor spread to-day that Farmer John Fulmer, living above Nazareth, has been swindled out of $2,000 by sharpers.
John B. Kerr, Vice-President of the New-York, Ontario and Western Railroad Company; Gen. Edward F. Winslow, Managing Director, and A. Marcus, another Director, have resigned.

A sensational story was published in a Brooklyn paper yesterday afternoon to the effect that the Kings County Elevated Railroad Company had made overtures to the members of the Railroad Committee of the Common Council which pointed toward an attempt at bribery.

BOSTON, Feb. 26.-Wentworth A. Brooks, a distributing clerk in the Boston Post Office, was arrested this morning on a charge of embezzling letters. Sixteen letters were found in his possession. He waived examination before Commissioner Hallett, and was held in $2,000 for the District Court.

The Cincinnati committee of the trunk line connections met yesterday at Commissioner Fink's office, and discussed at length the proposed pool of business to and from that city. No action was taken, nor will be until the meeting next week.

DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 26.-A break in the Miami Canal occurred at 10 o'clock last night between the foundry and machine shop of W. P. Callahan, flooding his premises and the several streets south as far as Fifth-street. Great damage will be done to the machinery and pat terns in Callahan's shop and to articles stored in cellars in scores of dwellings and stores.

The Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club held its annual meeting at Delmonico's last evening. The meeting was largely attended, as every one was anxious to hear the report of the special committee to whom was referred "the report of the Trustees in the matter of the clubhouse and anchorage at Tompkinsville.

Chang Yu Sing, better known as Chang the Chinese Giant, drove down in a hack to the County Court House yesterday in company with his manager, Mr. Cameron, declared his intention of becoming a citizen of the United States, foreswore allegiance to the Emperor of China, and took out his first naturalization papers.
When the streamship Roanoke, of the Old Dominion Steamship Line, left this city on her Southern trip on Thursday she carried as happy a lot of seamen as were ever rewarded for bravery.

PLAINFIELD, Feb. 26.-Much excitement was occasioned here to-day by the discovery early this morning of a large pool of blood on the front porch of Rudolphus Macdonald's residence,on East Front-steeet.
READING, Penn., Feb. 26,-John Schlaesman,65 years old, committed suicide early this morning in West Hamburg. He tried to shoot himself with a revolver first, but the cartridge failed to explode.

Prof. F. Nicholls Crouch says that if Cora Pearl, whose memoirs are about to be issued in Paris, is his daughter Emma, she is considerably older than she is stated to be in the account of her from Paris published yesterday.

FERGUS, Ontario, Feb. 26.--A freight train on the Grand Trunk Railway jumped the track near here to-day. The engine and 13 cars went over an embankment 20 feet high and were wrecked. One man was injured, but it is thought not fatally. The accident is supposed to have been caused by ice on the track. The loss to the Grand Trunk Company is estimated at $30,000.

WARWICK, N.Y., Feb. 26.--Miss Lizzie Clark, a maiden lady residing at Lake Station, in this county, was awakened in her bedroom about 9:30 o'clock last evening by a burglar, who covered her with a revolver and threatened her life if she made any outcry.
HUNTINGDON, Penn., Feb. 26.--A fraud committed by means of intimidation has just been perpetrated upon Jacob Bowser, a farmer, of Bedford County, adjoining the Huntingdon County line.

ALBANY, Feb. 26.--The Court of Appeals with meet on Monday, March 1. The day calender is as follows: Nos. 920, 959 524, 523, 528, 435, 496, 555, Tuesdays, March 2 and 16 will be motion days.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 26.-The coke drawers of the Morgan Foundry and the White and Summit Works, who struck yesterday for an advance of 5 cents per ton for drawing small ovens, returned to work this morning, the operators having conceded the increase.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26.-The queer circumstances connected with injuries received by Mrs. Mary Loughridge, a woman over 70 years of age who died on Wednesday from supposed violence at the hands of her son, were inquired into by the Coroner to-day.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 26.--The Democrats to-night nominated Mayor Thomas E. Kinney for re-election. A year ago, failing to secure the party nomination. Mr. Kinney ran as the citizens' candidate and was elected by a small plurality. The Republicans have nominated exMayor James Miller.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Feb. 26.-This was the second day of the Spring meeting at Wagener Park.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 16.-A Daily News special from Rensselaer, Ind., says Wiebern Wartena was hanged here this morning. There was a large crowd gathered to witness the hanging, estimated at over 3,000 people.

BOSTON, Feb. 26.--The storm of to-day, accompanied by a rattling gale, has been one of the severest of this season of unusually sharp storms. Early in the morning the wind sped along at the rate of 36 miles an hour, increasing to 42 as the day advanced, and growing more violent after nightfall.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 26.--Lexington enjoyed two turf sensations to-day, one among the thoroughbreds and the other among the trotters. The former was occasioned by an attachment issued here against Wiley Buckles, of Champaign, Ill., by E. Corrigan, of Kansas City.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Feb 26.--At the Coroner's inquest to-day in the Graham case a 13year-old son of the prisoner identified the clothing found with the body yesterday as that of his mother. Strong evidence was adduced showing that Graham murdered his wife, then threw her body and clothing into the well; that he had intended burning the clothes, but was frightened away. The feeling against the prisoner runs high.

HOUSTON, Texas, Feb. 26.--Great surprise was caused to-day by the announcement that the Houston Savings Bank had suspended soon after opening its doors this morning. On the petition of the stockholders Judge Masterson appointed D.F. Stuart Receiver.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 26.--The steam yacht G.G. Green, belonging to the person for whom she is named, in New-Jersey, and which was abandoned in Ocrrcoke Inlet, reached this port to-day.

The subcommittee of the Republican County Committee recently appointed to suggest reforms in the methods of conducting the organization in this city has agreed upon some changes the adoption of which will be urged. One of these, and by far the most important, is a return to the old plan of having district associations.

BOSTON, Feb. 26.-The veteran Joseph Hornung this morning signed a contract as left fielder with the Bostons for next season. He has gotten quite over his rueumatism of last year.

RUSK, Texas, Feb. 26.--A fire broke out at 12:30 this morning in the engine house at the Rusk Penitentiary Works, destroying the large machine shops, containing planing mills, cabinet, chair, and wagon factories, and a large amount of machinery and material used in the several factories.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 26.--An association of creole ladies gave a reception in Art Hall, at the Exposition, to-day, to Admiral Lacombe and the officers of the French fleet now at this port.

The Finance Committee of the Board of Education yesterday confirmed the report of the Trustees giving the contract for school furniture in Grammar School No.83, in West One Hundred and Tenth-street; to A.H. Andrews Co., although their bid was $700 above the lowest...

BOSTON,Feb. 26.-Albert Murdock, 30 years old,living at No.ll Boylston-place, committed suicide this morning by cutting his throat with a razor. Despondency caused by long illness is sunposed to have induced the act.

LONDON, Feb. 26.--The employes of the Nettlefolds Screw Works at Smethwick, numbering 3,000, struck work to-day. Subsequently a number of sympathizers joined the strikers, and a small riot occurred, during which the windows of the establishment were smashed. The rioters are now marching towards Birmingham. Mr. Joseph Chamberlain is a partner in the corporation.
Coroner Eidman and a jury spent nearly the entire day yesterday in investigating the cause of the death of Thomas E. Roche in the German Hospital on Feb. 17 while under the influence of chloroform.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 26.--There is being set up in the chapel of the United States Naval Academy a memorial tablet in honor of Charles Flint Putnam, who lost his life in 1882 in the arctic relief expedition. The tablet was made in New-York by Messrs. J. R. Lamb. It is 6 feet by 5 feet 5 inches and of Italian marble.

In the Sartorius case yesterday, Mr. Wills, father of Mrs. Sartorius, under crossexamination by Lawyer William N. Cohen as to his past life in Paris, told an interesting story as to how a man, under the French law, can be convicted of an imaginary crime and sentenced during his absence front the country to a term of imprisonment.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 26--Mr. Watterson was kept free from exciting interruptions to-day, the result being to his advantage. He is doing as well as could be hoped for under the circumstances, and his slow recovery is the natural result of the weakness to which his system has been reduced by the great strain of six weeks of almost deathly illness:

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26.--Sir Alexander Stewart, ex-Premier of New South Wales, his wife, son, and daughter, and Randolph C. Want, a large shareholder in the Mackay-Bennett Cable Company, and his wife left here to-day in a special car for New-York on their way to London.

The long-delayed trial before the Excise Commissioners of Thomas F. Parker, the licensee of "Tom" Gould's place in best Thirty-firststreet, on a charge of violating the excise law on the morning of Dec. 30, which was set down peremptorily for yesterday, was again adjourned...

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 26.-The proceedings in the Duncan murder trial this morning embraced more testimony of the searching party as to Duncan's actions and sayings about the time of Van Schaick's disappearance.
Charles Crooker has sent word to his sons to place $33,000 in the bank to the credit of the Boys and Girls' Aid Society.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES says of Senator Sloan's resolution inquiring where Health Officer Smith's fees come from, that " It would be interesting to know also where they go to." This is too much to expect. But if THE TIMES will pump seven Senators who might be named it may find out something.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Feb. 26.--Mrs. Mary Ramsey, of Brooklyn, N.Y., and George T. Nicodemus, formerly of Waynesborough, Penn., were arrested here to-day, charged with complicity in the murder of Peter Hansen on Jan. 5, in a house at Fort Hamilton, Long Island.
With this morning's cannon ball for St. Paul was Superintendent Austin Pound, of the Winnipeg and Port Arthur Division of the Canadian Pacific Railway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Capt. E.P. Lull, commanding the United States steamer Hartford, which was at Coquimbo, Chill, Jan. 15, has been condemned by medical survey and ordered to the United States for treatment.
Some of the Nova Scotia fishermen have been turning their eyes to the Pacific coast of the Dominion in search of a field for the more profitable pursuit of their calling.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26.--The trial of James C. Brown for killing B.J. Shay on Oct. 23 last, while the latter was sitting at dinner in the Nevada Restaurant with Mrs. Brown and a friend, was concluded last night by the jury returning a verdict of not guilty.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 26.--The little town of Westville, a suburb of this city, is all aroused over the work of incendiaries last night. Just before midnight fire was discovered in an old building used for storing hay. It was destroyed, the loss being $2,500.

The final performance that "Faust" is to have this season was given at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening. The representation of Gounod's masterpiece, although it cannot be classed with the most successful productions of the Winter in respect of closeness to the composer'a ideal, has afforded lively satisfaction to the frequenters of the theatre.
FORT WORTH, Texas, Feb. 26.--State Health Officer Swearingen arrived here last night, and 30 leading citizens and physicians met him at the hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26.--The Pennsylvania, the Beech Creek, and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Companies have issued orders to the different interests represented by them not to make any further contracts for coal until the first week in March.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 26.--Gen. Buell qualified as Pension Agent here to-day, and Col. Kelly, the present incumbent will surrender March 1.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Feb. 26.--The trial of James E. Myers for assault in the first degree was concluded to-day. The jury failed to agree and was discharged.

Superintendent Hall, of the working Home for Blind Men in West Philadelphia, said in a conversation upon this subject: "I have no greater pleasure in life, now that I have lost my sight, than in dreaming, for then, and then only, I catch glimpses of the world about me. I am no longer blind.

"Julius Caesar" was performed at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre last evening before a large audience. Mr. Booth being the Marcus Brutus. The eminent tragedian is scarcely seen at his best in this part, which is cast in a somewhat broader mold than the characters in which he most excels, but...

An interesting sale of Bronte relies has just taken place at Saltaire, in the course of the disposal of the effects of the late Mr. Benjamin Binns, tailor, of Saltaire, into whose possession they had come through his wife, the sister of that Martha Brown who was such a faithful domestic of the Brontes, and to whom they had been committed by the Rev. P. Bronte as mementoes of his famous daughter.

PARIS, Feb, 9.--The first two concerts of Mme. Patti filled the very large auditorium of the Eden Theatre from pit to dome. The usual appearance of the hall was very much changed seats having been placed in the galleries, aisles, and up to the footlights, the orchestra being seated on the stage.
William Johnson McCullough, a son of the late John McCullough, the tragedian, died suddenly yesterday at his home, 219 East Thompson-street. Mr. McCullough was in his twentysixth year.
The sale of the Edgewater stud or race horses in training, the property of T.J. Megibben, of Cynthiana, Ky., was held at the MadisonSquare Garden yesterday, William Easton, auctioneer.

The Rev. Sam Small's audience last evening was small on account of the rain. Near the opening of his sermon he read an item published in the Journal to the effect that Sam Small and Sam Jones were rampant rebels down in Georgia during the war.

It was rumored late last evening that the drivers and conductors employed on Deacon Richardson's various Brooklyn horse car lines, the Atlantic-Avenue and South Ferry, the Boerum-Street and Fulton Ferry, the Seventh-Avenue, the Vanderbilt-Avenue, and the Bergen...

Justice Donohue yesterday issued an order to show cause, returnable at Troy on March 1, why the collection of arrears of taxes due by the Western Union Telegraph Company should not be taken out of the bands of exSheriff Davidson and Edward J. Shelley, who has been acting in his behalf. The order was issued upon the application of Controller Chapin.
Between Feb. 10 and 18 five daughters of Thomas Hogan, of Newmarket, died of diphtheria.

The effort of Republican Senators to make political capital by getting up a contest over removals from office will serve a useful purpose if it results in forcing the whole business of making and confirming appointments into the light. There is no just ground for secrecy in any part of this business.
The Great American Desert has retreated to the extreme western limits of this flourishing State, and is making preparations to take its departure into Wyoming across the State line.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26.--Senators Hale and Blair were each disappointed when the Senate adjourned to-day. Mr. Blair had hoped to reach a vote on the Educational bill this week, and Mr. Hale wanted to secure the rejection of Messrs. Pillsbury and Chase before the beginning of another week.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 26.--The Coates-Keith tragedy of yesterday came very near being duplicated to-day. The principal actors were Louis Williams and William Jordan, both colored.
