Oliver Johnson and his wife, friends of Charles J. Boulin, who was locked up in the Tombs awaiting trial on a charge of having murdered his wife on Thanksgiving Day, went to make him a visit at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
The case of the Rev. W. A. Merrill, of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, Jersey City, came up before the Newark Conference yesterday afternoon in the Arlington-Street ...

LONDON, Feb. 26.--William Terriss, who was the leading support of Henry Irving on his first American tour, has concluded arrangements for a second visit to England of Augustin Daly's company from Daly's Theatre, NewYork.

The east-bound cargoes that reach San Francisco by the Pacific Mail steamships are handled by the Central Pacific Railroad at that point, and that road designates the routes over which the freight will travel after crossing the Rocky Mountains.

PANAMA, Feb. 26, via Galveston.--The Hon. John Bigelow has returned to Colon. He accompanied M. de Lesseps and party to La Boca, on this side, and it is believed that he has formed a favorable opinion of the canal.

PANAMA, Feb. 26, via Galveston.--The Hon. John Bigelow has returned to Colon. He accompanied M. de Lesseps and party to La Boca, on this side, and it is believed that he has formed a favorable opinion of the canal.

The legislative steeplechase hunt for the Aldermen who were bribed to give Jacob Sharp his Broadway Railroad franchise started off across the fields of investigation yesterday without the usual inquiry for the elusive "Billy" Moloney.
MURPHYSBOROUGH, Ill., Feb. 26.--A few tramps have been encamped two miles south of this city, on the Narrow Gauge Railroad. Yesterday a farmer passed the camp and found it deserted.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 26.--A fire broke out at 11 o'olock to-night in the vestry of the new St. Mary's Catholic Church.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 26.-On a bet yesterday William Barton, an employe at the Wallace shops in Wallingford, tried to eat 36 boiled eggs in 20 minutes. Some of the eggs had double yolks, but by the aid of copious draughts of cider Barton managed to gulp down 32 eggs in the time allotted, losing his bet. For some time he was unable to speak, but was again at work in the afternoon.

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 26.--Frank J. Cannon and Angus Cannon were held to-day in $1,000 bail each for assault on United States District Attorney Dickson. S.A. Kenner was discharged. H.I. Gowans, W.H. Lee, and H.J. Folger, convicted of unlawful cohabitation, were sentenced to-day to six months' imprison ment and $300 fine each.

The principal market for green tea is the United States. Having fallen rather into disrepute in the Old World, it has established itself in the New World, where it is largely consumed and known as "tea" simply, in contradistinction to "English breakfast tea," " China tea," or "Oolong," by which names the black teas are designated.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 26.--J.B. Stitzer, engineer of the Aspen Smelter, and another employe went to the cabin occupied by a German named Frank Toucer yesterday to discover the reason why he had not been at work for several days.

Mr. Lawrence Barrett presented another interesting bill at the Star Theatre last evening, appearing a Yorick in "Yorick's Love," and David Garrick in T.W. Robertson's English adaptation of "Sullivan"--two actors.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 26.--The Legislature to-day voted down a proposition to compel the State Printer to employ only union men on work done for the State. The line was drawn by the county delegations on the assertion that trades unions existed only in large cities, and the proposed bill would prevent bidding by printers in the smaller towns.

Solomon Klein, a cloakmaker, of No. 67 Allen-street, appeared yesterday in the Essex Market Police Court as a complainant against Louis Schifferts, one of his workmen, whom he charged with having stolen five screws from his sewing machines.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 26.--To-night, while men were putting ore into a crusher at the blast furnace of the Cleveland Rolling Mill Company, the ore, which was frozen on top, caved in and caught three men before they could get away. William Smith, of Vermont-street, and John Sabot, of Brooklyn Village, were killed, and John Kosa was terribly injured.

WASHINGTON, 25--Mr. Celso Caesar Moreno, of this city appered before the House Committee on Labor to-day and urged the committee to adopt some measure for the suppression of what he termed the "sale of Italian human flesh," which he asserted was now going on in this country.

Charles A. Ashburner, the geologist in charge of the second geological survey of Pennsylvania, lectured last night before the Engineering Society of the School of Mines of Columbia College, on "Petroleum and Natural Gas." He declared that instead of the oil fields being inexhaustible, in his belief the meridian of the oil business had passed.

From refusing to give the country any fighting vessels at all Congress is apparently proceeding to tumble them out in profusion. There are four new steel cruisers, the Chicago, Atlanta, Boston, and Dolphin, of which only the last is finished; there are authorized four more...

PARIS, Feb. 3.-The periodical effervescence concerning the sale of the crown diamonds has again bubbled up. To make the republic doubly strong it seems positively necessary in the eyes of the present French rulers to obliterate these glittering traces of past grandeur.

Notwithstanding the authority given to Assistant Commissioner Plerson, that official has not yet begun the issue of the daily rate sheet prorating the cuts between Chicago and Council Bluffs, and from Missouri River points westward.

Members of the McGloin and "Red" McKenna gangs, of the Ninth, Sixteenth, and Twentieth Wards, planned during New Year's week, 1884, to rob the grocery store of Frederick Thom Suhn, at No. 427 West Seventeenth-street.
ALBANY, Feb. 26.--Senator Fagan, of Queens County, launched further inquires to-day in relation to the New-York Dock Department. He said he had no idea of calling for any investigation.

Charles L. Webster Co., the publishers of Gen. Grant's book, sent Mrs. Grant a check yesterday for $200,000 as her proportion of the proceeds so far derived from the sale of the General's book.

The annual dinner of the St. David's Benevolent Society of New-York and Brooklyn will take place at the Westminster Hotel tomorrow evening.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27.--In a little back room on the top floor of the house at No. 117 Whalley-avenue lies a man who for five days has been writhing and moaning on his rough bed, enduring agonies which physicians have tried in vain to alleviate.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 27.--The jury in the Derringer-Coxe land case, who were out all night, came into court this morning with a verdict for the defendants. Clarence Derringer, attorney for the plaintiff, addressed the court, ...

Though Florence is not a town well suited for those who visit Italy in search of health, at least during the late and early months of the year, it is far from being an unpleasant Winter resort for strangers who have a less melancholy reason for traveling.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 27.--The Court of Appeals calendar for Monday has been changed, and will be as follows: Nos. 524, 523, 528, 435, 496, 555, 556, 558.

Gamma Chapter, Phi Beta Kappa, of the College of the City of New-York, held a special convocation last evening at Clark's Restaurant, in West Twenty-third-street. An address was delivered by Everett P. Wheeler on "The American City."

CHESTER, Penn., Feb. 27.--A span of horses attached to a cab ran away this afternoon, and James Dougherty, the driver, was thrown against a telegraph pole, striking it with his head and receiving injuries which resulted in his death shortly afterward.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 27.--This city, which asserts that it is going to be the largest in the State in a very few years, has enough of a worry on hand to keep all the rest of Connecticut in hot water.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 27.--A compilation of the assessments and collections of State taxes for the years 1884 and 1885 is officially promulgated this morning.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 27.--The debt question is giving the Democrats in Virginia no end of trouble. The decision of the United States Supreme Court declaring in effect that the coupons must be received for all taxes, in accordance with the contract under which they were issued, places the State in a most unenviable position.

COHOES, N.Y., Feb. 27.--The manufacturers of Cohoes have agreed that on and after Monday wages in the various departments of their mills will be restored to the scale paid before the reduction made Jan. 1, 1885.

The past week has partaken of a holiday nature, due to the fact that it started off with the birthday of the immortal George. To the few society people who remained in town the day was only a second Sunday, but to the many who were able to join the fifty or more parties which went to the country it was a merry one indeed.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 27.--Mr. Searls, of Thompson, a leading Republican member of the Legislature, is now investigating, as an official committee of one, the cause of the delay in public printing. The Legislature has been delayed a week or more by the failure to receive bills that should have been printed a number of days ago.

In the Superior Court yesterday the jury in the suit of John F. Preston against Wamsley Nedwell for a five-hundred-dollar fee as an attorney, brought in a verdict for 1 cent.

In a very pleasant editorial notice of the newly formed Whittier Club of this city, the Boston Traveller says its object "is to study his works," and questions whether there is anything to study in Whittier's poems.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 27.--A dastardly outrage was perpetrated by a mob of armed and masked men at Gullett's Station, in Gullett's cotton gin factory, a mile south of Amita City, La., on Friday night.

The Sub-Executive Committee of the Irish Parliamentary Fund association met yesterday afternoon at No. 20 Nassau-street and made arrangements for temporarily suspending the work of the association after the meeting tomorrow night at the Hoffman House.

Apropos of the recent riots at the West End and the consequent threatened prosecutions it may be interesting to recall the fact that the famous Earl of Surrey was once accused before the Privy Council of rioting in London streets and breaking windows with a crossbow.

LONDON, Feb. 27.--Mr. Gladstone is full of serene confidence. He said to a friends of mine two days ago that never before had he started on a Ministerial voyage with such bright prospects of a successful issue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.--Mrs. James Brown Potter and her play have been the chief topics of the week, and Washington has not in all ways indorsed the verdict of New-York. The fair amateur has been the first real social sensation of the Winter, and has been given an amount of attention and discussion quite unprecedented in the line of visiting New-Yorkers.

BROWNWOOD, Texas, Feb. 27.--Three masked men entered Cameron Co.'s office last night, made the clerks hold up their hands, and then secured $1,500. As they departed they were fired upon by one of the clerks, and one of the robbers was killed. He proved to be a painter, who was well known about town.
The long-talked-of tug-of-war between teams representing the Seventh and Thirteenth Regiments occurs at the armory of the Twentysecond Regiment, in East Fourteenth-street, on Saturday night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 27.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 25 cents, and telegraphic 30 cents.

The Trinidad left St. Lucia for Barbadoes at 4 o'clock in the afternoon of Thursday, Oct. 8, and we were to be off Barbadoes at daylight next morning. This most important of all the Caribbee Islands lies far to the eastward of all the others.

The testimony in the Sartorius case was brought to an end yesterday by the calling of Mr. Sartorius in rebuttal of his wife's evidence. He denied that she ever complained to him of being cold for want of underclothing.
"Say, boss," said a colored lad who accorted a TIMES reporter on Park-row a few nights ago, "Is this ring good?"
Joachim Spiro, a peddler, of No. 47 Sheriff-street, yesterday had Wolf Koch and Josiah Silverstein, of No. 80 Chrystie-street, arrested and arraigned in Essex Market Police Court.

The March meeting of the New-York Horticultural society will be held at Nilsson Hall, in East Fifteenth-street, on Tuesday. An exhibition of plants and cut flowers will be one of the features of the meeting, and liberal premiums will be awarded to exhibitors.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 27.--Yesterday, at the National Yards, a large handler of stock said; "This dressed beef matter has a peculiar interest to St. Louis. You see, the St. Louis institution has not been taken into the Chicago combination, and is antagonistic to the Armour-SwiftHammond combination.

Many of the Harpswell fishermen have been engaged of late in picking up wreckage from the lost steamer Cambridge. Several barrels and casks of gin, whisky, a.e, beer, , have been found. One barrel marked kerosene oil, when opened, was found to be filled with whisky.

Mary Jane Cleveland, a school teacher at the Lake and Watts Orphan Home, thinks the name Mary Jane too common. She petitioned Chief-Justice Larremore, of the Court of Common Pleas, to change it. The suave and accommodating Justice granted her request, and Miss Cleveland is now Mary Grover.

Two Sisters of the Order of Bon Secours arrived in this country some four years ago to establish a branch of their praiseworthy order, so well known in many of the European cities. The Sisters at present occupy the house No. 152 East Sixty-sixth-street.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 27.--Gilmore's Band, with Levy, the cornetist, concluded a week's musical festival at the Empire Rink in this city to-day. The attendance averaged 4,000 persons a day.

It was stated last night that Slosson had challenged both Vignaux and Schaefer to play a match game of billiards, 14-inch balkline, for $500 a side. Inquiry showed that the statement was probably correct.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 27.--Floyd Ganung and Charles Thomas were to-day charged by the Coroner with murdering Mrs. Thomas, an alleged wife of Thomas, making the tenth murder in Toledo within a year. Mrs. Thomas was found dying from the effects of a dose of corrosive sublimate last Tuesday morning. Ganung was a guard at Sing Sing Penitentiary in 1884-5, and later lived in Garrison's, N.Y., and Fishkill.

After the two weeks' excitement over the coal stocks the market flattened out. The trading during the past week has dwindled away daily, and yesterday sunk down to about 200,000 shares only. The number of stocks dealt in has been confined to half a dozon, or about that, and the commission houses are lamenting again the absence of business.

MORRISBURG, Ontario, Feb. 27.--The body of Jacob Henophy was found frozen stiff on the public highway eight-miles from here to day. Marks oa his body and the condition of his clothing-indicate foul play. An inquest will be held.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.--The silver advocates had it all their own way, as far as talk went, in the session of the House, in Committee of the Whole, to-day.

Chief-Justice Larremore, of the Court of Common Pleas, has appointed Charles T. Madison committee for the person and estate of David H. Goodrich, adjudged to be a lunatic, and also directing that, $1,800 a year be paid from his income for his support and that of his family.

Fiske, William George Merrill, H.G. Marquand, George Gordon King, LeRoy King, and Mrs. Sarah A. Kendall, of New-York, have been in town during the week.

AUBURN, N.Y., Feb. 27.--The deficiency at Auburn Prison for February is $8,850.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 27.--The funeral of the late Harrison Phoebus took place, from the Centenary Episcopal Church at Fortress Monroe this afternoon, and was attended by prominent people from all parts of the country.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 27.--News of a frightful affair in Washington County, Ga., reached this city yesterday. Sam Manning went to Peter Taylor's house to resent a remark made by the latter. A fight ensured, and Taylor rising from the floor reached for a scythe and plunged it into Manning's left temple. He died Thursday.

To-night the Titans meet at the Hotel Brunswick to greet the awakening of Mother Earth from her Winter nap. Wearing the violet, the sacred flower of the order, the "Sons of Earth" sing the praises of Mater Terra in songs of their own making.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 4.--Patrolman Donnegan, of the Grand-Street Precinct squad, had a pitched battle with a mad dog this afternoon. DELAWARE BREAKWATER, Del., March 4. --The schooner Bertha Deane, from Baltimore for New-York, arrived here at noon. BUFFALO, March 5.--The test gas well at the village of Gardenvill, six miles east of Buffalo, was torpedoed to-day with most satisfactory results.

Last night's performance of "Die Walkure" was the final evening representation of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House. The theatre was crowded in every part and everybody remained until the final scene, although the curtain did not fall until within a few minutes of 12 o'clock.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 5.--Judge Locke will return from Tampa on Monday, when an effort will probably be made by the naval authorities to bring the case of the City of Mexico and the filibustere before the court. The case against the latter may possibly be settled, but the vessel cannot be libeled until District Attorney Bethel is commissioned.

The suit of Louie Estelle Truman for an absolute divorce from George T. Truman, the gambler, who several months ago stabbed Larry O'Brien and was shot by him in return, was tried before Referee Samuel S. Thomas yesterday.

The public rehearsal prefacing the fifth concert given this season by the Symphony Society of New-York occurred yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The greatest art sale ever held in this country, that of the paintings belonging to the collection of the late Mrs. Mary J. Morgan, was concluded at Chickering Hall last evening. The third lot of the 80 paintings sold for $487,925, or $70,550 in excess of the sum received for the 160 paintings sold on Wednesday and Thursday evenings.

CHICAGO, March 5.--Mr. George B. Reeves, Traffic Manager of the Grand Trunk lines west of Detroit, was in the city to-day, and talked freely about the position of his road in relation to the fight between the live stock and dressed beef shippers.

The trial of James T. Holland, of Abilene, Texas, for the killing of Thomas Davis, of this city, on Aug. 31, 1885, ended last evening in a verdict of not guilty, to agree upon which the jury required only a quarter of an hour. The prisoner was in court bright and early, as usual. He had been freshly shaved, and had on a new collar.

WESTERLY, R.I., March 5.--Edgar C. Barber, aged 18 years, was caught on a shaft at C.B. Cottrell Sons' printing press works yesterday and whirled around with frightful velocity. The raps of his feet upon the ceiling alarmed the workmen overhead. He was terribly bruised, and death resulted in a few hours.
WINNIPEG, March 5.--Poundmaker and 11 other braves were liberated from the penitentiary at Stony Mountain yesterday. They will go west to their homes in charge of the Rev. Father Lacombe.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 5.--John Barrington, an aged patient in the insane department of the Allegheny City Home, jumped head first from a third-story window this morning and was killed instantly.

CHICAGO, March 5.--Scientific and relents boycotting has enabled Cigarmakers' Union No. 14, of this city, to bring I. Goldsmith Brothers, proprietors of the Chicago Cable Cigar Factory, at State and Lake streets, to terms, the firm having capitulated yesterday.
BUFFALO, March 5.--The new Seventyfourth Regiment Armory, the second in size in the State and fourth in the United States, was dedicated to-night with appropriate exercises.

PARIS, March 5.--Peronnier, the soldier who by firing his revolver in the Chamber of Deputies forced the State to take notice of him and his grievance, has already had an imitator.

The drivers and conductors on every line of street railway in this city obeyed the orders of the Executive Board of the Empire Protective Association yesterday and refused to go to work. For ten hours not a street car appeared, and public travel was confined to the elevated railways and to the cabs and hacks.
Excise cases have accumulated so rapidly in the Court of General Sessions of late that the Judges have decided to use stringent measuses to keep the dockets clear.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 5.--News received from the plantation of the Hon. R.S. McWhorter gives the particulars of the murder of Jim Waller by Berry Adams.
LONDON, March 5.--In the Mincing-lane markets sugar is steady; refined is rather dearer. Coffee sells readily at full to firmer prices. Tea is quiet. Rice is inacttve. Saltpetre is steady.

SEALE, Ala., March 5.--When the jailer entered the building this morning to feed the prisoners he was set upon by them, horribly maltreated, and then 10 prisoners escaped, among them three murderers. The escape was planned by Davis, the murderer of Reaves, who was recaptured and is now in irons. Four of the escaped men have been recaptured.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 5.--The situation at Nanticoke is becoming critical. Last week the officers of the Susquehanna Coal Company resolved to abandon the work of rescue and to leave forever entombed the 26 men and boys who met their death at No. 1 slope on Dec. 18 last.

WASHINGTON, March 5.--The House Committee on Naval Affairs has completed its report to accompany the bill providing for an increase of the naval establishment. It points out that the greographical situation of the United States and the relations this country bears to the other great nations are peculiar.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5.--Charles C. Marple, a florist, living in Gloucester, N.J., and doing business at No. 524 Market-street, Camden, shot his daughter this morning, mistaking her for a burglar. The wound is very serious, Miss Mary Marple, the victim, is pretty and intelligent girl, 20 years old. She assisted her father in his business and was noted for her taste in the arrangement of floral decorations.

DANVILLE, Va., March 5.--Some time ago J.C. Wilson was lynched in Patrick County for stealing a mule. At the last term of the Patrick court the Grand Jury found a bill of indictment against all parties concerned for murder. This is the first time within recollection that a lynching party has been formally presented by a Grand Jury for murder.

GALVESTON, Texas, March 5.--The steamer Alamo, from New-York, which arrived here to-day, beat the best previous record by 2 hours and 45 minutes. CHICAGO, March 5.--The committee in charge of the Jones-Small revival meetings explain to-day that, in deciding to have the afternoon and evening meetings next week conducted by Mr. Jones, they had no intention of casting a slight on Small.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 5.--J. Shepard Smith, uncle of Mrs. Theodore P. Rich, who was murdered by her husband at St. Paul last Saturday, arrived here with her body this afternoon, and left with it for Cobleskill at 5 P.M.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 5.--The Republican State Executive Committee held a protracted session to-day, adjourning at a late hour to-night. The committee decided to call two State Conventions. The first will be on May 9, to nominate candidates for the Supreme Court, and the second on Aug. 19 to nominate a candidate for Governor.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., March 5.--The schooner Charles S. Tappan arrived from George's Banks this morning with her flag at half mast for the loss of Thomas Johnson, one of the crew, who was swept overboard and drowned in Friday's gale. Johnson was a Swede, age 50 years. He leaves a widow and six children.
LONDON, March 5.--The steamship Paranagua, (Ger.,) Capt. Behrmann, from New-York Feb. 17 for Hamburg, passed Dover to-day.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 5.--Alexander Mitchell committed suicide last night by taking laudanum. He had become despondent over his failure to secure steady work. He leaves a widow and family.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 5.--Bishop Beckwith to-day ratified the finding of the ecclesiastical court which found the Rev. J.G. Armstrong guilty of drunkenness and visiting houses of ill-repute. The sentence of ten years, inflicted by the court, was reduced to five. St. Phillip's Vestry, of which Armstrong is Rector, is in secret session to-night and is loud in its denunciations of Beckwith's harsh action. Public sentiment is entirely with Armstrong.

C.P. Huntington's "Sunset Route," from New-York to San Francisco, made another cut in freight rates yesterday, bringing down the tariff from $1 to 75 cents for 100 pounds from this city to San Francisco.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 5.--Early this morning burglars attempted to force an entrance into the house of Charles Nichols, about two miles below Newtown.

TOCCOA, Ga., March 5.--Startling developments are promised in the Mauldin murder case. Aleck Mauldin, a youth of 12, went out hunting with Fred Freeman, the 14-year-old son of exSenator Freeman, and next day the decapitated body of Mauldin was found near an abandoned house frequented by negro gamblers.

UNIONTOWN, Penn., March 5.--The Grand Jury to-day ignored the bills against the striking cokers who were in jail charged with causing a riot and burning property at Broadford belonging to Frick Co. The prosecutor, B.F. May, who represents Frick Co., was sentenced to pay the costs.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 5.--The Payne investigating committee resumed business this morning. Ex-Senator Ramey, in his testimony to-day, unqualifiedly denied that he offered any member a bribe to support Mr. Payne.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 5.--The Rev. Henry L. Jones, Pastor of St. Stephen's Church, this city, has declined the call from St. Ann's Church, Brooklyn, at a salary of $8,000 a year. Mr. Jones's friends here are very jubilant in consequence.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 5.--The German steamer Weser, from Bremen, which arrived today, brought Capt. Reynolds and 21 men, composing the crew of the whaling schooner Aurora, of New-Bedford. They were picked up at sea on the 3d inst. in latitude 38 42' and longitude 70 52' west. Capt. Reynolds states that on the 3d inst., in a northwest gale, a plank was started on the bottom of the Aurora and she filled in three hours.

In one particular the history of strikes repeats itself with almost unfailing regularity. Whenever the strike is extensive, involving a large number of men, there is apt to be lawless and violent action of some sort, either in the attempt to prevent new men from taking the strikers' places or in direct attacks upon the property of the employer.

WASHINGTON, March 6, 1886. The Secretary of State and the Danish Min ister have signed an agreement between the United States and Denmark for the mutual exemption from readmeasurement of vessels of the respective countries.

BOSTON, Mass., March 6.--The first Winter meeting of the Harvard Athletic Association took place this afternoon in the Hemenway Gymnasium, Cambridge. No ladies were present, as the greater part of the time was devoted to wrestling and sparring. The number of students and graduates present, however, was very large, and the gymnasium was completely filled.

BALTIMORE, March 6.--The proposition of ex-Gov. Bowie, President of the City Passenger Railway, yesterday, 16 hours a day for $2.50 per diem, with two days a week off, has been rejected by the drivers and conductors.

NEWBURG, N.Y., March 6.--The Court of Appeals has decided the appeal from the order of the General Term which affirmed the order of Justice Brown fixing the fees of Horace Russell and Theodore Houston in the West Shore Railroad foreclosure case at $40,000 each.

MYSTIC, Conn., March 6.--Stephen H. Wheeler, aged 74 years, President of the Mystic National Bank, died yesterday while seated in a chair.

PORTLAND, Oregon, March 6.--Another Chinese outrage is reported near Port Townsend, Washington Territory. Two men attacked an inoffensive Chinaman, and, after beating his head against the rocks and fearfully maltreating him, tore his cue out by the roots and left him for dead. DUBUQUE, Iowa, March 6.--The first part of this week a family of seven persons in Guttenberg, north of this city, were taken suddenly ill, and from the symptoms the doctors suspected the cases to be trichiniasis. A small quantity of the sausage used by the family was sent to this city yesterday for microscopic examination, and upon being examined was found to be alive with parasites.
LANCASTER, Penn., March 6.--Joseph Herzog, the discovery of whose forgeries created a sensation in this city about a year ago, was brought up for sentence to-day.

The representation of Goldmark's "Queen of Sheba" given at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon brought the brilliant and prosperous season at the up-town temple of song to a successful termination.

KINGSTON, Texas, March 6.--At about noon yesterday W.B. Howard, editor of the Hunt County Chronicle, shot City Marshal A.R. Russell. Howard fired both barrels of a shot gun, and stray shots struck a spectator named Overholt and a boy named Kirkpatrick.

The coffin manufacturing firm of Morris Clark, of Newark, N.J., has been boycotted by the Furnituremakers's Union on account of the refusal of the firm to advance wages to compensate for a cut-down made some time ago. The firm states that the result of the boycott will be that no more coffins will be sold in Newark by the Coffinmakers' Association.

BALTIMORE, March 6.--While engaged in shooting rats in the cellar of a bakery in the western section of the city to-night Charles Reith shot and killed William Geblein. Both were boys and the shooting was purely accidental.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 7.--The following particulars of the disaster to the schooner New-England, of Gloucester, have been received: While lying to on Brown's Bank during the gale she was hove down, had her deck swept of everything, and in righting carried away the mainmast and sprung the foremast. She lost all sails except her jib. She was towed into Shelburne by another Gloucester schooner. No lives were lost.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., March 7.--Capt. Reynolds and four others of the whaling schooner Aurora, of Edgartown, abandoned on the 3d lust, who were carried into Baltimore by the German steamer Weser, arrived home to-day. The Captain says that they must have frozen that night if they had not fallen in with the steamer. They were frostbitten when rescued.

The Rev. C.D W. Bridgman completed the eighth year of his pastorate over the Madison Avenue Baptist Church yesterday. During that time the church has been built up from a small membership through his efforts.

The theatre, as usual, was crowded with the elite of the city. Notwithstanding the great success of this opera, Col. McCaull is compelled to withdraw it in three weeks, owing to contracts previously entered into.

CLARKESVILLE, Ga., March 8.--Robert H. Morris has been found guilty of the murder of Jasper Henderson and was to-day sentenced by Judge Brown to be hanged on the 16th of April.
POTTSVILLE, Penn., March 8.--About a year ago Stuart Wassen was found dead on the dirt bank at Silver Creek Colliery, and a Coroner's jury decided that death was caused by intoxication and exposure.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 8.--Mrs. Julia Evelina Smith Parker, wife of Amos A. Parker, died here on last night, at the age of 93 years and 9 months. Mrs. Parker was one of the famous Smith sisters of Glastonbury, who, as woman suffragists, refused to pay taxes without representation, and their Alderney cows were levied upon by the Tax Collector and sold under the hammer. The other sisters died some years ago.

ERIE, Penn., March 8.--The silver challenge cup offered by the Erie Ice Boat Club was sailed for to-day over a 21-mile course on Presque Isle Bay. A dozen craft carrying from 50 to 100 yards of canvas contested. The cup was won by the Esquimaux, owned by C.W. Prescott, a merchant.

The suit of Camilla Barnett for a limited divorce from Joseph Barnett was begun yesterday in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn. The plaintiff lived with the defendant's mother in 1881 when Joseph asked her to be his wife.

Big-headed Robert Sewell, bald-headed Everett P. Wheeler, and shaggy-headed Lawson N. Fuller were on hand in the Mayor's office yesterday to argue in behalf of the New-York Cable Railroad syndicate. Some of the lawyers and property owners opposed to the scheme were also present. Ferdinand Seeger spoke, as he claimed, in behalf of the Anti-Monopoly League, which was opposed to the cable scheme.

TROY, N.Y., March 9.--Last week an arrangement was made between the Troy and Lansingburg Street Railroad and its employes, by the terms of which the hours of labor were made 12 per day and the wages $2.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 9.--On Nov. 3, 1885, Otis D. Crocker, whose father is a wealthy property owner, was arrested at the instance of D.A. Bennett and Horace P. Hussey, upon the charge of obtaining property by false pretenses.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., March 9.--Mrs. Lloyd Sensenbach, of South Bethlehem, has died from trichiniasis after great suffering. A daughter died from the same cause three weeks ago, and another daughter is still seriously ill.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 9.--The Ministers' Association, composed of representatives of each church in the city, have passed resolutions to withdraw their patronage from all Sunday papers published in or out of the city.

WASHINGTON, March 9.--At last Mr. Edmunds has opened fire on the President in open Senate, before a great audience, and in a spirit that shows more of sensibility to the criticisms of the press than he has been accustomed to betray.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 9.--Suburban Buffalo is growing at an unprecedented rate. Over 1,000 acres of land have within a few weeks been bought by land associations and put on the market in village lots. A number of wealthy citizens yesterday paid $120,000 for a tract at East Buffalo. Villa Lawn is the name of a new suburb started this Spring north of Buffalo.
OTTAWA, March 9.--The report of the three Commissioners appointed to examine into Riel's mental condition before his execution was presented to-day.

Milk cans and horses have at least one point in common. Both will run away at times. There is a man in Jersey City who makes his living by chasing and capturing runaway milk cans, and very exciting chases he has sometimes. Every one knows or ought to know that fourfifths of the milk supply of New-York City comes to it by way of Jersey City.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., March 9.--Jacob Birty, known as " The Giant of Eastern Pennsylvania," was buried here to-day. He weighed 470 pounds, and as it was impossible to get the coffin into a hearse 12 men carried it. During the services Mrs. Kate Hodge, of Heifenstein, a relative of the deceased, wes overcome by heart disease and fell dead on the coffin.

TRENTON, N.J., March 9.--The first all night session held in many years was that of the Assembly last night. It was nearly 6:30 o'clock this morning when it adjourned, and when it did adjourn it was for the whole day. Even after their release, few of the members sought their couches.

CHICAGO, March 9.--Notwithstanding the action of the Pacific Coast Association lines, the Union Pacific made a rate yesterday of 30 cents per 100 pounds on all classes of freight to the Pacific coast. The Denver and Rio Grande also made such a rate, but withdrew it. The Union Pacific's action is announced to be on the theory that the fiercer the war the sooner the combatants will tire of the fight and seek to compromise.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 9.--The returns furnished by Milwaukee pork packers exhibit an increased number of hogs cut during the season beginning Nov. 1, 1885, and closing March 1, 1886.

The annual meeting and election of the New-York Athletic Club was held last evening and was attended by a very large number of members. There were three tickets in circulation, and there was no little electioneering of a good-humored sort. The polls were open from 8 o'clock until midnight.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 9.--A man named R.B. Barrick committed suicide in this city to-day. He was a victim of the opium habit and had been in Springfield for some months trying to break from the use of the drug. He failed in this, and being out of opium and with no money to purchase it he entered a hardware store, asked to look at some revolvers, filled one with cartridges, and blew his brains out.

MILWAUKEE, March 9.--Henry Roncke, a young farmer living near Waterford, was rescued late last night from the botton of a well, where he had been lying under a mass of stone and dirt since early Sunday morning. At that time Roncke went down the well, which is quite deep, to repair the tubing. While engaged at his work a portion of the stone curbing gave way near the top, burying the unfortunate man.

MIAMISBURG, Ohio, March 9.--William P. Howell, a rough character, came to this town yesterday, and after securing $270 on a forged check proceeded to "do" the town. The forgery was discovered, and the Town Marshal arrested Howell last night.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 9.--The sloop yacht Rival, of the New-Haven Yacht Club, has been sold to Messrs. Hope Chapman, of NewYork. She will be enrolled in the Atlantic Yacht Club, of New-York. The terms of the sale are not announced.
The New-York Steam-Heating Company, with their freshly purchased horses and carts, hauled 200 tons of coal yesterday, and the consumption amounted to 160 tons.
EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 9.--A serious railroad accident happened at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon two miles west of Oakland City, Gibson County, Ind., on the Lake Erie and St. Louis Railroad.

WORCESTER, Mass., March 9.--The tenthousand-dollar libel suit brought by the Rev. George Bremner, a Unitarian clergyman, against Judge Arthur A. Putnam, which has been on trial all the past week in the Superior Court in this city, is full of dramatic and sensational incidents. There is a Beecher-Tilton favor about it that is greatly relished by the public, and the court room has been daily crowded.

The nineteenth popular concert of the current season took place at the Academy of of Music last evening. The programme was rather less interesting than usual. Mayor Grace yesterday sent to the Board of Aldermen two messages vetoing the grants of franchises to the Madison-Avenue and Eighty-sixth-Street Railroad Company and the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company.

SOUTHINGTON, Conn., March 9.--There is a prisoner here to-night whom a good many citizens would like to see lynched. He is a negro named Henry Freeman, and about a year ago he attempted a criminal assault upon Mrs. Kirtland ...

From the final stage of the Balkan settlement Russia and France secure each a concession. France obtains an assurance that Roumelia will not impose additional duties at her frontier upon French goods that have already paid a customs tax to Turkey.

Gustav George Wolfram, a well known German business man, has been missing since Saturday morning, when he told his landlady, at No. 92 Second-avenue, that he was going to Philadelphia on business. He did not take any luggage with him, and his wife and child remained at home.
CHICAGO, March 10.--The duties on the first impor of spirits of wine from Jerusalem ever received in Chicago, direct, were paid today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 10.--The Payne investigating committee was not in session today. A number of suggestions have been offered to the committee, but no further subpoena will probably be issued after those now out have been complied with.

WHEELING, West Va., March 10.--About 3 o'clock this afternoon a personal encounter took place in the main street of Ravenswood, Jackson County, between Bird Pennybacker and a man named Coleman, which resulted in the death of the former.

ALBANY, March 10.--A certain Senator tells a good joke about a couple of the Assemblymen. He says that he was recently entertaining a member of the Assembly in his parlor, and had occasion to visit the kitchen downstairs.
Jonas Morrissey went to his home, at No. 191 King-street, Brooklyn, in an intoxicated condition last evening, and put his wife and four daughters into the street.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 10.--The Yale Faculty met this afternoon to act upon the petition of the students for a change in the chapel hour from 8:10 to 7:40 A.M.

HAVANA, March 6.--About five months ago a rumor was circulated that the person claiming to be the accredited Consul of Chill in this city was a fraud, and that the credentials which he had presented and through which he was allowed to occupy the post of Cousul were skillful counterfeits.

The trial of the civil suit of Miss Elfreda Robinson againat the Rev. Robert F. White, Pastor of the Methodist Church at Purdy's Station, was continued before Justice Dykman, at White Plains, yesterday.
The sale of Charles F. Haseltine's paintings was continued last evening at No. 290 Fifthavenue, and again drew an audience that taxed the capacity of gallery.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10.--An ordinance of City Councils, passed about two years ago, authorized the Pennsylvania and Philadelphia and Roading Railroad Companies jointly to build an extension to the river front railroad.
BOSTON, Mass., March 10.--On Feb. 25 the 68-ton schooner John Millard, left Cape Island in ballest with 19 cabin passengers for Boston, a voyage of 208 miles, which would ordinarily require 48 hours.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 10.--A special from Shoals, Martin County, gives the details of the triple lynching there a little after midnight this morning. Precisely at 11:30 o'clock a Vigilance Committee of about 100, composed of men from Martin and Orange Counties, surrounded the jail.

The late Harrison Phoebus was an epicure above everything else. The creator of a new dish was to him a greater man than he who won many battles. Among the guests at his hotel, at Old Point Comfort, a few years ago was the veteran showman, P.T. Barnum. He, too, loves the good things of this life.

RONDOUT, N.Y., March 10.--Thomas Miller lives in the quiet village of Mettacahouts, Ulster County, and his efforts in securing a bride have again demonstrated the old adage that the "course of true love never runs smoothly."

At 10:30 o'clock this morning will take place the funeral of Thomas P. Rich, the suicide, at Cobleskill. The services will be under the direction of the Odd Fellows, and the Rev. Dr. Kemperly will perform the services.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 10.--"Protection and Money" was the subject of Prof. R. E. Thompson's lecture to the Yale students in North Sheffield Hall to-night.

The Executive Committee of the Empire Protective Association began its day's work yesterday by calling at the office of Jacob Sharp's Bleecker and Twenty-third-street railroads. Arcade has a novel kind of a stock ranch and there is probably not another like it in Western New-York. Mr. Samuel Woolcott is the owner. It is no less than a place for raising and breeding skunks for their hides. At present he has a crop of 107 of the sweet-smelling animals on hand. The idea is a novel one, and will be watched with much interest by the public.

ST. LOUIS, March 10.--The officers of the Missouri Pacific Railroad asserted their authority to-day by ordering their yards cleared of all strikers and their sympathizers. In consequence of their action detectives are now on watch in the yards instead of strikers, as was the case yesterday and last night.
LONDON, March 10.--The Government has placed gunboats at the service of Mr. Tuke in his work of relieving the distress among the inhabitants of the islands along the western Irish coast.

ALBANY, March 10.--A bill to tax all the liquor saloons of the State was introduced today by Senator Vedder, Chairman of the Committee on Taxation. It stipulates that after July 1 next certain annual taxes shall be paid by proprietors of every place where liquors are sold in smaller quantities than a quart.

UTICA, N.Y., March 10.--The funeral of Mrs. Horatio Seymour took place from Trinity Church this afternoon, and was largely attended. The services, including the hymns, were the same as those recently held over the remains of Ex-Gov. Seymour. The remains were taken to Forest Hill Cemetery.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 10.--Messrs. Percy Talbert and W.H. Wilson, who went to Los Angeles, Cal., for that purpose, to-day purchased of L.J. Rose for $15,000 the noted trotting stallion Sultan, by The Moor, dam Sultana, by Delmonico. Sultan, for his age stands at the head of the list with 2:30 performers. He has a record of 2:24. He will be brought here at once.

BOSTON, March 10.--The tugboat John Markee, Capt. Nickerson, was suddenly destroyed by the bursting of her boiler when off Long Island Head to-day, and all on board were instantly killed. The wreck was complete. "It was the quickest thing I ever saw," said Capt. Dolan, of the tug Tremont, who was an eye witness.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 10.--Pneumonia has become epidemic at McKeesport. Within the last few days more than a dozen residents of the borough have fallen victims to its ravages, and physicians attribute it to natural gas.

Nothing was learned yesterday about Gustav George Wolfram, the Bowery broker and ticket went, who disappeared on Saturday. His friends now believe that he sailed for Europe on that day, under an assumed name, in a vessel bound to an English port, and that he will not be seen again in this city.

The suit of Camilla Barnett for a limited divorce from Joseph Barnett, was continued yesterday before Judge Bartlett, in Brooklyn. The plaintiff had sworn that Barnett had forged a marriage certificate.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., March 10.--John Johnson, a convict, aged 40 years, had been kept in solitary confinement at the Pittsfield Jail for shamming illness to avoid work. This noon he was making so much noise that Keeper Charles W. Fuller went to quiet him.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 10.--Miss Belle Finch, of Covert, a few miles north of here, has been an invalid for over two years, suffering from some nervous disorder. For more than 80 days past she has been in a semi-conscious state, and has taken no nourishment whatever. The case is regarded as very singular and baffles the skill of the physicians.

The silverware belonging to the estate of Mrs. Mary J. Morgan was sold yesterday afternoon at the American Art Galleries. One hundred and fifty-five lots were sold for a total of $39,502.50. Many of the articles brought small prices, the average being a trifle less than $255.

A dozen boys employed in the Newark Steel Works struck for an advance in wages yesterday morning.

Just inside the fence surrounding the establishment of Van Reiper Brothers, florists, at Lipp and Tonnelo avenues; Jersey City Heights, the almost nude body of a male infant, about a year old, was found yesterday afternoon by one of the florist's gardeners.

Diamond collar buttons and silk hats were as think as chestnuts at a burlesque show last evening in the Metropolitan Hall when the hour approached for beginning the second night's play of the big billiard match.
The exercises of the twentieth annual Commencement of the New-York College of Dentistry were held last evening in Chickering Hall.

BUFFALO, March 10.--The poisoned pumpkin pie murder trial continued at Little Valley to-day. Mrs. Wileman's defense was begun. The people make a strong circumstantial case, but do not prove the purchase or possession of arsenic by the defendant. The defense is suicide.
VICKSBURG, Miss., March 10.--About 11 o'clock last night Mr. J.F. Aden, a resident of Smith's Station, was knocked down and robbed by a negro on Levee-street, in this city.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 10.--Gen. J.A. Devereux, President of the Cleveland, Columbus. Cincinnati and Indianapolis Railroad, is very ill at his residence in Euclid-avenue. Gen. Devereux is one of the best known railroad men in the country, and was a confidential friend of W.H. Vanderbilt.
The schedule of games of the Amateur Baseball League has been arranged, and will be adopeted at a meeting of delegates next Saturday.

FREEHOLD, N.J., March 10.--The Democrats of Atlantic Township, Monmouth County, have re-elected John E. Vanderveet to the County Board of Chosen Freeholders. Mr. Vanderveet is a distiller and was recently indicted by the United States Grand Jury for the District of New-Jersey on a charge of defrauding the Government by evading the liquor tax.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10.--Austin Corbin was in the city to-day at the meeting of the Reading reorganization Trustees, which was stated by those present to have been "long and harmonious."

NEW-ORLEANS, March 10.--Some weeks ago a handsome and elegantly dressed woman appeared at the St. Charles Hotel with a maid, and registered as Mrs. Effie Hankins, of Chicago. She said she had been traveling in Florida for her health, and had dropped in on NewOrleans to see the carnival. She was well supplied with money, and said she was the wife of the biggest gambler in Chicago.

VINCENNES, Ind., March 10.--An examination of the books, concluded this forenoon, shows an approximate shortage against County Treasurer Hollinsworth of $78,278.33.

TRENTON, N.J., March 10.--In the House this morning Speaker Armstrong named Messrs. Parker, Besson, Throckmorton, Gangewer, and Hutchinson as the managers of the impeachment trial of Patrick H. Laverty, Keeper of the State prison. Mr. Besson stated that he preferred not to serve.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 10.--A fatal duel occurred at 1:30 o'clock to-day in the private office of the Clerk of the United States District Court, in the Custom House Building. M.A. Grace, a young lawyer, was prosecuting the case of a negro roustabout claiming wages from the steamboat Charles C. Carroll.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 10.--The village of Westville, a suburb of this city, has been infested by incendiaries for some weeks.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 10.--A builder of this city recently decided to move to Los Angeles, Cal. The tariff rate on a carload to Los Angeles is $360, but the agent of the Santa Fe quoted him a rate of $175.

VALPARAISO, March 10, via Galveston.-- At 1:45 o'clock this morning fire broke out in the Cafe Comercio, situated on the Calle Esmeralda, and an entire block, including the principal shops in the city was burned to the ground. The lose is estimated at $1,000,000. The property belonged to Sefiora Juana Ros de Edwards. The owner of the cafe has been arrested on suspicion of incendiarism.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 10.--About 500 depositors of the insolvent Hopkinton Savings Bank at Hope Valley met in the latter place today, and a statement of the depreciation of values, also of all resources and liabilities, was made to the depositors.

The New-York Staats-Zeitung's employes, to the number of 175, received yesterday their annual dividend of 10 per cent. on their total earnings for the year. It has been the practice of the establishment for the past six years to give this dividend to every employe, from the chief editor to the office boy, who zealously devotes his time and attention to the paper.
A bundle of letters which Lawyer George M. Curtis put into the Winans divorce suit yesterday made the millionaire defendant and witness pale and agitated.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 10.--Tramps and burglars have infested the upper part of Fairfield County for the last month and committed a number of depredations, robberies, and assaults.

No more will the City Fathers listen with emotion to him as he reads through hundreds of pages of minutes and proceedings without a stop or an inflection.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., March 10.--The strike of the bituminous coal miners in the Broad Top region, Huntingdon and Bedford Counties, has become general, and there are no indications of a cessation of the difficulties between them and the operators.

LONG BRANCH, March 10.--In June last, Thomas C. Pearce, at that time an insurance agent in Hightstown, Mercer County, went along the shore region of Monmouth and Ocean Counties placing fire insurance on many properties at very low rates.
In August, 1884, the arrival of the celebrated 457-carat-fine white diamond from South Africa and its subsequent purchase by a syndicate of London and Paris diamond merchants were announced.

WASHINGTON, March 10.--When Senator Pugh, of Alabama, rose to reply to-day to the speech of Mr. Edmunds on the Senate's right to demand papers from the President relating to the suspension of officers, he faced an audience even larger than that which greeted the Vermont Senator yesterday.

READING, Penn., March 10.--Mrs. Marcus Eck, of Forgedale, committed suicide to-day by hanging herself with a rope in the bay funnel of the barn. She had been subject to melancholy spells, and, while her husbund was attending a funeral and the servant was up stairs, she slipped out of the house to commit the dead. She was 53 years old, and was the daughter of a Mr. Stahinecker, who cut his throat several years ago.

LEWISTON, Me., March 10.--The second election for Mayor yesterday, there having been no choice on March 1, resulted in a victory for the Republican candidate, David Cowan, who received 312 majority over D.J. McGillicuddy, Democrat. The labor candidate withdrew. This is the first time the Repubblicans have carried the city for several years.

Chicken thieves have so annoyed John Kreischer a farmer, of Elmont, Long Island, of late that he and his farm hand, Conrad Gassner, have taken turns in watching the outbuildings at night from a window in the house.

The Senate Committee on Undervaluations, after a good deal of investigation in this city and in Boston, is reported to have come to the conclusion that the best remedy for the trouble in collecting the ad valorem duties is to establish a commission of expert appraisers.

NORWICH, Conn., March 10.--One thousand hands of the Baltic Cotton Mill, eight miles north of this city, quit work in a body yesterday and the big mill is idle. They had not asked for an advance in wages or that the hours of labor be shortened.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10.--The Harvard chapter of the fraternity of Phi Beta Kappa is increased annually by 25 members elected from the Senior Class, largely according to their standing during the first three years of their college course.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 10.--While working to-day for Edward McMahon, in a trench in the southern part of the town, Mortimer Salvery was caught under a caving bank. Two tons of frozen earth fell upon him and broke his bank, killing him instantly. Salvery was 30 years old and unmarried.
Prince Louis Napoleon is having a good time of it in India. On the 13th of January he went into the jungle and shot his first tiger with a well directed bullet in the throat.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 10.--In two of the largest precincts of Englewood yesterday several members of the Englewood Woman's Suffrage Association carried out their intention of going to the polls for registration, in order that they might vote on election day.
The old trouble between the city of Elizabeth and the Singer Sewing Machine Company may be renewed on Saturday next.

The Governor has given the senate no excuse for not promptly filling the offices of Quarantine Commissioners and Health Officer at this port in the character of the nominations made yesterday. All these officers have been holding over after the expiration of their terms for two years and more.
CUMBERLAND, Md., March 10.--Thirteen miners who have been working in the NewHampshire mine since the strike commenced were to-day induced to stop, thus making the suspension in this region complete.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, March 10.--Gov. Murray to-day sent to the Legislature a veto of the General Appropriation bill. DANBURY, Conn., March 11.--Peter Hall, of Brookfield, has lately been involved in a number of lawsuits, and threats have been made that he would suffer for the litigation. Yesterday Mr. Hall went out to his pasture lot and found his Jersey bull dead in the field. Suspecting foul play, he opened the animal's stomach and found that it contained a quantity of poison. The bull was valued at $750.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11.--While Frank Murgatroyd was in bed early this morning he was seized with a violent spell of sneezing. The family was aroused, and everything was done for the man's relief that could be thought of. The sneezing was kept up with unabated vigor, however, and before medical aid could reach him Murgatroyd was a corpse. It is supposed that he ruptured a blood vessel.

ST. LOUIS, March 11.--The Planter and Stockman, of this city, publishes a very full report of the condition of the wheat crop in the entire Winter wheat belt, the information being derived from a large number of reliable correspondents.
EASTON, Penn., March 11.--Twenty-four more Lafayette College students were suspended from recitation this afternoon, but will be permitted to remain at college. They were among the Salford hazers.

The strike of the steam fitters and tin and iron workers on the building of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank on Chambersstreet because of the employment of "scab" carpenters has left that structure in a deserted condition.
The Boston Athenaeum will hereafter open its library on Sunday afternoon for readers, but not for issuing books.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 11.--Bernard Schade, formerly of St. Paul, who died in the County Hospital of apopley two weeks ago, was a probable bigamist. Schade arrived in Milwaukee Feb. 27, and was struck down with apoplexy the next day.

WASHINGTON, March 11.--The President returned to the Senate to-day the bill to quiet title of settlers on the Des Moines River lands in Iowa, with a message informing the Senate that he declines to approve the bill and giving his reasons therefor.
The trial of the suit of Miss Elfreda Robinson against the Rev. Robert F. White, of Purdy's Station, for $10,000 damages for assault, was concluded yesterday.

NYACK, March 11.--A flutter has been caused in society circles here by a revelation of the fact that a suit for breach of promise has been brought against Commodore William Voorhis, of this place, in the Supreme Court of New-York.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 11.--A special dispatch received from Falls Village says that the Hon. William H. Barnum is not seriously ill, though he is temporarily confined to the house. It is expected that he will be out in a few days.
LEBANON, Penn., March 11.--Over 100 inmates of the Lebanon County Almshouse after partaking of a hearty meal yesterday at the institution were seized with terrific pains in the stomach.
VICKSBURG, Miss., March 11.--The small sternwheel steamer Ike Bonham exploded her boiler to-day at noon about six miles below the city in midstream on her way to Davis Bend.

AKRON, Ohio, March 12.--John Wilson carelessly threw a handful of powder into a stove in a grocery store yesterday, the ignition of which caused a large quantity of the combustible to explode, shattering the building and frightfully burning Wilson and three others. They will all probably die.

The town of Montezuma, in this State, beats Cortland all hollow in the line of split tickets. At the recent town meeting held there 302 votes were polled, 7 of which were straight Republican and 29 straight Democratic.

FOXBOROUGH, Me., March 12.--The skeleton of a woman as yet unidentified, with a bullethole through the head, was found by a hunter yesterday, under a pile of brush, near Archer's Pond, in Wrentham. Two lockets containing pictures were found near by.

LONDON, March 12.--In the Mincing-lane markets sugar is quiet; beet is easier; refined is firmer; stoved is unimproved; cane is unaltered. Ceylon coffee sold at 1s. to 1 florin advance; East Indian is but little changed.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 12.--The Typographical Union struck on the Constitution four years ago, and the office has since been a nonunion office. Six months ago the union demanded that the Constitution should reacknowledge the union rate, discharge its employes, and employ none but union printers. These demands were refused, and a boycott was ordered.

AUGUSTA, Me., March 12.--The total cut of ice in the Kennebec River this Winter is estimated at about 500,000 tons, a shortage of about 400,000 tons as compared with last Winter. There are 150,000 tons of old ice on hand.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 12.--Fifteen delegates from Brown, Harvard, Dartmouth, Amherst, Princeton, and Yale Colleges attended the Intercollegiate Baseball Association meeting this morning. Chambers, of Yale. The applications of Williams College and the University of Pennsylvania for admission were rejected.

For a time the principal streets were practically in the hands of a violent and furious mob, which as its members increased got entirely beyond the control of the police. It was at one time thought necessary to call out the militia to put down the mob.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 12.--The steam yacht Atalanta, with Mr. Jay Gould and party on board, sailed at 5:30 o'clock this morning for Fernandina.

LONDON, March 12.--The House of Commons to-night adopted a motion that, pending the passage of new rules of procedure, no member would be allowed to give oral notice of questions except by the special permission of the Speaker of the House.

VALENCIA, March 12.--Mme. Patti, who appeared here this evening in "Traviata," was loudly hissed owing to hitches in the first-duet. She at once left the theatre and returned to her hotel escorted by police.

LYNCHBURG, Va., March 12.--A strange disease has broken out among the horses in Campbell County, in this State. Over 75 fine animals have died within the last few weeks. The disease is called brain fever or jaundice.

BUENOS AYRES, March 12.--The Catalinas Custom House, with all its contents, has been destroyed by fire. The loss is $5,000,000.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 12.--H.E. Potter, who as station agent or the Consolidated Road at Windsor embezzled about $2,500 last year, and disappeared, was captured at his parents' residence in Enfield yesterday. He waived an examination, and was held in $3,000 bail.

The funeral of George G. Small, a well known contributor to a certain class of light literature under the nom de plume of "Bricktop," occurred yesterday at the Hotel Hungaria. Services were conducted by the Rev. Thomas H. Sill, of St. Chrysostom's Church.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 12.--The Utah Legislature yesterday passed resolutions severely criticising Gov. Murray's action in vetoing the General Apropriation bill and making a savage attack upon his motives.

CHIPPEWA, Ontario, March 12.--An unknown man committed suicide at Niagara Falls this forenoon by deliberately jumping into the river from a small platform at the north end of Cedar Island and boldly swimming right over the cataract. One of the trains was backing and the other going forward.

COHASSET, Mass., March 13.--George Crocker, aged 55 years, a fish dealer, was found dead in his chamber this morning, having hanged himself to a bedpost with two handkerchiefs knotted together. CHAMBERSBURG, Penn., March 14.--Joseph McCall, aged about 35 years, of Philadelphia, met with a horrible death here last night. He had just been released from jail, and, becoming intoxicated, went to a lime kiln and laid down to sleep. He was overcome by the gas, and the fire, breaking through the crust of the kiln, burned his body terribly.

LONDON, March 15.--Mr. Gladstone authorizes the statement that he will take no notice of the various versions of his Irish plans that have recently been given to the public.
