ST. PAUL, Minn., March 16.--For some time past it has been rumored that E.H. Cowles, of the Concord Cattle Company, had sold his interests on Tongue and Powder Rivers, Montana, to his partners in the company.
A woman named Eliza Wallace was found lying on the sidewalk on Danforth-avenue, in the Greenville section of Jersey City, early yesterday morning.

Some gentlemen who were examining an unoccupied house in One Hundred and Thirty-fifth-street, near Sixth-avenue, yesterday, with a view to hiring it, found things in the utmost confusion and saw a man jump out of a window.

The Trustees of the College of the City of New-York, at their annual meeting yesterday, appointed William Stratford, A.M., M.D., Ph. D., to the chair of Professor of Natural History, Physiology, and Hygiene, made vacant by the death of the late Dr. John C. Draper.
DETROIT, Mich., March 16.--An interesting life insurance case was decided by Judge Brown, in the United States Circuit Court, today.

CHICAGO, March 16.--A Montreal special published here says that the Dominion customs authorities at Ottawa have seized 2,500 copies of Beaconsfield's "Endymion," published by Harper Brothers, of New-York, and sent into Canada for sale. It is understood that the reason for the seizure is that a Montreal firm has the copyright of the work. The books, it is stated, will be destroyed to-morrow.
The House Committee on Public Lands to-day agreed to report favorably upon the bill to repeal the pre-emption, timber culture, and desert land laws.

GENEVA, Ill., March 16.--It is learned here to-day that Harry Estee, of Aurora, brother of Cashier Estee, of the First National Bank, and son of Elder Estee, a once well known Baptist preacher in St. Charles and Aurora, now dead, is under arrest by the Pinkertons at Chicago for the murder of John H. Grant, one of our policemen, on Aug. 28 last.

CHICAGO, March 16.--The close-mouthed detectives who are trying to find out who murdered Express Messenger Nichols on the Rock Island Railroad between Joliet and Morris last Saturday morning are doing a vast amount of the portentous silence business, but there is no reason to believe that they have any tangible clues.

WASHINGTON, March 16.--The Secretary of the Treasury has received a letter from the Secretary of War in regard to the memorandum made by the Sec ond Controller in regard to the accounts of disbursing officers of the Signal Service, which letter is accompanied by reports from the Chief Signal Officer, the Quartermaster-General, and the Paymaster-General of the army.
The men recently employed by the NewYork Steam-Heating Company are finding that the company is getting the best in the fight at every point.
Two men were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday charged with carrying on a systematic course of swindling. One of the men would go from house to house selling rugs on the installment plan.

WASHINGTON, March 16.--The dispute in the Senate on the question of the respective powers of that body and the Executive concerning papers addressed to the President has already become an "old story," and to those who have followed the debate a very tiresome one.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 16.--The new lodge of the Lambda Chapter of the Delta Psi Fraternity was opened last night with appropriate ceremonies.

ERIE, Penn., March 16.--James Mahoney, the oldest inhabitant of Erie, died to-day at the age of 100. He served under Perry in his memorable fight on Lake Erie, served in the Mexican and in the civil war. He was remarkably well preserved.
TRENTON, March 16.--The one absorbing feature of the Legislature to-day was the Laverty impeachment trial. While the proceedings lasted only half an hour, the law-makers...

The second series of games in the pool contest between J.L. Malone, of Chicago, and Albert Frey, of this city, for a purse of $500, was played last evening at Maurice Daly's rooms, in Washington-street, Brooklyn.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 16.--Mayor Rhoads is lying critically ill at his house in this city from the effect of injuries received by being thrown from a carriage near Newport on the 4th inst., and his death is hourly expected.

BOSTON, Mass., March 16.--Anna A. Coolidge, the woman who was, with others, indicted in December last, after a long delay, on the charge of conspiring to kill Mary J. Mellen, wife of Adrian Mellen, of ...
A bedridden old lady who lived on the fourth floor of a tenement house at No. 41 Parkstreet was burned to death last evening.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 16.--The annual meeting of the Pittsburg, Cincinnati and St. Louis stockholders was held in this city to-day.

BOSTON, Mass., March 16.--Charles Francis Adams, Jr., President of the Union Pacific Railroad, lectured this evening before the students of Harvard College in Sever Hall, Cambridge, on "Railroad Management as a Profession for College Graduates." There is one great principle, said the lecturer, running ...

"The Jilt," a comedy in five acts, was made known at the Star Theatre last night, after having been acted in San Francisco and Boston and the towns of Australia. "The Jilt" is the work of Mr. Boucicault, and there has been a deal of cackling over it ever since it was laid--that is to say, written.

MATAMORAS, Mexico, March 16.--Military and upper circles of society in this city are in a perfect turmoil of excitement over the most sensational event that has ever been made public within its precincts.

Henry and Frederick Gifford, father and son, were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday, charged with swindling John P. Reilly, of No. 326 East Twenty-sixth-street, on Aug. 20 last. Reilly, who had just arrived from Ireland, was in Brooklyn that day with his nephew, John McGuire, and the two met young Gifford in Fultonstreet, the latter having stopped Reilly and asked for a light for his cigar.

The universal language known by the name of Volap ck--or rather the language which its inventor, Herr Schieyer, of Constance, is ambitious enough to think will become universal--is, notwithstanding its unattractive and unpolitical name, making some progress.
Abraham Lincoln has to bear the responsibility of many stories of which he never heard, much less told.

Police Captain Glenny, of the Third Precinct of Jersey City, died last night at the age of 70 years. He had a complication of diseases. He had been connected with the Police Department since 1872. Previous to that year he was connected with the police force of New-York. He was Sergeant from 1857 to 1871.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 16.--Capt. James T. Waddell, the commander of the rebel Shenandoah, died last night of congestion of the brain. He was born in North Carolina in 1824 and entered the American Navy in 1838, at the age of 14. When a midshipman he was insulted by a senior officer.
As Patrolman George Murdock, of the Fifteenth Frecinct, walked past the alleyway at No. 22 South Fifth-avenue at 3 o'clock yesterday morning his attention was attracted by the noise of a scuffle.
Olga Pfieff, the adopted daughter of Reinhardt Pfieff, of No. 207 East Twenty-firststreet, died at 2 o'clock yesterday morning from the effects of a dose of Paris green.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., March 16.--Early this morning Constable Roger S. Austin, tired and dusty after a long trip, reached this town, bringing with him as a prisoner Frank H. Morse, one of the best known young men in this neighborhood. An hour later young Morse was taken before Justice Bartholomew to answer to the charge of arson.

WASHINGTON, March 16.--It would be difficult to make most persons believe that this short, thick-set, active man, whose beard of black and gray conceals his wrinkles--if he has any--and whose head is well covered with black hair sparsely streaked with gray, who stands beside a portrait of himself that is startlingly ...

AKRON, Ohio, March 16.--A buggy containing a man and his wife, whose names are not learned, was struck near Clinton, this county, by the Cleveland, Akron and Columbus southbound express to-day. The woman's legs were broken and she was otherwise mangled. She died within half an hour. The man's legs were crushed and will have to be amputated. It is believed he will die.

The parade of the Irish societies to-day in honor of St. Patrick will be well worth seeing. The fact that the Sixty-ninth Regiment will turn out for the first time in several years on an occasion of this kind will add interest to the affair.

The wrecking crew that was sent out on Sunday night by order of General Agent Brown, of the Cunard Company, to determine the exact location of the sunken steamship Oregon, returned to this city on the steamer Rescue yesterday morning.
ZANESVILLE, Ohio, March 16.--A very singular case has occupied the attention of the court in Hocking County, this State, during the last week.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 16.--A high society event here to-night was the marriage of the Hon. Noah H. Swayne and Miss Frances Sickles, a neice of Gen. Dan Sickles, of New-York. The groom is a son of the late Justice Swayne, of the United States Supreme Court, and was a member of the last General Assembly of Ohio. The wedding was very quiet, only a few intimate friends of the couple being present.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Marsh 16.--The fourth annual bench show of the Western Pennsylvania Poultry Society opened to-day. More than 400 dogs were on exhibition and at least 1,000 people crowded the Central Rink building during the day.

I am sorry to know that for some time past the Prince of Wales, although in other respects in fine health, has been rather a martyr to dyspepsia, which threatens to assume a chronic form, and that he is reduced to an "iron ration," both as regards quantity and character.

SALEM, Mass., March 16.--Miss Kin Kats, a graduate of the Normal School of Tokio, has been chosen by the Japanese Government to receive three years' training at the Government's expense at the Salem Normal School for the purpose of taking supervisory charge of the Normal Schools of Japan. She will be the first Japanese woman to be educated at the Government's expense in America.

BOSTON, March 16.--In the New-York and New-England bond sale hearing, at the State House, to-day, Cyrus W. Field's counsel managed, toward the close, to get one of their witnesses on the stand, but the evidence they secured was trifling.
The correspondence between Gen. Lawton and Gov. McDaniel will be read with interest throughout the State.

TROY, N.Y., March 16.--An explosion occurred this morning in the upper wheel house of the Schaghticoke Powder Company, near Valley Falls. C.J. Olds, the Superintendent of the mills, and Charles Rose, an employe, were found in an injured condition.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., March 16.--The testimony in the Graham wife murder trial yesterday developed nothing new save that Mrs. Graham, according to the surgeon, was undoubtedly killed by a gunshot wound.

TROY, N.Y., March 16.--Ellis Wolfson, convicted of arson, was to-day sentenced to seven years and six months' imprisonment. Wolfson has been engaged in the sale of carpets in this city for several years. A fire occurred in his store in March, 1885, which was clearly of incendiary origin. After the sentence had been passed Wolfson's father, with a loud shriek, fell to the floor unconscious.

The "boys" in the Republican County Committee and some of what Capt. "Mike" Cregan calls "the other element" last night succeeded in putting through the amendments to the constitution recommended by the Executive Committee.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 16.--A Shoals (Martin County) special to the Journal says: Much violence seems to have spread to adjoining counties. A report was current here today for the first time that a bold attempt at lynching was made on Friday night last near French Lick, Orange County. This was not generally known until to-day.
The West Shore Railroad Company is building a branch road from its station in Weehawken to Jersey City.

The Senate yesterday allowed the cable railroad people to have their own way with the bill providing for the sale of the privilege of using streets for the construction and operation of railroads. The whole purpose and object of legislation on the subject would be defeated by the ...
Fifty of the fifty-five men employed in the Preston Fertilizer Works, at Blissville, Long Island, went on strike at noon yesterday.

Robert Gair, paperware dealer at No. 163 Chambers-street, yesterday appeared in the Tombs Police Court and charged Charles J. Rose, his cashier, with having made a false entry of $3,300 in his daily balance book.

Funeral services for Dr. Austin Flint were held yesterday afternoon at Christ Church, Fifth-avenue and Thirty-fifth-street. During the early portion of the day the body lay at Dr. Flint's residence, No. 418 Fifth-avenue, where friends and relatives were given a last opportunity to view the dead physician's features, and a ...
The charter election in Tarrytown which took place yesterday was the most hotly contested that has ever occurred there.

It was whispered around confidentially yesterday morning among Wall-street speculators that the transcontinental railway war was to be settled finally before the day was over, C.P. Huntington and the other contending magnates having determined upon compromises.
The Maharajah Dhuleep Singh announces that he has definitely resolved to return to India the week after next.

RONDOUT, N.Y., March 16.--The First National Bank of Rondout owes the city about $7,000 for taxes, and the officers of the bank have begun a suit in the United States Circuit Court to restrain the collection of that amount for the current year.

The letter of congratulation and adhesion of the Archbishop and Bishops of the Province of New-York, recently addressed to the Pope upon the occasion of his encyclicals Immortale Dei and Quod Auctoritate Apositolica, has just been translated in this city.
CONCEPCION, Argentine Republic, March 16, via Galveston.--A street railway will shortly be established in this city.

DANBURY, Conn., March 16.--John Springer, a German, employed in Beckerie's hat shop in this town, was found dead in his bed this morning with three bullets in his body. By his side lay his revolver. He had been despondent for some time, and ended his troubles by shooting himself. As far as known he had no relatives in this country.
PHILADELPHIA, March 16.--The Reading Trustees to-day finally agreed upon their reconstruction plan, and by a vote of 6 to 1 E.C. Knight sent it to their counsel to be prepared for publication.
Della Watson, or "Mlle. Ceni," who is 23 Years old, and lives at No. 236 East Twentyseventh-street, and Frank Decker, a "theatrical manager," of No. 228 East Twenty-seventh-street, ...

ALBANY, March 16.--There are more railroad lobbyists, lawyers, interested stockholders, and hangers-on generally, in the corridors of the Delavan to-night than have been seen before this Winter. Charles P. Shaw, the apostle of the cable railroad system, joined the immense caravan to-night.

The following facts may be interesting and instructive to the long-suffering Londoner: Early on Friday morning there was a heavy fall of snow in Paris, which ceased about 9 A.M., leaving the streets covered to the depth of several inches all over the city.
ERIE, Penn., March 16.--The investigation of the Soldiers' Orphans' School at Mercer continues to stir up a very rank odor. The Kaltenbach children, Frank, Willie, Annie, and Carrie have testified.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 16.--Mrs. Grace Turnbull, of New-York, secured a divorce from her husband, Henry Turnbull, to-day. Mrs. Turnbull had a clear case, and it was evident from the testimony that she was justly entitled to a separation.

Mrs. Mackay, the wife of the "Silver King" of California, has rented No. 7 Buckingham-gate from Lord Sudeley for the season. This will be joyful news for the Lord Outatelbows and the Lady Nothing Nowhere class of aristocrats who sponge so assiduously upon wealthy Americans.

Brooklyn's Academy of Music was filled to its utmost capacity last evening when the Brooklyn Excise League held its third annual meeting. Every seat in the great house was occupied, and hundreds of the 3,000 present stood through the evening, listening to the addresses in favor of the strict enforcement of the ...
WINDSOR, Ontario, March 16.--Michael Reilly, a boilermaker, killed his wife here this afternoon. The couple were in the habit of getting intoxicated and quarreling.

WASHINGTON, March 16.--The announcement of the death of Mrs. George Bancroft was received with the greatest sorrow by her friends to-day. For more than two years she has been wholly confined to the house, although she was able to be taken to Newport each Summer, and to see her own intimate friends in her home.

Two Germans, Ernest Strongfeldt and Jacob Kaufman, were proceeding quietly to their homes early yesterday morning when they were set upon at First-avenue and Thirty-ninthstreet by a gang of roughs, who beat and kicked ...
WASHINGTON, March 16.--The House Post Office Committee to-day heard President Norvin Green, of the Western Union, upon the alleged monopoly of the telegraphic facilities of the Pacific railroads.

DENVER, Col., March 16.--The ColoradoUtah pool meeting adjourned yesterday to meet at the call of the Pool Commissioner Rich. Yesterday's session was devoted to discussing the freight business, arranging the new agreement ...
The British bark Monsita, Capt. Wallace, which arrived at this port yesterday from Barbadoes, had on board as passengers Capt. ...

Alderman Eugene M. Earle, who was elected last Fall against Broadway Railroad Alderman Henry L. Sayles, on pledges not to vote for railroad grants without obtaining adequate compensation for the city, yesterday sought to straighten out his curiously inconsistent record on the New-York Cable Railroad scheme. Mr. Earle, notwithstanding the plea of Alderman ...

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 16.--W.B. Galbreath Son failed to-day, the total liabilities being placed at $73,000 and nominal assets $101,000. Fifty thousand dollars are secured and the remaining assets will probably pay $10,000.

"Pepita, or the Girl with the Glass Eyes," the joint work of Messrs. Alfred Thompson and Edward Solomon, was produced at the Union-Square Theatre last evening. It is not exactly a comic opera. The division of the music into solos, duets, and concerted numbers ...
The first train that started out from Rosella over the New-Jersey Central Railroad to Newark yesterday morning carried 25 passengers and was drawn by locomotive No. 127.
The steamship Orinoco, which arrived last evening from Bermuda, brought 5 officers and 23 seamen of the steamship Darlington, of London, which was lost on the Northwest Reefs of Bermuda on Feb. 22.

The interest of the large audience which attended the twentieth Thomas concert at the Academy of Music last evening centred in the first production of a new composition by Liszt-- a "Concert Pathetique" for piano and orchestra --and the performance of Mozart's concerto in E flat for two pianos and orchestra.

WASHINGTON, March 16.--An order was issued from the War Department to-day retiring Major-Gen. Pope. It is understood that the nomination of his successor and of two Brigadier-Generals, with the consequent promotions, will be made to-morrow.
The mystery of Edward Coughlin's disappearance from his home, No. 62 Columbiastreet, Brooklyn, on Thursday last, was cleared ...
Mrs. Rosina Cooke, of Freehold, N.J., who created a sensation in Surrogate Lott's office, in Brooklyn, on Monday, by applying for $3,000 which she claimed ex-Auditor Voorhies, ...

John Higgins, Jr., a youth whose education was derived from dime novels, returned to his home in Orange Valley, N.J., from an unsuccessful Indian-killing expedition to Texas some time ago with the intention of making his father support him.

ERIE, Penn., March 16.--The Hon. Elijah Babbitt, the oldest living counselor, appeared to-day in court to prosecute a claim for personal damage for Mrs. Driscoll, a poor washerwoman, who fell on a defective sidewalk. Mr. Babbitt is 92 years old, has practiced law 62 years, and has filled every office of public trust up to the United States Senate.

Fritz Heider, for 10 years editor of the Hudson County Journal, of Hoboken, committed suicide yesterday afternoon at his home, in Bloomfield-street, by shooting himself in the head. He had been ill for some time and despondent, and had frequently threatened to kill himself.

An amicable settlement of the dispute as to pay and hours of labor on the Bleecker, Twenty-third, and Thirty-fourth street horse car lines was reached between the Empire Protective Association and Mr. Jacob Sharp in a three hours' conference yesterday. Committeemen O'Donnell, Graham, Best, Downing, and ...

Dr. Ezekial Mulford Wade, who died at his residence in the town of Watervliet, near Latham's Corners, Monday, March 1, was born Nov. 14, 1814, in Niskayuna, Schenectady County. His grandfather, Edward Wade, was a Revolutionary patriot, and took part in the battle of Bunker Hill.

LIMA, March 16, via Galveston.--The elections are going on tranquilly throughout the country except at Huacho, where a sharp struggle for the possession of the voting tables resulted in 13 persons being killed or wounded. The Chilian corvette Chacabuco has left for the north.

The House yesterday took a vote which Mr. HISCOCK proposed should be a test of the strength of the Free Coinage bill, though it was not a test, and it is difficult to see how Mr. HISCOCK could himself regard it as one from his own arguments.

Louis Kolman, a resident of the east side, got drunk on Sunday and was locked up in the prison in the Essex Market Police Court, Justice Welde expecting to let him out on Monday, as some friends had interceded for him.
The Duke of Edinburgh has put all his people on half pay during the term of his command, and the most severe economy is to be enforced in all departments of his household.
BUFFALO, N.Y., March 16.--The Standard Oil Company, that proposes to supply natural gas to this city, won its fight in the Common Council yesterday, only a few Aldermen opposing it.
BUFFALO, N.Y., March 16.--A very remarkable piece of engineering came to an end at Niagara Falls yesterday. It was the tunneling of the ice mountain at the foot of the American Falls.
HAMILTON, Ontario, March 16.--There are fresh complications in the case of Cadby, the Hudson (N.Y.) forger. Chief Stewart, of this city, telegraphed from New-Castle, New Brunswick ...

Perhaps Mr. GLADSTONE'S Cabinet was foredoomed to be split by the Irish question. But nobody could have foretold the rupture which has in fact occurred by the resignation of Mr. TREVELYAN and of Mr. CHAMBERLAIN. Mr. CHAMBERLAIN is the most advanced Radical in the Cabinet ...

Mrs. Elizabe th Weigand's suit against her husband for divorce was begun before ViceChancellor Van Fleet in Newark yesterday. Her husband is a florist living at Secaucus, and is reported to be worth over $100,000.
Harper for April shows among its illustrations a scene at table where two men are shaking hands, the hand used by the elder and more striking figure being the left instead of the right one.

The Committee of Inscriptions in Paris has been continuing its useful and interesting work. The house in the Chaussee d'Antin where Rossini lived for so many years has been distinguished with a plaque marking out the circumstances.

A dinner was given at the Union League Club last night in commemoration of the departure for the seat of war of the Twentieth Regiment of New-York Colored Volunteers, which was organized and sent to the front in 1863 by the club.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 16.--Mrs. Effie Hankins, of Chicago, who was robbed here on Mardi Gras night of about $7,000 worth of diamonds and other jewelry, succeeded in recovering all the lost diamonds to-day.
On April 1 the newspaper agency conducted for almost 40 years by S.M. Pettingill will be consolidated with that of J.H. Bates, No. 41 Park-row.

The foxhound owned by Mr. L.M. Thompson, of New-York, and lost while on the scent of a fox a few weeks ago, has been found in Yarmouth, and on Sunday last Eli Sabourin, the well known hunter and sportsman, drove 48 miles after the dog.
The Society of Arts last evening listened to an interesting paper on "The Roadways of New-Mexico" by Mr. Clarence Pullen, late Surveyor-General of that Territory.

ALBANY, March 16.--By a combination of knaves and some witless associates, a bill was passed in the Senate to-day which if it becomes a law will not only saddle the cable railroad system upon New-York, but will also rob the city of any equivalent for the 70 miles of streets which the cable people will capture.
PARIS, March 16.--There is great indignation among the people who compose the "English circles" here at the revival in the French press of wanton and scandalous attacks on the Prince of Wales.
WASHINGTON, March 16.--The proceedings in the Supreme Court of the United States were as follows:

BOSTON, Mass., March 16.--The rag importers, paper manufacturers, and others who protest against the order of the Board of Health requiring the disinfection of all foreign rags on arrival at this port, whether they have been disinfected before shipment or not, and that this be done by a certain patent process, were heard ...
The confirmation of DEMENT has disclosed to all men the inconsistency of the Senate, the hypocrisy and insincerity of certain Senators, and a new use for "Senatorial courtesy."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 16.--The broadening of the State League into an international association by the recent admission of two Canadian clubs, the Torontos and the Hamiltons, has had a beneficial effect in the way of increased interest in the game of baseball all over Central and ...
The commercial relations that have for some time existed between wholesale fish dealers of this city and Boston have lately become so strained that they are liable to be severed at any moment.

Thirty-two girls employed as weavers in the rope walk of L. Waterbury Co., on Ten Eyck-street, Williamsburg, struck yesterday against a decrease in wages and thereby threw out of employment over 300 men and women.

BALTIMORE, March 16.--Isaac Gillespie was convicted to-day, in the United States District Court, of forging papers upon which he obtained the pension of two quarters due Peter Parker, colored. He was sentenced to the penitentiary for two and a half years. Hezekiah Lee, an accomplice, is yet to be tried.

LONDON, March 16.--Despite all stories to the contrary, it is learned to-day authoritatively that both Mr. Joseph Chamberlain President of the Local Government Board, and Mr. Trevelyan, Secretary for Scotland, have placed their resignations in the hands of Mr. Gladstone.
Joe Ellingsworth, the amateur middleweight champion, has challenged Jack Dempsey for a fight with small gloves for $1,000 a side and a purse of $1,500.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 16.--As a hand car carrying Foreman Dennis Sullivan and four section hands was crossing the Air Line trestle over the Quinnipiac meadows this morning it was run into by an engine coming down from Willimantic.
The meeting of the Door, Sash, and Blind Makers' Union at No. 142 West Thirty-first-street last night was well attended.

The Harlem River Bridge Commissoners have decided upon the plan and style of bridge which, under the law of 1885, they were appointed to build across the Harlem River north of High Bridge, and have issued notice to contractors that plans and specifications will be ready for examination on Monday next.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., March 16.--A lamp exploded early this morning in the room of N. P. Butler, in the Clarendon Hotel, this village. Mr. Butler, who was an invalid, gave an alarm, but was unable to get out of the room, and was burned to death before assistance came. The pecuniary damage is slight.
A remarkable return, quoted in the Standard of Monday last, seems to supply another reason for the speedy passing of a shipping bill.

On Saturday afternoon a Witness reporter noticed two quiet-looking citizens in a sleigh on Notre Dame-street, and recognized the world-renowned oarsman Edward Hanian, of Toronto, with his friend Mr. Sam Coulson, who was a member of the Hanlan Club.
The "Gorillas" gathered at No. 98 Veseystreet last night to form a club to eclipse the successful up-town "Growlors."

ST. LOUIS, March 16.--The Knights of Labor are still firm, and the same may be said of the officers of the Southwestern system. The situation up to noon to-day was unchanged as far as actual accomplishment on either side was concerned. The company still express their determination to resume the traffic of the country ...
A thick fog rested on the Bay and rivers early yesterday morning. The ferryboats were obliged to proceed with great caution, and in many instances were considerably delayed.
On the application of Gen. George W. Wingate, as counsel for a Lexington-avenue property owner, Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday granted an injunction ...
The counsel for Ross R. Winans, in the reference suit before Referee Nash, rested his case yesterday. Henry L. Jackson, Winans's cousin, was the important witness of the day.

The movement for a Zeta Psi Club in this city was advanced last evening by a meeting at Delmonico's, at which the committee appointed to inquire into the feasibility of the project reported in its favor.

The Friendly Sons of St. Patrick had an exceedingly jolly time at Delmonico's last evening when they assembled to eat their one hundred and second anniversary dinner. SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, March 17.--Directly upon the accession of President Cleveland's Administration Gov. Murray signified, through Judge Harlan; that his resignation was at the disposal of the President whenever desired.

There is a queer sort of strike in progress at the wharves of the New-York and Cuba Steamship Line, Piers Nos.16 and 17 East River, and at the Bristol Line wharf, Pier No. 18 East River. "Scabs," or men not belonging to the Longshoremen's Unions, have been employed at these piers for some time past, and they have been paid 30 cents an hour, or 10 cents less than was paid to union men.

John V.B. Lewis, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Constitution Club, read a paper at the club's meeting last evening, prepared by Dr. Henry C. Adams, of Cornell University. Its title was, "Principles that Should Govern State Interference with Industries." Dr. Adams first referred to the evils which had grown up under the laissez faire doctrine.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., March 17.--Samuel Osborne, of Edgartown, owner of the whaling schooner Aurora, abandoned at sea on the 3d inst., only one day's sail from home, has a telegram from the Treasury Department stating that the cutter Alexander Hamilton has been ordered to search for the wreck.

An attachment was issued yesterday against the property of Goldstein Levy, cloak dealers, of No. 368 Broadway, in a suit brought against the firm by Joseph Levy, the father of Isidor D. Levy, the junior partner.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17.--The favorable prospects of the bill now on the calendar of the United States Senate granting American registers to the 10 steamships owned by the International Navigation Company, or the Red Star Line, of Belgium, plying between this port, New-York, and Antwerp, have given rise to much discussion among the ...

NEWPORT, R.I., March 17.--The Grand Jury to-day indicted Allan W. Dorsey for the murder of his father-in-law, Benjamin J. Burton. His wife and his wife's sister, Emily D. Burton, were also indicted. The full particulars of the case have already appeared in THE TIMES.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 17.--The proceedings of the Kentucky Legislature are once more being relieved of their usual monotony by a personal row, this time between the Speaker, W.T. Offutt, and E.F. Madden, correspondent of the Cincinnati Commercial Gazette. Speaker Offutt at the afternoon session of the House yesterday ordered the Doorkeeper not to allow E.F. Madden on the floor as correspondent.

PEORIA, Ill., March 17.--Harlan P. Tracy, the well known banker of Elmwood, made an assignment to-day to W.A. Clinch, W.S. Barber, and Thomas Clinch. The estimated indebtedness is $60,000, and the property assigned consists of a paper mill and real estate at Elmwood and Kansas lands, $40,000 in bills receivable, and stock in the Peoria Cattle Company, valued at $93,000.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17.--In the Central Station this afternoon Officer Wolf pushed his way through the crowd holding by the arm a little girl. She was a sweet-faced little thing, not more than 16 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17.--Vessels arriving at this port still report terrible weather at sea. Over 25 English steamers bound here from Spain with iron ore are considerably overdue, and it is thought that they must have suffered severely during the recent gales, as they are deeply laden.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 17.--William Medcalf went to the house of Miss Lydia Gafford, at Elizabethtown, Hardin County, last night, and asked her to elope with him. She refused, and, drawing a dirk, he threatened to cut her throat if she did not consent.

BALTIMORE, March 17.--The admirers of Parnell and his sympathizers in his efforts to obtain home rule for Ireland celebrated St. Patrick's Day by holding the largest and most enthusiastic meeting ever held in this city in aid of the Parliamentary fund.

Pretty Louise Balfe told a pitiful story in her dressing room at the Windsor Theatre last night. She was specially engaged for the week as leading lady to support Harry Lacy in "The Planter's Wife," under the management of McKay and Edwards. Next week she is to appear in "Dagmar," under her old manager, A. L. Erlanger, with whom her husband, George H. Leonard, had a couple of collisions last Summer.

James Clain, an embosser, who lived at No. 265 Spring-street, was arrested last night by an officer of the Eighth Precinct for intoxication. He was taken to the Prince-street police station, searched, and locked up in a cell. At 12:30 this morning he was found in his cell with his head almost severed from the trunk. He had killed himself with his razor, which had been overlooked in searching him.

The three popular artists that are now engaged for a series of entertainments on which the absurd title of "Concerts Artistiques" has been bestowed, appeared yesterday afternoon at Steinway Hall in presence of a numerous audience.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 17.--At 8 o'clock to-night Emma Norman, a young lady 21 years of age, shot and killed Henry Arnold, proprietor of a grocery store, at No. 109 Beal-street. Arnold betrayed Miss Norman about 18 months ago, and had made repeated promises to marry her.

And not the least remarkable feature of this singular affair was the fact that a detective actually discovered its existence and put an end to it.

HARTFORD, March 17.--The Finance Committee of the Legislature closed an important hearing to-day upon a resolution passed by both houses inquiring whether there was a discrepancy between the reports made by the NewYork, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company to the Board of Railroad Commissioners and to the State Controller.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 17.--The rumor is to-night that ex-Senator John D. Gordon has resigned all his railroad interests and will re-enter politics by running for Governer of Georgia. He was in private consultation with Gov. McDaniel to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 17.--Prof. R. E. Thompson, of the University of Pennsylvania finished his lecture on protection before the Yale students to-night. He had a rather small audience in North Sheffield Hall, but he seemed to put forth his best efforts in giving his answers to some general objections to the tariff.

Contrary to all tradition and time-honored precedent, the sun shone in a cloudless sky yesterday, and the Irishmen who were out celebrating in honor of St. Patrick marched through dry streets. The pleasant, Spring-like weather had very much to do with the success of yesterday's demonstration. It swelled the ranks of 49 Hibernian societies represented in the procession and filled the thoroughfares with people to look at them and cheer them on.
The friends of Treasurer Ogilby, of the broken New-Brunswick (N.J.) Dime Savings Bank, have secured practically the whole amount required to meet his deficiency.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 17.--Gen. J.H. Devereaux, President of the Cleveland, Columbus, Cincinnati and Indianapolis Railroad, died at 11:10 o'clock to-night of cancer of the stomach. Mr. Devereaux's illness had been comparatively brief.

WASHINGTON, March 17.--Senator Edmunds has more than once given evidence since the beginning of the discussion about the Senate's right to the papers in the Duskin case that he was annoyed, but his fellow-Senators have rarely seen him openly exhibit such anger as he showed late in to-day's session.

The constitution of the Republican organization of this city has been amended by the action of the present County Committee. The most important change relates to the annual enrollment. This year the enrollment is to be made on the second Friday of April, but hereafter on the second Friday of January.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 17.--Jay Gould left here to-day for Fernandina, where his yacht lies. To-morrow he will sail for Charleston, where he will remain several days, and then set sail for New-York.

The Directors of the St. Paul Railroad Company held a meeting at their Wall-street office yesterday, declared a dividend of 3 per cent. on preferred stock and 2 per cent. on the common, and made public the company's annual report.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 17.--The stockholders of the Chicago, St. Louis and Pittsburg Railroad held their annual meeting in this city today. The annual reports show the earnings during the year to have been $4,567,596, an increase of $170,755.

LONDON, March 17.--A banquet in honor of St. Patrick's Day was given at the CannonStreet Hotel this evening. There were 250 guests, including Earl Ashburnham and many Parnellite members of Parliament. Many telegrams were read expressing confidence in Mr. Parnell and the Irish Commoners.

On the 22d of December, 1884, a large bald-headed eagle was noticed at Cortlandt, a town in Westchester County. It attracted much attention, because it had about its neck a sleigh bell, the ringing of which could be distinctly heard by all who saw it.

CITY OF MEXICO, March 17, via Galveston.--United States Minister Jackson has left for home on three months' leave of absence. Consul-General Porch also is investigating a number of similar cases.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 17.--The legislative Committee on Woman Suffrage voted today 7 to 1 in favor of a bill allowing women to vote in school district meetings without any property qualification. In all respects they are put upon an equality with men regarding the suffrage in school matters. Senator Staub, of the committee, says the committee is in earnest this year, and will push the bill to its passage.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18.--A. P. Roberts Co., of the Pencoyd Iron Works, in a notice to their striking employes say that upon careful consideration they believe it impossible to bid upon work in the present unsettled condition of affairs and therefore, having no orders of any magnitude at present, they regret to anfurther notice.

It was about the middle of February, 1861, when Mr. Davis was notified of his election as Provisional President of the Confederate Congress then in session at Montgomery.

A crowd of striking longshoremen stood opposite Piers Nos. 16, 17, and 18 East River yesterday, but gave the police no trouble. The agents of the Dorset had difficulty in obtaining men to unload the vessel, and little work was done on Pier No. 18 during the day.

ERIE, Penn., March 18.--Chairman W. W. Gray, of the State Fish Commission, is placing fifty millions of the white fish hatched here in Lake Erie. The fish will be put in at different points, but it is expected that they will migrate to other lakes.

It has been decided to undertake experiments with a view to establishing telephonic communication between Vienna and Pesth. The experiments will begin next week.

EASTON, Penn., March 18.--Twenty-five of the students who were suspended for hazing Freshman Stalford were to-day permitted to participate in the annual examinations which were bugun at Lafayette College, they having been reinstated at the meeting of the Faculty on Tuesday evening. These include most of those confined to their rooms, and a few under full suspension. Nearly all the students made application to be reinstated, but several were refused.

The Board of Trustees of Mount Vernon at their meeting on Wednesday evening signed the franchise to the Mount Vernon and New-York Water Company to lay mains through the village.

Mr. J. Henry Work, the friend and side partner of William S. Warner, views the report of Referee Hamilton Cole in the Holt-Warner litigation with grave disapproval. In speaking of the matter last evening, Mr. Work said that the report was to him very humiliating.

Capt. Merritt started last evening for the scene of the Oregon wreck, having sent the steamer Rescue and a schooner there, with a wrecking crew and three divers, in the morning. It is expected that to-day the divers will try to reach the steamship.

Mr. Bronson Howard is to lecture before the members of the Harvard Dramatic Club in Sander's Theatre, at Cambridge, March 26. The author of "Young Mrs. Winthrop" and "One of Our Girls" is a Yale man.

The Young Men's Prohibition Club of Kings County gave a dinner to a large number of guests last night at the Hotel Dieter, in Brooklyn. There were about 80 altogether at the table, which was presided over by E.J. Wheeler, the President of the club.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., March 18.--The Hon. W.L. Sessions, of this district, has introduced into Congress a bill providing for the sale of the Seneca Indian Lands in the Cattaraugus Reservation, in Cattaraugus County.

Edward Welsh, James Tuomey, and Thomas Dalton, the ticket speculators who were arrested for peddling tickets in front of Harrigan's Theatre on Wednesday night, were arraigned before Justice Power, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday morning.

UTICA, N.Y., March 18.--The dry goods firm of Buckley Co., consisting of John Buckley and William E. Shirler, has assigned under liabilities estimated to exceed $100,000. The assets, consisting of stock and fixtures, are estimated at near the same figures.

Mr. John L. Wyckoff and Miss Jennie H. Spader were married yesterday at the residence of the bride's parents, at Jamaica, Long Island, by the Rev. W.H. De Hart. BUFFALO, N.Y., March 18.--The Rev. Charles W. Ward, at present Rector of St. Paul's Church in Englewood, N.J., has been called recently to take charge of Trinity Church in this city. He is to have a salary of $6,000. The church is a new one and the finest in Buffalo.

An inquiry recently ordered by the Hungarian Government has led to the discovery that most of the so-called Tokay wine exported from Kaschau and other places to Germany, France, and England is adulterated, and that most of it was never near the Hegyallja Mountains where the genuine Tokay is grown. The Hungarian Government will take energetic measures to restore the reputation of this celebrated wine.

In the course of the last three months several persons in South Hungary, especially Servians and Roumanians, have been poisoned or have poisoned themselves. The police have been making inquiries, and to-day they arrested a greengrocer, who, it appears, has been selling quantities of arsenic to women of the lower classes, and had dealt in poisons generally for a long time.

The much-talked-of peachblow vase from Mrs. Mary J. Morgan's collection has finally found a resting place in the porcelain collection of Mr. William T. Walters, of Baltimore. BALTIMORE, March 18.--A meeting of the oyster packers of this city was held to-day and an agreement reached not to pack any oysters after the 1st of April under a penalty of $1,000. The oyster season has heretofore continued until the 1st of May each year, but the oyster beds in Chesapeake Bay have been so much depleted that a fear is entertained that they may be destroyed.

OTTAWA, March 19.--The statement of the chartered banks of the Dominion for February shows their total assets to be $223,131,130, and liabilities, $141,772,523. Compared with the January statement there is an increase in their assets of $225,578, and a decrease in their liabilities of $450,183; and compared with the statement for February, 1885, an increase of $10,020,506 in their assets, and $8,940,478 in their liabilities.

TROY, N.Y., March 19.--Paddy Ryan made his first appearance on the dramatic stage here to-night. He was the hero in an Irish play called "Terry the Fox," written by a local author. During the play he appeared in a mimic ring fight. The house was crowded, and the audience laughed at Ryan's ludicrous efforts to play a leading part.

More than 100 members of the Yale College Alumni Association of this city assembled in the University Club Theatre last night, enjoyed a pleasant social reunion, and listened to an address on "The Growth and Condition of Yale," by the Rev. Dr. George P. Fisher, the theological Professor at Yale.
WASHINGTON, March 19, 1886. The President this afternoon approved the bill to increase the pensions of widows and dependent relatives of deceased soldiers and sailors.

WASHINGTON, March 19.--Major James Biddle, Sixth Cavalry, now in Washington, was to-day assigned to the command of Fort Myer, Virginia. Sergt. James Barrett, Troop B. Sergt. Joseph Collins, Troop H. Second Artillery, have been placed on the retired list.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 19.--All the members of the Connellsville Coke Producers' Association, with only one or two exceptions, have signed the pooling agreement for the ensuing year. NEW-ORLEANS, March 19.--They are having warm times in the Nineteenth Judicial District. Upon the death of Judge Goode, several months ago, Gov. McEnery appointed B.F. Winchester temporarily to fill the place and ordered an election for March 31.

BOSTON, March 19.--The police have investigated the alleged visit to McGrory's liquor saloon last Wednesday of George E. Stowers, the suspected murderer of Agnes Long, and are convinced that McGrory was imposed upon. The visitor wore no glasses, yet he reorgnized the barkeeper from across the room, while Stowers is so near-sighted that without glasses he cannot see a yard.

DANVILLE, Va., March 20.--The incorpotors of the Danville and Northwestern Railroad met here to-day and passed resolutions to meet again on April 1 for organization. This road is designed to connect with the Baltimore and Ohio at Balcony Falls, and will form part of that system.

CHICAGO, March 20.--The record of east bound freight shipments from this city for the month of March shows a steady falling off. NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 21.--Edward L. Kimberly, who visited the office of the West Haven Budget yesterday afternoon for the purpose of horsewhipping Editor Shillito, and who had a lively battle with the editor's son, was arrested to-day on a warrant charging him with assault and battery. ST. LOUIS, March 21.--The strike of the Knights of Labor against the Southwestern system, some say, is very near a settlement, while others claim that the settlement is as far off as ever. To-day Govs. Marmaduke and Martin again met the officials of the Southwestern system.

CINCINNATI, March 21.--Sol Smith Russell appeared at Havelin's Theatre-to-night, and immediately after the performance he was arrested at the instance of the Law and Order League. He gave bonds for his appearance.

UTICA, N.Y., March 21.--At Manheim, Herkimer County, yesterday, a bald eagle, measuring about 7 feet from tip to tip, tried to carry away the 8-year-old son of Joseph Davis, but was prevented by farm hands after a desperate struggle. The child is not seriously injured. The eagle succeeded in making good its escape.

TROY, N.Y., March 21.--"Sheeny Mike," alias Michael Kurtz, the king of safe blowers, arrives in this city in the custody of two officers at 3 o'clock this afternoon. He was kept in the Stanwix Hall in Albany for several hours, during which interval he held a levee, and was presented to several Albany statesmen.

VINCENNES, Ind., March 21.--Dr. S.C. Warren, a prominent homeopathic physician, was arrested here yesterday on the charge of bigamy. He came here about a year ago with a young and wealthy wife from Hastings, Neb. He married her in Syracuse, N.Y., but it seems he had been married before.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 22.--A charter was granted at the State Department to-day to the New-York, Bloomsburg and Western Railroad Company to build a new line from Mauch Chunk to New-Castle, a distance of 280 miles. The capital is $10,000,000, of which $1,400,000 has been subscribed.

MARQUETTE, Mich., March 22.--A furious snowstorm raged all over the peninsula Sunday. All the railroads are blockaded. No trains were run yesterday and few to-day. The Marquette, Houghton and Ontonagon Road has suspended all trains until to-morrow. A train left Ishpeming this afternoon for Chicago, but none is expected up.

EASTON, Penn., March 22.--Charles Barrett, aged 55, proprietor of the Kenlessville Hotel, has been suffering for some time from melancholy. This morning he took down his bird gun, and loading it with an extra charge of shot placed the muzzle against his abdomen and pushed the trigger with his toe. The charge entered his body, making a bideous wound, from which he died shortly afterward.

Henry J. Hall, the Californian who shot himself at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel recently, left a holograph will. Yesterday it was brought down to the Surrogate's office.

A convention of delegates from the Irish societies of New-Jersey convened in the Catholic Institute, Newark, yesterday afternoon. M.B. Holmes, of Jersey City, stated that the meeting had been called to arrange some plan for the more thorough organization of the Irish National League throughout the State.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 22.--A private letter received here to-day by an old army friend of Major-Gen. John H. Pope, until last week in charge of the Division of the Pacific, with headquarters in San Francisco, states that he is in very feeble health. Fears are entertained by his family that he cannot live long. Gen. Pope is a native of Louisville.

The big dining room of the Metropolitan Hotel was crowded to the doors last evening by scores upon scores of bright-looking young men from Rogers, Peet Co.'s clothing store, just across the way. The occasion was a banquet given by the firm to its friends and employes.

GALVESTON, Texas, March 22.--A sad reminiscence of the great war of the rebellion occurred here yesterday. When Galveston was being menaced by the Federal forces in 1862, Gen. Hebert, who was then in command of the Confederate forces on the island, erected several batteries along the bay and the gulf coast.

President Wilson, of the Consolidated Petroleum and Mining Exchange, is working hard to straighten out certain matters connected with the failure of Broker M.J. Waters on last Thursday. It may become a very interesting tangle before it is put aside.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 22.--Seventyfive employes of Scott's printing press works struck at noon to-day for an increase of 25 cents per day. The demand was made last week in the absence of the proprietor. On his return today he addressed the men and said that they had ...

Mr. Charles E. Loew, who it was thought was recovering from a severe attack of pneumonia, has again shown some dangerous symptoms. His physicians held a consultation last evening, and pronounced him in a very precarious condition. His brother, Controller Edward V. Loew, has been almost constantly with him since his filness.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 23.--Great excitement and disorder reigned here to-day, and the west end has been in possession of a mob which came to the assistance of the striking drivers of the Third-street car line, who went out last Saturday demanding $1.75 per day and 12 hours' work.

CORNING, N.Y., March 23.--The Methodists of Cohocton village sent word to the Genesee Conference at its late session that they wanted a certain minister sent to occupy the pulpit of their church for the ensuing three years.

Tucson, Arizona, March 23.--In answer to a telegram regarding the reported surrender of Geronimo and his hostiles, Gen. Crook replied that there was not one word of truth in the statements. He says the Apaches are camped in the vicinity of the San Bernardino ranch, and that he will leave Fort Bowie to-day to have a conference with them.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 23.--News was received in this city today that the oyster schooner Ovetta, Harvey master, had sunk in the Rappahannock River, Virginia, whither she had gope for a cargo of oysters. The Ovetta was of about 200 tons burden, and was worth $4,500. She was owned in Fair Haven, and had on board a cargo of oysters for this port.

Vice-President Henry W. Jaehne, of the Board of Aldermen, must have had horrible dreams on Monday night, if he slumbered at all, on the miserable cot in cell No. 49 in the City Prison. When the inside door of his cell was opened by a keeper he glared at the official in a way that was startling. His eyes were red and his hair and mustache were twisted out of shape.
WASHINGTON, March 23.--The report of the Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads to accompany the bill providing for the extension of the special delivery system says:

Capt. Henry P. Conner has been engaged by the Pacific Mail Steamship Company to take out the new steamer Starbuck, which sails for San Francisco, Hong-Kong, and Yokohama on April 1. Capt. Conner is an old and reliable steamship commander, well and favorably known in this city, who retired on his laurels some time ago. He has taken command of the Starbuck partly for recreation as well as to oblige the company.

The Senate Committee on Finance to-day deelded to report favorably upon the nominations of several Internal Revenue Collectors, in respect to whose predecessors Secretary Manning says no charges reflecting upon their official of moral character are pending.

MILWAUKEE, March 23.--J.B. Oliver Co., the large grain commission firm whose suspension caused such a flutter several weeks ago, created a sensation on Change to-day by circulating a petition among their creditors asking for a release from all indebtedness in consideration of the nominal sum of $1 to each creditor paid.

SAUGERTIES, N.Y., March 23.--Cheany A. Burhans, of Flatbush, this afternoon shot a hair seal in the Hudson River. It weighed 65 pounds, and measured over four feet in length. It is the first hair seal that has been shot along the Hudson River in many years.

HANOVER, N.H. March 23.--The students of Dartmouth College at a meeting last night pledged $1,800 for the support of the college baseball nine. No attempt to form a new league will be made, but games will be arranged with all the colleges and some professional clubs.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 23.--Sight drafts on New-York, 20 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents.

ST. LOUIS, March 23.--There was a clash between the Knights of Labor and the officers of the Missouri Pacific Railroad this morning when the latter attempted to move a freight train. Freight engine No. 825 backed down from the machine shops to the Seventeenthstreet yards.

CORNING, March 23.--A thunderstorm of great violence passed over the village of Wayland between 1 and 2 o'clock last Saturday morning.
Capt. Nichols, of the bark Herbert Black, which arrived yesterday from Marseilles, passed at noon last Monday a blue booby batch, a mail bag, and a large brown leather valise.

Bernard Outman, of No. 149 Mercerstreet, a bookkeeper, was charged with abduction at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23.--The city was started early this evening by reports that Secretary Manning had fallen in an apoplectic fit, had been carried home in an unconscious condition, and that a serious result might be expected of the sudden attack.

TRENTON, March 23.--The Senate Chamber was filled to Overflowing to-day when the trial of the impeachment charges against Keeper Laverty was begun. The seventh performance of the series of matinees of orchestral music given at the Brooklyn Academy of Music during the current season occurred yesterday afternoon. The programme was of more than ordinary interest, as it included three numbers that had not before been interpreted by Mr. Thomas's band.

The whereabouts of William S. Warner still remain a mystery. Mr. Hornblower, the counsel for Julien T. Davies, the Assignee of Grant Ward, having exhausted every means of discovering Warner, yesterday made a formal demand on his counsel, Alexander Green, to be informed where he is.
In a communication to Corporation Counsel Lacombe regarding the taxation of surface railroad companies Controller Loew calls attention to the diverse ways in which this is sought to be accomplished.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn,, March 23.--The New-Haven Lodge of Elks had their annual benefit to-night at Carll's Opera House, the biggest theatre in the city, and it was packed with spectators.

CHICAGO, March 23.--A party of policemen visited the little cottage in the rear of No. 231 West Twentieth-street this morning in search of Christ Komnes, the supposed shooter of Louis Friedman and Bernard Barowsky. They did not find their man, but in Komnes's bedroom they saw a trunk in a corner and pried it open.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 23.--Gen. Pope left here to-day for his temporary home in St. Louis.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah March 23.--An immense meeting was held last night in the Walker Opera House, presided over by the Salt Lake member of the Democratic National Convention, to indorse the acts of Gov. Murray during the past six years.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 23.--At 1:30 o'clock this afternoon, Theodoro N. Ely, of Altoona, Superintendent of the Motive Power Department of the Pennsylvania Railroad, was married to Miss Sue, second daughter of T.T. Weirman, Superintendent of the Pennsylvania Canal Company.

BOSTON, Mass., March 23.--In the peculiar case of Maria Taylor Norcross against Alvin C. Norcross, for alimony and allowance for counsel fees, pending her application for divorce, heard last week by Judge Oliver Holmes, Jr., of the Supreme Court, decision was rendered to-day.

Filippo Carlomagno, an Italian keeper of a lodging house at No. 31 Crosby-street, was tried before Judge Cowing, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, on a charge of killing a lodger, Giovanni Arlotti, on the night of Jan. 1.

A grand bazaar for the benefit of the hospital of the New-York Medical College and Hospital for Women, at No. 213 West Fiftyfourth-street, will be held at the University Club Theatre, beginning this afternoon and continuing through the week from 2 to 10:30 P.M. daily.
Samuel L. Clemens, of Hartford, is at the Hotel Normandie. The Rev. George C. Lorimer, of Chicago, is at the Grand Hotel.

COOPERSTOWN, Dakota, March 23.--The Bank of Cooperstown suspended to-day, owing to the recent failure of the Lenham Elevator Company. There were no very heavy depositors. The County Treasurer had $4,000 in the bank.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 23.--The speakers for the Yale Junior exhibition on April 15 were announced to-day by the Faculty.
Patrick H. Lalor, a well-to-do builder of Harlem, disappeared on Feb. 2. Mr. Lalor was about 45 years of age, and had been largely engaged in building in Harlem for about twelve years.

The first annual bench show of the NewJersey Kennel and Field Trial Club was opened yesterday in the Metropolitan Rink, Newark. Last night over 500 dogs lifted up their voices and howled, barked, yelped, or growled, just as the spirit of the visitors moved them.

CHICAGO, March 23.--As the Rock Island train pulled out from the station in this city Sunday night the conductor noticed a peculiar individual enter the smoking car. The man was James Barquit, a large-sized negro, whose pitted face, low brow, and glittering restless eyes made up a countenance of the most repulsive nature.

BOSTON, March 23.--The very interesting course of lectures on the professions which has been delivered on successive Tuesday evenings at Harvard College was brought to a close this evening by a lecture by Mr. Henry Cabot Lodge on "The Uses and Responsibilities of Leisure."
LONDON, March 23.--Mr. John Bright, the Pall Mall Gazette says, has, since his interview with Mr. Gladstone on Saturday, been more in favor of the Premier's scheme of Irish Government.

The Trunk Line Passenger Agents were in session all day yesterday engaged in the discussion of the Immigrant Clearing House, which began its operations at Castle Garden under a joint agency on Feb. 15.

BOSTON, March 23.--Steamship agents were among those testifying to-day before the city Committee on Health in support of the protest against the stringent regulations of the Health Board for the disinfection of all foreign rags entering this port.
Secretary Taylor, of the American Yacht Club, called the members together in special meeting last evening to listen to a lecture by Mr. R.J. De Cordova on "The New-York Stock Exchange."

LA CROSSE, Wis., March 23.--A street car, horse, driver, and passengers, were precipitated over the La Crosse River bridge yesterday afternoon, making a perpendicular fall of 12 feet. The horse was killed, the car crushed, and five passengers seriously injured.

When at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Aldermen Mr. Van Rensselaer presented a protest against the passage of the cable railroad resolutions over the Mayor's veto, President Nooney said that the Cantor bill having been enacted all railroad business pending before the board was wiped out.

OTTAWA, March 23.--The illness of Sir John A. Macdonald has taken a turn for the worse, and he is now suffering severely from sciatica. Dr. Howard, whose name figured frequently in the Riel debate, has come here from Montreal as consulting physician.
CHICAGO, March 23.--Opinion on the Board of Trade with regard to the exact meaning of the Supreme Court's decision in the Higgins Gilbert against McCrea cases is considerably mixed up.

TORONTO, March 23.--Judgment was given here to-day by the Master in Chambers unseating Mayor W.H. Howland, the temperance candidate, who was elected Jan. 1 by an overwhelming majority over the candidate of the liquor interests.

MADISON, Ind., March 23.--The safe in Lockard's store, at Canaan, was blown open before daylight and $10,000 in notes, $10,000 in registered Government bonds, and $120 in cash stolen. The Post Office at the same place was also robbed.

CORNING, March 23.--Owing to the small demand and unfavorable prices for apples in the New-York and Chicago wholesale markets the apple growers of Western New-York have on their hands this Spring over 60,000 barrels of choice fruit for which they do not expect to find a sale. There are 20,000 barrels stored at Lyons alone waiting for a market.
SACRAMENTO, Cal., March 23.--Gov. Stoneman appointed George Hearst United States Senator vice John F. Miller, deceased.

CHICAGO, March 23.--C.A. Burgess, the broker whose disappearance was mentioned Sunday, died at the County Hospital to-day from the effects of a dose of strychnine, supposed to have been taken with suicidal intent.
LONDON, March 24.--The steamship Hermann, (Beig.,) Capt. Meyer, from New-York March 7 for Antwerp, passed Scilly March 23.

The first shad taken in the Hudson this season was captured on Monday night by J.C. Olden, at Yonkers. It was a fine specimen of a roe shad, weighing four pounds. Fish Commissioner Eugene G. Blackford secured the fish and sent it to Mayor Grace, as it was formerly the custom to send the first shad to the Mayor.

Last evening's Popular Concert at the Academy of Music--the twenty-first of the current series--was quite as attractive as the concert given by the orchestra in Brooklyn some hours previous, for it included almost the same numbers.

Robert H. Woods, one of the Tarrytown masked burglars, was arraigned yesterday morning in the Court of Oyer and Terminer at White Plains, before Justice J.O. Dykman, on an indictment of burglary in the first degree.
PHILADELPHIA, March 23.--Official notice will be given the employes of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company on Thursday of the result of the conference held last month respecting the relief plan.

Mr. Henry Clews has written a letter to the Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange in which he presents a unique method for securing the additional room necessary for the members without moving to up-town quarters.

COLUMBUS, March 23.--The petition of bill of complaint in the suit brought by the United States Government to annul and vacate the Bell telephone patents was filed in the United States Circuit Court here to-day by District Attorney Kumler.

There were many callers yesterday at the home of Mrs. S.L.M. Barlow, on Madisonsquare, to inquire after her condition. From early in the day it was known that she was cognizant of what was going about her and recognized her family and attendants.

The meeting of the Nineteenth Century Club last night was somewhat of an anomaly. The discussions are usually arranged so as to bring together speakers of widely different views on the topic under debate, and the remarks are well seasoned with sharp but goodnatured criticism.
HEMPSTEAD, Texas, March 23.--A daring burglary was perpetrated here at an early hour this morning, the Post Office being entered and robbed of $2,800 in money and stamps.
ALBANY, March 23.--A man about 60 years old, with gray hair and whiskers, and carrying a valise, went down on a float in the basin this morning and, stooping over, began washing his hands.
Surrogate Rollins yesterday rendered a decision sustaining the will of Catherine Henrietta Marx. Miss Marx was one of the three daughters of Asher Marx, of this city.

Senators and Representatives of Mississippi: GENTLEMEN: On my return after a long absence from home I found your letter of the 27th ult. with the joint resolution of the Legislature inviting me to visit and orally or in writing address the two houses on the subject of the "establishment of a home for indigent and wounded Confederate soldiers."

BATH, Penn., March 23.--The Mace Distillery was started up here on Saturday in the presence of the Unites States Deputy Collector. This morning the boiler exploded, wrecking the building and seriously injuring a small boy. There was no safety valve on the boiler.

ATCHISON, Kan., March 23.--This has been another exciting and eventful day in the strike. At 12:45 this morning the 10 men on guard at the Missouri Pacific roundhouse were surprised by the appearance of 35 or 40 masked men.

PARIS, March 23.--One of the wolf-bitten Russians who recently camp here and were treated by M. Pasteur to prevent rabies died last night in great agony with all the symptoms of hydrophobia. M. Pasteur is not at all dismayed by the failure of his treatment in this case.

The General Surface Railroad act of 1884 provides that all companies organized under it shall, in cities of 250,000 population, pay 3 per cent, of their gross receipts for the first five years and 5 per cent. thereafter into the public Treasury as compensation for the use of the streets.

ALBANY, March 23.--The Bruns bill, consolidating and reducing the number of bureaus in the Department of Public Works of NewYork, has progressed far enough to attract some attention. Its effect is to give Commissioner Squire greatly increased powers over those ever before conferred upon any one man in New-York.

THE HAGUE, March 23.--The lower house of Parliament has, by a vote of 53 to 22, rejected the bill to re-establish differential duties in the Dutch East Indies.

E.J. Denning Co.'s large store, which is in the full blossom of its annual Spring opening, was crowded with ladies yesterday. The house, which has an established reputation in its various lines, has outdone itself this year. The Spring opening presents the largest, finest, and most varied assortment of goods ever displayed on its acres of counters and shelves.

Mrs. Lillie Devereux Blake and seven other ladies stepped on to the platform of the Masonic Temple at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon amid a dead silence and faced an audience of about 300 ladies and a sprinkling of gentlemen. The quiet proceedings which followed were those of the seventeenth annual convention of the Woman's Suffrage Association of this State.

The twentieth annual report of the Wetmore Home for Fallen and Friendless Girls shows the institution to be in a flourishing condition. Since the opening of the Home, in 1865, there have been admitted to its shelter 1,635 young women and girls.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 24.--Mrs. Sarah McKenzie was accidentally killed by her son at their residence, near Waverly, yesterday. WASHINGTON, March 24.--Senator Mitchell, of Oregon, is the first Republican in the Senate who has had the courage publicly to dissent from the resolutions attached to the Edmunds report on the Duskin case. He did so to-day in a short but spirited speech, every word of which was listened to by every Senator present.

ERIE, Penn., March 24.--Another of the unfortunate bank depositors, Mrs. Mary Sephle, was removed to the Warren Insane Asylum today. This victim lost $10,000 in one of the several rotten savings banks which burst during the year. Since the bank suspended Mrs. Sephle had large amounts of money about her house She made a desperate attempt to kill a bank officer a short time ago.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 24.--Late yesterday afternoon the body of John Harrison, an aged and well-to-do North Branford farmer, was found in a pond in North Haven. Harrison's pockets were full of stones, and this fact leads to the belief that he committed suicide. His wife died recently, and her death unsettled his reason.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 24.--The well known sportsman, Prof. Louis G. Dromel, is lying at the point of death at his private apartments over the Turf Exchange. A few days ago he began complaining, and immediately was confined to his bed. His ailment is heart disease and dropsy. Death is merely a question of a few days.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 24.--Hugh J. FORT KEOGH, Montana, March 26.--A great prairie fire is raging on the Crow Reservation. The fire, under the influence of a very strong wind, has already covered many miles of territory and burned thousands of tons of uncut hay. A report from Billings says it is charged that the Crow Indians fired the prairie and that it is a move to drive cattle off the reservation.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 27.--James Hubbard, living six miles from here, to-day celebrated his one hundred and first birthday. Last year his centennial birthday was celbrated by a public dinner, and a like ceremony was observed to-day. The old gentleman is in good health.

LEBANON, Ind., March 24.--A few days since George Shelton, living west of this city, near Dover, put a bar of lead in a quart of water, then boiled it until the water was reduced to one pint, which he drank as a cure for boils, with which he was afflicted. He was taken sick immediately, and despite all efforts of the attending physician, died to-day after lingering a few days in great pains

The Sells family commenced in life very poor. The father educated himself after he had married. So determined was the whole family to obtain education that the father and children were often scholars in the same school. The father taught while the mother took care of the children and tilled the farm.

Justice Lewis, of Babylon, Long Island, yesterday issued a warrant for the arrest of Frank Davis, traveling agent for F.S. Baird, a jeweler at that place. PHILADELPHIA, March 27.--The typesetting tournament which began here on Tuesday, March 16, closed to-night, Duguid, of Cincinnati, taking first prize and McCann, of New-York, the second.
UTICA, N.Y., March 27.--The Committee on Location of the State Agricultural Society met here to-day and decided to hold the State fair in this city from Sept. 20 to 30, inclusive.

BOSTON, Mass., March 27.--Brig.-Gen. Jonathan A. Hill, the gallant commander of the Eleventh Maine Volunteers, lost his right arm at the battle of Deep Run Aug. 16, 1864. The limb was amputated improperly, and Gen. Hill has suffered from the wound until the present time. A second amputation has just been performed at the Massachusetts General Hospital.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 27.--The strikers at the Arctic Mill have followed the example of their Quidnick brethren and given in. More than half the machinery was started up this morning and a large number of weavers told the Superintendent that they would resume work Monday at the former terms.

Two burning ships were reported yesterday by incoming vessels. Capt. Atkins, of the bark Hannah Blanchard, from Amsterdam, stated that during the night of March 9, when in latitude 41 35' and longitude 41 30', he saw a large ship on fire. She seemed to be fully 25 miles to windward. Capt. Atkins tried to beat toward her, but could not make much headway.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 27.--Within the past two months there have been a number of burglaries in this vicinity. In January last the Monmouth Beach villa of Mr. John McKesson, of the wholesale drug firm of McKesson Robbins, was entered and completely ransacked.
PARIS, March 1.--The Dudlay question has been terminated officially by the Minister, who, in defiance of the vote of the committee, has imposed the artist as societaire for 10 years longer.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 27.--Waterbury's dancing school held no session this afternoon. Its New-York proprietor was missing. After two months' persistency he had just succeeded in overcoming the odds of a French accent and Hibernian dress and manner enough to obtain number of pupils from leading families, whom he instructed at Music Hall.

The port of Copenhagen was reopened for navigation on Friday, but as the Cattegat and the Sound are still packed with ice the passage from the North Sea to the Baltic is not without danger. Owing to the severe snowstorms having stopped railway traffic everywhere in Denmark, the capital was without any foreign mails for several days. Part of the regular traffic has now been restored.

The Treasury Department has prepared a new design for ten-dollar silver certificates, which includes an excellent vignette portrait of the late Vice-President Hendricks. New designs for certificates of other denominations will be adopted from time to time.

The inactivity proved to be, as intimated, merely the preparations for another movement; much as the apparent quiet of a besieging force is deceptive, while the plans are being perfected to deliver an assault.

MONTREAL, March 27.--The French Canadians who voted with the Government on the Landry motion are being held up to public execration by the liberal and disaffected organs, which call upon their constituents to turn them out on the first opportunity.

Senator EDMUNDS has finished his campaign on the Duskin resolutions, and has won a doubtful victory. He has succeeded in securing their adoption by one majority in the absence of a Democratic successor to the late Mr. MILLER, of California. The substantial results of the long discussion, which, on the Republican side depended ...

The strike of the employes of the Broadway Railroad Company of Brooklyn, which was begun at 1:45 o'clock on Friday afternoon, was ended yesterday afternoon. The company ended the strike by acceding to all the demands of the men.

A number of gentlemen interested in National Guard work, among them Judge Gildersleeve and Gen. Shaler, assembled in the Seventh Regiment Armory last evening and listened to the reading of several papers on military subjects. The first was by Lieut-Col. E. H. Sanford, whose subject was "Rifle Practice."
A man tiptoed into an editor's office and looked furtively about.

BOSTON, March 27.--Alfred H. Schumaki was arraigned this morning charged with aiding and abetting the suicide of his roommate, Gustave Desmet, on Thursday last. The case is the first of the kind that has ever been tried here, and the prisoner, if found guilty, will be liable for murder.

The New-York and New-Jersey Road Racing Association met last evening at the Citizens' Bicycle Club house, No. 313 West Fiftyeighth-street. The following organizations were represented: New-York Bicycle Club, Citizens' Bicycle Club, Harlem Wheelmen, Pegasus ...

ALBANY, N.Y., March 27.--Seventy-five knit goods manufacturers met here last evening and formed a National Association of Knit Goods Manufacturers, with the following officers: President--H.V. Silliman, of Cohoes; Vice-President--M.R. McCowett, of Amsterdam; Secretary--C.F. North, of Cohoes; Treasurer--John H. Giles, of Amsterdam.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 27.--The Times-Union to-morrow will publish a letter from Gov. Perry, saying that Senator Jones's absence from his seat does not make a vacancy in a constitutional sense, and consequently he has no power to make an appointment to fill a vacancy which does not exist.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 27.--A Philadelphia military company is now considering the project of a trip to Newport during the coming Summer. The organization is Company B, State Fencibles Battalion, First Brigade, National Guard of Pennsylvania, and is one of the crack companies of the Quaker City.

A somewhat notable character has died in Bombay in the person of Mr. Kessowjee Jadowjee, a wealthy Bhattia merchant, who was popularly spoken of during life as a "millionaire." The amount of property he has left behind him does not probably fall far short of 90 lacs of rupees.

An Austro-Hungarian company has obtained the concession for transporting petroleum from the great wells in the Caucasus district to Europe by railway or boat. The company has already distributed 200 immense tanks along the Baku-Batoum Railway line, and pipes are laid from Batoum station to the pier, where the oil will be run into boat tanks specially constructed for the purpose.

The excitement of the Morgan sale and the humors of the peachblow exposure have kept attention from two collections belonging to Messrs. Berlah Wall and John A. Brown which are on exhibition at the American Art Galleries and will be sold on the evenings of March 30 and 31 and April 1.

"The Physiology of Artistic Singing" is a book of upward of 300 pages, copiously illustrated and beautifully printed, and containing much interesting information for advanced students of song who may care to learn something more of the source of their vocal powers than is found in an ordinary work on anatomy or physiology.
The Longfellow Association has only $13,000 of the $50,000 needed to place a seated statue of the poet upon suitably decorated grounds in Cambridge.

Another story of the late William Gray has reached me. Years ago, under the old and cumbrous organization of the Supreme Court of Michigan, the Judges of that tribunal were numerous. A young man in a neighboring city applied recently for a marriage license and the clerk in attendance said in answer to his request, after he had made some other inquiries. "What was the name of the lady's father?" "You've got me there," was the response. "Well, then, what was her mother's name?" "I give it up," was the answer.
