CHICAGO, March 27.--Warrants were sworn out last night for the arrest of Christopher Boll, John Duggan, and William Lawler, Election Judges, for violation of the recently enacted primary election law. It is charged that they refused to comply with the law governing the primaries, which states that the canvass of the ballots must be made in the presence of the bystanders.

A consignment of Russian arms will shortly be sent from Odessa to Antivari. The Russian Government at first refused the request of the Prince of Montenegro to be supplied with new and good Russian arms for his troops. M. de Giers declared that Russia could not comply with this request without provoking discontent in Austria.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 27.--A syndicate composed of New-York bankers and capitalists, doing business under the name of the New-York Gas Company, has leased a territory in the Murraysville field, and will at once develop it for gas. The Duff farm, on which there is a well now being used by the Philadelphia Company, forms part of the territory. They intend to sink 20 wells on this farm and to begin work at once.

A children's industrial exhibition, under the auspices of the Industrial Education Association, will commence next Wednesday at Cosmopolitan Hall, Broadway and Forty-first-street, and continue until April 6. The exhibition is the outgrowth of a suggestion made last November to members of the association by Mr. Charles Barnard.

At the Manhattan Cottage, opposite the parade ground on the old Coney Island road, the headquarters of the Manhattan Cricket Club, the black and white barroom cat has taken it into her head to try and hatch out a brood of chickens.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27.--The scheme to erect a public monument to the memory of the late John McCullough is meeting with general condemnation by the members of his profession in this city, and it is asserted that the matinee for the benefit of the monument fund, announced to take place at the Academy of Music in April, will not come off.

FRANKLIN, Ky., March 27.--Mrs. Neely Sexton, against whom an indictment was found for carrying a pistol at the last term of court, was arrested to-day and placed in jail to await her trial, having failed to give a five-hundreddollar bond. This is the first case on record in this county where a white woman was arrested on a charge of this kind.

Fitzpatrick, who owns a large cattle ranch about 20 miles from this city, in Valencia County, came riding post haste into town with the news that a band of Mexican herders had attacked Fitzpatrick's cowboys, killing one ...
This will be the last week of "The Jilt" at the Star. "The Gypsy Baron," remains the attraction at the Casino.

PANAMA, March 27, via Galveston, Texas. --Great excitement is occasioned by the dictatorial decree of Gen. Santo Domingo ordering the suspension, and the closing by force if necessary, of the American newspaper, the Star and Herald, notwithstanding the recent official declaration of the freedom of the press.

There was nothing at all to terrify the Aldermen suspected of taking Jacob Sharp's bribes in the testimony heard yesterday before the Senate Railroad Committee. Encouraged by the know-nothing exhibition made by Alderman Duffy, the men who voted for the Broadway Road franchise sat around with some complacency to see how Alderman Fullgraff was going to behave himself.

NEW-HAVEN, March 27.--Figure it as they may Yale's most enthusiastic backers can only figure out second place for their college at the coming intercollegiate games in New-York City. For the last two or three years Yale has worked unsuccessfully for the intercollegiate cup and Harvard has taken the silverware to Cambridge.
Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes said, among other things, at the dinner of the Alumni of Phillips Andover Academy in Boston, Wednesday evening, March 24.
SACRAMENTO, Cal., March 23.--Gov. Stoneman has appointed George Hearst United States Senator, vice John F. Miller, deceased.

CHICAGO, March 27.--Though the Western roads brought into Chicago more freight than usual the past week, yet shipments east by rail increased only 2,000 tons. The aggregate for the week was only 25,952 tons, against 25,915 tons last week and 71,082 tons in the corresponding week in 1885.
Michael Kelly, a New-York cabman, was arrested at his home, No. 5 Rutgers-place, on Friday night by Detective Peirce and a policeman from Jersey City.

LONDON, March 27.--The Right Hon. James Stansfeld, Radical member of Parliament for Halifax, has been appointed President of the Local Government Board, in the place of Mr. Joseph Chamberlain. Mr. Stansfeld occupied the same office once before, but without a seat in the Cabinet, resigning in 1874.

WASHINGTON, March 27.--The National Council of the National Union League held its annual session at the Ebbitt House, in this city, to-day. There was a very full representation of States. HARTFORD, Conn., March 27.--Work is still continued on the four tracks of the New York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad from the Harlem River to Stamford. George W. Cram is the contractor for the division to Port Chester, and will probably complete the excavation and grading by next Fall.

The Spartan Harriers held their regular chase yesterday from Roe's Hotel, Mount Vernon. The chase was run during a pouring rain, but this did not interfere seriously with the enjoyment of the sport, the general verdict being that the chase was one of the most enjoyable of the season.

The sixteenth annual report of St. Vincent's Home, Brooklyn, for the care and instruction of poor and friendless boys, for the year ending Sept. 30, contains much interesting information in regard to the work of the institution. During the year the Directors received $2,912 77, the greater part of which was contributed by the conferences of the St. Vincent de Paul Society.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 27.--The petition was filed in the Court of Common Pleas this afternoon in what promises to be a highly sensational case. George P. Smith is the plaintiff and the Cleveland Rubber Paint Company, N.C. Brewer, and four others are defendants.

Fred Decker, better known as the "Ossian Giant," died at his home at Swains, Allegany County, Sunday night, at the age of 50 years. During his earlier life he was 7 feet 2 inches in height and weighed 325 pounds. As he grew older he became round-shouldered, and at the time of his death he was but 6 feet 11 inches high.

The committee of the Manhattan Protective Association held a meeting on Thursday and ordered a general boycott against the NewYork Steam-Heating Company on account of the unsettled strike of the journeymen steam fitters.

The death is annoudced of M. Bertrand, the President of the Civil Tribunal of Grenoble. He has directed in his will that his funeral should take place without any religious ceremony and that his grave should be unmarked. This is the first French Judge who in our time in dying has broken with the creed in which he was brought up.

VINCENNES, Ind., March 27.--At midnight a warrant was issued for the arrest of Spear S. Hollingsworth, County Treasurer of Knox County, on the charge of embezzlement. The affidavit against Hollingsworth was sworn out by County Commissioner Bartlett, and was brought about by a suspicion that the County Treasurer would leave town before daybreak.

Mr. James H. Temple, of this city, about a month ago, while coming from his country home, at Huntington, lost a sachel containing his wife's diamonds, valued at $5,000. Mrs. Temple has recovered her diamonds through a priest of the Roman Catholic Church.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 27.--The funeral of the late Dr. Samuel W. Francis was solemnized at Trinity Church this noon, the Rev. G.J. Magill, the Rector, officiating. The church was well filled with citizens, embracing the representative men of the community in every profession and department of life and of every class of society.

Among the men who have made a deep impression on the industrial history of Maine is Gen. Davis Tillson, of Rockland. Gen. Tillson is one of those rare spirits in whom dash is united with judgment. His far-seeing sagacity has led him into brilliant enterprises that seemed chimerical to his less gifted friends--then his brains and courage have carried him through them in triumph.

Charles Greenwald was a prosperous barber who lived at No. 250 West Thirty-second-street. On Dec. 15, 1876, he made a will, leaving his entire property, amounting to $15,000, to his wife. In case of her remarriage, however, the wife was only to get her dower right of one-third, and the rest was to be given to relatives.

It is Southey, isn't it, who says in "The Doctor" that a household is never complete unless it has as inmates a kitten and a child not much past its third birthday? While we cling to the kitten and the baby we feel that the family is not yet finished. We would add to it a grandmother.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 27.--One of the breaker boys at the Mount Pleasant Mine was reprimanded by the foreman yesterday and this morning discharged. His companions to the number of 50 struck, throwing 300 miners out of work. The leader of the strike is only 11 years old.

Only a short time ago the Chinese were rapidly obtaining a monopoly of the boot and shoe manufacturing business in this city. Most of the shops were crowded with them. They either took the places of white operatives or prevented whites from being employed. The manufacturers were warned of the dangerous course they were pursuing.

There are signs of an early termination of the cloak operators' strike. The rooms of the strike committee at No. 177 East Broadway yesterday contained many strikers who urged a speedy settlement of the difficulty and protested the impossibility of bringing the large manufacturers to do away with the contract system.

WASHINGTON, March 27.--The debate on the silver question was opened in the House to-day by Mr. Culberson of Texas, who announced himself in favor of fair play and fair dealing with silver. He was a friend of silver and in favor of placing it on the same plane with gold in regard to coinage and making it a full, unqualified debt-paying power.

Denver has another distinguished visitor and guest in the person of Sir Alexander Stuart, Knight Commander of the Order of Saints Michael and George, and ex-Premier of NewSouth Wales. He arrived last evening on a Salt Lake train and put up at the Windsor Hotel. There accompanied him Lady Stuart, Miss Stuart, Kenneth Stuart, N.S. Ward, and R.C. Ward and wife, of London, England.

He made his first appearance in London, at Lincoln's Inn, in 1725, and passed over to Drury-Lane in 1733. Most of the contributions to the conscience fund of the National Treasury are unaccompanied by the name of the person making restitution or a statement of the fraud or mistake by which the writer became possessed of money which his conscience will not let him keep.

BALTIMORE, March 27.--Charles W. Hitchcock, convicted several days ago of having stolen letters committed to his care for delivery as a letter carrier, was to-day sentenced to three years in the Maryland Penitentiary.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., March 27.--The trial of William H. Jones and Frank Jones, father and son, indicted for the murder of Mary Rice, closed this afternoon at 5 o'clock, with a verdict of not guilty. The jury was out about one hour. The trial began on March 10. The evidence was purely circumstantial.

When the Rev. Oscar F. Brown, on Friday night, left No. 350 East Sixty-first-street, where he had been found after more than three weeks' search for him, he went with George S. Bailey to the latter's house in Morrisania. It was midnight when they reached there. Mr. Brown said little on the way, except to make a few remarks about his sickness, which he said had kept him so long from home.
BOSTON, March 27.--A novelty in the way of athletic exhibitions took place this afternoon in the Hemenway Gymnasium, Cambridge.

A delightful entertainment was given at Chickering Hall last evening. Mr. George Riddle read the text of "A Midsummer Night's Dream," or a large portion of it, while Mendelssohn's lovely music was performed by a detachment of the Symphony Society orchestra and a chorus of women from the Oratorio Society under the direction of Mr. Walter Damrosch.

I give you to-day some notes I have made on the way public men dress. They are as careful of their clothes as are the noted society belles, and their idiosyncrasies are as many almost as there are men. Garland still shuns a dress coat, and he wears his shirt with the buttons in its bosom. President Cleveland is at home in nothing but black broadcloth and boots.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 27.--Roberts's Opera House was leased this afternoon for five years from July 1 to F.F. Proctor, of Jacobs Proctor, of Albany, N.Y., who will run his various circuit attractions at popular prices. Manager Roberts, while reticent as to the price per year, is satisfied that he can make a better thing than to keep it as he has been doing.

EL PASO, Texas, March 27.--The American gamblers played the gold brick swindle on Thursday evening on Senor Samiengo, a physician of Chihuahua, fleecing him out of $5,000. The doctor was accosted by one of the swindlers with the old story of a solid gold brick stolen from California which would be sacrificed, as the parties did not know how to get rid of it.

No Russian lady can travel without her husband's assent to the issue of her passport, but in Austria woman's right to a veto has just been recognized. It is stated that a decree has recently been promulgated to the effect that no married Austrian subject shall henceforth receive a passport for journeying beyond the frontier without the express consent of his wife.

TROY, N.Y., March 27.--The evidence in the trial of Michael Kurtz, alias "Sheeny Mike," for the Marks jewelry burglary closed this afternoon. Annie Derrigan, of Lexingtonavenue, New-York, was the last witness for the people. She said she went to Albany with Kurtz and Porter, but did not know the year.

WASHINGTON, March 27.--Judge Thacher and Mr. W.E. Curtis, of the South American Commission, addressed a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations to-day in support of Senator Frey's bill for a Congress of American Republics. Mr. Curtis discussed at some length the statistics of trade, showing the enormously disproportionate share which falls to European countries as compared with that of the United States.

Considering the state of the weather the American Opera Company had a very good audience in the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, last evening, when Victor Masse's one-act opera, "The Marriage of Jeannette," and Delibes's "Sylvia" ballet were revealed to the dwellers on the other side of the East River.

I heard yesterday the first true version of the monkey and hand organ story which has been privately told in army circles here now and then, but not always correctly. It comes to me from a high Treasury official, who had something to do with the settlements of Gen. Butler's army accounts.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, March 27.--The Bexar County Bar is experiencing a sensation. One of its heretofore most aspiring and brilliant members, Thomas Harrison, languishes in the county jail on the charge of perpetrating a very big swindle.

The semi-annual dividends payable in Boston April 1 aggregated $6,909,743, of which the banks pay $1,396,000. The changes in bank dividends, as compared with October last, are as follows: The City increaces from 2 to 2 per cent., Commerce 2 to 3, Continental 2 to 3, Shawmut 2 to 3, Shoe and Leather 2 to 2 , and Webster 1 to 2 per cent.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 27.--In Wallingford, on Monday, a trial will take place which will be of far more than ordinary interest. It is the case of the State against Frank H. Morse, the story of whose arrest on a charge of arson has been told in THE TIMES. Morse is now out under bonds of $5,500.

TRENTON, March 27.--The hearing in the matter of the passing of the accounts of ex-Judge Ashbel Green, Receiver of the North River Construction Company, was continued before Barker Gummere, Master in Chancery, this morning.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 27.--Prof. Hadley, of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, is still unable to formulate his schedule of work for his next report.
The military order Loyal Legion meets at Delmonicos on Wednesday evening, April 7.

CHARLEROI, March 27.--A reign of terror prevails in this city. The rioters, thousands in number and armed with weapons of every conceivable kind, have virtually held possession of the streets all day. Many stores and dwellings have been attacked and pillaged, and in some cases burned.

If its walls could speak--to use a favorite phrase of the novelists--an interesting story could be told by those of the University Club, on the southeast corner of Madison-avenue and Twenty-sixth-street. The building could not be better adapted for the occupancy of a club. All of its principal rooms are spacious, and the accommodations are those of a small hotel rather than of a private city house.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 27.--A special dispatch from Shoals, Ind., gives the conclusion of the trial of Sam Archer, the last of the gang three of whom were recently lynched in the Court House yard. The trial has been proceeding since Wednesday, the prisoner being under the guard of a company of State militia from this city.

Mrs. De Towser--Yes, poor Mrs. Smith returned from Europe with the most superb wardrobe I ever saw. Why some of the gowns were simply poems--all from Worth's, and she had only been home a week when her husband died. It was terrible, terrible!

Mme. Madeline Schiller gave the first of two recitals of piano music at Steinway Hall yesterday afternoon. The programme she interpreted was of respectable proportions, and its numbers were representative of a dozen composers, the array extending from Beethoven to Godard.

PARIS, March 9.--The Carnival winds up its forlorn existence to-day, and, though I have written nearly the same thing on the same occasion every year of the last eight, I never was nearly so exact as I am now in asserting that within man's memory nothing so dull has ever been known as this once festive season.

LONDON, March 27.--This was the third day of the Liverpool Spring meeting. The race for the Liverpool Spring Cup was won by Mr. W. I'Anson's 5-year-old bay or brown horse Prince Rudolph. Mr. Abington's 5-year-old chestnut horse Kimbolton was second and Mr. J.B. Leigh's 3-year-old brown colt Andrassy third.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 27.--Just as THE TIMES reached here this morning with an account of the embarrassment of so many manufactures because of the Western railroad strike it was announced that the concern known as the Waterbury Button Company, New-York office No. 46 Howard-street, will be obliged to suspend, in part at least.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 27.--The taking of testimony for the Government in the case of Kelly, Delgado, Morey, and Soto, the alleged filibusters, was concluded to-day. Mr. McFarland made a brilliant argument for the defense.

WASHINGTON, March 27.--Late to-night the report was freely circulated that Mr. Manning's condition was less favorable than it had been during the day. It was asserted that the Secretary had complained of more than usual pain in his head, and that he was feverish and restless.

In the ordinary course of things Mr. Henry Broadhurst should have been now the happy owner of two costly uniforms of the "second class." A day or two after his appointment he was asked what he meant to do in the matter, and the member for the Bordesley division of Birmingham quietly answered that "he hoped his friend Albert Edward would see him well through the difficulty."

LONDON, March 27.--The prevailing excitement reaches almost to fever heat to-night as the tension of political anxiety is subjected to still further strains by the knowledge that Mr. Chamberlain and Mr. Trevelyan have definitely seceded.
WASHINGTON, March 27.--President Cleveland returned at 11:30 o'clock to-night from Magnolia, Md., where he was entertained by the San Domingo Ducking Club.

In preparation for the proper observance of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Archconfraternity of the Holy Family, attached to the Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, Third-street, special services and sermons have been held in the church on the last four nights, and on each evening over 4,000 people have been present.

The Blossom Club gave a reception last night, at which artists, actors, and politicians mingled in a most agreeable manner. Henry E. Dixev told what he had learned about the unknowable in the transmutations of Adonis. Edward E. Rice spoke in beautiful terms of Acadia.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 27.--The 25-mile bicycle record of America was broken to-day by L.D. Munger, of Boston, who made the distance in 1:24:46 4-5 on an asphalt road from Lee Circle to Carrollton and back--two round trips.

BOSTON, March 27.--The Lynn boycott continues, and the manufacturers affected by it are to appeal to the joint board of arbitration. If the matter is not settled at Monday's meeting of the board a general lockout is threatened in 125 factories, entailing a loss of wages amounting to $1,000,000 a month.

The Executive Committee of the Knights of Labor proposed to Jay Gould yesterday that the strike on the Missouri and Texas Pacific Railroads be settled by arbitration, and the proposition was rejected by Mr. Gould, who gave his reasons for his refusal at considerable length. General Master Workman Powderly remained in consultation ...

CHICAGO, March 27.--It is learned here that Chief Arthur, of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, has issued an order to the members of the organization requesting them to withdraw from the Knights of Labor, if they are members of that body, and forbidding them to join the order in the future. This edict is in harmony with the sentiments expressed by Mr. Arthur here during the earlier part of the week.

UTICA, N.Y., March 27.--A largely attended meeting of the Oneida County Bar was held here this afternoon to take action in respect to the death of ex-Justice Ward Hunt. Addresses were made by ex-Senator Kernan, Arthur M. Beardsley, Judge Cox, and others, and resolutions eulogizing the character and services of the late Judge were adopted.

The managers of the New-York Cooking School and others interested in its work, attended its first exhibition yesterday. The school was founded in 1876, but two years ago it took up a new class of work--that of giving cooking lessons to the poor.

CHICAGO, March 27.--The Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of New-York filed an auxiliary bill in the United States Circuit Court today against the Chicago and Atlantic Railroad Company, asking that should the Receiver applied for in Indiana be appointed his jurisdiction be extended to property in Illinois so that it may not be sold in parcels.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., March 27.--While a loaded car was being hoisted from the Mount Carmel Colliery this morning and when it had almost reached the head of the incline the chain broke and the car dashed to the bottom, fatally injuring George Hoerter, an employe, and also severely injuring Joseph Kellagher. Three cars were wrecked and the colliery was forced to suspend work.

McBlain, Ninth Cavalry, whose nomination for promotion was recently rejected by the Senate, has asked that a court of inquiry be appointed by the Secretary of War to investigate the charges which are supposed to have resulted in his rejection by the Senate.

There is a fierce controversy raging in the Daily Telegraph as to the prevalence of kissing in Sunday schools. CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 27.--P.M. Arthur, Grand Chief of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, returned to the city today from Chicago.

Mrs. W.S. Warner, through her counsel, Lauterbach Spingarn, has brought a suit for trespass against Sheriff Grant for levying on the furniture and other personal property contained in the Warner mansion, at No. 64 Fifth-avenue.

A mid shipman not more than 15 years of age was told off with a party of blue-jackets to take possession of the company's telegraph apparatus. The company's employes stood aghast with solemn faces. Such an act of desecration had never been dreamed of.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 27.--Yesterday a brutal-looking negro called at the house of John L. Boshet, 10 miles west of this city, and, finding Mrs. Boshet alone, sprang upon her, threw her to the floor, and assaulted her. He threatened her life if she made any outcry until he was safely out of the vicinity.

CHICAGO, March 27.--It is stated here on the highest authority that United States Judge Charles E. Dyer, of Milwaukee, will shortly resign to resume the practice of law. His retirement is due to his inability to live comfortably on the small salary of $3,500 of that position.

LEADVILLE, Col., March 28.--John Timmons, aged 53 years, an old professional gambler, arrived here a few days since, without money. Failing to secure employment, be to-day took a close of laudanum, from the effects of which he died. He was a native of Kentucky, but spent most of his life in Cincinnati and St. Louis. He leaves a widow and four children in the latter city.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 28.--Charles Reynolds, Jr., managing editor of the Baltimore Morning Herald, died here this morning of paralysis of the brain, aged 28 years. Mr. Reynolds came to Annapolis on Friday evening, and after taking supper at the Maryland. Hotel paid a visit to the residence of Mr. William A. Abbott, the proprietor of the Evening Capitol.

PANAMA, March 28, via Galveston.--The Star and Herald newspaper suspension is for 60 days, and if issued during that period the owners will be fined $200 per copy. The seizure was made because a subeditor declined to publish certain correspondence submitted in an unofficial manner by the Governor-General, Santo Domingo Vila.

--Mr. Corcoran, of Washington, has presented to the Virginia Historical Society the stereotype plates of "The Madison State Papers," which for 40 years or more have been in his possession. The House Committee on Expenditures in the War Department to-day heard Mr. Leonard Whitney, of the Western Union Telegraph Company and Lieuts. Holtnorth and Greene, of the Signal Corps, in the matter of the alleged irregular expenditures in the Signal Service. The Lieutenants bore testimony to the necessity and regularity of the expenditures, and Mr. Whitney testified that Gen. Hazen examined all telegraph bills and restricted the expenditures on that account.

AUBURN, Me., March 29.--On Saturday last the firm of A. Cushman Co., shoe manufacturers, laid before a meeting of their 750 employes the details of a plan whereby the net profits of the business shall be divided among the workmen.

CHICAGO, March 29.--The City Council tonight unanimously passed an ordinance declaring that on and after May 1 next eight hours shall constitute a day's work for all persons employed by the city or upon city contracts for city work. An election is to be held next Tuesday for successors to half of the present Council. Many of the Aldermen are candidates for re-election, and the ordinance adopted to-night was presented by one of the candidates.
AMSTERDAM, N.Y , March 29.--For some days a disease of a highly contagious character has been the source of much excitement in Johnstown, Fulton County.

Snow Burgess, the agents of the ship Tsernogora, which went ashore near Spring Lake, N.J., Saturday night, said yesterday that John Lovitt, the managing owner of the vessel, had gone down to her on a tug.

TOMBSTONE, Arizona, March 29.--Frank Leslie and Tom Green, mounted United States Customs Inspectors, while searching for smugglers near Lanoria, on the boundary line, 25 miles southwest of this city, were attacked by Mexicans. The Inspectors promptly recrossed the line, and when on American soil Green opened fire on the Mexicans. It is believed that he wounded one. The Mexicans retired.

The newsboys who sell the Brooklyn Times created a disturbance at the office of that paper on Broadway, Williamsburg, yesterday afternoon, by refusing to take copies for sale or to allow any one else to do so.

ALBANY, March 29.--The Senate Railroad Committee has heard rumors of an impending attempt to bribe members of the Legislature and so prevent the passage of its bills affecting Jacob Sharp and the Broadway Railroad. At its meeting in New-York on Saturday the subject was discussed and Mr. Conkling suggested a line of action to head off the bribers.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., March 29.--A Norfolk (Va.) dispatch says that the 46-ton schooner Electric Light, of this port, was run down Saturday night by a coaster. Nothing was saved. She was insured for $6,678 on the vessel and $2,000 on the outfit.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--A statement was published here this afternoon to the effect that President Cleveland had been in telegraphic correspondence with Jay Gould concerning the labor troubles in the Southwest, urging him not to stand in the way of arbitration.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 29.--The State Democratic Executive Committee met here today with a full attendance. Many prominent Democrats were present by invitation. After four hours' discussion, it was determined to hold two conventions, one for the nomination of Supreme Judges and the other for a candidate for Governor. June 9 is the date chosen for holding the Judicial and Aug. 11 for the Gubernatorial Convention.
RICHMOND, Ind., March 29.--The Sunday quiet of this Quaker city was disturbed by the excitement attending the report of an attempt to poison an old lady named Eliza Hopkins.

ELMIRA, N.Y., March 29.--George Schooville, of Hornellsville, aged 21 years, working for H. Tucker, a farmer near Candor, Tioga County, N.Y., was instantly killed by an explosion of giant cartridges at 9 o'clock last night. His body was blown to pieces, and only portions of it were found. It is supposed that he was experimenting. The accident occurred in the dooryard.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29.--Col. John A. McCaull has achieved another great triumph at his opera house in this city. A more unpromising evening for the production of a new opera could not well be imagined.
ATHENS, March 29.--The Chamber of Deputies will reassemble on April 3.

The amount in Chica go elevators was: Wheat 13,991,480; corn 3,435,704; oats, 500,488; rye, 230,405; barley, 112,889.

Morse, one of the town's most prominent young men, was guilty or not guilty of arson. The shops were as good as closed, for nearly every man who was able to walk managed to reach the hall.

CINCINNATI, OhiO, March 29.--Judge Goebel, in the Probate Court, to-day disposed of the exceptions to the account of John B. Mannix, as Assignee of the late Archbishop Purcell and Edward Purcell.
The best-liked scenes from "H.M.S. Pinafore" were represented at Koster Bial's to the delight of a large audience last evening.

The charter and by-laws of Typographical Union No. 6 provide that $150 shall be taken from its treasury and applied to the payment of the cost of burying each deceased member who had belonged to it for a year and had been in good standing continuously for six months prior to his death.

ST. LOUIS, Marsh 29.--The situation relative to the strike in St. Louis proper has grown more tranquil, while that in East St. Louis is more alarming. In St. Louis, the report that Gould had agreed with Powderly to arbitrate was accepted by the strikers as a signal to quietly rest on their oars and await further developments from the Executive Committee.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 29.--Arrangements are being made for the construction of a railway from Fort Scott, Kan., to NewOrleans, a distance of 1,200 miles.

"The Little Tycoon," a two-act "comic opera" that has drawn overflowing audiences for many weeks to the Temple Theatre, in Philadelphia, was represented for the first time in New-York at the Standard last night. The words and music of "The Little Tycoon" are the work of Mr. Willard Spencer.

WILLCOX, Arizona, March 29.--With the Chirlcahuas under Geronimo was a white boy, aged 10 years. He says his name is Santiago McKinn, and that his father is Irish and his mother Mexican; that he was captured near Mimores, New-Mexico. He has light hair, gray eyes, and is of light build. He says the Indians treated him kindly.

The coal companies sent their Presidents down to Bowling Green yesterday to try once more to fix up that long-talked-about "coal combination."

WASHINGTON, March 29.--Nearly a week has elapsed since Secretary Manning was stricken with apoplexy and carried home in a helpless condition, one side paralyzed, his speech thick, his mind dwelling upon the work he was engaged in when he was prostrated, and his general weakness admitted to be deplorable.

The Siouz Indians, about 28,000 in number, occupy in the Territory of Dakota a reservation nearly as large as the State of Indiana, and as large as all New-England, Maine excepted. When this tract was set aside for them by treaty, in 1868, there was an abundance of large game in it.
NEW-ORLEANS, March 29.--The twentieth game in the championship contest was played this afternoon.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 29.--The Government steamer Lansdowne arrived at Shelburne on Saturday afternoon from a cruise along the coast.

LONDON, March 40.--The steamship Lydian Monarch, (Br.,) Capt. Huggett, from New-York March 17 for London, passed the Scilly Islands March 29. The steamship Benicla, (Br.,) Capt. Jones, from Philadelphia Feb. 16, arr. at Bombay March 29. The steamship Navarro, (Span.,) Capt. Aldecocea, from Baltimore March 18, arr. at Liverpool March 29. The ship Ulrica, (Br.,) Capt, Scurr, from San Francisco Dec. 9, arr. at Liverpool March 29.

LONDON, Marsh 29.--Mr. Gladstone, in the House of Commons, this afternoon, stated that on April 8 he would ask permission to introduce his Irish Government bill. He added that on April 12 the budget would be introduced, and that on April 15 he would request permission to introduce a bill to amend the laws for the sale and purchase of land in Ireland.

ST. LOUIS, March 29.--The announcement that Gould had consented to submit the difficulty between the Missouri Pacific and its employes to an arbitration committee composed of representatives from each side was received with a great deal of satisfaction by the members of the Joint Executive Committee of the Knights of Labor.

A quarrel on Sunday night between Peter J. Reilly, an agent of the Prudential Life Insurance Company, and his wife, Mary, at their residence, No. 245 Washington-street, Brooklyn, culminated last evening in a shooting affray.

CHALEROI, March 29.--This city to-day is a vast military camp, from which flying columns are operating in all directions. The Government has authorized the peaceable inhabitants of the city to arm themselves and to use every means in their power to defend their domiciles. There is a more confident feeling.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 29.--The annual meeting for election of officers of the Yale Tennis Club was held to-night.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 29.--The fall of rain in this locality to-day has been exceedingly heavy. To-night the storm is so heavy that all railroad communication is cut off.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--Dissatisfied members of the House have been complaining for weeks because they cannot get from the Committee on Education a report, favorable or unfavorable, on a bill similar to that which was recently passed by the Senate, and which proposes a distribution of $77,000,000 for educational purposes.

DOVER, N.H., March 29.--Two months ago ex-Chief of Police Charles Armstrong was held in $1,000 for trial on a charge of stealing gold watches. The evidence was not conclusive and many people believed him to be innocent, and censured the Judge who held him. To-day two of the stolen watches were found concealed in the mattress of the bed in the cell in which Armstrong had been confined.

Pilots and shipping men are strongly of the opinion that the schooner whose three masts have been seen sticking out of the water southwest of Shinnecock Light is the Charles H. Morse, and that this vessel is the one that came in collision with the Oregon. The wrecks of the steamship and schooner are 16 miles apart, the schooner lying southwest of the steamship.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 29.--The little village of Oxford, four miles northwest of Seymour, was to-day the scene of one of the most horrible tragedies in the history of Connecticut. A prominent and well connected citizen of the town assaulted a defenseless woman with an axe, felling her to the ground, and then went home and soon afterward poisoned himself.

Chicago will be 50 years old as an incorporated city on March 4, 1887. That anniversary will be an interesting one in the history of the Garden City. There are certain reasons why such an event should be properly observed, and why preparations should be undertaken early to make such a celebration a success.

MOBILE, Ala., March 29.--Based upon a proposition by a New-York syndicate, T.G. Bush left here two weeks ago, carrying a power of attornoy of the Mobile stockholders of the Alabama Grand Trunk to sell the road.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--The consideration of Mr. Logan's Army bill was resumed in the Senate today. In reference to the assumed increase of expense Mr. Logan said it would be only $15,000,000. The existing law authorized 25,000 enlisted men, but there were not so many in the army, and if the present bill authorizing 30,000 were passed there would never be actually more than 27,000 men ready and fit for active service.

The case of Major Holsborn against his wife, Regina, and Nelson Pardee, whom he charges with perjury, was up again yesterday in the Tombs Police Court.

CHICAGO, March 29.--W.A. Pinkerton, the detective, has Mme. Ollie E. Ellis, the adventuress who was recently quietly expelled from Washington, D.C., upon his list, and is pretty familiar with her career, particularly in this city.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 29.--A case of great interest is pending for argument in the United States court. Mr. John Thompson, of Harrodsburg, several months ago bonded a lot of whisky, and it was gauged for export.
Julius Von Stavenow, who for some years was an inspector at the Custom House, died in New-York last Wednesday, and was buried on Sunday at Troy.

NEWBURG, N.Y., March 29.--John Ellinger, an unmarried German, residing at Goshen, was run over and killed by an Erie train near Goshen late on Saturday night, while walking toward his home in an intoxicated condition. Ellinger was 22 years old, and a farmer by occupation.

Once more the disputes between Actor George Herbert Leonard on one side, and his wife, known on the stage as Louise Balfe, and Manager Abraham L. Erlanger on the other, were before Judge Lawrence in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday. Actor Leonard appeared as a prisoner, brought into court on a writ of habeas corpus.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 29.--By a trick the Democrats of this Legislature have outgenaraled the Republicans and places them in a position from which it will be hard to extricate themselves.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 29.--Miller Brothers, dry goods dealers, made an assignment to-day of all real estate, goods, and personal property to secure creditors.

CLINTON, Mass., March 29.--In February the Bigelow Carpet Company voluntarily raised the pay of its dyers from $1.30 to $1.40 per diem. On Saturday the dyers, 80 in number, demanded $1.50 per diem, and thrir request not having been granted, struck this morning.

ERIE, Penn., March 29.--Mr. Charles Streuber, formerly of the firm of Walter Streuber, committed suicide to-night by hanging.

BUTLER, Penn., March 29.--The residence of William Haven, at Mount Chestnut, Penn., was destroyed by fire yesterday morning. His son Frank, while assisting in rescuing other members of the family, perished in the burning building, and a daughter was so badly burned that her life is despaired of. The cause of the fire was a defective flue. Loss not known.
QUEBEC, March 29.--At Lachevrotiere, Quebec, to-day, Eleazar Marcotte shot and killed Alphonse Perriult. An officer has been dispatched from here to arrest Marcotte.
TRENTON, N.J., March 29.--Mr. Noonan's pet scheme, the bill against the Pennsylvania Railroad's plan of insurance of its employes, came up in the House on final passage to-day.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 29.--Col. Moontooth filed a bill in the Court of Common Pleas to-day on behalf of Samuel Barkley, the ball player who was suspended and fined by the American Baseball Association. The bill asks that the association be restrained from interfering with Barkley, and that the actions complained of be declared null and void. Next Friday was fixed for a hearing

GALVESTON, Texas, March 29.--An exceedingly cold norther for this season of the year set in last night and is still blowing.

Fire broke out at about 3 o'clock yesterday morning in Frederick W. Blume's grocery store, on Varick-street, Jersey City. It did $2,000 damage.
NEWARK, March 29.--George W. Neal lies chained to a bed in his home, No. 462 Broadstreet, suffering with a well-developed case of hydrophobia.
About 300 of the 450 employes of the Chelsea Jute Mills, at the foot of West Twentyfifth-street, are on a strike for better wages.

VICKSBURG, Mo., March 29.--An armed mob visited the jail at 1 o'clock this morning, and, after battering down the doors, secured possession of Fred Villerosa, an Italian, charged with rape. The man was taken to a tree in front of the jail and hanged. His victim was the 13year-old daughter of Postmaster Groome.
Sorosis celebrated its eighteenth anniversary yesterday afternoon by a dinner at Delmonico's.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 29.--Mrs. Mary Hall, of Miner's Mills, the largest woman in this section of the State, fell dead while eating breakfast this morning. She was 6 feet 2 inches high and weighed 328 pounds. She was born in England. She leaves two sons who are over 6 feet in height.
Mr. John L. Stoddard gave the fourth lecture of his course at Daly's Theatre yesterday morning. Every seat in the house was occupied. "Mary Queen of Scots," was the subject of the lecture.
Ernest Schelenger, a destitute Bohemian cigarmaker, age 40, killed himself last night at No.176 East Seventy-seventh-street, by cutting his throat with a razor.

PANAMA, March 29, Via Galveston.--The Star and Herald published a flysheet to-day giving the details of the cause of the suspension of that journal. The damages caused by the suspension are estimated at over $250,000 gold.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--The Senate to-day in executive session confirmed the following nominations: William L. Alden, of New-York, Consul-General at Rome; Charles T. Russell, of Connecticut, Consul at Liverpool, vice Stephen Packard, suspended; Samuel E. Wheatley, to be Commissioner of the District of Columbia: Samuel T. Corn, to be Associate Justice of Wyoming Territory; L.W. Atlee, of Pennsylvania, to be Assistant Surgeon in the navy.

The bill of Senator FRYE for a congress of American republics has been discussed more or less languidly in the press, the general feeling being that nothing would come of it, and that the commercial evils with which it proposes to deal are practically irremediable by any means now at our command.

Peter Blake, of No. 229 North Ninth-- street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, appeared in Surrogate Lott's Court yesterday to obtain the probate of a will left by his brother, Dennis, who died on Jan. 26.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 29.--Daniel Guthrie, a prominent citizen of Crockett County, was murdered 10 days ago by Weakley Ridley and Gabe Williams, two negroes, who were subsequently arrested and lodged in jail at Alamo.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 30.--John E. Sullivan, the professional baseball player, committed suicide here last night by taking morphine. He leaves a widow in destitute circumstances.

BRUSSELS, March 30.--The situation created by the strikers remains threatening at Tourney. Elsewhere throughout Belgium comparative quiet prevails. Quiet has not only been restored at Charleroi, but the strikers are generally returning to work and the civic guard has been disbanded.

WILLICOX, Arizona, March 31.--Gen. Crook arrived at Fort Bowie on Monday night, having left Lieut. Maus in charge of Geronimo and the other surrendered Apaches. News, however, has just been received that Geronimo, with 20 other Indians and some squaws, escaped during the night. Lieut. Maus and all the men that could be spared have started in pursuit of them. It is believed that Geronimo has gone to join Chief Mangus.

John F. Gleason is to be buried this morning from St. Agnes's Roman Catholic Church, Forty-third-street. He was one of the best known of the billiard men of this country, and was held in general esteem.

The boys at Rye Beach fish for bass off "Passengers' Rock" when the tide is low. The ledge bears that name because some passengers on a schooner that was wrecked in a gale years ago clambered on it for safety.

A prisoner at Police Headquarters, about whose identity a good deal of mystery has been created, was said last night on good authority to be Horace Lyons, alias Richmond, one of the men concerned in the burglary at Mrs. Schuyler Hamilton's, and in the subsequent disposal of the stolen property at Alderman Jaehne's metal melting establishment.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 31.--The sympathy of every one living in the vicinity of Cave and Shelby streets has been aroused in behalf of Mr. Bright Bentel, a laboror living at that place. About two weeks ago he buried on the same day two promising daughters.

There were rumors and some excitement yesterday over the prospect of a tie-up of the Broadway lines of horse cars. It was stated that there had been orders for a cut of wages from $2.25 to $2 on the University-place and Seventh-avenue lines.

In the installation to-night of the Rev. Richard D. Harlan as Pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, at Fifth-avenue and Eleventhstreet, one of the oldest churches in the city will pass under the charge of one of the youngest Pastors.
BOSTON, Mass., March 31.--Benjamin R. Tucker, editor of the Anarchist paper Liberty, exposes in his paper to-day what he calls "a gang of criminals," among the followers of John Most.
The hospitality extended here to the English cricket teams last year by American clubs was so much appreciated that the number of visiting cricketers this season will be trebled.

Auctioneers E.H. Ludlow Co. sold some well known property in Flushing at the Liberty-street Real Estate Exchange yesterday, including the noted "old Bowne House," built in 1661. This landmark, with a plot of land 135 by 150 feet, and all of its antique furniture brought $10,000. Mrs. Mary M. Parsons, a connection of the family whose homestead the old house was so long, was the purchaser.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 31.--Coroner Mix, of New-Haven County, paid an official visit to Oxford to-day, to investigate the murder of Miss Elsie Williams by her luckless lover, James Andrews, and his subsequent suicide. He finds that there is no reason to believe that the murderer and suicide was insane. Andrews was buried to-day in Woodbury, and funeral services over the remains of Miss Williams will be held to-day.

The Chinese Sunday School Union has prepared a memorial to Congress asking redress for the various acts of violence inflicted lately upon Chinese on the Pacific slope and elsewhere. As a means of adding weight to the memorial a public meeting has been called for Monday evening next at Steinway Hall.
Adrian H. Muller Son sold the following securities at auction at the Liberty-street Real Estate Exchange yesterday:
At Special Term of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, Judge Pratt heard argument for alimony and counsel fee in the suit of Kate O'Sullivan for absolute divorce from her husband, Jeremiah.

WASHINGTON, March 31.--Second Lieut. Charles B. Vogdes, First Infanty, has been granted a four months' leave of absence. The leave of absence of Second Lieut. Charles H. Osgood, Twelfth Infantry, has been extended two months on account of sickness.

PITTSBURG, March 31.--Mrs. Frank E. Hill, of Greensburg, who eloped with a young lawyer of the same place named Marchand, yesterday had her husband arrested on a warrant issued by Squire McMasters, of this city, on a charge of conspiracy.
City Works Commissioner Conner, of Brooklyn, caused a breeze in his department yesterday by sudden and unexpected changes among his clerks.

TRENTON, N.J., March 31.--The prosecution in the impeachment trial of State Prison Keeper Laverty rested this morning after Minnie Schaefer, who was recalled, had testified as to two or three minor points.

PANAMA, March 31, via Galveston.--The Star and Herald appeared under the title of the Evening Telegram last evening. No attempt was made to stop its circulation. The editor and proprietor is Augustus Kruger.

PANAMA, March 31, via Galveston.--At Calevra, two leagues from here, on the line of the canal, nine tons of gunpowder and dynamite were exploded by a pistol shot fired by a guard at a band of robbers. Six men were killed and several others wounded. The force of the explosion was terriffic.
The infant child of Mrs. Marie Rose Bariere that was shot in the head at Mrs. Bariere's house, in River-street, Newark, Tuesday evening, died yesterday, and Coroner Williams will hold an inquest.
A hearse, followed by a few mourners, left an apartment house in East Twenty-fifthstreet, between First and Second avenues, yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, March 31.--The Executive Committee of the Knights of Labor were busily engaged in their session from 10 0'olook this morning until late in the day making the preliminary arrangements for the conference which is to be held with Mr. Hoxie upon the arrival of the Executive Board.

BOSTON, March 31.--Cyrus W. Field's investigation as to the New-York and New-England bond sale was renewed to-day, and the examination of President Clark was continued. Mr. Eddy, of Brewster, Cobb Estabrook, was recalled and further questioned about the sales of bonds and preferred stock between Nov. 18 and March 9, and Charles C. Jackson, of the firm of Jackson Curtis, who distributed the bonds after Mr. Higginson's purchase, was examined.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 31.--The Morning News was put under a boycott this evening by the local typographical union and the Knights of Labor. About 18 months ago the News reduced the pay for composition, and the men went out on strike. The foreman, however, remained and "ratted" the paper.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 31.--A heartbroken man appeared at the District Attorney's office yesterday, to ask the assistance of that official in recovering a runaway wife.

LONDON, March 31.--The Dublin Freeman's Journal says that the Irish Land bill which Mr. Gladstone will propose does not, as has been stated, involve either a compulsory purchase or the advance of any specified sum from the imperial Treasury.
Fire on the upper floor of the threestory building at No. 54 West Thirty-first-street early yesterday morning caused a loss of about $400. Indications of incendiarism were discovered by the firemen.
CHICAGO, March 31.--The Western Silk Association is in session in this city. The membership represents the 18 silk manufactories whose agencies are situated in Chicago, St. Louis, and Cincinnati.

Edward Roberts, a young colored man, living at No. 114 Sullivan-street, went into the liquor store of Mendelken Buck, at Sixthavenue and Twenty-sixth-street, on Tuesday, and had drinks amounting to 40 cents.
PHILADELPHIA, March 31.--The Board of Managers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company to-day adopted the following resolution:
WASHINGTON, March 31.--Senator Harris, of Tennessee, took the witness stand when the Telephone Investigating Committee met to-day. He was allowed to make his statement in his own manner.
The Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Railway Company made public its last annual report yesterday. It covers the year ending Dec. 31, 1885.

PETERSBURG, N.J., March 31.--Two weeks ago a young daughter of Jacob Niper walked a distance of two miles with her parents, wearing new shoes and red stockings. The shoes were tight and greatly irritated her feet.

GALESBURG, Ill., March 31.--A tea store here belonging to J.H. Cox of Aurora, was closed to-day by the Sheriff, on an execution in favor of Nicholas Martin, of Chicago, whose claim amounts to $5,400. Other creditors are Reed, Murdock, Fisher Co., and Pilkins Brooks, of Chicago. In the store were 119 chests supposed to contain tea, but which when opened were found filled with sawdust.
W.T. Walters, of Baltimore, is at the Brevoort House. John F. Seymour, of Utica, is at the Buckingham Hotel.

"Sheeny Mike," or Michael Kurtz, is said to have made a confession at Troy implicating Lyon Langer, of No. 61 East One Hundred and Tenth-street, in his numerous crimes. Kurtz's confession was sent to Police Headquarters by special messenger, and detectives were detailed to find Langer. Last night he sur rendered himself to the police.

WORCESTER, Mass., March 31.--"Doc" Wilson, the plaintiff in the famous Wilson-Moen suit, has disappeared and is supposed to have gone to California. He lately told his attorneys that he was now obliged to work for a living, and had accepted an offer for 60 days at a good salary. His furniture was attached for debt, and yesterday his household effects were sold at Providence. His wife has gone home to her father, Caleb Harnum.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 31.--The funeral services of the late Francis H. Olmsted, one of the Class of 1874 in Yale, who died in his ranch in Colorado, were held to-day in the Chapel of Grove-Street Cemetery, and were attended by many sorrowing friends and classmates.

Frank B. Hebert, a clerk in the real estate office of F.A. Carruthers, at No. 1,357 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, has disappeared. The young man came to this city on Saturday to deposit $500 in the bank and has not since been seen. Mr. Carruthers asserts positively that Hebert has not taken a cent of money that did not belong to him.

BERLIN, March 31.--The Reichstag today voted to prolong the Anti-Socialist law two years. During the discussion Prince Bismarck, in accepting an amendment prolonging the measure two years, said that Herr Babel's remarks in favor of murdering monarchs and making assassination a part of his programme would justify a further prolongation of the law.

PITTSBURG, March 31.--The Convention of Anti-Instrumentalists of the United Presbyterian Church adjourned to-night after adopting a declaration of principles. The paper denounced the use of instrumental music in the ...

GALVESTON, Texas, March 31.--A heavy frost in Northern Texas, Monday night, did great damage to vegetation. From Dangerfield, Henrietta and other points come reports that nearly all the early fruit trees in the vicinity have been blasted. Garden vegetation has been set back fully two weeks over a very wide expanse of Southwestern Territory. The cold wave extends far beyond the Rio Grande. Winter wraps were comfortable here at midday yesterday.

Last evening's representation of "The Flying Dutchman" at the Academy of Music introduced Mme. Christine Dossert as Senta, the cast in respect of the remaining personages of the opera being as heretofore.

The barkentine Kloto, loaded with coal, sailed from Baltimore for this port on Feb. 22. Nothing has since been heard of her. Messrs. Loud, Claridge Co., her Baltimore agents, are wondering if her disappearance may not lead to a solution of the Oregon mystery.

The Senate did wisely in extending the powers of the Broadway franchise investigating committee to cover an inquiry into the present activities of those unhappy persons whom Mr. SEWARD described as "white-robed innocents."

Mr. Jack Dempsey, the invincible pugilist, visited the Germania Assembly Rooms in the Bowery last evening and informed Mr. William E. Harding that as he had an engagement as an usher at a wedding in an up-town fashionable church he could not act as the referee in the Graeco-Roman wrestling match.

Articles of incorporation of the Lexington-Avenue and South Ferry Railway Company were filed yesterday at Albany. Among the incorporators are Rowland N. Hazard, Homer A. Nelson, Thomas W. Evans, Lawson N. Fuller, Eugene T. Connell, Wallace C. Andrews, and William S. Williams, all of whom are well known in connection with the cable railway scheme.

BARDSTOWN, Ky., March 31.--Mrs. Elizabeth Wilson died at the home of her son, David Wilson, at Botland, in this county, last evening, of old age. She had reached the good old age of 105. She was the mother of Benjamin F. Wilson, former proprietor of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, Louisville.

BRUSSELS, March 31.--Work has been resumed in all the factories and collieries in the Charleroi district. The authorities have, however, forbidden the workmen to celebrate the ending of the strike by a carnival. The conference between the masters and workmen at Tournai resulted in disagreement and the strikers have resumed rioting.

ALBANY, March 31.--The Broadway Railroad Investigating Committee reported its four bills favorably to the Senate to-day, and they were made a special order for next Tuesday. The only one of the seven committeemen who dissented from the report was Henry C. Nelson, Democrat, of Westchester County.
WASHINGTON, March 31.--The proceedings in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day were as follows:
Brooklyn Rapid Transit Commission No. 1 met yesterday morning in the Garfield Building, on Court-street, and adopted 10 plans for as many rapid transit routes through the city.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 31.--In its weekly review of flour production the Northwestern Miller of Friday will say: "The mills now have almost as much water as they can use, and show greater activity than for a long time. Eighteen recorded their output last week the largest since November.

LONDON, March 31.--The Daily News to-day demands of the Government an explanation of the statement printed in NewYork that British contractors and officers are interested financially in the construction of the new vessels to be built for the American Navy.
WASHINGTON, March 31, 1886. It is estimated at the Treasury Department that there has been a reduction of about $14,250,000 in the public debt during March.

George W. Atkinson cabled Richard K. Fox yesterday, saying that the backers of Jem Smith, champion of England, had posted 100 with Bell's Life to support a challenge by Smith to John L. Sullivan for a fight for 1,000 for the championship of the world and the Police Gazette belt.
The following are the weights assigned to the entries in the Croton and Fordham handicaps to be run at the Spring meeting of the American Jockey Club. The declarations are to be made by May 15:
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 31.--Drafts on New-York-Sight, 20 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 31.--The loss of property by yesterday's fire is estimated at $1,500,000. Four thousand persons are thrown out of employment.

In the trial of Frederick Goebhardt for the shooting of Ellen Phibbs, which was continued before Judge Gildersleeve in Part I, of the Court of General Sessions yesterday, motions for acquittal on the charges of murder in the first and second degrees were denied on the ground that the case should go to the jury.
Between two showers of rain last evening Barnum gave the street parade, the postponement of which for three nights had been made necessary by the weather.

What is said to be the only hand-painted lace for trimming on sale in this city was exhibited yesterday in the vast building occupied by J. Johnston at Broadway, Fifth-avenue, and Twenty-second-street.
Abram C. Hull, the Captain of Patrol No. 1, who becomes Superintendent of the Fire Patrol to-day, was agreeably surprised last night when he was ushered into the patrol house in ...

One hundred property owners of the Eighth and Twenty-second Wards, Brooklyn, met at Prospect Heights Hall, at Fifth-avenue and Nineteenth-street, last evening, to protest against the passage of Assemblyman McCauh's bill making it illegal to construct an elevated road on Fifth-avenue.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 31.--At the time the Daily States discharged its union printers and employed imported hands for that purpose, about a year ago, a street difficulty occurred between the printers, and the result was the arrest of Philip and Eugene Munch, Watt Duffy, ...

HARTFORD, Conn., March 31.--There was a lively slugging match in the office of the Daily Telegram last night. A young man named Fletcher has been the Meriden correspondent of that paper for some time, and had several weeks' back pay overdue, which he tried in vain to collect.
The ferryboat Delaware, of the Erie Railway Line, came into collision with the Susquehanna, of the same line, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 31.--Jean Baptiste Revol committed suicide yesterday by shooting himself in the right temple at his grandson's residence, corner of Chartres and Conti streets. Death was instantaneous.
"A.S."--There is no free dramatic college in this city. "S.S."--Apply to the Central Labor Union for the information you seek.

Senator VANCE has made his attack on the civil service law and on the President, and we have no doubt he is much better satisfied with himself than he will be when his constituents shall have had a chance to read his remarks.
The sale of the private collection of modern paintings belonging to Mesers. Beriah Wall and John A. Brown was continued last evening at Chickering Hall.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 31.--The Democratic State Central Committee met today and selected Little Rock as the point and fixed June 30 as the time for holding the Democratic State Convention. The basis of representation was fixed on the number of votes cast at the last Gubernatorial election, which will largely increase the number of delegates.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 31.--The American fishing firms here have chartered a large schooner at Clark's Harbor and another at Cape Sable, in Shelburne County, to carry a large number of men to Maine to man fishing vessels awaiting them there.

All the members of the New-York Baseball Club have reported for duty, and the opening game of the season, if the weather permits, will be played on the Polo Grounds this afternoon, when the "Giants" will encounter the Jasper nine, of Manhattan College.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 31.--At 10:30 o'clock this forenoon, in a one-story cottage, at No. 33 Causey-street, where the couple lived, ostensibly as man and wife, Al Bennett was shot through the heart and instantly killed by Laura May Porter, alias May Roberts, alias Bennett.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 31.--According to the notification of the officials of the Central Union Telephone Company, the exchange service of 477 of its patrons in this city ends to-night.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31.--A meeting of the subcommittee appointed to arrange the percentages in the anthracite coal combination was held at the office of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company this afternoon.

Edward P. Kennard, owner of the missing steamer Rapidan, which left here on Feb. 1 to start a transportation line between Aspinwall and Carthagena, doubts no longer that she was lost in the heavy storm of the first week of February.

Assistant Engineer Royal Chapin, who on Tuesday swore that an attempt had been made to intimidate him from telling the truth about the work on the new aqueduct, in charge of Chief Engineer Church, was the first witness before the Commission of Engineers yesterday.
The Board of Trustees of the Grant Monument Association held a meeting yesterday afternoon to complete its organization, preliminary to earnest work in behalf of the fund.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 31.--The editor of the Chronicle, the Hon. Patrick Walsh, who is also a National Democratic Committeeman, has sent circulars to other members of that committee, and to prominent Democrats of the country, asking their views on the President's civil service policy.

TRENTON, N.J., March 31--In the House to-day Mr. Seymour, of Jersey City, introduced a bill prohibiting the election of any member of the Legislature to any office in the State in the gift of the Legislature.

The Amherst College Glee Club gave their annual concert at Steinway Hall last evening. Their programme embraced 14 numbers-- exclusive of the inevitable encore pieces--and all the favorite college songs were interpreted and listened to with enthusiasm.
Attractive Parisian novelties in the line of evening costumes, dress goods, wraps, and parasols are displayed at the store of B. Altman Co., at Nineteenth-street and Sixth-avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 31.--There are before the House Committee on Foreign Affairs two joint resolutions and a bill suggesting diplomatic negotiations between the Government of the United States and other Governments on this continent looking to a convention in Washington to secure co-operation for various purposes.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 31.--A special to the Journal from Lafayette says: A few days ago Orth Stein, proprietor and editor of the Comet, left the city for St. Louis for the purpose, he said, of removing his paper to that city in order to give it a wider field of circulation.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 31.--The Chicago Stove Works, employing 250 men, have shut down. An accident to a portion of the machinery is the reason given, but there is a dispute between the firm and some of its employes in regard to wages. Pending a settlement the works will not start up again.

We give below the number of passengers arrived at this port from foreign countries during the month of March, as compiled from the books of the Government, kept at the Barge Office by Mr. James O. Ellery, Boarding Officer:
The order has been sent out by the Executive Committee of Assembly No. 101 of the Knights of Labor at St. Louis for a resumption of work by the strikers on the Missouri Pacific Railroad this morning.

A small army of lawyers filed in before Surrogate Rollins yesterday morning to talk about the report of Referee George W. Lyons on the accounting of Frederick Bernard Wendt, Executor of the will of David M. Peyser.

CHICAGO, March 31.--An amusing sort of a scandal, in which Police Jurtice George A. Meech shines like a paste diamond on a flannel shirt front, is the talk of the town this evening, and Justice Meech is at work revising his rules for accepting gifts. In November last the Justice's little son had a birthday, ...

WASHINGTON, March 31.--Commissioner Black was again before the Senate Committee on the Expenditure of Public Money this morning. He was examined by Senator Plumb in respect to the case of Mark Robinson, Chaplain of the Fifty-second Indiana Volunteers, one of those submitted by the Commissioner in support of his charges, and was asked to state ...

CINCINNATI, March 31.--Gov. Foraker today appointed Robert J. Morgan and George R. Topp, Republicans, and Milo G. Dodds and Dr. T.C. Minor, Democrats, as Police Commissioners under the new law providing for a non-partisan police force for the city of Cincinnati.

NYACK, March 31.--Last evening John Whalen, Police Constable of South Nyack, and William Felay, a young man of about the same age, were arrested and put under bonds of $250 each on a charge of having assaulted an agent who was selling the New-York Tribune.

Spring styles in ladies' and misses' dresses, cloaks, wraps, jackets, bonnets, and hats and unusually attractive dress goods novelties were displayed yesterday in Lord Taylor's establishment, at Broadway and Twentiethstreet.

Secretary D.W. Richman, of the Cloak Manufacturers' Association, notified the strikers yesterday that the association could not comply with their request to abolish the contract system either at once or on July 15, but informed them that they could return to work on the old ...

We give below the number of arrivals of vessels from foreign countries at this port for the month of March, distinguishing their class and nationality. This table is compiled from the books of the Government, kept at the Barge Office by Mr. James O. Ellery, Boarding Officer:
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 14.--During the afternoon of June 29, 1885, the schooner yacht Brunhilde, of the New-York Yacht Club, weighed anchor for Cowes, Isle of Wight, on a voyage around the world.
QUOGUE, Long Island, March 31.--The iron steamer Europa, of Carr's Direct Hamburg Line, went ashore about a mile to the eastward of the Quogue Life-saving Station, at 11:30 o'clock last night.

Ex-Judge Platt Potter, of Schenectady, has given to the New-York Historical Society six volumes of the "State Trials of England," issued in 1742, which originally belonged to Sir William Johnson, Bart., his autograph being inscribed on the title page of each volume.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 31.--The outlook for higher prices in the Northwest for wheat is more encouraging. The enormous receipts at this point, which have so long been a bugbear to the bulls, have shrunk to very moderate proportions.
Miss Georgia Cayvan will act in "May Blossom at the Windsor next week. "Der Zigeuner Baron" will be represented to-night at the Thalia Theatre.

The sixth annual dinner of the NewYork Association of the Alumni of Cornell University was held at Delmonico's last evening. About 200 persons were present, including Charles Kendall Adams, the new President ...
HARTFORD, Conn., March 31.--Both houses of the Legislature passed to-day the compromise bill on the Fairfield County question, and it went to the Governor for his signature.
WASHINGTON, March 31.--"Black Jack" Logan came into the Senate this morning with "blood in his eye." A storm lurked under his raven locks and heat lightning flashed from his snapping eyes.

RICHMOND, Va., April 1.--The James River at this point has been rising steadily all day, and at this hour (9 P.M.) nearly all that portion of the city known as Rocketts is submerged to a depth of from eight to ten feet.
The third and last of these entertainments was given at Steinway Hall last evening by the artists that took part in the concerts already referred to in this place.
College days will be recalled at Chickering Hall this evening, when the Wesleyan University Glee Club will make their bow to a New-York audience.

QUOGUE, Long Island, April 1.--The tug Rescue and a lighter arrived here at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The wind had changed from southeast to southwest, and cleared away the fog that had enveloped Long Island for several days.

MIDDLETOWN, Del., April 1.--This beautiful little town of upward of 2,000 inhabitants, containing two banks, two excellent hotels, three or four beautiful church buildings, and several important factories, is situated in the centre of the New-Castle County peach district.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 1.--One of the most interesting events which take place annually in connection with Cornell University is the contest for the election of an Alumni Trustee. Any 10 Alumni are empowered to nominate a candidate, all names to be sent in by April 1.

No recent meeting of the Chamber of Commerce has drawn out so full or distinguished a gathering as that which yesterday filled every seat in the hall. Among those present were Levi P. Morton, ex-Collector W.H. Robertson, Jackson S. Schultz, Cornelius N. Bliss, Erastus Wiman, and ex-Mayor Edson.

On motion of ex-Judge A.J. Dittenhoefer, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, Judge Lawrence made an order continuing in force the injunction restraining Harry W. Williams from producing Dion Boucicault's plays ...
The last act in the tragedy of the "House of Blazes," where Ellen Phibbs was shot on Jan. 30 by Frederick Goebhardt, a keeper on Blackwell's Island, was finished yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 1.--Several weeks ago the Rev. Chauncey C. Williams, Rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, this city, was elected Bishop of Easton, Maryland, and declined. To-day Mr. Edwin G. Weed, Rector of the Church of the Good Shepherd here, was informed of his election to the Bishopric of Florida. It is not believed that he will accept. He is a man of fine ability, very popular, and enjoys considerable wealth.

ALBANY, April 1.--Thirteen New-York Knights of Labor marched up to the Capitol this morning, announced that their order was opposed to the repeal of the charter of the Broadway Railroad, sternly demanded to see the New-York Senators at 7 o'olock this evening, and than disappeared.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 1.--Advices from all parts of the State indicate that the fruit crop is not seriously injured by the recent cold wave. In some localities peaches are reported damaged, but growers generally predict an average yield. Corn and cotton planting is going forward rapidly, with an increased acreage in the latter.
The baseball season was opened yesterday in this city by a game on the Polo Grounds between the Jaspers, of Manhattan College, and the New-York League Club.

"Boodle" Alderman John O'Neil was the only one of the suspects who sat throughout all of yesterday's meeting of the Board of Aldermen. He has a friend who bas been engrossing Aldermanic mortuary resolutions for some time.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., April 1.--William Gebo, a farmer, who has made some money lately by speculations in land, and who besides was possessed of a goodly fortune, committed suicide this morning by hanging himself in his barn. No cause can be assigned for the deed. He passed his fiftieth birthday yesterday, and loaded a wagon with furniture, intending to make an early start for a new home.
NEW-ORLEANS, April 1.--The weather to-day was clear and cool. The track was in fair condition.

FORT Worth, Texas, April 1.--Valentine Sanford, a boy 14 years old, was to-day convicted of murder in the first degree at Henrietta, Clay County, Texas. The punishment was assessed at life imprisonment. The boy shot his mother.

Ex-Fire Commissioner Cornelius Van Cott, whom Mr. Waite mentions in his statement, was found by a TIMES reporter last night at his residence, No. 49' Clinton-place. "I have not been well for some time past," he said, "and have been obliged to keep indoors."

WASHINGTON, April 1.--Senator Harris's examination was resumed to-day by the Telephone Investigating Committee. At the request of the President of the Washington Company, witness had seen the Commissioners of the District with a view to securing permission for the Washington Company to run certain overhead wires for experimental purposes.
ALBANY, April 1.--The Legislature of 1882 passed a law authorizing School District No. 8, in the town of Cortlandt, in the county of Westchester, to raise money on its bonds to be issued.

Since the first reference by the Times about a week since to the fact of the existence of some old continental notes, a number have been brought to light. We have mentioned several of these. Yesterday, however, a well known citizen brought to the Times office a well preserved note of the date 1762, the oldest that has yet been presented. It is of the denomination of 5 shillings, and bears the following inscription:

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 1.--By order of the Board of Health the sleeping car Eldorado, of the West Shore Road, the colored porter of which is ill with smallpox at Syracuse, was stopped here this afternoon and disinfected, and the passengers were vaccinated.
One day last week Mr. Bob Griffin, residing near Smith's mills, made the best shot at wild turkeys we have ever yet chronicled. We would better state how he killed them before we ...

CHICAGO, April 1.--Despite the agreement of the General Freight Agents of the Northwestern roads in St. Paul Tuesday to maintain the tariff for one week any way, rates went all to pieces to-day, and an energetic war of no mean proportions is ...

It was an open secret last night that the cable railroad man whom Mr. Waite referred to in his interview as visiting him at New-London and offering him money for favorable votes of the Aldermen was Charles P. Shaw, who was at that time carrying the entire cable road scheme on his back.

The Parkville Racing Association opened the season on Long Island yesterday in a successful manner. The track is a half mile one, and in consequence of the heavy rains of the past three days it was not in good condition, although no mud was visible on the surface.

Wall-street was excited yesterday over the report that the long-continued transcontinental railroad war had been settled, or that if not settled the important questions involved had been satisfactorily arranged at a conference ...
CHICAGO, April 1.--There is pending before the Council an ordinance granting valuable franchises to the Chicago Steam and Power Company, recently incorporated by D. Alonzo Child.
WASHINGTON, April 1.--The following is a recapitulation of the debt statement issued to-day:

MATAMORAS, Mexico, April 1.--Word was received here to-day of a fight with smugglers near the town of San Fernando, 50 miles south of here. That particular section of Tamaulipas lying between San Fernando and the Gulf coast, 15 miles distant, has for ...

DANBURY, Conn., April 1.--Oscar O'Connell and Charles Nadic are in the hospital here suffering from injuries received by the falling of the plank shop in the rear of Byron Dexter's shop, on Centre-street, yesterday. O'Connell was seriously hurt about the head and received internal injuries which are probably fatal. Nadic was cut and bruised severely by falling timbers. The building was 25 by 40 feet, and was erected about a year ago.

STONEHAM, Mass., April 1.--The street railroad company last night agreed to offer the conductors $2 a day, as demanded, and to raise the wages of drivers from $1.50 to $1.75. It is believed that the men will accept the offer.

The programme interpreted in yesterday's Popular Concert at the Academy of Music included, with the usual allowance of familiar compositions, one number that was new to local audiences. This was in shape of three brief movements from Bruch's cantata of "Achilleus," intended to ...

NYACK, N.Y., April 1.--The Rockland County Journal, the oldest newspaper but one in the county, was sold to-day by John Charlton, the proprietor, to Dr. Frank B. Green, or Brooklyn, ...

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1.--The contest over the will of the late Thomas Fallon, one of the most prominent Democrats of the State, has opened with every probability of a long trial. The estate is valued at $300,000, and is chiefly in real property.

TAYLORSVILLE, Ky., April 1.--Capt. Cornelius Snyder died yesterday at his residence, near Little Mount. He was 95 years of age, the father of 22 living children, and a soldier in the war of 1812. He was married four times and leaves a widow. He voted the Democrtic ticket until 1884, when he voted for Blaine.
