The Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard College is to give two performances at the University Club Theatre on the evenings of April 12 and 13 for the benefit of the College Boat Club.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 1.--The report of the Brown investigating committee represents the views also of Senator Whiting, except that the latter thinks the Auditor should not be censured for what Whiting believes is a common custom in all State offices.

"Strikes: Their Causes and How They May be Prevented," was the topic of discussion at the meeting of the Baptist Social Union last evening. About one hundred and twenty gentlemen gathersd at Delmonico's to hear and be heard upon the subject.
OWINGSVILLE, Ky., March 30.--Jefferson Harman, a farmer and respected citizen, living a few miles east of this place, met with a serious and peculiar accident yesterday afternoon.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 1.--The House disposed of two important labor bills to-day by passing both. One is the bill providing that no child under 13 years of age shall be employed in any manufacturing, mercantile, or mechanical establishment.

BOSTON, April 1.--Of several witnesses summoned by Cyrus W. Fields's counsel to-day to testify in the New-York and New-England bond sale investigation only one, George M. Rice, of Worcester, appeared.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 1.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20 cents; drafts on New-York, telegraphic, 25 cents.

The ninety-sixth session of the NewYork Methodist Episcopal Conference was begun yesterday at St. John's Church, in West Fifty-third-street. Bishop John F. Hurst presided, and more than 200 clergymen were present.

A fire in a three-story frame cottage at the corner of One Hundred and Seventy-fourthstreet and the Boston road last night damaged the furniture and pictures--the property of Isaac Walker, the occupant--to the extent of $18,000. The building, which is owned by Thomas Mulford, was damaged to the amount of $4,000.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, April 1.--At an early hour this morning the United States Marshal and three Deputies raided the house of George Woods, at South Bountiful, seven miles north of this city.

PARIS, April 1.--Dispatches from Anam report fresh massacres at the Catholic missions in the Province of Quang Bing. The number of victims is said to be 442.

EATONTOWN, N.J., April 1.--Edward H. Johnson, one of the leading butchers of this village, was arrested this morning on a charge of murder in the "Mingo Jack" case, and has been taken to Freehold, the county seat, and locked up in the county jail. Great indignation is expressed at this action, and the excitement runs high. It is not believed that Johnson knows anything about the murder. Other arrests are expected this afternoon or to-morrow.

During January, February, and March of last year three cargoes of codfish were exported from Provincetown, Mass., to Portugal, but owing to the very high duty ($2.50 a quintal) the shipment did not realize much, if any, more than if sold in the home markets.

ROME, N.Y., April 1.--In the trial of Fong Ah Yu for murder the people rested the case last evening and the defense opened this morning. Only three witnesses were sworn and no important testimony was obtained.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 1.--The funeral of Charles Reynolds, Jr., late editor of the Baltimore Morning Herald, took place here this morning, and was largely attended.

TORONTO, April 1.--The Mail newspaper building, one of the handsomest structures in the city, the rebuilding of which has just been completed after its destruction by fire 18 months ago, was partially destroyed by fire this morning.

TRENTON, N.J., April 1.--The Assembly held brief sessions, but busy ones. Among the bills passed were those confining contracts for State prison supplies to residents of the State, appropriating $9,000 for the erection of monuments pointing out the resting places of Union soldiers in the Gettysburg burying ground, and appropriating an additional $10,000 for the support of the Soldiers' Home.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 1.--The Citizens' Committee of Fifty, in aid of the Irish Parliamentary fund of Philadelphia, closed its work to-day, having collected over $35,000. By unanimous vote a draft to the order of the Treasurers of the Parliamentary fund in London was ordered to be sent for the full amount to Rev. Dr. O'Reilly, of Detroit, Treasurer of the National League of America, for transmission.

A table published by the New-England Insurance Exchange of Boston gives the net premiums and losses paid during 1885 of the 59 insurance companies authorized to do business in New-Hampshire. The total net premiums were $449,583 43, and the losses incurred aggregated $360,998 69. The footings show that a trifle over 80 per cent. of the receipts were absorbed by the losses.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 1.--This afternoon at 4:30 o'clock the Mission Home of the Church of Our Merciful Saviour, on Madisonstreet, between Ninth and Tenth, was dedicated by Bishop E.N. Dudley.

WASHINGTON, April 1, 1886. The bill appropriating $500,000 for the erection in Washington of a monument to Abraham Lincoln was passed by the Senate to-day.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 1.--In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Charlton moved the second reading of his bill providing for punishment for seduction and like offenses and making further provision for the protection of women and girls. He said the entire Christian and moral element sentiment of the country was now in favor of his bill. After his speech a division was taken on its second reading, which was carried by a majority of 67.

The Aldermen of 1884 seemed on the whole to take all the rumors of the day philosophically. They had passed through a similar crisis when Alderman Jaehne was arrested and it was said that he had confessed.
A Rondout Democratic politician said, this morning, that the much wanted "Billy" Moloney, of New-York City, was in Rondout last night.
There were funeral services in St. Francis Xavier's Church, in West Sixteenth-street, yesterday morning over the remains of Bernard McCauley, the well known actor and theatrical manager.

LONDON, April 1.--The Earl of Rosebery, Secretary for Foreign Affairs, had long interviews to-day with the Russian and Turkish Ministers. The Government regards the situation in the East as very serious.

TORONTO, April 1.--A number of policemen attended J.L. Sullivan's entertainment here last night, with instructions to arrest him if he acted indecently or molested any one. While on his way to this city the train stopped at Coborough.
MARTIN, Texas, April 1.--At noon yesterday Wash Washington (colored) was executed here in the presence of 5,000 persons for the murder of Willis Durden a year ago.
"The England of To-day" was the subject of a lecture delivered last evening in the University Club Theatre by Mr. Moneure D. Conway. It was the first of a series on England and English subjects.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1.--Newton A. Turner, Division General Freight Agent of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad for this city, whose office is at No. 417 Walnut-street, resigned to-day, after having been for many years in the company's service.

TRENTON, N.J., April 1.--Chancellor Runyon to-day rendered a decision in the case of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company against the Central Railroad Company of New-Jersey to recover $200,000 for breach of contract.
VINEYARD HAVEN, April 1.--The barkentine Josephine, sugar laden, is ashore on No Man's Land. A steam tug and a lighter have gone to her assistance.

Fresh arguments in support of postal savings banks can be found in the history of the broken savings bank in NewBrunswick, N.J., and of other similar violations of trust in that city. When a savings bank goes down it is the poor who suffer.

WASHINGTON, April.--Republican Senators who supposed when they passed the Edmunds resolutions last week that they had got through with a discussion which had been neither as interesting nor as profitable as they had anticipated find that they were mistaken.

EXETER, N.H., April 1.--An appeal has been taken in the celebrated contest over the will of the late Edward S. Sanborn, the Boston millionaire, on the ground of undue influence on the part of the Trustees of Sanborn Seminary, to whom he gave the bulk of his property and of alleged insanity at the time of the making of the will in question.

A representation of "The Flying Dutchman" was given at the Academy of Music, in Brooklyn, last evening, by the American Opera Company. To-night, in this city, "Lakme" will be sung.

QUEENSTOWN, April 1.--The White Star Line steamer Britannic, Capt. Perry, which sailed hence March 26 for New-York, arrived off Brow Head at 6:40 o'clock this morning. Her forward crank shaft is broken. The Britannic reached Queenstown at 1 o'clock this afternoon.

BUFFALO, April 1.--By all the usual rules of lake underwriting insurance on hulls should have begun to date from noon to-day. But though dozens of applications for policies have been made none have been written, for the simple reason that the agents do not know what the rates are to be.

Unseemly strifes prevail among them, and the spirit of peace which has brooded over the hills ever since the first settlers treated the Indians to New-England rum seems in a fair way to be banished forever.

ALBANY, April 1.--The Hagan bill permitting the opening of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the American Museum of Natural History on Sundays passed the Assembly to-day by a vote of 76 to 31. Considerable discussion occurred over it.

MAUCH CHUNK, Penn., April 1.--James Alexander, for 22 years a porter at the Mansion House, was drowned this afternoon by being dragged into the Lehigh River by a wheelbarrow as he dumped its contents from the bank. He could probably have been saved had not the river been so greatly swollen by the recent rains and the current so rapid.

The sale of the paintings of Mr. Beriah Wall and Mr. John A. Brown came to a successful close at Chickering Hall last night. The audience was larger than on the two preceding evenings and was animated in its bids and applause.

The newsboys who refused to sell the Brooklyn Times a few days ago, because they were compelled to pay one and one-fifth cents for it, sent a committee to see Bernard Peters, the publisher, last evening, and an agreement was reached by which the boys are to get the paper in the future for 1 cent a copy. The boycott will be removed this afternoon.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 2.--L.D. Minger, of Detroit, to-day made 50 miles, using a 57-inch bicycle on an asphalt road in 3:02:34. It is claimed that this lowers the road record of the world by 6 minutes and 56 seconds.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 2.--Half a dozen boys were playing in a vacant lot in Sylvan-avenue yesterday afternoon when one of them, Harry Loomis, 8 years old, living at No. 82, met with a serious accident.

CANTON, Miss., April 2.--At a meeting here to-day of prominent commercial travelers a call was made in the columns of the Canton Dally Picket for a meeting of all commercial travelers at Jackson on Sunday, April 4, to take action in the matter of the Drummers' Tax act recently passed by the Mississippi Legislature, and to take steps to test its constitutionality.

ST. LOUIS, April 2.--The Rev. Dr. S.H. Sonnescheim, Rabbi of the largest Jewish temple in the city, the Shaare Emeth, resigned last evening after a continued Pastorate of 17 years. Dr. Sonnescheim is known all over the country because of his liberal views.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 2.--Pistols and knives in a ballroom last night paralyzed the young gentlemen and ladies present, and resulted in the dangerous cutting of one of the participants. It was a general shooting affray at one time, but none of the balls did any damage.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 2.--Miss Rose Cleveland, sister of the President, arrived in this city this evening, accompanied by Miss Van Vechten.

John Haupt, a young German, hired a room in the Glen Island House, at Cortlandt and West streets, about 4 o'clock yesterday morning. He told the hotel clerk that he had just put his wife aboard a steamer, which would sail for Germany early in the day.

The Broadway Railroad Aldermen and the other political magnates were greatly disturbed by the course of events yesterday. They were frightened at the turn which affairs had taken, and some of them were evidently afraid to say anything on the subject.

OEWEGO, N.Y., April 2.--Police matters here are in a bad state. In July J.A. Baker, the Chief, died, and by consent of the Commissioners, two of whom are Democrats and two Republicans, Officer Grant was allowed to look after the affairs of the office.
ST. LOUIS, April 2.--A special from Lexington, Mo., to the Post-Despatch says that Jeff Wilson (colored) was hanged there to-day for the murder of Jennie Sanford, his mistress, on July 31, 1884.

ST. LOUIS, April 2.--The Grand Jury of St. Clair County, Ill., to-day presented indictments against about 100 of the East St. Louis strikers, and as none of them had yet been put under arrest Judge Watts refused to allow the names of the indicted persons to be made public.

WINCHESTER, Mass., April 2.--Ira L. Gove, 70 years old, a respected citizen, arose from bed early yesterday morning, walked out on the Woburn Branch Railroad bridge, tied a heavy stone to his neck and jumped into the water, where his body was found at daylight. He left a note giving directions where search should be made for his body. The cause of his act is unknown. He leaves a widow and several unmarried children.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 2.--Much interest has existed here for the last 10 days over the death of a lady whose name has since been found to be Miss Julia Lock, of King's Mountain, N.C.
BUFFALO, N.Y., April 2.--B.B. Crandall, a real estate dealer, of this city, informed his wife yesterday afternoon that he was going to Pine Hill, a small suburb.

DURANGO, Col., April 2.--C.L. Creek, of this place, is a gambler and has a bad reputation. A feud of long standing has existed between him and Marshal Heck, and Creek has frequently boasted that Heck could not take him alive.
FORT WORTH, Texas, April 2.--Lawlessness and disorder have won in Fort Worth. One thousand desperado men have set the law and its executors at defiance, and their sweet will rules.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 2.--Col. George T. Fry, a leading attorney, was interrupted in what he conceived to be an offensive manner, in an argument before Judge McCay, of the Federal court, yesterday. To-day Col. Fry swore out a writ of lunacy against Judge McCay. He says he is in earnest to his effort to end the scenes which have taken place in the Federal courts here for a year past.
LONDON, April 8.--The White Star Line steamship Germanic, Capt. Kennedy, from New-York March 25 for Liverpool, arr. at Queenstown at midnight last night.
CHICAGO, April 2.--The pay of the conductors and drivers of night cars on the West Side Street Railway of this city was cut down yesterday, and there is some grumbling among the few men affected.

CHICAGO, April 2.--An explosion occurred at an early hour this morning in the new tank house of Swift Co., the packing firm. The house was a new three-story brick building in Centre-avenue, near Forty-fifth-street.
TOLEDO, Ohio, April 2.--During the past three days C.A. King Co. have received 1,700 reports, covering every important wheat county in Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Kansas, and Missouri.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 2.--Joseph Wharton, as a holder of $500,000 of the convertible adjustment scrip of the Reading Railroad Company, to-day filed a bill in equity in Common Pleas Court, No. 1, against that corporation and Samuel W. Bell, Trustee of the income mortgage.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 2.--True to his pledge, Auditor Brown addressed a brief letter to the House, which Speaker Head caused to be read this morning, demanding that impeachment proceedings be instituted against himself ...
C.S. Seton, whose death in London by the accidental discharge of an electric gun was cabled over on Thursday, was many years ago one of the leading brokers in Wall-street.

ST. LOUIS, April 2.--The St. Clair County (Ill.) Grand Jury returned a second indictment to-day against T.A. Canty, City Clerk of East St. Louis, and D.J. Canty, County Recorder, who were indicted yesterday for conspiracy.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., April 2.--The striking weavers of the Potomska Mills have been ordered back at an advance, 3 cents less than they asked.

A contest at opening oysters created a sensation in the Assembly Rooms at the corner of Seventh-avenue and Twenty-sixthstreet last night. Frank Barrett, an old oyster opener bailing from Norfolk, Va., and John Lahey, of Providence, were matched to open 1,000 oysters, and the reward for the one ...

Jay Gould received a number of telegrams from Vice-President Hoxie, St. Louis, yesterday. Their tenor was encouraging, and Mr. Gould seemed satisfied that his brilliant piece of work at this end of the line would be supplemented by Mr. Hoxie at the headquarters of the strike.
DETROIT, Mich., April 2.--Allen Bailes, of Greenville, in this State, has just come into possession of a fortune of $20,000 from his grandmother in quite a remarkable way.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 2.--The Newhart Hominy Mills at Terre Haute were destroyed by fire to-day. Total loss, $40,000: insurance, $34,000, in Eastern and foreign companies.

The Long Island Underground Telegraph Company was incorporated yesterday. The object of the company is to construct underground telegraph lines, to run from Brooklyn to Jamaica, Rockaway, Babylon, Patchogue, Sag Harbor, Hempstead, Locust Valley, Port Jefferson, ...
A man whose dress and appearance were those of a prosperous country merchant was stricken with cerebral apoplexy at Thirty-thirdstreet and Broadway last night, and was taken to the New-York Hospital.

The Tammany Gas bill, introduced at Albany by Senator CULLEN, defender of the east side manure dumps, and supported by those eminent patriots and antimonopolists, GRADY and SPINOLA, has been ordered to a third reading in the Senate.

The graduating exercises of the Training School for Nurses were held last evening at the New-York Hospital. W.W. Hoppin, Jr., Chairman of the Conference Committee, read an abstract of the committee's report and presented the graduates with their diplomas and Philip Schuyler presented the badges.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 2.--Private advices received this morning say that a negro and his wife named Stephens, living 30 miles from Natchitoches, La., were killed last Wednesday night, being assassinated in their cabin. They were witnesses in a case of murder and arson soon to be tried, and it is believed their lives were taken to prevent damaging disclosures respecting certain persons in the neighborhood.
GLENWOOD, Minn., April 2.--The house of Joseph Hobel, in Reno, was burned by an incendiary yesterday and Hobel's 2-year-old daughter was burned to death.

Civil Justice Stockler decided yesterday that musical instruments are personal property of a kind that may be carried as baggage by a passenger traveling on a railway and need not be paid for as freight.
Mrs. Sallie J. Drew sent $25 to the Irish Parliamentary fund yesterday, the result of a collection among her neighbors at Rockland Lake.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 2.--At the last meeting of the Board of Directors of the Indiana State Prison South, at Jeffersonville, an old gray-haired, feeble-looking man came tottering into the Directors' room and asked to be permitted to spend the remainder of his life inside the prison.

John Gill, who for several years has been known to the United States Secret Service officers in this city, got into trouble on the 1st of April. He undertook to pass a counterfeit silver dollar in the saloon of John Hall, at No. 22 South-street.

UTICA, N.Y., April 2.--Fong Ah Yu, the young Chinaman of Montreal who was charged with the murder of Sing Lee, of Rome, in July, 1885, was convicted this afternoon of murder in the second degree. He will be sentenced on Monday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 2.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20 cents; drafts on New-York, telegraphic, 25 cents.

MALDEN, Mass., April 2.--Edward Aylesbury, 18 years old, of Everett, was arrested on Wednesday for lewd conduct. Last night, while in jail, he confessed to having set the fires which caused the partial demolition of the Belmont schoolhouse last Summer and endangered the lives of 350 pupils.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 2.--The question of cutting off the south end of Long Branch from Bath-avenue to Deal has not met, so far, with the approbation of the majority of the residents, as those who are seeking secession appear to have a private scheme of their own to further.

Another conference held yesterday afternoon between President Hazzard, of the Brooklyn City Railroad, and the Executive Committee of the Knights of Labor, resulted in an agreement that was satisfactory to both parties.

VINCENNES, Ind., April 2.--Samuel Archer, sentenced to be hanged July 9 for his many crimes, confessed in jail yesterday that the testimony of John Lynch against him was correct from beginning to end, and attributes the misfortunes and criminal actions of the Archer family to his uncle, Martin Archer, who, Sam said, seemed to enjoy killing people.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., April 2.--The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company is having a new route surveyed between Pittston and Fairview, to be used for coal and freight. The proposed route will follow close to the Lehigh and Susquehanna tracks, and between the two points the distance ...

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 2.--About 6 o'clock this morning a New-York Central locomotive struck and killed John Tierney, who was asleep in a buggy in the railroad tunnel just east of this city. How the horse and vehicle got into that difficult situation is not known.

The Tammany Hall Committee on Organization met last night in the wigwam and extended every facility to the ex-Aldermen who are members of that body and voted for the Broadway Railroad franchise to step gracefully down and out.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 2.--In the Superior Court this morning the will of the Rev. Hugh Carmody, formerly Roman Catholic Pastor of New-Britain, was probated on the consent of all the contestants after having been three years in the courts of this State.
MELBOURNE, April 2.--Beach, the sculler sailed to-day for England. He challenges any man in the world to row him on the Thames for the championship.

CHICAGO, April 2.--A special dispatch from San Francisco says: "The schooner J.H. Congdon was wrecked off Point Reyes, 40 miles north of here, yesterday. Her crew were lost. The coast there is of a dangerous character. The supposition was that the vessel had struck a hidden rock.

The New-York Conference continued in session yesterday at St. John's Methodist Church, in West Fifty-third-street. The morning was devoted to receiving the reports of the Presiding Elders. Dr. Gregory, of the New-York District, reported that during the year about $40,000 had been raised in that district for church building ...
CHICAGO, April 2.--A special dispatch from Sioux Falls, Dakota, says: "The developments in the silver discovery inside the city limits of Sioux Falls are increasing in importance.

CONCORD, N.H., April 2.--The Rev. William Hammond, of the Free-Will Baptist Church, of Franklin, fled on Thursday morning with $3,000 belonging to a newly wedded bride. He was arrested in a Boston bank as he was cashing a check and taken to Franklin.

City Works Commissioner Conner, of Brooklyn, who has created three new positions in his department to provide places for his son, his son-in-law, and a nephew, concluded yesterday that his pay roll was too extravagant.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 2.--William Postell, a young man well known in this city, was forcibly abducted Tuesday night by three men and led four miles into the country, where he was tied to a tree with his back to the tree.

The convict, Horace Lyons, alias Richmond, who disposed of Mrs. Schuyler Hamilton's silverware to Alderman Henry W. Jaehne, was yesterday taken away from Police Headquarters, and it was said that he had been removed to the Tombs, pending his production before the Senate committee.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 2.--The joint convention to select a site for the Soldiers' Home, under the law which took effect by publication yesterday, met this morning at 10 o'clock and balloted until 6 without result.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 2.--In the Senate to-day Gov. Hull was presented with a gold watch, Senator Casey (Democrat) making the address. Carson introduced a resolution citing Union Pacific unfairness toward Iowa, and protesting against the company being allowed to effect its proposed change in debentures. The House passed Robb's bill prohibiting aliens from owning real estate in Iowa.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 2.--Engineers from nearly every city in the Eastern and Middle States met here yesterday and organized the Council of Engineering Societies on National Works.
PORTLAND, Me., April 2.--Capt. William H. Bartol has been remiss in his duty to his family for some time, spending much of his time in the company of a handsome widow.

Although ex-Alderman Charles B. Waite had a most excellent bed upon which to rest his weary bones on Thursday night, he arose yesterday morning in a weary way and a troubled look overspread his expansive countenance.

Edward H. Goff, President of the American Electric Manufacturing Company, at No. 10 West Twenty-third-street, who has been fighting since December the efforts of the Canadian authorities to get him back within the Dominion, to stand trial for forgery, is under arrest.

WASHINGTON, April 2.--Senator Edmunds has ceased to wear the look of happy contentment which settled upon his face a week ago tonight, when it was announced that enough Republican Senators had followed his lead to secure the adoption of the resolutions attached by him to the Judiciary Committee's report on the Duskin case.

WASHINGTON, April 2.--Indian Commissioner Atkins was placed upon the witness stand when the telephone investigating committee met to-day. In response to the Chairman's invitation to tell what he knew of the Pan Electric Company, of which he was an original member.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 2.--The Ford murder case, which has sent already three men to he penitentiary for 20 years and broken the necks of two on the gallows, has not yet been wiped entirely from the criminal docket.

LIVERPOOL, April 2.--A leading weekly grain circular says: "Firmness prevails in the market and prices are gradually tending upward. Wheat in all branches is rather dearer. At to-day's market there was an average attendance. Wheat was firm; California and Indian wheats were 1d. dearer, the advance checking business. An advance was asked for flour; trade was quiet. Corn was in fair demand; prices favored buyers."

The agents of the stranded steamship Europa said yesterday that the vessel was still ashore at Quogue. The wreckers had not boarded her because of the high sea. It was hoped, however, that the vessel would be floated. There was some water in her hold, but she had not showed any signs of breaking up.

NASSAU, New-Providence, March 28.-- The United States Fish Commission steamer Albatross sailed for Key West on March 24. The naturalists on board secured many specimens of interest and value in the Bahamas. They were kindly entertained while here.

ALBANY, April 2.--After a long pull, a strong pull, and a pull altogether the Republican majority in the Assembly passed to-day the Capitol Appropriation bill as amended by the Senate. The Democratic minority undertook to obstruct its passage, but was finally compelled to succumb to the inevitable.
ALBANY, April 2.--Six of the Knights of Labor came to the Senate this morning and addressed themselves to Senator Plunkitt.

HARTFORD, CONN., April 2.--The Senate to-day made short work of the three bills most strongly opposed by the fire insurance companies, which were reported favorably by a majority of the Insurance Committee.

RUTLAND, Vt., April 2.--The underpinning of the central pier of the Gookins Falls bridge was washed away yesterday afternoon. Passengers on the Saratoga and other trains were transferred be carriages. Extra trains were run from Albany to the west side of the bridge, where the passengers for Rutland were transferred.

Sixty Alumni of the University of Michigan sat down to dinner at the Union-Square Hotel last night, and spent the entire evening in recalling college days and events and in listening to pleasant speeches. The number of Professors, doctors, and ministers present was very large, and those without titles to their names ...

The summary printed in THE TIMES yesterday of the memorable interview at John Kelly's house, at which the deal referred to by Alderman Waite in his published interview was arranged, gave the arrangement by which Alderman Kirk was made President of the board a new significance in the light of passing events.

The Symphony Society of New-York, prefaced by a public rehearsal, given at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon, this evening's final concert of the current season. Schumann's music to Byron's "Manfred" and Beethoven's Ninth Symphony were the works rehearsed, and they will be repeated to-night, and probably with increased impressiveness.

To doubt the opinions of free traders is to make one's self a subject of doubtful mental ability, ...

LONDON, April 2.--A great mass meeting was held this afternoon in Guildhall to protest against the granting of a Parliament to Ireland. The Lord Mayor presided. Sir John Lubbock, (Liberal,) member of Parliament for London University, moved the adoption of a resolution condemning Mr. Gladstone for his intention of "handing Ireland over to Mr. Parnell, whom he previously denounced."

LONDON, Ontario, April 2.--The wife of Nathan Griffith, of Westminster, cut her husband's throat with a razor while he was asleep this morning. Her mind became unbalanced by religious excitement. She says she wanted to kill her husband and go preaching.
HOUSTON, Texas, April 2.--Information reached here late to-night of the cold-blooded murder of Capt. Brown Harrison, a prominent citizen of Cook County, Texas, by a negro desperado named Hamp Butler.

Eager expectancy was upon the face of every one who attended last night's meeting of the Executive Committee of the County Democracy. The low ceilinged and stuffy little room at No. 1 Union-square was crowded with people who were anxious to see what the organization would do in reference to the Broadway Railroad Aldermen who are identified with the faction.

BOSTON, April 2.--Such strong opposition to the proposed cable street railway through Beacon-street has been shown that it is reported that the company has postponed its application for a location on this avenue.

OSWEGO, N.Y., April 2.--The schooner Speedwell, with barley, from Toronto, arrived here last evening, being the first arrival of the season. The first arrival last season was on May 6. The Speedwell reports the lake free of ice.

The Georgia State bonds, by the repudiation of which after the reconstruction period Northern and foreign investors were swindled out of enormous sums, are again the subject of litigation, and the case will come up for argument in the Court of Claims, at Washington, on Monday next.

DOVER, Del., April 2.--The fame of Dover as an important peach shipping point has departed. The Delaware Fruit Exchange is situated at Wyoming, three miles below, and to that station nearly all the growers who formerly shipped this fruit from Dover now carry their peaches. The Exchange attracted to it quite a number of buyers from New-York, Philadelphia, and the West, ...

WASHINGTON, April 2.--The opening game of the baseball season was played here today between the new League nine of this city and the Metropolitans, resulting in a victory for the visitors after a close contest.

BOSTON, April 2.--Franklin Sargent, of the New-York School of Acting, lectured this evening in Sanders's Theatre, Cambridge, before the Harvard Shakespeare Club. The theatre was well filled, among the audience being President Eliot, Prof. J.W. White, Dean Smith, and others of the Faculty.
The Wesleyan University Glee Club gave a concert last evening at Chickering Hall. An appreciative audience, which nearly filled the house, listened to the singing.
An Italian woman with bright, black eyes, dangled a child on her knees before Judge Lawrence in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday morning.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 3.--For the second time the Planters' Hotel records a horrible catastrophe. At 3:45 o'clock this morning, while the guests were asleep and the big hotel seemed wrapped in security, there was a cry of fire, and immediately after the few people in the street at that hour saw flames rising from the rear of the building.

METUCHEN, N.J., April 3.--Detectives from the Pinkerton agency recently effected, by the use of the "tramp dodge," the capture of a novice in burglary, who about three weeks ago stole $400 worth of clothing and jewelry from the cottage of William Lundy, in the outskirts of this village.
LONG BRANCH, April 3.--During the past week there have been further developments in regard to the robberies in this vicinity during the past three months.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 3.--Reports have been received from Labrador to the effect that the people living between Esquimau Point and Blanc Sablon are starving and keep themselves alive only by eating the flesh of dogs, 500 of which have been killed. It is feared, unless aid is rendered them, that from 100 to 150 of these people will die this spring from starvation.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 3.--The absorbing local question is the city election, which takes place on Monday. The Republican Mayor Bulkeley has been nominated by the largest attended caucus of the party ever held in Hartford.

William E. Sinclair, an assistant Treasurer of the Barnum show, is mysteriously missing, together with $6,500 in money. In the absence of the regular Treasurer the enterprising Mr. Sinclair filled his pockets and fled. He is believed to be over the border in Canada.

DETROIT, Mich., April 3.--The annual township elections throughout the State will occur on Monday, when Supervisors and other ordinary township officers are to be chosen. Never in the history of the State has there been such a go-as-you-please style on the part of the voters as characterizes them this Spring.

The Chapter of Hereford recently advertised for a bass voice for the cathedral choir. LANCASTER, Penn., April 3.--Simon F. Barr, night clerk at the Sprecher House, this city, met with an accident this morning that caused his death. As he was leaving the barroom of the Stevens House, between 10 and 11 o'clock, he fell down a long flight of steps, cutting his face badly.

CHICAGO, April 3.--A decree for $6,000 alimony was yesterday awarded to Mrs. Mary A. Woodworth against her husband, Dr. W. Woodworth, alias Dr. William F. Wood. Dr. Wood is President of the Beach Medical Institute, in Indianapolis.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 3.--Enoch S. Woods, the sculptor, has a mask of J.B. Lippincott, of Philadelphia, and will work it out. It has been viewed by several citizens and pronounced perfectly taken and worthy of excellent elaboration.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3.--Long before 8 o'clock to-night every seat in McCaull's Opera House was sold for the seventh performance of Dellinger's romantic opera comique "Don Caesar," which has made one of the greatest hits ever known in Philadelphia.

I was last week at an afternoon tea at the house of a blonde Cuban, who expects to be included in the household of the Princess Antonia de Montpensier, "when she becomes Queen of Spain." All her energy goes in adorning her own fair person and the shrine consecrated to it.
WASHINGTON, April 3--The Tariff bill that will be reported will be substantially the bill outlined in THE TIMES three or four weeks ago, so far as its tax rates are concerned.

CHICAGO, April 3.--George Scoville, the lawyer, whose divorced wife, Mrs. Frances M. Scoville, figured conspicuously as the sister of President Garfield's assassin, was locked up in the Cook County Jail yesterday in default of the payment of $15 alimony. Mr. Scoville would not ask any one to sign a bail bond for him.

CHICAGO, April 3.--East-bound shipments of flour, grain, and provisions over the pool lines from this city during the past 1 week amounted to but 22,842 tons, against 27,952 tons last week and 75,109 tons during the corresponding week last year. The shipments the past week were less than in any week during the past three years.

WASHINGTON, April 3.--In reporting back to the House the bill "To consolidate certain bureaus of the Department of the Navy," the Committee on Naval Affairs says that the present organization of the Navy Department is largely the creature of Executive orders and customs so long acquiesced in that they have almost the force of positive law.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 3.--The Faculty of Rutgers College held a long and stormy session to-day, and spent the time in discussing the cases of the students concerned in the mutilation and defacement of the college buildings last Wednesday and Thursday nights.

WASHINGTON, April 3.--The Metropolitans found no difficulty in winning their second game from the local League club to-day. Both teams presented their left hand pitchers, Cushman, of the Metropolitans, proving very effective, while Shaw, of the Nationals, was not only hit hard, but was very wild.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 3.--A few years ago the citizens surrendered by a popular vote all their right, title, and interest in and to Coasters' Harbor Island. The beneficiary was the United States Government, desiring the place for the establishment of a naval training station.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 3. --Intelligence from Pope County says intense excitement prevails caused by mad dogs. Numbers of persons have been bitten, and one or two cases of genuine hydrophobia are reported.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 3.--The Hendricks Monument Committee has extended the time for the local committees to report until May 1, so as to give additional time within which to solicit subscriptions. There is now about $12,000 in the general treasury, 75 per cent. of which is individual gifts and outside regularly organized committee work. Like all monument funds and movements this was biggest when it was born.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 3.--Mrs. Maria Dorsey, who with her husband and sister, Miss Burton, are charged with murdering her father, Benjamin J. Burton, gave birth to a son in jail last night.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 3.--Joseph McDonald, a brick yard employe at New Windsor, while in an intoxicated condition and walking on the track in this city Thursday night, was struck by a West Shore freight train and instantly killed. One hand and one foot were cut off, and his skull was fractured in three places. McDonald was 45 years of age and is supposed to have been unmarried.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 3.--Herman Leopold Herzog, dry goods merchants at No. 411 North Fourth-street, confessed judgment in the Circuit Court this morning for various amounts aggregating about $17,000. SELMA, Ala., April 3.--The river at this point has ceased to rise after rising two feet higher than at any time within the recollection of the oldest inhabitants. The destruction of property has been great all along the river and many lives have been lost.

RICHMOND, Va., April 3--The visit of the Seventh Regiment, N.G.S.N.Y., to this city on Apri1 26 is anticipated with exciting interest in military circles.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 3.--Yale University oarsmen always have big, healthy appetites, and it has generally been a difficult problem for the managers of the navy to secure them a caterer. Good rates were paid, but the men ate so much that there was no profit in boarding them.

QUINCY, Mass., April 3.--Suspicion has arisen that the death of Charles Magnusson, whose body was found in a quarry on Wednesday last, was caused not by accident, but by foul play. It transpired yesterday that on Monday Magnusson quarreled with a housemate named Holenberg, who, it is said, made threats to do him an injury. Magnusson disappeared that night.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., April 3.--Collector Oliver Kelly, of Perth Amboy, has discharged the duties of his office since his appointment in a manner satisfactory to the people of his district.

ELMIRA, N.Y., April 3.--The strike of miners at Arnot, Penn., was settled this morning, and the men have returned to work for 10 days. The managers have agreed in the meantime to meet committees of the miners and adjust the difficulty.

Columbia has won it three times and Princeton once. For the last six years, however, the cup has been won annually by Harvard.

Duffy, of De Soto, the lady who so gallantly held the mob at bay and saved the life of Yardmaster Tod, who was pursued by the infuriated crowd to her house, is receiving unstinted praise at the hands of the people of De Soto, who have determined to reward her brave act in a substantial manner.

Last evening Dr. John A. Broadus returned home from New-York after a successful effort for the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, in which he is a Professor. He is now, among religious people, and especially among Baptists, the hero of the hour.

SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Mexico, March 10.--We were nearing the end of a long half day's journey, begun on a fresh and frosty morning. The sun was near its noon. Earth and air were full of light, warmth, and midday silence. The chatter of birds and the multitudinous bleating of flocks were stilled.

The Senate committee, on the lookout for the money that Jacob Sharp paid the 1884 Aldermen for giving him his Broadway Railroad franchise, discovered a member of that memorable board yesterday who handled one-thousanddollar bills almost as freely as he passed drinks over the bar in his liquor saloon, and was particularly flush with them soon after the franchise was granted. This man was Alderman Patrick Farley.

BOSTON, April 3.--Justice Aldrich, of the Superior Court for Essex County, has set aside the verdict of $6,500 for plaintiff in the case of David T. Winter, against the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad, as being contrary to law and evidence. In this case Winter stepped on a train without taking a stop-over ticket, and on resuming his journey the conductor refused his punched ticket and put him off the cars.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 3.--Superintendent of Public Works Shanahan has sent requests to all officials along the State canals to arrange for the opening of the canals at the earliest period practicable for the public benefit, if possible by April 25. This will be governed by the opening of the lakes and straits. Considerable freight is held in vessels at Chicago awaiting the opening of the waterways.

The Grand Jury for March finished its work, and was discharged with thanks by Judge Cowing, in Part II. of the Court of Special Sessions, yesterday noon. No indictments in connection with the Broadway Railroad bribery were handed up.

PALERMO, March 10.--Few tourists in Italy visit Palermo. The visit involves a sea voyage of at least seventeen hours from Naples to Palermo, which ordinarily involves seventeen times as much seasickness as the passage of the British Channel.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 3.--Edward A. Donant, Jr., was nominated for Mayor by the Republicans to-day. He is a School Commissioner and ex-President of the Board of Trade.

The Treasury Department has approved the action of the Collector of Customs at New-York in refusing to accept in part payment of duties on importations trade dollars to the amount of $5 as in strict accordance with law.
The West Side Athletic Club added to its exchequer by a boxing and athletic exhibition in its rooms, No. 324 West Fifty-fourthstreet, last evening.

LONDON, April 3.--The annual university boat race between the Oxford and Cambridge crews was rowed this afternoon, over the usual course on the Thames River, from Putney to Mortlake, and resulted in a victory for Cambridge. The sky was cloudly, the weather mild, and the wind pretty strong at the start and during the race.

CINCINNATI, April 3.--George R. Topp, one of the recently appointed non-partisan Police Commissioners, at the first meeting of the board after organization, held last evening, voted against the confirmation of Arthur G. Moore, Mayor Smith's excellent appointee for Chief of Police.

The United Protective Salesmen's Union, which was organized a week ago as a branch of the Central Labor Union, with a membership of 200 salesmen in the boot and shoe business, has made substantial progress in its efforts to have the shoe stores closed on Sunday.

BOSTON, April 3.--The Rev. William Hammond, the Pastor of the Free Will Baptist Church of Franklin, N.H., who was arrested in this city for taking funds belonging to his wife, to whom he had been married but a few weeks, explained to the Inspector that she voluntarily made over all her property to him after their marriage, and that he had a right to do with it as he pleased.

The third meeting of the New-York Horticultural Society for this year will be held on Tuesday next in Nilsson Hall, Nos. 130 to 134 East Fifteenth-street. The usual exhibition of flowers and plants will be open from 2 to 10 P.M.

At 11 o'clock an engine, with 20 armed deputies, backed into the yard to take out a train of 20 cars when ready.

WASHINGTON, April 3.--Dr. Hamilton said this afternoon that while Secretary Manning was convalescing slowly, his condition today was virtually unchanged from yesterday. "I'm going away, soon," he said in conclusion," and you people must keep on going to church.

WATERBURY, Conn., April 3.--John T. Malone is taking Frederick Paulding's place as leading man in Margaret Mather's company through New-England. Last night the company gave "Leah" here.

ALBANY, April 5.--The Senate has ordered to a third reading the Murphy Gas bill, sometimes called the Thomas bill, from the fact of having been advocated by ex-Senator Thomas in behalf of the Gas Consumers' Association. DETROIT, Mich., April 5.--On Saturday, in the Probate Court, at East Saginaw, a petition for the revocation of the will of the late Jesse Hoyt, of New-York, was filled by Miss Hoyt, through Gen. Roger A. Pryor, of NewYork; Gen. Benjamin F. Butler, of Boston, and local attorneys.

Mayor Grace said yesterday that Corporation Counsel Lacombe had advised him that the law providing for the nomination of Excise Commissioners on the first Monday in April was directory and not mandatory in character.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--Second Lieut. B.M. Purssel, Signal Corps, has been ordered from Washington to Trustom Pond, R.I., Narragansett Pier, Newport, and Block Island under special instructions of the Chief Signal Officer. Capt. Frank Heath, Ordnance Department, has been ordered from Springfield to Hartford to inspect machine guns.

FORT WORTH, April 5.--In this time of peace, when our country is on friendly terms with all the outside world, the streets of our city swarm with armed soldiers, with loaded guns, called here by the lawless acts of our own citizens.

DURHAM, Penn., April 5.--Joseph R. Ainey, living near this place, committed suicide this morning by hanging himself with a halter in his barn. Financial troubles are supposed to be the cause of his action, although on Saturday he settled all of his business affairs and found himself to be worth $10,000.

The people of this city are willing to pay for gas a price that will yield dividends of 10 per cent. upon the capital actually invested by a gas company whose business is economically and honestly carried on.
BOSTON, Mass., April 5.--Margaret Murphy, living at the Highlands, died on Saturday from the effects of injuries resulting from a fall down stairs. She made, it is said, an ante-mortem ...

AUSTIN, Texas, April 5.--An officer of the local assembly of Knights of Labor makes a statement here to-day that two colored lodges of Knights have recently been organized among the laborers of the cotton districts on the Colorado River and its tributaries below this city.

BRIDGETON, N.J., April 5.--The 2-yearold son of Charles Stratton was burned to death this morning. The child had been left alone in the house and got hold of a box of parlor matches, which ignited. When discovered the room was full of smoke and the child so horribly burned that it died in a few minutes.

ALBANY, April 5.--The Rochester attorney who was appointed by Gov. Hill a Commissioner to report findings of fact in the case of the accused New-York Excise Commissioners, and to render that report on or about the time the term of the Commissioners should expire, lest a prior report might occasion them inconvenience, rendered a return to-day which has been a Chinese puzzle to the Governor and everybody else about the Executive Chamber.
OLEAN, April 5.--The Hon. Thomas Storrs, of this city, has received a registered letter which was sent from England, went down With the wreck of the steamship Oregon, and was subsequently recovered.
LONDON, Ontario, April 5.--Hanlan, on hearing of Beach's challenge to the world, sent the following cablegram to W.J. Innes, editor of the News of the World, London:

Fifty new member were initiated at a meeting of the Tammany Society last night. Among them were several prominent Democrats in the West and South, including Congressmen W.C. Maybury, Ezra C. Carleton, and Timothy E. Tarsney, of Michigan, and John H. Rogers, of Arkansas; William Dickson, Chairman ...

WASHINGTON, April 5.--Decisions were rendered in the Supreme Court to-day as follows: No. 180--Turpin Brother, plaintiffs in error, vs. Rush Burgess, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third District of Virginia.--In error to the Circuit Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.--The Supreme Court, Justice Bradley delivering the opinion, declared constitutional the exportation stamp required to be affixed to every package of tobacco intended for exportation before removal from the factory.
MONTREAL, April 5.--Moloney was sporting about town yesterday and spending money lavishly. He has gone into private lodgings and is now keeping very quiet. Keenan has not been seen.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 5.--John Cashman, a trackman living at East Hampton, Conn., was struck by the limited express on the Air Line Road near the Lyman Viaduct station this evening and instantly killed. He was 25 years old and leaves a widow and child.
BALTIMORE Md., April 5.--A letter from Capt. C.A. Todd, of the British steamship Sarah, from Baltimore to Galway, tells a strange story of the sea.
CHICAGO, April 5.--At a meeting to-day of the General Committee of Arrangements for the General Convention of the Episcopal Church to be held in October, Bishop McLaren ...

HARTFORD, Conn., April 5.--To-day Judge Birdsall, who was arrested Saturday night on a criminal charge of assault and mayhem on complaint of Mr. Fletcher, a newspaper correspondent, was before the police court, and the hearing was adjourned to Friday.

BOSTON, Mass, April 5.--This morning the 100 journeymen tailors who struck against the firms that refused to accede to the union's demand, together with all working members of the order who could get leave of absence, paraded the streets with music and banners bearing appropriate inscriptions.

A spirited and thoroughly enjoyable representation of Goldsmith's "She Stoops to Conquer" entertained a large audience at Wal lack's Theatre last evening. None of the old English comedies has been better acted here for a long while.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 5.--Chancellor Runyon has appointed the former managers of the Dime Savings Bank a committee to settle up its affairs. The appointment was made after a sworn statement of the Directors was received declaring the bank insolvent.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 5.--Edward Schermann, for whom the police have been looking on a charge of counterfeiting, walked into Police Headquarters last night and gave himself up.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 5.--The Board of Revenue of this county in a communication to Gov. O'Neill stated that large numbers of people would have to be maintained for an indefinite period and at public expense, and suggested that he memorialize Congresss for such relief as may be needed.
With the opening of fine weather the Bartholdi Statue Committee intend to begin work for the mounting of the massive figure of "Liberty."
DULUTH, Minn., April 5.--The Board of Trade announced to-day that the grain firm of Hooper, Crittenden Co. has suspended.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--Mr. Steele, of Indiana, will to-morrow report to the House a bill to promote the efficiency of the army, which has been prepared es a substitute for all other bills on the subject. As the provisions of the bill are fully set out in the accompanying report, the following synopsis of that document will sufficiently explain its scope.

Thirteen arrests for breach of the excise law, mostly of small dealers, resulted from a special effort of the Tombs police squad in the Seventh Ward on Sunday.

Livery stable keepers may now detain horses in their charge as a lien for board, according to a decision handed down yesterday in the case of Lessels Co. against George Farnsworth, in the General Term of the Court of Common Pleas. Farnsworth keeps a stable.
ATHENS, April 5.--The Minister of War has returned from a tour of inspection of the frontier defenses. He expressed his delight to the various commanders at the efficiency of the works.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 5.--Farmer John Devon, of Moodus, came to Middletown a day or two ago and brought $200 with him. He met two nice young men, drank with them, and awoke next morning in a vacant lot. His money was gone, and he has been looking for his two friends in vain ever since.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 5.--The Labor League, which took possession of the Democratic Convention, and nominated E.M. Graves for Mayor, met its Waterloo to-day.

RICHMOND, Va., April 5.--Gov. Lee this evening issued a proclamation, in accordance with the request contained in the joint resolutions adopted at the last session of the General Assembly, which resolutions declare that "the people of Virginia are determined that no settlement of the State debt shall ever be made ...

PHILADELPHIA, April 5.--In the United States Circuit Court, before Judges McKennan and Butler, argument was to-day heard upon the petition filed by counsel for the Clay Commercial Telephone Company, which asked ...
Charles A. Buddensiek writes to THE TIMES, denying that he owned, or had anything to do with the erection of the buildings in Sixtyfirst-street, which fell on April 1.

BOSTON, April 5.--The fourth attempt to cast the last of the large rifles for the Government was successfully made at the South Boston Iron Works to-day under the supervision of Lieut. Borup, of the army, and Lieut.Commander Lyon, of the navy.
HAVANA, April 5.--In the elections here yesterday, 15 members of the Constitutional Union and 5 of the Autonomist Party were elected Deputies. The result in the Province of St. Jago is not yet known.

Secretary Turner, of the Executive Committee of the Knights of Labor, having stated in St. Louis that Mr. Hoxie was not acting in conformity with the terms of the agreement entered into at the New-York conference, Mr. Gould yesterday said:

The lyrico-terpsichorean performance of the American Opera Company, including "Sylvia" and "The Wedding of Jeannette," was repeated at the Academy of Music yesterday evening.
PENSACOLA, Fla., April 5.--The movements of the naval squadron were postponed to-day on account of bad weather.
PHILADELPHIA, April 5.--Capt. Dexter, of the British bark Emma Payzant, which arrived at this port to-day from Dunkirk, reports that on March 28, in latitude 34 56' north, longitude ...
TOLEDO, Ohio, April 5.--Owing to the slow method of counting the votes made necessary by the new Pugsley law, it is impossible to say definitely to-night how the city has gone.
PETERSBURG, Va., April 5.--A murder has just been discovered in Brunswick County.

Two long sessions and some spicy discussions finally led up to a "coal combination" yesterday. The Presidents of the various coal companies met early in the day and staid together till late in the evening.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 5.--The printers in the Times-Union, Evening Herald, and Morning News offices struck to-night for an advance to 35 cents a thousand ems. The proprietors refused the advance, and have declared their offices non-union. They will publish half sheets to-morrow.
HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., April 5.--Notwithstanding the heavy storm which prevailed here throughout the day the large poll of 366 votes was made at the annual election for borough officers.

Charles F. Meyer, a middle-aged German, Who had been employed as a bookkeeper by Gustave Schirmer, a manufacturer of surgical instruments at No. 209 Centre-street, left the office of his employer at noon on Tuesday last to go to dinner.
Nearly 500 slips of cardboard, lettered as follows, were received through the mail last week by society people of musical proclivities more or less pronounced:
BOSTON, Mass., April 5.--The Pilot Chart of the North Atlantic for April, which has just been issued by the Hydrographic Office, ...

The outside cloak operators, having failed in obtaining concessions from the Manufacturers' Association, made terms with the contractors yesterday, and the four weeks' strike, which had dwindled through desertions to small proportions, came to an end.
John Murphy, a boatman, while on the wharf at the foot of West Forty-ninth-street at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, noticed a woman floating in the water at the head of the wharf.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 5.--Charles Butcher, a locally famous resident of Newtown, was found dead by the side of the Bridgeport turnpike half a mile below Newtown-street yesterday afternoon. Butcher's death was due to laudanum taken with suicidal intent. No cause is known for the deed.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 5.--Seventy-five persons are under a rigid quarantine in Union Village, North Manchester, for smallpox.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 5.--The Hasty Pudding theatricals which are to be given in New-York next week took place this evening at the clubrooms in Cambridge before a large number of graduates and active members of the club' who expressed themselves as greatly pleased with the performance.

BERLIN, Md., April 5.--This town, which is situated in Worcester County, about 15 or 20 miles north of Virginia, while not a very important fruit centre, affords an opportunity to study the extent of the damage wrought by the extreme cold of last Winter.

NEW-EGYPT, N.J., April 5.--Three weeks ago Jesse Higgins had his handsome young wife arrested on a charge of arson, accusing her of setting fire to the outbuildlags on his premises. Levi Challender furnished bail for her and aided her in numerous ways.

LONDON, April 5.--Mr. Gladstone's Home Rule bill will be submitted to the Cabinet to-day. The Conservatives are making strenuous efforts to form a coalition with the Whigs against Mr. Gladstone. Lord Salisbury had a conference with other Conservative leaders today, but no decision was reached relative to the course to be pursued on the Irish measures.

ALBANY, April 5.--Since the new freight rates on live stock went into effect on the railroads the cattle business at West Albany has shown a material increase. The receipts there in January were 18,972; in February 19,125; in March 21,825.

Mme. Judic entered upon a farewell engagement, to extend over a fortnight, at the Star Theatre last evening. "La Belle Helene" was given, and an audience of somewhat unusual proportions and of a very representative character witnessed the performance of the opera.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--Solicitor-General Goode appeared before the Telephonic Investigating Committee this afternoon to tell what he knew of the circumstances leading to the institution of the Memphis suit.

TRENTON, April 5.--In his last annual message Gov. Abbett adverted to the defiant attitude of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad on the question of railroad taxation and advised that the Legislature take steps to ascertain whether the Morris and Essex, which it leases, has returned its taxable property unfairly and so cheated the State in 20 years out of large sums.

The Down East fishermen have been "dead set" against, any renewal of recip rocal relations between this country and Canada an the subject of the fisheries. They have professed entire willingness to give up the privilege of fishing within the three-mile limit and to fall back on the protection afforded by the treaty of 1818, provided the duty on Canadian fish is maintained.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 5.--Capt. Scott, of the steamer Lansdowne, will commence to-day to select sailing cruisers for the protection of the fisheries.

The Panama Railroad Company held its annual meeting yesterday, re-elected its old Board of Directors with one exception, and issued the annual report. J. Hood Wright is the new Director, succeeding E.P. Fabbri, who retires because of poor health.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday unanimously adopted a resolution denouncing the Bruns bill extending the powers of Commissioner Rollin Macbeth Squire, which he tried to have rushed through the Legislature.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 5.--The municipal election today was held under two laws of recent enactment, one providing for the appointment of judges and clerks of election by a non-partisan board selected by the Governor and the other ...

BOSTON, April 5.--At the annual meeting of the Mexican Central stockholders to-day the old Board of Directors was re-elected with the exception of Charles C. Blodgett, resigned, in whose plane Charles F. Lonergan, of Mexico, was chosen.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 5.--Sodergist Victor. Theodore Hortensen, Martin Henson, and Claus Jordensen, of the crew of the Swedish bark Halder, were arrested to-day on the charge of mutiny near the Delaware Capes and assault on Capt. Lovold.
There was a mass meeting of 1,500 barbers and some of their employers at Concordia Hall, No. 28 Avenue A, last night, under the management of the Journeyman Barbers' Protective Union No. 1.

A meeting of east side retail dealers who favor closing at 6 o'clock and Saturday half holidays was held last evening at the store of Coogan Brothers, at Grand-street and the Bowery.
In spite of the storm last evening there was a large audience at the Madison-Square Garden to see the entertainment offered by the Barnum show.

The new Massachusetts Liquor Dealers' Protective Association is not a passing story peculiar to the first day of April, but a bonafide organization, whose power for securing protection, the leaders say, will be felt when the proper time arrives.
ERIE, Penn., April 5.--This morning Thomas Lattimer, a young business man of Waterford, this city, was fatally poisoned through what was intended as a kindness on the part of a neighbor.
The miscellaneous entertainment gotten up by Mr. Courtice Pounds at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon was very largely attended.

CHICAGO, April 5.--Local labor organizations, both inside and out of the Knights of Labor, are greatly excited over what they believe to have been a scheme of Gould and Hoxie to entrap the Executive Board of the order into stealing private dispatches passing between the two men named, and a ...

The attaches of the District Attorney's office had an easy time of it yesterday. Bribe takers and bribe givers might have walked in and out of the office at their own sweet will. None of them was arrested.
BALTIMORE, Md., April 5.--Shortly after the failure of Painter, Tongue Co., the Trustee made sale of the stock on band, to which the creditors in New-York, Philadelphia, and ...

INDIANAPOLIS, April 5.--At the township election here to-day the Republicans elect their entire ticket by a majority that will not be far from 1,000 and may go above that figure. Two years ago the Democratic candidate had a majority of 991.
ST. LOUIS, April 5.--It has been decided by the head of the Knights of Labor that upon the result of the great railroad strike in the Southwest depends the welfare of the order.
Contrary to expectation a very lively opposition was developed at the annual election of the St. Nicholas Club last evening.
Mr. George Riddle read Mr. Edgar Fawcett's tragedy called "Arnold and Andre" before a small audience in the University Club Theatre yesterday afternoon.
Mayor Grace yesterday nominated William S. Andrews, John Von Glahn, and Charles H. woodman as Excise Commissioners, and sent their names to the Board of Aldermen for confirmation.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 6.--The police say that the Second Ward in this city is flooded with counterfeit ten-cent pieces, and that they have proof that a relative of Edward Schirmann, now in jail on the charge of making counterfeit money, was detected in passing one at a store on Union-street.

NEW-HAVEN, April 6.--Mrs. Daniel Hurd, a colored woman of middle age, living at No. 69 Webster-street, made an unpleasant discovery to-day. Up to within two weeks she had living with her three daughters, one of them named Hattie, 15 years old, who was inclined to be wayward.

It was decided by the Bar Association at its meeting last night that the Legislature should be advised to pass the bills prepared by the Land Transfer Commissioners who are in favor of indexing, according to the lots marked on the tax maps of the city, every incumbrance in the form of judgment, mechanic's lien, ...

The soloist at the twenty-third Thomas Popular Concert in the Academy of Music, last evening, was Mme. Pauline L'Allemand, of the American Opera. With very good judgment Mme. L'Allemand did not depart from the realms of operatic music, in which she has during the season now approaching its close demonstrated that she is well fitted to hold a most estimable ...

LA CROSSE, Wis., April 6.--One of the most disastrous conflagrations that ever visited La Crosse broke out at 10 o'clock this morning in John Paul's mill, and swept southward, destroying the mill and several thousand feet of lumber belonging to Mr. Paul. Thence it swept to the yards and mill of C.L. Colman, destroying everything to the river and for two blocks south.

The election in Flatbush yesterday for Justice of the Peace resulted in the re-election of Joseph F. Curran, Democrat, by a majority of 3 in a total vote of 657. His opponent was Charles W. Jennings, Republican.

DENVER, Col., April 6.--All the hightoned colored people of this city are greatly stirred up over a sensational shooting affray which occurred in the backyard of the Zion Baptist Church yesterday afternoon, and in which the Pastor of the church wounded James Hawkins in the foot.

TRENTON, April 6.--A large committee of prominent citizens and bondholders of Elizabeth appeared before the Committee of the House on Municipal Corporations this afternoon, among them Mayor Greer, City Attorney Bergen, ...

PHILADELPHIA, April 6.--James A. Herne's comedy-drama, entitled "Herne's Minute Men," was produced for the first time tonight at the Chestnut-Street Theatre, with beautiful scenery and an excellent cast. The author and company were twice called before the curtain, and Mr. Herne made a neat speech of thanks in acknowledgment of the flattering reception accorded the play.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 6.--The Keystone Coal Company, a new organization of capitalists, filed its charter in the Recorder's office here to-day.
MELBOURNE, April 6.--Public meetings have been held in Sandhurst, Geelong, and Ballarat to protest against France being allowed to annex the New-Hebrides.
BOSTON, April 6.--The Advertiser will publish a significant editorial article in the morning on the next United States Senatorship from Massachusetts.

CHICAGO, April 6.--Eighteen of the 36 members of the City Council of Chicago were elected to-day, and Assessors and several other town officers were chosen. The result is a Republican victory, which takes the control of the Council away from the Democratic gang.
Officer Edward O'Brien, of the Sixth Police Precinct, yesterday arraigned William F. Guyner, of No. 299 First-avenue, and Michael Cavanagh, of No. 335 East Thirty-fifth-street, in ...

An exhibition of athletic sports in allround competition was given under the auspices of the Lenox Club, in Turn Hall, No. 68 East Fourth-street, last evening. About 200 spectators were present, most of them being members of various athletic clubs in this city and Brooklyn. P.J. Donohue acted as master of ceremonies.

The Donskoi wool cases, which have led to disagreement between New-York merchants and the customs officers, are now in a fair way toward settlement. Collector Hedden sent to washington yesterday his decision in 81 of the 100 cases in dispute.

The Senate Committee on Education and Labor at a special meeting this morning ordered a favorable report on the Arbitration bill without amendments. Senator Blair, in reporting it to the Senate, gave notice that he would call it up at the first opportunity. He privately expresses a hope to find the opportunity before the end of the week.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--The Post Office Appropriation bill was passed this afternoon without a division, and it goes to the Senate just as Mr. Blount and his committee, or a large majority of them, reported it. Debate on the bill has drawn some fire upon Postmaster-General Vilas, but it was feeble and ineffectual.
GUAYMAS, Mexico, April 6.--The steamer Altata, which has arrived here, brings news of a great anti-Chinese demonstration, ending in a riot, which occurred at Mazatian on March 28.

Joseph Heldman, a machinist, of No. 170 Elm-street, was tried in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday on a charge of shooting at Mary Ellbrow and hitting Ernest Hinger, a bartender, of No. 154 Grand-street.

One of the most interesting of the war features of the Century is printed in the April number. This is an account of the cruise and sinking of the Alabama. Since the Monitor and Merrimac fight was described nothing quite so interesting as this has appeared.
The Directors of the Jersey Central Railroad Company met yesterday to consider the decree of the court about taking their property out of the hands of the Reading Company.

CHICAGO, April 6.--Representatives of the railroads which were members of the Northwestern Traffic Association, together with representatives of Wisconsin Central and the St. Paul and Duluth, to-day succeeded in patching up a truce in the rate war, which is, however, subject to the approval or the Illinois ...
SULPHUR SPRINGS, April 6.--The Farmer's Alliance, of Hopkins County, at their meeting to-day, passed the following resolution by a unanimous vote:

The old suit of Collis P. Huntington against Henry Y. Attrill and William K. Soutter for $99,068, the balance of a loan of $100,000 made to the defendants to construct the big hotel at Rockaway Beach, came up for trial yesterday in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn.

CINCINNATI, April 6.--The Fidelity National Bank, holding $13,688 40 of hypothecated Baltimore Union Passenger Street Railway stock, which has been called in, yesterday telephoned the Third National Bank, the Cincinnati agent of the Baltimore Company, to ask whether the stock would be taken up if presented.
FORT BOWIE, Arizona, April 6.--Sheriff Slatch, of Cochise County, Arizona, came here a few days ago with a warrant for Geronimo and 41 "John Does." Gen. Crook told him to make his demand in writing.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6.--To-night a large public meeting was held here to aid in building the Augusta and Chattanooga Air Line Railroad. This line is to be 240 miles in length, and will pass through the richest farming and mining section of Georgia.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 6.--The weather to-day was fine, and the North Atlantic squadron commenced the drill at sea off Santa Rosa Island at 8 o'clock. The exercises included practice with shot and shell from the great gun, steam tactics, and torpedo practice. The Brooklyn's firing was especially good.

PITTSBURG, April 6.--The storm, which set in yesterday morning, continues to-day. Rain and snow have fallen without interruption for 24 hours. Telegraphic communication East and West is much retarded, the sleet breaking down the wires. On the middle division of the Pennsylvania Railroad 40 telegraph poles are down between Everett and McConnellsburg.
ELIZABETH, N.J., April 6.--Some time ago the Law and Order people hired a detective from New-York to come out to Elizabeth and obtain evidence against liquor dealers who were selling on Sunday.

HARRISONBURG, Va., April 6.--After two days' preliminary trial the counsel for S.R. Sterling, the defaulting County Treasurer, waived further examination, and the prisoner was to-day bailed in the sum of $10,000 for his appearence before the Grand Jury at the April term of the County Court.

The Rev. Dr. Reese F. Alsop, Rector of Grace Church, Philadelphia, has accepted the call to St. Ann's Church, Brooklyn, and will preach his first sermon in his new parish on Sunday, May 2. Dr. Alsop succeeds the venerable Archdeacon Kirby, who goes to his old church at Fernandina, Florida.

SPRING PLACE, Ga., April 6.--Mr. B.C. Coyle, an old and respected citizen of Dalton, who has been working in the gold mines upon Cohutta Mountain, in Murray County, was recently taken at night by 12 masked men and severely beaten.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 6.--The students of Rutgers College listened to a halfhour speech by President Gates this morning in the chapel on the subject of the recent troubles in the institution. Resolutions of the Faculty were read announcing that in future any combinations ...

L. Colmeyer, a cabin passenger on the steamship Niagara, from Havana, which arrived at Quarantine Monday night, disappeared mysteriously yesterday morning, and it is supposed that he committed suicide by jumping overboard.

Gen. Alexander Shaler was in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday only a few minutes. His retrial on a charge of accepting bribes while a member of the Armory Commission was to have taken place there.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--The Senate received from the President to-day a long message transmitting correspondence between the Secretary of State and the Chinese Minister with regard to the treaty rights of Chinese subjects other than laborers "to go and come of their own free will and accord." The President says cases of individual hardship beyond the power of the Executive to remedy have occurred ...

BOSTON, April 6.--Judge Carpenter, in the United States Circuit Court, to-day rendered an opinion of interest to insurance people. The ruling was made in advance of the trial of several important cases, the one in point being that of James. E. Crossley against the Connecticut Fire Insurance Company.

QUOGUE, Long Island, April 6.--An examination of the steamship Europa was made yesterday. Capt. Bishop, of the wrecking company, found the forward part of the vessel free of water, but she is full aft. A heavy storm is now raging and immense breakers are dashing over the steamer. It is feared she will be badly damaged if the storm continues.

RICHMOND, Vs., April 6.--Last week E. G. Jones, a commercial traveler from Philadelphia, who had offered to pay his license tax with State coupons, which were refused, was arrested for selling goods without a license.

Col. Emmons Clark, Quartermaster John F. Long, and Adjt. George W. Rand, of the Seventh Regiment, will go to Washington to-morrow to complete arrangements for the visit of the regiment to the national capital.
The committee chosen by the New-York Conference to consider the labor question made its report at the session yesterday morning at St. John's Church, in West Fifty-third street.

TRENTON, N.J., April 6.--The trial of the impeachment of State Prison Keeper Laverty was continued before the Senate to-day. Miss Borrow, who has been a day matron of the prison for a dozen years past, have some important testimony for the defense.

OWENSBOROUGH, Ky., April 6.--The steamship Mountain Boy was turned over in a gale at this place at 2 o'clock this morning. Frank Absher, a watchman; Scott Lowery, a roustabout, and William Stateler, a passenger, were drowned. The other persons aboard the vessel, 14 in number were saved.

The storm that has caused a continuous spread of umbrellas for three days was a product of the Gulf, and it followed the coast in its journey. Yesterday morning the centre of it was at Atlantic City, and it gave notice of its intention to take a journey off shore to the northeast.

GALENA, Ill, April 6.--The dry goods house of J.M. Spratt Co., proprietors of the St. Louis store, one of the largest and oldest in Galena, was closed by the Sheriff yesterday on a warrant of attachment at the instance of the Galena National Bank, a judgment creditor for $7,500.

DENVER, Ind., April 6.--A.N. Lawrence challenged Fled Site at the polls yesterday. Site turned, stabbed Lawrence four times with a pocket knife, and fled. Lawrence will die. Site has not yet been captured.

Elbridge T. Gerry, President of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, states in a letter to THE TIMES that the presentment of the Grand Jury last Friday in regard to the Ramscar Unsectarian Home was not made at the instance of the society or as the result of any complaint preferred by it.

The annual concert given by the pupils of Mme. de Wilhorst-Raucourt may be attended at Chickering Hall this evening. To-morrow night Lotta will present to her admirers at the Grand Opera House a new farcical piece by Mrs. Charles A. Doremus called "Larks."

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 6.--In a quarrel at the Elba Iron and Bolt Works this afternoon between two workmen named Hanlon and Woods, Hanlon struck Woods over the head with an iron bar, crushing the skull and inflicting fatal injuries. Hanlon has been arrested.

NORFOLK, Va., April 6.--The American bark May Queen, of Baltimore, which went ashore at Little Island, N.C., Saturday night, is now breaking up. Cocoanuts, which made up her oargo, now line the beach for miles.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April. 6.--His Excellency Chang Yen Hoon, the new Chinese Ambassador to the United States, accompanied by 20 attendants, arrived here from Hong-Kong today on the steamer Gaelic. He will remain here one week, and then go direct to Washington. Capt. S.M. Mills, of the United States Army, late disbursing officer in the Signal Service, was also among the arrivals.

A number of the officers of the Swedish corvette Balder, now lying in the North River off Twenty-third-street, came ashore on Thursday evening last to attend a Swedish festival in this city. On their return, at midnight, to the West Twenty-third-street dock, the officers hired a boat to take them to their ship.

LANCASTER, Penn., April 6.--Philip Wolf, a well-to-do pretzel baker, shot himself fatally at 8 o'clock this morning at his home in West King-street, this city. For some time past Wolf and his son John, a young man about 20 years of age, have been unable to agree, and this morning they had another difficulty.

The annual town elections in Queens and Suffolk Counties were held yesterday. The severe storm made some of the roads impassable and many of the voters did not go to the polls. The vote was therefore light.
