CLINTON, Mass., April 6.--The Bigelow carpet mills having used up the material on hand substantially shut down this forenoon in consequence of the dyers' strike. As the mills are making no attempt to hire new help the question is simply one of endurance.

LONDON, April 6.--The Cabinet met at noon to-day and remained in session until 2 o'clock. Mr. Gladstone laid before the Ministers his Irish home rule scheme. It is reported that the discussion which followed resulted in continuing the Ministerial opposition to certain features of the Premier's proposals.

Yesterday's orchestral matinee at the Brooklyn Academy of Music brought the series of entertainments given during the concert season under the above title to a close. EAU CLAIRE, Wis., April 7.--Four miles from here, in a log cabin in the brush, Mrs. Lars Gindahl, aged 37 years, gave birth on Sunday to four male babies, weighing 20 pounds in all, each alive, bright eyed, and healthy. NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 10.--Leopold Putzel is a shoe dealer who has a store at No. 463 State-street. He also has a tenant, who pays no rent and rules one part of the premises so thoroughly that Putzel has been trying to evict him for weeks without the slightest success.
The tenth annual bench show of dogs, to be given under the auspices of the Westminster Kennel Club, will be held at Madison-Square Garden on May 4, 5, 6, and 7.

President Simmons, of the Stock Exchange, sails for a tour through Europe on June 5. He will be away all Summer. Members of the Governing Committee of the Exchange will give him a banquet before he leaves.

HUNTSVILLE, Texas, April 10.--On Wednesday evening last Mrs. William H. Roe, a prominent and highly respected lady of this city, while seated at table was seized with convulsions and died in a few moments. The Coroner held a secret investigation and many witnesses were examined.
Plucky little Mrs. Gray did more business at her bakery, at No. 508 Hudson-street, yesterday than she has ever done in one day since the bakery was established.
The last Philharmonio concert of the current season--the forty-fourth of the existence of the society--took place at the Academy of Music last evening.

The Emperor has contributed a thousand marks toward the monument which the Geographical Society intends to erect at Cape Palmas in memory of Dr. Nachtigal, the celebrated African traveler. The imperial gift was accompanied by a letter speaking highly of the merits of Dr. Nachtigal, with whom the Emperor was well acquainted.

BEAVER FALLS, Penn., April 10.--This week a series of experiments have been made with natural gas in the puddling and heating furnaces of the Beaver Falls Iron Company, which it is claimed by those who have been conducting the experiments demonstrated as an actual fact that which has heretofore been deemed an impossibility.

Prof. Billroth, of Vienna, accompanied by one of his assistants, recently went to Alexandria, Egypt, to perform an operation upon the person of a rich banker there. For the expenses incurred and his services he was to receive the sum of 25,000f.

MEADOWVALE, Ontario, April 10.--A Canadian Pacific freight train heavily loaded with timber ran into the rear of another train loaded with ties at the station here to-day. The ties and timber were piled up to a great height. One engine and 14 cars were badly damaged. The train hands jumped from the trains and escaped unhurt. The loss is heavy.
The New-Jersey Legislature has just passed a bill establishing a State charities aid association similar to that now existing in this State. Morris County has a charities aid association of its own.

He is mistaken. There may be some question about its being a nuisance, but it is tolerated in this city without any audible protest.

HAWK'S NEST, West Va., April 10.--A terrible accident, involving the loss of three lives and the narrow escape of two other persons, occurred at the hamlet of Sunnyside, a few miles above here, on the New River, this morning.
CHICAGO, April 10.--The Chicago and Northwestern and Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Roads to-day met the 8 and 10 cent rates on the various classes of freight from Chicago to St. Paul.

RICHMOND, Va., April 10.--The first elections under the local option law passed by the last Legislature took place today at Floyd Court House and Wytheville. At the first named place the "dry" movement was defeated by a vote of four to one in favor of granting license to sell liquor, while in the latter place the "dry" men were victorious by a small majority, and consequently no license will be issued in that town.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 10.--The Police Department has been engaged quietly for the last few days in working up evidence with a view of prosecuting a number of persons known to have voted illegally at the municipal election last Tuesday.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 10.--The third session of the Wyoming Conference today was largely attended. Bishop Mallalieu presided.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 10.--The body of William H. Murray, a married man of middle age, was taken from the Hudson River this morning, a mile above Fishkill, and removed to that place. INDIANAPOLIS, April 10.--Superintendent Beach, of the Central Union Telephone Company, has ordered managers of Exchanges in the smaller cities of Indiana to notify patrons that the Exchanges will continue to be operated as usual, and at the rates prescribed by law--$3 per month, and $2 50 per month where two instruments are rented by one party.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 10.--Charles B. Thayer, who started this morning, by way of New-Haven, for the Pacific slope, on a bicycle, is a brother of Mrs. McCray, author of "Wheels and Whims." Mrs. McCray's experience was on a tricycle. Thayer will take the Erie Canal towpath to Buffalo. He will cross the Mississippi at Rock Island. He will return in the Fall. Unlike most wheelmen, he carries his goods in a knapsack on his back.

BRUSSELS, April 10.--The Government has ordered the residences of all known Anarchists living within the kingdom to be thoroughly searched for the purpose of procuring incriminating evidence against them. The authorities have resolved to act with all possible vigor in the work of stamping Socialism out of the country.

LOWELL, Mass., April 11.--The body of Patrick Harrington was found in the woods at Westford this afternoon.
MACOMB, Ill., April 11.--It is announced that the First National Bank of this city will at once relinquish its charter and retire from business.

Brother Similian, Treasurer of Manhattan College, at One Hundred and Thirty-firststreet and the Boulevard, died Saturday night, at the age of 59 years. He had been Treasurer of the college since its organization.

LONDON, April.--Mr. Charles Russell, Attorney-General, will reply to Lord Randolph Churchill in the House of Commons to-morrow, and it is expected that Messrs. Goschen, Childers, Cowen, and Bright will follow.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., April 11.--Detective Smith, of this place, to-day arrested a man whom he recognized as John Wilcox, supposed to be one of the men connected with the murder of the Kister brothers at Seybertville, Luzerne County, in October last.

John Zorambisky was fatally stabbed at Winfield. Long Island, yesterday, by John and Frank Machkosky, two brothers. All are Poles, and are employed as laborers on the Long Island Railroad. The stabbing was the result of a long-standing quarrel. The weapons used here a pair of scissors and a penknife. Zorambisky received 17 wounds in the body. The murderers are in hiding.

BOSTON, Mass., April 11.--John O. Patten, of Bath, Me., managing editor of the Post since H.H. Nelson's retirement, has resigned. A number of reporters were discharged last night, also the recently engaged special correspondents in the United States and Canada. Eight men now complete the local force.

ERIE, Penn., April 13.--A distressing case of suffocation from gas was discovered to-day. On Sunday night Charles and Annie Rooney, a recently wedded couple, retired, and nothing more was seen or heard of them until to-day, when the silence of their rooms suggested an investigation. Rooney was found alive, but violently insane, and his wife was living, but died soon after the discovery. A leaky stove was the cause of the trouble.

A petition for the probate of the will of Richard Arnold, of the firm of Arnold, Constable Co., was filed in the Surrogate's Court yesterday by Townsend Wandell, Mr. Arnold's counsel.

The journeymen harness makers of Newark, to the number of about 700, went on strike yesterday morning. The Principal houses whose men went out were the Peters Calhoun Company, N.J.Demarest Co., and E.F.Beck Son.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April l3.--President Noah Porter, of Yale College, and Mrs. Porter celebrated their golden wedding this afternoon at their home on Hillhouse-avenue. Only relatives and old and intimate friends of the family were present.

ST. LOUIS, April 13.-The General Executive Board of the Knights of Labor has learned that its opponents are both powerful and energetic, and that its organization does not combine all the labor of the country.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18.--John Welsh was buried to-day at Laurel Hill, after the celebration of the Episcopal service for the dead in St. Peter's Church, where he had been a vestry man for more than half a century. The funeral was conducted with the utmost simplicity, though the scene at the church was made striking by the presence of a Large body of Philadelphia's representatives in every walk of life.
ALEXANDRIA, April 13.-An emissary is believed to have left Khartoum for Cairo With a proposal of peace from El Mahdi's successor.
The thirty-fourth annual Commencement of the New-York Ophthalmic College occurred last evening in the college building, Third-avenue and Twenty-third-street.

The Kings County Republican General Committee made another effort, last evening, to get together two-thirds of its membership in order to adopt the proposed changes in the bylaws, and made another failure.

Very much lower prices were obtained at the opening of the sale of the second portion of the Charles F. Haseltine collection of paintings last evening, as compared with those of a few weeks ago. Seventy pictures were sold by Auctioneer William P. Moore for $28,840.

Holloway, of the grain commission firm doing business as Holloway Brothers, at No. 14 Exchange Building, which suspended on Monday, were arraigned before Magistrate Durham to-day on complaint of E. A. Hancock, on a charge of fraudulently assigning grain with intent to defraud their creditors.
NEWBURG,N.Y., April 13.--The case of Margaret Shiner against the West Shore Railroad Company was tried before Judge Brown at Newburg yesterday afternoon.

When James Johnston was dismissed from the Custom House a few days ago Collector Hedden announced that it was for "offensive partisanship." Mr.Johnston said yesterday that the Collector had assigned no reason to him for the discharge.

LOUISVILLE, April 13.-A gentleman just from Bell County gives the particulars of three sensational murders which occurred in that county within the past week. Elihu Saylor had married a sister of William Shell. The couple had quarreled, and the woman, tired of his abuse, deserted him.

Mme. Judic will act in " Divorcons" at the Star Theatre this evening. "Lakme" will have its final representation at the Academy of Music to-night. Just three years have gone by since the opera had its first hearing at the Opera Comique in Paris.

WASHINGTON, April 13.--Two reports by the minority of the Judiciary Committee upon the resolution submitted to that committee inquiring into the power of the Government to institute suit at the instance of private corporations to annul patents were presented to the House to-day.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 13.--A special dispatch from Merrillan, Wis., announces the burning of the Oriental Hotel and several adjoining, buildings this morning. The charred remains of Bert Aldrich, aged 18, a guest at the hotel, have been removed from the debris. It Is believed that all the other occupants of the hotel escaped. Loss on property, $8,000; insurance, not stated.

The grocery man at Hudson and Tenth streets got hungry yesterday afternoon. Hatless and coatless he trotted down Hudson-street to Mrs. Gray's bakery. He bought a big roll, and trotted back to his store.
Mr. Visscher Ten Eyck, of Albany, who died at the Gilsey House in this city early yesterday morning, was long prominent as a public and private citizen in his native town.

Walters, on Mount Vernon-plaec. The party will spend several days here.

WASHINGTON, April 14.--Mr. Van Benthuysen again took the stand when the telephone investigat ing committee met to-day. He produced a copy of the record used in the New-Orleans suit, to show, as he said, that the insinuations that he had used a facsimile of the record of the Interior Department proceedings was not true.
ST. PAUL, Minn., April 14.--Late this afternoon the Manitoba Railroad Company received a dispatch from St. Cloud stating that a terrible cyclone had struck that place, and asking that help be sent.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14.--One of the most largely attended and noticeable social events of the season was the reception to-night at the residence of Theodore Engel, the millionaire brewer, in honor of the wedding of his daughter, Miss. Josephine Engel, to Aaron Graef, of New-York.

MONTREAL, April 14.--The authorities here have begun a crusade against the nude in art. Action is to be taken against one of the wealthiest gentlemen in the city for keeping in his house copies of the Venus of Milo, the Venus di Medicl, Canova's Venus, Powers's Greek Slave, the Laocoon, and other works.
CHICAGO, April 17.--A few days ago a county official visited a broker's office for the purpose of cashing a quantity of county scrip issued in March last and amounting to several hundred dollars.

The full returns of the local election in Jersey City show a majority for Cleveland, Democrat, for Mayor, of 1,075. The new Police Board, which now is Republican, will be evenly divided; the Fire Board, now Republican, will be Democratic, and the Board of Works, now a tie, will be Democratic.

The congratulations sent by the Porte to Russia on the upshot of the Roumelian troubles certainly have a basis of fact to justify their display of courtesy. In forcing Prince ALEXANDER to content himself with a five years' Governorship of Eastern Roumelia instead of a life tenure the Czar gained a sorely needed triumph.

BOSTON, Mass., April 14.--A Newport special to the Herald states that Edwin Booth has telegraphed his agent not to sell his place as advertised, as he will occupy it this Summer. It is believed that the illness of Mr. Booth's daughter, Mrs. Grosman, occasioned the change in his plans.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 14.--During the storm of yesterday afternoon the barn and bay house of Ross Innis, six miles west of Newburg, were struck by lightning and burned with their contents. Lightning also struck a large house two miles below Garrisons, on the bank of the Hudson and it was destroyed by fire.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., April 14.--J.L. Biggs, a clerk in the Auditor's office of the Lake Erie and Western Railroad, was arrested to-day, charged with stealing $5,000 to $10,000 worth of railroad tickets.

EATONTOWN, N.J., April 14.--Johnson and Dangler, who have been under arrest and in the county jail for two-weeks charged with complicity in the Mingo Jack lynching case, were relesed to-day. There was much rejoicing here this evening, and bonfires were burned in the public square and other places. John Syckles, also charged with being one of the lynching party, was arrested last night.

The steamship Britannic, of the White Star Line, which recently put back to Liverpool with her crank shaft broken, arrived here yesterday after a stormy passage. She encountered, a series of violent westerly gales, which set in on April 5, shortly after Queenstown had been passed, and continued until the night of April 11. The steamship Richmond Hill, from, London, also met with very rough weather.

TRENTON, N.J., April 14.--The Laverty impeachment trial is drawing to a close. The respondent occupied the stand all of to-day.

TORONTO, Ontario, April 14.--The subscription list for the $20,000,000 Canadian Pacific Railway bonds closed in London, England, Tuesday. This was quite unexpected, and was a day earlier than first announced. It is reported that the applications reached $30,000,000.

There was a quarrel on Tuesday night in Arthur Upshur's colored sailors' boarding house, No. 42 Baxter-street, between Arnold Watson, his express wagon driver, and Louis Joie, the cook, over some trifling matter.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14.--Gen. James A. Beaver will be elected Governor of Pennsylvania by a majority ranging from 40,000 upward, always provided the labor vote is not alienated from the Republican Party between now and election day in November next.

The death at Niagara Falls, on Tuesday, of John Humphrey Noyes brings conspicuously before the public, probably for the last time, one of the most curious of the Socialistic experiments for which the first half of this century is noted, the Oneida Community of Perfectionists, which Noyes founded, and which, so long as he was able to manage it, maintained a wonderful degree of material prosperity and vitality.
DETROIT, Mich., April 14.--The report of the Rev. Dr. Charles O'Reilly, Treasurer of the Irish National League of Americn, for the four weeks ending April 10 has been made public.

ST. LOUIS, April 14.--An outrage of a peculiarly venomous character was perpetrated in East St. Louis at a nearly hour this morning. Bart Fry, a train hand on the Illinois and St. Louis Railroad, lives in a little house on the outskirts of the town with his wife and baby.
John Boyle, aged 25, died on the 10th inst. in Bellevue Hospital. He had been there about two days suffering from acute alcoholism and with symptoms of pernicious typhoid fever.
STRATFORD, Ontario, April 14.--H.S. Roy, Teller of the Bank of Montreal here, has been missing since last Saturday. It is alleged that he is a defaulter to the extent of several thousand dollars.

Auditeau, from St. Pierre, Martinique for Boston, dismasted and abandoned.

Nancy Wainwright, the Brontes' nurse, has just died in the Bradford Workhouse. It was her last wish not to be buried in a pauper's grave. I have sent a guinea, and perhaps some of your readers may care to send the small amount that is still necessary to give Nancy a private funeral.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., April 17.--Prof. Foster will say in to-morrow's Times that during the great storm period from April 25, to 29, a hurricane will organize on or near the Gulf, and sweep up the southeast Atlantic coast, and that about the same time a cold wave will appear in the northwest, and run down into the Southern States, followed by heavy frosts as far South as Tennessee and Southern Kansas.
